<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Quality Control in Clinical Chemistry 95</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="staff-development">Staff Development<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#staff-development" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Faulty techniques in the performance of analytical procedures lead to incorrect results. Faulty techniques are usually due to the carelessness of the laboratory worker as well as inadequate training of the staff. One of the most effective ways to ensure correct results and so, maintain a high standard for the laboratory is through constant training and retraining of staff. For this reason, opportunity should be made available to staff members for further training and education.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="instrument-quality-control">Instrument Quality Control<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#instrument-quality-control" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Quality control on instruments is very essential if the laboratory must continue to produce reliable results. Unfortunately, this aspect of quality control is often given very little attention. This negligence very often leads to the typical laboratory "confusion" when inconsistent results are being produced. Analytical instruments and equipment such as balances, water baths, spectrophotometers etc. must be routinely checked in order to prevent errors. Some of these instruments like spectrophotometers, are supplied with the means of checking their efficiency. However, the very expensive ones are usually maintained by the manufacturers or their representatives. A well maintained instrument may probably go wrong, but a badly maintained one will surely go wrong. Breakdowns are virtually eliminated if, and only if, the manufacturer's instructions for operation and maintenance are strictly adhered to.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="performance-standard">Performance Standard<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#performance-standard" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The choice of test methods is usually left to the most senior laboratory staff to make. Such test methods must prove to work reliably before they are used for patient specimens. After the method has been introduced, it must be constantly and adequately controlled. For the purpose of quality control, a test method should be considered on the basis of the following criteria:</p>
<p>(i) Specificity A method selected to measure, for example, glucose, should ideally be specific for glucose. Such a method has an advantage over other non-specific methods which, in addition to measuring the substance under investigation, measure other unwanted but similar substances.</p>
<p>(ii) Simplicity A simple test is usually faster to perform than a more complex one, and so, allows more samples to be tested within a given time. In addition, a simple test is easier and safer for the not too experienced staff to carry out.</p>
<p>(iii) Accuracy and precision Accuracy is the nearness of a result to the true value. Precision implies reproducibility. Therefore, a good test method must be accurate and precise. For example, if a true value of a sample is 75 units, the same sample, when tested 5 times must give the same value or a value very close to the original value. This property of a test method is affected if, for example, the reagents are unstable, instruments are faulty or if the method is not specific.</p>
<p>(iv) Other considerations There are many other factors to be considered in the choice of a test method. These factors may include cost of instruments and reagents; safety of reagents and procedures; and availability of reagents and special glassware.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="errors-in-test-methods">Errors in Test Methods<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#errors-in-test-methods" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>There are two types of error that can occur when performing biochemical tests. These are:</p>
<p>(i) Errors of scatter i.e. imprecision, and
(ii) Errors of bias, i.e., inaccuracy.</p>
<p>(i) Errors of scatter These are random errors in which the results differ from the correct result by varying amount. The commonest causes of this type of error are</p>
<p>(a) Faulty technique This may include</p>
<ul>
<li>incorrect pipetting</li>
<li>inadequate mixing of sample with reagents</li>
</ul>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>96 Clinical Chemistry</p>
<ul>
<li>Wrong incubation of test at wrong temperature or for the incorrect length of time.</li>
</ul>
<p>The errors due to faulty technique can be minimised if a laboratory manual for test methods is clearly written and in sufficient details, and followed exactly by all members of staff. Any changes to the manual should also be in writing.</p>
<p>(b) Dirty apparatus Dirty tubes, pipettes and other items of apparatus used in the test.</p>
<p>(c) Erratic instrument readings</p>
<p>(d) Incomplete removal of interfering substances in serum</p>
<p>(e) Carelessness This refers to lack of concentration on the part of the analyst.</p>
<p>(ii) Errors of bias These are regular errors in which results differ from the correct results by approximately the same amount. These errors may arise from</p>
<p>(a) Use of impure chemicals</p>
<p>(b) Incorrect calibration of test method</p>
<p>(c) Use of expired reagents or reagents stored at wrong temperature.</p>
<p>(d) Use of incorrect light filter.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="standard-deviation-sd">STANDARD DEVIATION (SD)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#standard-deviation-sd" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>It is important to check regularly for “scatter” and “bias” errors. This helps to detect at an early stage when errors are being introduced into routine test procedures. A statistical value that is used to measure precision is called Standard Deviation (SD). One way to determine SD is to repeatedly analyse one sample and then apply the formula:</p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mi>S</mi><mi>D</mi><mo>=</mo><msqrt><mfrac><mrow><mo>∑</mo><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>x</mi><mo>ˉ</mo></mover><msup><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mfrac></msqrt></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">SD = \sqrt{\frac{\sum (x - \bar{x})^2}{n - 1}}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05764em;">S</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.02778em;">D</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.44em; vertical-align: -0.7773em;"></span><span class="mord sqrt"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.6627em;"><span class="svg-align" style="top: -4.4em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 4.4em;"></span><span class="mord" style="padding-left: 1em;"><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.427em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal">n</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mop op-symbol small-op" style="position: relative; top: 0em;">∑</span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal">x</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mord accent"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.5678em;"><span style="top: -3em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">x</span></span><span style="top: -3em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="accent-body" style="left: -0.2222em;"><span class="mord">ˉ</span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose"><span class="mclose">)</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7401em;"><span style="top: -2.989em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7693em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.6227em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 4.4em;"></span><span class="hide-tail" style="min-width: 1.02em; height: 2.48em;"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="400em" height="2.48em" viewBox="0 0 400000 2592" preserveAspectRatio="xMinYMin slice"><path d="M424,2478
c-1.3,-0.7,-38.5,-172,-111.5,-514c-73,-342,-109.8,-513.3,-110.5,-514
c0,-2,-10.7,14.3,-32,49c-4.7,7.3,-9.8,15.7,-15.5,25c-5.7,9.3,-9.8,16,-12.5,20
s-5,7,-5,7c-4,-3.3,-8.3,-7.7,-13,-13s-13,-13,-13,-13s76,-122,76,-122s77,-121,77,-121
s209,968,209,968c0,-2,84.7,-361.7,254,-1079c169.3,-717.3,254.7,-1077.7,256,-1081
l0 -0c4,-6.7,10,-10,18,-10 H400000
v40H1014.6
s-87.3,378.7,-272.6,1166c-185.3,787.3,-279.3,1182.3,-282,1185

c-8,0,-12,-0.7,-12,-2z M1001 80
h400000v40h-400000z"></path></svg></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7773em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p>where <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>∑</mo><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>x</mi><mo>ˉ</mo></mover><msup><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\sum (x - \bar{x})^2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mop op-symbol small-op" style="position: relative; top: 0em;">∑</span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal">x</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0641em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord accent"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.5678em;"><span style="top: -3em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">x</span></span><span style="top: -3em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="accent-body" style="left: -0.2222em;"><span class="mord">ˉ</span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose"><span class="mclose">)</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> is the sum of the differences of each individual test from the mean, and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>n</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">n</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">n</span></span></span></span></span> is the number of observations. The <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>n</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">n</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">n</span></span></span></span></span> should be greater than 30 for an adequate measure.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="coefficient-of-variation-cv-or-cv">Coefficient of Variation (CV or % CV)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#coefficient-of-variation-cv-or-cv" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The difficulty in interpreting SD is usually over, come with the coefficient of variation (CV). The CV expresses SD as the percentage of the mean. For example, an SD of 0.4 with a mean value of 25 shows the same precision as SD of 0.8 with a mean value of 50. Therefore,</p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mi>C</mi><mi>V</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>0.4</mn><mn>25</mn></mfrac><mo>×</mo><mn>100</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>1.6</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">CV = \frac{0.4}{25} \times 100 = 1.6\%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">C</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.22222em;">V</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.0074em; vertical-align: -0.686em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3214em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">25</span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0.4</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.686em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">100</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">1.6%</span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p>or</p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mi>C</mi><mi>V</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>0.8</mn><mn>50</mn></mfrac><mo>×</mo><mn>100</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>1.6</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">CV = \frac{0.8}{50} \times 100 = 1.6\%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">C</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.22222em;">V</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.0074em; vertical-align: -0.686em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3214em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">50</span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0.8</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.686em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">100</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">1.6%</span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p>The CV for several levels must be obtained for normal and abnormal ranges; and when using any CV, the mean value should be established.</p>
<p>The procedure for assessing reliability and variability is carried out under the best possible conditions. This condition is referred to as the Optimal Condition Variance (OCV). It is used to compare with the Routine Conditions Variance (RCV) of the test method when in routine use.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="control-sample">Control Sample<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#control-sample" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>It is the sample that simulates the physical and chemical pattern of a clinical sample being analysed and it is treated just like the clinical sample. The control serum will detect errors due to reagents and standards only. Most laboratories make use of commercially prepared control sera which are fairly expensive. It is cheaper, however, to use analysed pooled sera which can be prepared and calibrated using a commercially prepared serum. To be excluded from the pool are those sera that are:</p>
<ul>
<li>icteric (partaining to jaundice),</li>
<li>cloudy,</li>
<li>haemolysed, or</li>
<li>grossly coloured due to dyes.</li>
</ul>
<p>Commercially prepared control sera are available in two forms, freeze dried (lyophilized) sera, and synthetically produced liquid sera. It is very important to follow the manufacturer’s instructions for the preparation, use and calibration of control sera.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Quality Control in Clinical Chemistry 97</p>
<p>It is equally important to have information on a wide variety of control sera from different manufacturers.</p>
<p>To measure performance with respect to accuracy and precision, the following control measures are carried out:</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Obtain a large quantity of control serum and divide it into suitable volumes and keep them frozen. Thaw only the amount required for immediate use. Many tests may be carried out from a single batch so that assayed value gradually emerges. This is referred to as the Drift Control.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Freeze dried commercially prepared control sera are made in large batches and bottled. Any bottle from one batch will contain serum with the same value as any other bottle from the same batch.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>At least one sample from a previous batch of sera is retested with a new batch of tests to check on the consistency of the day-to-day results. This is known as Interbatch Control.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>External quality control, or more appropriately, external quality assessment, is a system of assessing a laboratory's ability to ensure that the result it produces are reliable. This checking system is monitored by an organisation outside the laboratory, e.g., a central laboratory. Participation in this scheme should be encouraged as it serves as an additional internal quality control measure, though it should never be a substitute for organised internal quality control. The system involves each laboratory being asked to analyse a predetermined set of samples and send the results back to the organisers. Each laboratory receives a feedback on its performance. In this way, the laboratory is able to compare its standard with that of other laboratories that use the same analytical methods. The scheme also helps a laboratory to decide whether or not to change a method in use.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="quality-control-chart">Quality Control Chart<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#quality-control-chart" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>After a test method has been introduced as a reliable routine method, regular check on the precision of results is made with the use of a control chart. A control serum is used with each batch of tests. The control chart helps to reveal, diagnose and treat faults at an early stage before patient test results are affected and report delayed.</p>
<p>There are several ways to produce a quality control chart. A simple control chart can be produced in the following way:</p>
<p>(i) Take a sheet of graph paper and draw 3 horizontal lines to correspond to mean, mean + 2 SD and mean - 2 SD.</p>
<p>(ii) With the same control serum for each batch of test, plot the values on the daily control chart as shown in Fig. 2.1</p>
<p>(iii) Each day, the value should fall within the acceptable limit of + or - 2 SD.</p>
<p>As shown in Fig. 2.1, from day 1 to day 18, the control value falls within the acceptable limit. However, there is a downward shift from day 9 until on day 19, the control value falls outside the acceptable limit. The fault is immediately detected and rectified, and the control value again falls within the acceptable range.</p>
<p>When the control value falls outside the + or - 2 SD limit, the errors can be due to any of the following factors:</p>
<p>(i) Deterioration of reagents.</p>
<p>(ii) Increase or decrease in the concentration of the standard.</p>
<p>(iii) Contamination of serum.</p>
<p>(iv) Faulty equipment like the water bath not being at the correct temperature.</p>
<p>(v) Incorrect preparation of reagents.</p>
<p>(vi) Wrong light filter or wavelength being used in the colorimeter/spectrophotometer.</p>
<p>(vii) Incomplete protein precipitation.</p>
<p>(viii) Wrong incubation time due to faulty timer.</p>
<p>(ix) A change of worker to one less experienced or less careful.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>98 Clinical Chemistry</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-2ffd059c.jpeg" alt="img-9.jpeg">
Fig. 2.1 Quality control chart</p>
<p>A drift of values above the upper limit or below the lower limit is a clear warning that the test method is becoming unreliable. Therefore, the faults must be corrected before another batch of tests can be carried out. A new quality control chart must be prepared when the first control chart is about to be completed. It is necessary to include one or more samples from the previous batch.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="post-analytical-control">POST ANALYTICAL CONTROL<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#post-analytical-control" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Post analytical quality control is an area which concerns the reporting and verification of test results before they are dispatched to the clinics and wards. It has to do with that area of laboratory activity that is very often neglected but is equally as important as the pre-analytical and the analytical quality controls. All efforts and costs expended on quality control of methods, reagents and instruments will be a sad loss if test results are not clearly and correctly reported. There is no doubt that the task of reporting and cross-checking hundreds of specimens daily is a tedious one. It becomes necessary, therefore, that such a duty should not be handled by untrained and non-professional staff without adequate supervision. The introduction of computers in the laboratories has gone a long way in minimising clerical errors when reporting test results.</p>
<p>An efficiently run laboratory must have a well laid down quality control programme in order to improve its standard of work. A constant review of the various aspects of the programme should be given top priority. As a matter of departmental policy, a very senior staff is usually appointed as a quality control officer. It is the duty of this officer to monitor all quality control measures in order to detect faults and errors, and arrange for immediate correction.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Chapter 3</p>
<p>Carbohydrate Metabolism</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="metabolism">METABOLISM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#metabolism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Metabolism is a process made up of:</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Catabolic reactions, in which complex substances are broken down to simpler forms with release of energy for cellular activity. e.g., hydrolysis of glycogen to glucose.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Anabolic reactions, in which absorbed nutrients are built up into complex compounds that the body needs for its activity. e.g. synthesis of protein from amino acids.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>Metabolism is the general term that describes the different changes taking place in the body. Catabolic processes involve the production of heat and energy. The energy requirements of an individual depends on his/her age, size and metabolic rate. The metabolic rate is partly controlled by the thyroid gland hormones and is affected by temperature and a person's activity. What is referred to as Basal Metabolic Rate (BMR) is the heat and energy required to maintain cellular functions when the body is at rest.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="metabolism-of-carbohydrates">METABOLISM OF CARBOHYDRATES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#metabolism-of-carbohydrates" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Carbohydrates are made up of carbon, hydrogen and oxygen. They act as source of body heat and energy. Carbohydrates are found in sugar, jam, cereals, fruits, potatoes, yams, vegetables and milk.</p>
<p>There are three major groups of carbohydrates. These are:</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Monosaccharides These are simple sugars that can be absorbed directly from the intestine. Monosaccharides include the hexoses (which contain 6 carbon atoms) such as glucose, fructose and galactose; and the pentoses (which contain 5 carbon atoms) such as xylose, ribose and arabinose.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Disaccharides These are not directly absorbed from the intestine. On hydrolysis with specific enzymes, they yield two molecules of monosaccharides. This group includes sugars such as sucrose, lactose and maltose. Table 3.1 shows the specific enzymes acting on these sugars and the monosaccharide components.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>Table 3.1 Monosaccharide components formed by disaccharides by the action of enzymes</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Enzyme</th><th>Disaccharide</th><th>Monosaccharide</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Lactase</td><td>Lactose</td><td>Galactose + glucose</td></tr><tr><td>Sucrase</td><td>Sucrose</td><td>Fructose + glucose</td></tr><tr><td>Maltase</td><td>Maltose</td><td>Glucose + glucose</td></tr></tbody></table>
<ol start="3">
<li>Polysaccharides Many carbohydrates in nature exist in the form of polysaccharides. They are more complex and are not easily absorbed in the body. The most common polysaccharides are</li>
</ol>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>100 Clinical Chemistry</p>
<p>starch and glycogen which are hydrolysed by amylase to mainly maltose and glucose.</p>
<p>When carbohydrate which has been ingested is converted into glucose by various enzymes, and the glucose is absorbed from the small intestine, then the metabolism of carbohydrate in the body begins. The glucose is transported through the bloodstream to the liver where it is used or stored depending on the need of the body at that time.</p>
<p>There are three ways in which the glucose is either utilised or stored in the body:</p>
<ol>
<li>Glycolysis Glycolysis is the breakdown of glucose to pyruvic acid or lactic acid (or both) for the production of energy in the form of the compound adenosine triphosphate (ATP). It is used to control the level of glucose in the blood. Glucose is taken from the blood by the tissues and is converted into pyruvic acid by glycolysis. The heat and energy produced is used for cellular activity.</li>
</ol>
<p>Glycolysis occurs through aerobic or anaerobic pathway.</p>
<p>glycogenolysis describes the breakdown of glycogen. Glucose is converted to glycogen and stored in the liver and skeletal muscles when it is not needed for immediate use.</p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mtext>Glucose</mtext><mover><mo stretchy="true" minsize="3.0em">→</mo><mpadded width="+0.6em" lspace="0.3em"><mtext>Glycogenesis</mtext></mpadded></mover><mtext>Glycogen</mtext></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\text{Glucose} \xrightarrow{\text{Glycogenesis}} \text{Glycogen}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.1191em; vertical-align: -0.011em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Glucose</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel x-arrow"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.1081em;"><span style="top: -3.322em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight x-arrow-pad"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord mtight">Glycogenesis</span></span></span></span></span><span class="svg-align" style="top: -2.689em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="hide-tail" style="height: 0.522em; min-width: 1.469em;"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="400em" height="0.522em" viewBox="0 0 400000 522" preserveAspectRatio="xMaxYMin slice"><path d="M0 241v40h399891c-47.3 35.3-84 78-110 128

<p>When glucose is required, the stored glycogen is converted back to glucose.</p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mtext>Glucose</mtext><mover><mo stretchy="true" minsize="3.0em">←</mo><mpadded width="+0.6em" lspace="0.3em"><mtext>Glycogenolysis</mtext></mpadded></mover><mtext>Glycogen</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">.</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\text{Glucose} \xleftarrow{\text{Glycogenolysis}} \text{Glycogen}.</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.1191em; vertical-align: -0.011em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Glucose</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel x-arrow"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.1081em;"><span style="top: -3.322em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight x-arrow-pad"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord mtight">Glycogenolysis</span></span></span></span></span><span class="svg-align" style="top: -2.689em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="hide-tail" style="height: 0.522em; min-width: 1.469em;"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="400em" height="0.522em" viewBox="0 0 400000 522" preserveAspectRatio="xMinYMin slice"><path d="M400000 241H110l3-3c68.7-52.7 113.7-120

<p>A number of enzymes are involved in glycogenesis and glycogenolysis, as shown below.</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>Conversion to fat Excess glucose which is not immediately needed by the body and which cannot be stored as glycogen in the liver, is oxidised to fatty acids and is stored as fat in the tissues.</li>
</ol>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mtext>Glucose</mtext><mover><mo stretchy="true" minsize="3.0em">→</mo><mpadded width="+0.6em" lspace="0.3em"><mtext>Oxidation</mtext></mpadded></mover><mtext>Fatty&nbsp;acids</mtext><mo>⟶</mo><mtext>Fat</mtext></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\text{Glucose} \xrightarrow{\text{Oxidation}} \text{Fatty acids} \longrightarrow \text{Fat}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.1191em; vertical-align: -0.011em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Glucose</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel x-arrow"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.1081em;"><span style="top: -3.322em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight x-arrow-pad"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord mtight">Oxidation</span></span></span></span></span><span class="svg-align" style="top: -2.689em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="hide-tail" style="height: 0.522em; min-width: 1.469em;"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="400em" height="0.522em" viewBox="0 0 400000 522" preserveAspectRatio="xMaxYMin slice"><path d="M0 241v40h399891c-47.3 35.3-84 78-110 128

<p>Glucose, when needed by the body can be recovered from fat and protein. This process of re-conversion is known as gluconeogenesis.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-9e80afd3.jpeg" alt="img-10.jpeg"></p>
<p>Aerobic pathway</p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mtext>Glucose</mtext><mo>→</mo><mtext>Pyruvate</mtext><mo>→</mo><mtext>Energy,&nbsp;Heat</mtext></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\text{Glucose} \rightarrow \text{Pyruvate} \rightarrow \text{Energy, Heat}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Glucose</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8778em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Pyruvate</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8778em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Energy,&nbsp;Heat</span></span></span></span></span></span></div>

<p>Anaerobic pathway</p>

 39-84.5 73-119.5s73.7-60.2 119-75.5c6-2 9-5.7 9-11s-3-9-9-11c-45.3-15.3-85
-40.5-119-75.5s-58.3-74.8-73-119.5c-4.7-14-8.3-27.3-11-40-1.3-6.7-3.2-10.8-5.5
-12.5-2.3-1.7-7.5-2.5-15.5-2.5-14 0-21 3.7-21 11 0 2 2 10.3 6 25 20.7 83.3 67
 151.7 139 205zm0 0v40h399900v-40z"></path></svg></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.011em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7667em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Lactate</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">+</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8778em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Energy</span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p>Anaerobic pathway occurs when the energy requirement exceeds the oxygen available. This process continues only for a limited period till enough oxygen is made available for the cellular activity.</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>Glycogenesis The process of glycogen formation is called glycogenesis, while the term</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="factors-determining-blood-glucose-level">Factors Determining Blood Glucose Level<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#factors-determining-blood-glucose-level" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Insulin Insulin is a hormone produced and secreted by the beta cells in the islets of Langerhans in the pancreas. It is the most important hormone that regulates the level of glucose in the blood, the rate of its absorption and its conversion to glycogen. Its secretion is stimulated by a rise in the blood glucose level and by some gastrointestinal hormones, some sugars and fatty acids. In the absence of insulin, the blood glucose level rises.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Glucagon Glucagon is a polypeptide hormone secreted by the alpha cells of the islets of Langerhans. It stimulates:</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Carbohydrate Metabolism 101</p>
<p>(i) Breakdown of stored glycogen
(ii) Liver gluconeogenesis
(iii) Hepatic lipolysis.</p>
<p>Thus, when this hormone is secreted, the blood glucose and free fatty acid levels rise.</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>
<p>Adrenalin The hormone, adrenalin (epinephrine) is produced and secreted in the medulla of the adrenal gland. It increases glycogenolysis and inhibits the uptake of glucose in the tissues, thus resulting in rise in the blood glucose level.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Growth hormone Growth hormone (somatotrophic hormone) is synthesised in the anterior pituitary gland. It inhibits the uptake of glucose by tissues and increases liver glucose output. It also helps in gluconeogenesis of fat. In this way, it increases the overall blood glucose level.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) This hormone is produced by the anterior pituitary. Its action is similar to that of the growth hormone as it inhibits the action of insulin.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Corticosteroid hormones These hormones are also known as glucocorticoids and are secreted by the adrenal cortex. They inhibit the action of insulin thus blocking glucose utilisation by the tissues and promoting the use of protein instead of glucose for the production of heat and energy.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Thyroxine It is one of the hormones produced by the thyroid gland. It increases the absorption of glucose from the gastrointestinal tract and stimulates glycogenolysis. It promotes an increase in blood glucose level by degrading insulin.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="glucose-homeostasis-in-the-blood">Glucose Homeostasis in the Blood<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#glucose-homeostasis-in-the-blood" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The level of blood glucose is maintained within the fairly narrow limits by the homeostatic mechanisms described above. Following the intake of carbohydrates, all metabolic activities lead to lower blood glucose levels till it reaches the fasting level. The storage and distribution of glucose by the liver, and the use of glucose by tissues are determined by the above mentioned hormones. A simplified mechanism of glucose homeostasis is illustrated in Fig. 3.1.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-c50cb42b.jpeg" alt="img-11.jpeg">
Fig. 3.1 Simple mechanism of glucose homeostasis</p>
<p>When the fasting blood glucose level rises above 100 mg/dl (5.56 mmol/L), the condition is known as hyperglycaemia. A fasting blood glucose level which is less than 80 mg/dl (4.44 mmol/L), is known as hypoglycaemia. Glucose is normally filtered by the renal glomeruli and almost totally reabsorbed by the renal tubules. When, however, the blood glucose concentration rises above the range of 160 to 180 mg/dl (8.89 to 10.0 mmol/L), glucose appears in urine. This condition is characteristic of diabetes mellitus (which means "lots of urine tasting of honey"), and is referred to as glycosuria. A blood glucose level of 160 to 180 mg/dl is referred to as the renal threshold for glucose.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="blood-glucose-and-blood-sugar">Blood Glucose and Blood Sugar<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#blood-glucose-and-blood-sugar" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Glucose is the main carbohydrate in the blood, but the term "blood sugar" is generally used to include glucose, other sugars and reducing substances that may be present in the blood.</p>
<p>Some methods of estimation of glucose depend on the reducing properties of the sugar. These properties are shared by other sugars and reducing substances. Thus, these methods are not specific for glucose; and such estimations are expressed as Blood Sugar estimations. When the non-glucose reducing substances are removed as part of glucose determination, the resulting value is known as the true glucose value. Other methods like the</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>102 Clinical Chemistry</p>
<p>oxidase-peroxidase method, confer a high degree of specificity on the measurement of glucose in blood and urine.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="glycolysis">Glycolysis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#glycolysis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>When blood is shed, the cells do not die immediately. They continue to metabolise and use up glucose as a source of energy. Glucose, thus, disappears from whole blood on standing over a period of time. This is known as glycolysis. Glycolysis can be prevented with an enzyme inhibitor. The commonest inhibitor for this purpose is sodium fluoride which is usually used in conjunction with an anticoagulant potassium oxalate or sequestrene. Fluoride actually inhibits the enzyme enolase which is found in the metabolic pathway of glucose and has little effect on glucose oxidase and peroxidase enzymes. It also inhibits bacterial growth.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="estimation-of-blood-glucose">Estimation of Blood Glucose<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#estimation-of-blood-glucose" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="specimens">Specimens<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#specimens" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Blood glucose is usually measured on a protein-free filtrate of whole blood. This normally gives a value lower than that of plasma due to the presence of RBCs. However, most methods make use of plasma instead of serum or whole blood. Glucose estimation using plasma or whole blood requires the use of an anticoagulant. The fluoride-oxalate mixture used for this purpose is composed of 2 mg of sodium fluoride and 6 mg of potassium oxalate per ml of blood. More than 5 mg of sodium fluoride per ml of blood acts as an inhibitor for the enzymatic estimations.</p>
<p>Collection of specimen for measurements of blood glucose level should be done on the day and time requested. This is because collection times are usually related to food intake, insulin treatment, or both. It may be necessary sometimes to note the time of blood collection on the specimen container and on the patient's request form. Urgent glucose measurement becomes necessary in cases of severe hypoglycaemia or hyperglycaemia as both conditions can result in loss of consciousness (coma).</p>
<p>Fasting specimen refers to blood collected after a period of no food intake. For adults, fasting time is usually 10 to 16 hours; while for children, it is 6 hours. Post-prandial specimen is blood collected usually 2 hours after a meal has been eaten. Random specimen refers to blood sample collected at any time regardless of food consumption. Collection of blood samples for glucose tolerance test is described separately.</p>
<p>Four methods are described in this book for the estimation of sugar/glucose levels in the blood. They are: 1. Oxidase-peroxidase method; 2. Reduction of cupric to cuprous salt (Folin-Wu method); 3. Reflometric method, and 4. O-Toluidine method.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="oxidase-peroxidase-method">Oxidase-peroxidase Method<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#oxidase-peroxidase-method" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="principle">Principle<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#principle" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Glucose oxidase catalyses the oxidation of glucose to produce hydrogen peroxide and gluconic acid. The hydrogen peroxide, in the presence of enzyme peroxidase is broken down and the oxygen given off reacts with 4-aminophenazone and phenol to give a pink colour.</p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mtext>Glucose</mtext><mo>+</mo><mtext>Oxygen</mtext><mover><mo stretchy="true" minsize="3.0em">→</mo><mpadded width="+0.6em" lspace="0.3em"><mtext>Glucose&nbsp;oxidase</mtext></mpadded></mover><mtext>Hydrogen&nbsp;peroxide</mtext><mo>+</mo><mtext>Gluconic&nbsp;acid</mtext></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\text{Glucose} + \text{Oxygen} \xrightarrow{\text{Glucose oxidase}} \text{Hydrogen peroxide} + \text{Gluconic acid}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7778em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Glucose</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">+</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.3025em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Oxygen</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel x-arrow"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.1081em;"><span style="top: -3.322em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight x-arrow-pad"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord mtight">Glucose&nbsp;oxidase</span></span></span></span></span><span class="svg-align" style="top: -2.689em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="hide-tail" style="height: 0.522em; min-width: 1.469em;"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="400em" height="0.522em" viewBox="0 0 400000 522" preserveAspectRatio="xMaxYMin slice"><path d="M0 241v40h399891c-47.3 35.3-84 78-110 128

<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mtext>Hydrogen&nbsp;peroxide</mtext><mo>+</mo><mtext>Aminophenazone</mtext><mo>+</mo><mtext>Phenol</mtext><mover><mo stretchy="true" minsize="3.0em">→</mo><mpadded width="+0.6em" lspace="0.3em"><mtext>Peroxidase</mtext></mpadded></mover><mtext>Pink&nbsp;coloured&nbsp;complex</mtext></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\text{Hydrogen peroxide} + \text{Aminophenazone} + \text{Phenol} \xrightarrow{\text{Peroxidase}} \text{Pink coloured complex}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; <div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="reagents">Reagents<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#reagents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>(i) Protein precipitant 10 g sodium tungstate, 10 g disodium hydrogen phosphate and 9 g sodium chloride, all dissolved in 800 ml of distilled water. Add 125 ml of 1.0 M HCl to bring the pH to 3.0. Add 1 g phenol and dilute to 1 litre with distilled water. This solution has very long shelf-life at 4°C.</p>
<p>(ii) Phosphate buffer, pH 7.0. Dissolve 8.52 g of disodium hydrogen phosphate and 5.44 g of potassium dihydrogen phosphate in 500 ml of distilled water. Adjust the pH and make up to 1 litre.</p>
<p>(iii) Colour reagent 300 ml of phosphate buffer, add 5 ml of Permcozyme 952 DM (glucose oxidase and peroxidase), 0.3 g phenol, 0.3 g sodium azide and 0.1 g 4-aminophenazole. Mix and store at 4°C. It is stable for at least 2 months.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Carbohydrate Metabolism. 103</p>
<p>(iv) Standard glucose solution (10 mmol/L or 180 mg/dl): Dissolve 1.80 g of glucose in, and make up to, 1 litre with saturated (0.3 %) benzoic acid. Prepare the benzoic acid at least 24 hours before use.</p>
<p>Technique</p>
<p>(i) Set up three test tubes as follows:</p>
<table><thead><tr><th></th><th>Blank</th><th>Standard</th><th>Test</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Protein precipitant</td><td>2.9 ml</td><td>2.9 ml</td><td>2.9 ml</td></tr><tr><td>Distilled water</td><td>0.1 ml</td><td>-</td><td>-</td></tr><tr><td>Working standard (10 mmol/L)</td><td>-</td><td>0.1 ml</td><td>-</td></tr><tr><td>Test sample</td><td>-</td><td>-</td><td>0.1 ml</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>(ii) Mix well and centrifuge at 2500 rpm for 5 minutes.</p>
<p>Calculations</p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mtext>Glucose&nbsp;mmol/L</mtext><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mtext>Ab&nbsp;Test</mtext><mtext>Ab&nbsp;Std</mtext></mfrac><mo>×</mo><mtext>conc.&nbsp;of&nbsp;std</mtext></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\text{Glucose mmol/L} = \frac{\text{Ab Test}}{\text{Ab Std}} \times \text{conc. of std}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Glucose&nbsp;mmol/L</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.0574em; vertical-align: -0.686em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3714em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Ab&nbsp;Std</span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Ab&nbsp;Test</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.686em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">conc.&nbsp;of&nbsp;std</span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p>Ab Test = Absorbance of Test</p>
<p>Ab Std = Absorbance of Standard</p>
<p>Alternatively, a calibration curve can be prepared for the measurement of blood glucose. Dilute the glucose standard as shown in Table below.</p>
<p>Mix well, remove 1.0 ml from each tube and add 3.0 ml of the colour reagent.</p>
<p>Mix well, and proceed as steps (iv) and (v) above.</p>
<p>Plot a graph of absorbance of each standard on vertical axis against its concentration in mmol/L on the horizontal axis. A linear calibration should be obtained as shown in Fig. 3.2.</p>
<p>The concentration of glucose in the test sample can be obtained from the graph after reading its absorbance.</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Tubes:</th><th>1</th><th>2</th><th>3</th><th>4</th><th>5</th><th>6</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Glucose Std (ml)</td><td>0.0</td><td>0.1</td><td>0.2</td><td>0.3</td><td>0.4</td><td>0.5</td></tr><tr><td>Protein precipitant (ml)</td><td>6.0</td><td>5.9</td><td>5.8</td><td>5.7</td><td>5.6</td><td>5.5</td></tr><tr><td>Final conc. of glucose (mmol/L)</td><td>0.0</td><td>5.0</td><td>10.0</td><td>15.0</td><td>20.0</td><td>25.0</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>(iii) Take a second set of tubes as in (i) above.</p>
<table><thead><tr><th></th><th>Blank</th><th>Standard</th><th>Test</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Supernatant</td><td>1.0 ml</td><td>1.0 ml</td><td>1.0 ml</td></tr><tr><td>Colour reagent</td><td>3.0 ml</td><td>3.0 ml</td><td>3.0 ml</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>(iv) Mix well and incubate all tubes at 37°C for 10 min. Shake occasionally.</p>
<p>(v) Remove from the water bath, cool and measure the absorbance within 30 minutes. Set the zero with the Blank.</p>
<p>Colorimeter: Green filter</p>
<p>Spectrophotometer: 515 nm.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-5f99eb7a.jpeg" alt="img-12.jpeg">
Fig. 3.2 Calibration curve for estimation of glucose</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>104 Clinical Chemistry</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="reduction-of-cupric-to-cuprous-salt-folin-wu-method">Reduction of Cupric to Cuprous Salt (Folin-Wu Method)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#reduction-of-cupric-to-cuprous-salt-folin-wu-method" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This is one of the oldest methods for the estimation of blood sugar. However, it is still very much in use in countries where enzyme preparations are not easy to obtain.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="principle">Principle<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#principle" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The method is based on three stages:</p>
<p>(i) Precipitation of blood proteins with copper tungstate.
(ii) Reduction of cupric sulphate to cuprous oxide.
(iii) Colorimetric measurement of the subsequent blue-green colour produced on the addition of molybdate reagent to the cuprous oxide.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="reagents">Reagents<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#reagents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>(i) Sodium tungstate (10 %) Dissolve 10 g per 100 ml distilled water.
(ii) Sulphuric acid, 2/3 N Add 2 ml of conc. sulphuric acid to about 50 ml of distilled water and dilute up to 100 ml with distilled water.
(iii) Alkaline copper tartrate reagent Dissolve 40 g sodium carbonate and 7.5 g tartaric acid in about 400 ml of distilled water. Separately dissolve 4.5 g copper sulphate in about 100 ml of distilled water. Mix both the solutions together and make the volume up to 1 litre with distilled water. Filter before use.
(iv) Phosphomolybdic acid reagent Dissolve 35 g molybdic acid and 5 g sodium tungstate in 200 ml of 10 % sodium hydroxide. Add it to 200 ml of distilled water in one litre beaker. Boil for 45 minutes to remove ammonia, cool and add slowly 125 ml of 89 % phosphoric acid (specific gravity 1.75). Make up the volume to 500 ml with distilled water.
(v) Stock glucose standard solution (1 g/dl) Dissolve 1 g of glucose in 100 ml of saturated benzoic acid (0.3 %).
(vi) Working glucose standard solution (10 mg/dl) Dilute the stock standard 1:100 with saturated benzoic acid to give 10 mg/dl glucose solution (1 ml glucose stock standard + 99 ml benzoic acid).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="technique">Technique<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#technique" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>(i) Place 1.0 ml of blood in 7.0 ml of distilled water and mix.
(ii) Add 1.0 ml of 10 % sodium tungstate. Mix.
(iii) Add 1.0 ml of 2/3N H₂SO₄. Mix by inverting several times. Allow it to stand for 5 minutes at room temperature.
(iv) Centrifuge or filter using Whatman No. 1 filter paper.
(v) Set up 3 Folin-Wu tubes as follows:</p>
<table><thead><tr><th></th><th>Blank</th><th>Standard</th><th>Test</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Distilled water</td><td>1.0 ml</td><td>-</td><td>-</td></tr><tr><td>Working std.</td><td>-</td><td>1.0 ml</td><td>-</td></tr><tr><td>filtrate/supernatant</td><td>-</td><td>-</td><td>1.0 ml</td></tr><tr><td>Alk. copper tartrate</td><td>1.0 ml</td><td>1.0 ml</td><td>1.0 ml</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>(vi) Place the tubes in boiling water bath for 10 minutes.
(vii) Cool and add 1.0 ml phosphomolybdic acid reagent to each tube.
(viii) Shake the tubes to get rid of the air bubbles and add distilled water up to 12.5 ml mark.
(ix) Mix and read the absorbance (Ab) immediately at 680 nm or using a red filter. Set the zero using the blank.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="calculations">Calculations<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#calculations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Note</strong></p>
<p>1.0 ml of blood was diluted 1:10 for protein precipitation. 1.0 ml of the diluted blood was then used for the test. Therefore, the actual volume of blood used for the test is 0.1 ml.</p>
<p>Also, 1.0 ml of the working standard (10 mg/dl) contains 0.1 mg of glucose.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Carbohydrate Metabolism 105</p>
<p>Mg of glucose/dl</p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mtable rowspacing="0.16em" columnalign="left" columnspacing="1em"><mtr><mtd><mstyle scriptlevel="0" displaystyle="false"><mrow><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mtext>Ab.&nbsp;of&nbsp;test</mtext><mtext>Ab&nbsp;of&nbsp;std.</mtext></mfrac><mo>×</mo><mtext>Conc.&nbsp;of&nbsp;std.</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mstyle scriptlevel="0" displaystyle="false"><mrow><mo>×</mo><mfrac><mn>100</mn><mtext>Amount&nbsp;of&nbsp;blood&nbsp;used</mtext></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mstyle scriptlevel="0" displaystyle="false"><mrow><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mtext>Ab.&nbsp;of&nbsp;test</mtext><mtext>Ab.&nbsp;of&nbsp;std</mtext></mfrac><mo>×</mo><mn>0.1</mn><mo>×</mo><mfrac><mn>100</mn><mn>0.1</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mtext>Ab.&nbsp;of&nbsp;test</mtext><mtext>Ab.&nbsp;of&nbsp;std</mtext></mfrac><mo>×</mo><mn>100</mn></mrow></mstyle></mtd></mtr></mtable><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\begin{array}{l}
= \frac{\text{Ab. of test}}{\text{Ab of std.}} \times \text{Conc. of std.} \\
\times \frac{100}{\text{Amount of blood used}} \\
= \frac{\text{Ab. of test}}{\text{Ab. of std}} \times 0.1 \times \frac{100}{0.1} = \frac{\text{Ab. of test}}{\text{Ab. of std}} \times 100 \\
\end{array}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 3.6853em; vertical-align: -1.5927em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mtable"><span class="arraycolsep" style="width: 0.5em;"></span><span class="col-align-l"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 2.0927em;"><span style="top: -4.2126em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8801em;"><span style="top: -2.655em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord mtight">Ab&nbsp;of&nbsp;std.</span></span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.394em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord mtight">Ab.&nbsp;of&nbsp;test</span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.345em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Conc.&nbsp;of&nbsp;std.</span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.0074em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">×</span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8451em;"><span style="top: -2.655em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord mtight">Amount&nbsp;of&nbsp;blood&nbsp;used</span></span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.394em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8801em;"><span style="top: -2.655em;"><span class="pstrut" mtight">0.1</span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.394em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">100</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.345em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8801em;"><span style="top: -2.655em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord mtight">Ab.&nbsp;of&nbsp;std</span></span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.394em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord mtight">Ab.&nbsp;of&nbsp;test</span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.345em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mord">100</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.5927em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="arraycolsep" style="width: 0.5em;"></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p>Alternatively, the concentration of glucose in the test sample can be obtained by the use of a calibration curve as in the oxidase-peroxidase method.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="reflometric-method">Reflometric Method<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#reflometric-method" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is a simple enzyme method in which oxidase-peroxidase enzyme and the colour reagent are impregnated on the reagent strips. The method uses a Reflocheck meter to register the amount of glucose in the blood.</p>
<p><strong>Technique</strong> A drop of capillary blood is placed on the test strip which after the prescribed time interval is wiped and inserted into the instrument. The colour change is read in a reflectance meter on which the result in mg/dl is visualised.</p>
<p>There are many instruments based on the same principle which are used mainly by diabetic patients.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="advantages-of-reflometric-methods">Advantages of Reflometric Methods<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#advantages-of-reflometric-methods" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>(i) They are simple and reliable.
(ii) They have excellent correlation with reference methods.
(iii) They give good precision and accuracy.
(iv) The meter is automatically calibrated by the bar code on each test strip.
(v) They are battery or mains operated.
