(vi) They can measure values as high as 450 mg/dl.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="o-toluidine-method">O-Toluidine Method<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#o-toluidine-method" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This method makes use of the principle that glucose reacts specifically with O-toluidine, an aromatic amine, in glacial acetic acid at 100°C to produce a blue-green colour. This colour can be measured colorimetrically. The method has the additional advantage that it can be performed directly on serum, plasma, cerebrospinal fluid or urine without deproteinization. The O-toluidine method is no longer widely used today because O-toluidine is believed to be a carcinogen.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="reference-range-of-normal-values">Reference Range of Normal Values<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#reference-range-of-normal-values" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Fasting blood glucose level:</p>
<p>For adults—3.3–5.6 mmol/L or 60–100 mg/dl</p>
<p>For children—2.5–5.0 mmol/L or 45–90 mg/dl</p>
<p>Post-prandial blood glucose: up to 6.9 mmol/L or up to 125 mg/dl.</p>
<p>Random blood glucose: 3.3–7.4 mmol/L or 60–132 mg/dl.</p>
<p>&gt; <strong>Note</strong> Reference range of blood sugar level is about 20 mg/dl or 1.1 mmol/L more than the true glucose level.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="interpretation-of-test-results">Interpretation of Test Results<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#interpretation-of-test-results" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A raised blood glucose level is called hyperglycaemia, where as a low glucose level is known as hypoglycaemia. Mild or transient hyperglycaemia may also occur following injury and diseases of certain glands such as pituitary, adrenal and thyroid.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="causes-of-abnormal-glucose-levels">Causes of Abnormal Glucose Levels<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#causes-of-abnormal-glucose-levels" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="severe-hyperglycaemia">Severe hyperglycaemia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#severe-hyperglycaemia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Diabetes mellitus</li>
<li>Adrenal cortical hyperactivity (Cushing’s syndrome)</li>
<li>Acromegaly</li>
<li>Obesity</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="mild-transient-hyperglycaemia">Mild/transient hyperglycaemia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mild-transient-hyperglycaemia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Severe liver disease</li>
<li>Pancreas disorder</li>
</ol>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>106 Clinical Chemistry</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>Pituitary disorder</li>
<li>Steroid therapy</li>
<li>Shock</li>
<li>Acute stress reaction (Physical or emotional)</li>
<li>Convulsions</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="severe-hypoglycaemia">Severe hypoglycaemia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#severe-hypoglycaemia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Insulinoma</li>
<li>Hypopituitarism</li>
<li>Ectopic insulin production from tumours</li>
<li>Adrenal cortical insufficiency</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="transient-hypoglycaemia">Transient hypoglycaemia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#transient-hypoglycaemia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Acute alcohol ingestion</li>
<li>Drugs such as salicylates, anti-tuberculosis agents</li>
<li>Severe liver diseases</li>
<li>Glycogen storage disorder</li>
<li>Hereditary fructose intolerance</li>
<li>Kwashiorkor (malnutrition)</li>
<li>Addison’s disease</li>
<li>Neonatal hypoglycaemia</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="false-glucose-levels">False glucose levels<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#false-glucose-levels" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A false high glucose level may result if blood sample is collected from an arm receiving an intravenous (i.v.) infusion.</p>
<p>Icteric samples can likewise give falsely low glucose levels.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="diabetes-mellitus">DIABETES MELLITUS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#diabetes-mellitus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>When glycosuria is detected and hyperglycaemia is established, a chronic metabolic disorder known as diabetes mellitus is indicated. It is a condition which is characterised by disturbances in carbohydrate, lipid and protein metabolism. Hyperglycaemia and glycosuria indicate the major metabolic lesion in carbohydrate metabolism, accompanied by metabolic disturbances in protein (gluconeogenesis) and lipids (ketosis and hypercholesterolaemia).</p>
<p>The presence of hyperglycaemia and renal glycosuria with an osmotic diuresis (polyuria) eventually will lead to dehydration and its associated polydipsia (increased thirst). Hyperglycaemia is sustained by the processes of glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis which enhance the production of more glucose.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="formation-of-ketone-bodies">Formation of ketone bodies<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#formation-of-ketone-bodies" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Acetoacetic acid, beta-hydroxybutyric acid and acetone are collectively known as ketone bodies or ketones. When any of these substances is detected in blood, the condition is referred to as ketoacidosis or ketonaemia; and when found in urine, it is called ketonuria.</p>
<p>When the intake of glucose is insufficient, as in starvation, or when glucose metabolism is impaired due to lack of insulin as in the case of untreated or uncontrolled diabetes, the body obtains its energy by breaking down fats to fatty acids. This increase in fat metabolism leads to the production of acetyl coenzyme A. The two carbon fragments in this enzyme condense to form the ketone bodies. Ketoacidosis is a potentially fatal complication of diabetes mellitus.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="types-of-diabetes-mellitus">Types of Diabetes Mellitus<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types-of-diabetes-mellitus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>There are two types of the conditions known as primary diabetes:</p>
<ol>
<li>Maturity-onset (adult type)</li>
<li>Growth onset (juvenile or child diabetes)</li>
</ol>
<p>The course of diabetes mellitus runs in four stages:</p>
<ol>
<li>Prediabetes — The prediabetic stage is the period from birth until the first evidence of diabetes emerges.</li>
<li>Suspected diabetes — When an individual displays abnormal glucose tolerance test (GTT) result, or shows symptoms of diabetes under stressful conditions such as obesity, pregnancy, trauma or infections, the condition is referred to as suspected diabetes.</li>
<li>Chemical or latent diabetes — When a patient who is not under any stress and with no signs or symptoms of disease, displays an abnormal GTT</li>
</ol>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Carbohydrate Metabolism 107</p>
<p>result, or fasting hyperglycaemia, he/she is said to have chemical or latent diabetes.</p>
<ol start="4">
<li>Overt diabetes With overt diabetes, symptoms of polyuria, polydipsia and weight loss are often linked to fasting hyperglycaemia and glycosuria.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="modern-classification-of-diabetes-mellitus">Modern Classification of Diabetes Mellitus<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#modern-classification-of-diabetes-mellitus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>National Diabetes Data Group has proposed a classification for hyperglycaemic disorders which is outlined below:</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="1-idiopathic-diabetes-mellitus">1. Idiopathic diabetes mellitus<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-idiopathic-diabetes-mellitus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>(a) Insulin dependent diabetes mellitus (IDDM Type I)</p>
<p>The individuals in this category produce very little insulin. The patient is acutely ill with severe hyperglycaemia at the time of diagnosis. Satisfactory control of blood sugar is obtained with insulin treatment. About 10 per cent of diabetes mellitus cases belong to this category.</p>
<p>(b) Non-insulin dependent diabetes mellitus (NIDDM)</p>
<p>This is the most common form of diabetes mellitus (80–90%). Most patients with this form of diabetes are relatively deficient in insulin and have mild hyperglycaemia. Obesity is commonly associated with NIDDM and decrease in obesity brings about reduction in hyperglycaemia in most cases. Some persons with NIDDM may be non-obese. A small percentage of NIDDM patients may require insulin injections or an oral hypoglycaemia agent to control hyperglycaemia.</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>
<p>Gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) In these cases, glucose intolerance is discovered for the first time during pregnancy. Such a woman is at high risk for foetal morbidity and should be promptly treated.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Impaired glucose tolerance (IGT) Persons with IGT are borderline cases with slightly raised glucose levels without overt hyperglycaemia. Such cases may later develop diabetes mellitus or revert to normal levels. Generally, they are at high risk of development of cardiovascular disease.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Previous abnormality of glucose tolerance (Prev. AGT) Persons in this category have a history of diabetes but have reverted to normal levels. e.g. those with GDM or obese NIDDM.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Potential abnormality of glucose tolerance (Pot. AGT) Persons at a more than average risk of developing diabetes belong to this category. e.g., child of parents with NIDDM.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Glucose intolerance associated with other disorders Hyperglycaemia due to underlying disorders such as chronic pancreatitis, Cushing’s disease, and acromegaly are included in this category.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="screening-tests-for-diabetes-mellitus">Screening Tests for Diabetes Mellitus<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#screening-tests-for-diabetes-mellitus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The screening tests for diabetes include urine and blood glucose examinations.</p>
<ol>
<li>Urine glucose In determining the presence of glucose in urine, it should be remembered that “true glucose” must exceed 10 mmol/L (180 mg/dl) before glucose can pass into the urine (Renal threshold).</li>
</ol>
<p>The renal threshold is, however, elevated in diabetic kidney. Also, the renal threshold increases with age. In some elderly patients no glycosuria may be present even with serum glucose level as high as 11.1 mmol/L (200 mg/dl).</p>
<p>Methods of screening for urine glucose are discussed later in the next chapter.</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>Fasting blood sugar It is preferable to use plasma for this test. Glucose levels in excess of 6.6 mmol/L (120 mg/dl) is suggestive of diabetes mellitus; and values between 6.0 to 6.6 mmol (110 to 120 mg/dl) are doubtful and should be confirmed by performing the glucose tolerance test. It is important to remember that conditions such as emotional hyperglycaemia resulting from secretion of epinephrine; general brain damage such as skull</li>
</ol>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>108 Clinical Chemistry</p>
<p>fractures, tumours, vascular accidents, encephalitis as well as carbon monoxide poisoning can provoke hyperglycaemia and glycosuria.</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>Two-hour post-prandial (pp) blood glucose</li>
</ol>
<p>Two hours after the patient has broken fast by being fed on adequate carbohydrate meal, a single blood sample is collected and analysed. Glucose level in excess of 10 mmol/L (180 mg/dl) is highly suggestive of diabetes mellitus and should be confirmed with a GTT. A single two-hour pp glucose level has the limitations due to</p>
<p>(i) Delayed peak level due to slow absorption
(ii) Early hyperglycaemia due to rapid absorption
(iii) Quick fall in concentration of blood glucose level due to the release of insulin.
(iv) Wrong specimen collection timing.</p>
<ol start="4">
<li>Glucose Tolerance Test (GTT)</li>
</ol>
<p>This is also usually referred to as oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT). Glucose tolerance test (GTT) measures the ability of the body to tolerate a measured dose of glucose. The rate of glucose absorption and response of insulin mainly determines the extent of glucose tolerance as shown by the changes in the level of blood glucose. When there is rise in blood glucose, insulin is released from the pancreas to lower the glucose level. Tolerance is reduced when insulin is absent or insufficient. A rise in blood glucose value usually occurs after having a meal containing carbohydrates. Therefore, the response to carbohydrate level depends on the previous carbohydrate diet and on the amount ingested. The effect of ingested carbohydrate is the basis of the glucose tolerance test. It simply detects abnormalities in the carbohydrate metabolism and in cases where glycosuria has been found.</p>
<p>The oral glucose tolerance test is performed in order to screen</p>
<p>(i) Patients having glycosuria with no apparent symptoms of diabetes and with normal fasting and post-prandial blood glucose levels.</p>
<p>(ii) Patients showing symptoms of diabetes with no glycosuria and normal fasting level of blood glucose.
(iii) Persons with family history of diabetes but with no overt diabetes.
(iv) Patients having glycosuria in conjunction with pregnancy, thyrotoxicosis, liver disease or infection.
(v) Patients showing evidence of neuropathies and retinopathies of unconfirmed origin.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="preparing-the-patient-for-gtt">Preparing the Patient for GTT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#preparing-the-patient-for-gtt" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>(i) Place the patient on a diet containing not less than 150 g of carbohydrate for about three days before the test.
(ii) The patient should not eat anything after supper and no breakfast is given on the day of the test. No drink, except ordinary plain water should be given. For children, the time the food is denied is as follows:</p>
<p>(a) Infants less than 4 months = 4 hours fast
(b) Infants age 4 to 6 months = 6 hours fast
(c) Children aged 6 to 24 months = 8 hours fast.
(iii) Patient should not be subjected to excessive exercise like walking long distance, excitement or fear, because all these can lead to a reduction in glucose tolerance.
(iv) The test is preferably done in the morning and ideally, when the patient is not suffering from any other disease.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="glucose-tolerance-test-method-who-reference-method">Glucose tolerance test method (WHO Reference method)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#glucose-tolerance-test-method-who-reference-method" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>(i) Collect a fasting sample for blood glucose and collect a urine sample from the patient.
(ii) Give the patient 75 g glucose dissolved in 250 to 350 ml of water to drink. For children 1.75 g per kg body weight to a maximum of 75 g is given. Alternatively, a 105 ml of lemon flavoured glucose syrup called Hycal (Beecham research</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Carbohydrate Metabolism 109</p>
<p>laboratories), diluted to 250 to 350 ml with water, can be given. This dose applies to adults only. For children, the pharmacy will supply the appropriate dose on request.</p>
<p>(iii) After one hour, take a sample for blood glucose and also collect a urine sample.
(iv) After 2 hours take a further sample for blood glucose and collect the final urine sample.
(v) Estimate the blood glucose levels of each specimen, and test the urines for the presence of glucose.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="results">Results<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#results" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Normal response: The fasting blood glucose should be less than 5.5 mmol/L and the two hour level less than 7.0 mmol/L.</p>
<p>Diabetic response: The fasting levels of glucose should be greater than 7.0 mmol/L and the two hour level should be greater than 10.0 mmol/L.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="evaluation-of-gtt-results">Evaluation of GTT results<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#evaluation-of-gtt-results" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="method-1">Method 1<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#method-1" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p><strong>Healthy individual</strong></p>
<p>Fasting : &lt; 5.5 mmol/L
1 hour specimen : &lt; 10.0 mmol/L
2 hour specimen : &lt; 7.0 mmol/L</p>
<p><strong>Diabetic individual</strong></p>
<p>Fasting : 7.8 mmol/L
1 hour specimen : 11.1 mmol/L
2 hour specimen : 11.1 mmol/L</p>
<p><strong>Impaired glucose tolerance</strong>
fasting : 7.8 mmol/L
1 hour specimen : 11.1 mmol/L
2 hour specimen : 7.9–11.0 mmol/L</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="method-2">Method 2<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#method-2" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>One can prepare a curve of blood glucose level against minutes (time) for the GTT. Compare it with a normal curve (Fig. 3.3).</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-31040f36.jpeg" alt="img-13.jpeg">
Fig. 3.3 Glucose tolerance test curves</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>110 Clinical Chemistry</p>
<p>Method 3
Wilkerson point system</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Time</th><th>mmol/L of glucose</th><th>Points</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Fasting</td><td>7.0 or more</td><td>1.00</td></tr><tr><td>1 hour</td><td>10.0 or more</td><td>0.5</td></tr><tr><td>2 hour</td><td>8.0 or more</td><td>0.5</td></tr><tr><td>3 hour</td><td>7.0 or more</td><td>1.00</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>The GTT is diagnostic of diabetes mellitus with this point system, if
(i) Two or more points are scored with up to 3 hour sample, and
(ii) One or more points are scored with up to 2 hour sample.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Chapter 4</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="renal-function-tests-and-urine-analysis">Renal Function Tests and Urine Analysis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#renal-function-tests-and-urine-analysis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The urinary system is made up of a pair of kidneys, a pair of ureters, the bladder, and the urethra.</p>
<p>The two kidneys form and excrete urine. The urine is carried from each kidney through a ureter to the urinary bladder by peristalsis. The urine is temporarily stored in the bladder before it is voided through the urethra to the exterior (Fig. 4.1(a)).</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-72e386c7.jpeg" alt="img-14.jpeg">
Fig. 4.1 (a) Urinary system</p>
<p>The kidneys are located one on each side of the vertebral column at the posterior side of the abdomen. Each kidney is bean shaped and is enclosed in a capsule of fibrous tissue. Beneath the capsule is the cortex followed by the medulla. The medulla consists of renal pyramids which converge into the renal pelvis (Fig. 4.1b). The hilum is the point from where renal arteries and nerves enter and renal veins leave the kidney.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-7dfe06ad.jpeg" alt="img-15.jpeg">
Fig. 4.1 (b) Kidney</p>
<p>The functional unit of the kidney is the nephron. There are one million nephrons in each kidney. The nephron itself is made up of a cup shaped structure known as Bowman's capsule, which surrounds a mass of capillaries, the glomerulus, the proximal convoluted tubule, loop of Henle, and the distal convoluted tubule. (Figs 4.1(c) and 4.1(d)).</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>112 Clinical Chemistry</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-9a1181a9.jpeg" alt="img-16.jpeg">
Fig. 4.1 (c) Nephron</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-7f66f33e.jpeg" alt="img-17.jpeg">
Fig. 4.1 (d) Glomerulus</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="renal-function">RENAL FUNCTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#renal-function" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>Maintenance of water and electrolyte balance of the body. The proximal renal tubules reabsorb about 85% of the water filtered by the glomerulus while the rest passes through the loop of Henle where some of the water is reabsorbed. Under normal circumstances all the glucose, amino acids, potassium, bicarbonate and about 70% of the sodium are also reabsorbed by the proximal tubules. The distal renal tubules, on the other hand, control the amount of water (tubular fluid) reabsorbed.</li>
</ol>
<p>Tubular fluid passes into the collecting ducts which stretch through the renal medulla and empty urine into the renal pelvis. The cells lining the collecting ducts which are normally impermeable to water are rendered permeable by the action of an antidiuretic hormone (ADH, vasopressin). Thus water is allowed through the wall of the tubule to re-enter circulation. When the body needs to excrete more water, the level of ADH is reduced, making the tubules impermeable to water, resulting in more water being excreted in the urine (dilute urine).</p>
<p>About 70% of sodium is reabsorbed in the proximal tubule. The remainder of the sodium is reabsorbed in the distal convoluted tubules and collecting ducts under the stimulus of the hormone aldosterone produced by adrenal cortex. The presence of aldosterone causes increased reabsorption of sodium by the tubules. In order to maintain electrolyte balance in the body, reabsorption of sodium is linked to potassium and hydrogen ions excretion and chloride and bicarbonate ions reabsorption.</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>Maintenance of blood pH. Substances that cause the pH of blood to rise or fall are removed by the kidneys. Substances of acid reaction are the waste products of protein metabolism. These substances are urea, uric acid, and creatinine. They are continually formed and so, must be excreted. On the other hand, the alkaline reaction substances are the salts of sodium, potassium, calcium, magnesium and phosphorous. If the concentration of these</li>
</ol>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Renal Function Tests and Urine Analysis 113</p>
<p>salts becomes too high, they are removed by the kidneys.</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>
<p>Excretion Waste products of drugs which are left in the body are later on excreted via kidneys. Toxic substances which are rendered harmless in the liver are excreted by the kidneys in the urine.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Filtration The afferent (entering) arteriole carries blood to the glomerulus while the efferent (leaving) arteriole takes the blood from the glomerulus. The walls of the capillaries within the glomerulus, and the walls of the Bowman's capsule act as semipermeable membranes. They allow some molecules to pass through while others are held back within the capillary lumen. Since the efferent arteriole is able to constrict, the pressure in the glomerulus is higher than that in the capsule. As a result, water, glucose, electrolytes, amino acids and waste products of metabolism like urea, creatinine and uric acid are able to pass from the bloodstream and to the Bowman's capsule. This process is known as ultrafiltration.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>The glomerular filtration rate (GFR) measures the efficiency of this filtration and it is determined by urea or creatinine clearance tests. The filtrate passes from the Bowman's capsule into the renal tubule. During this passage, the tubular cells reabsorb those substances that are needed by the body into the bloodstream.</p>
<ol start="5">
<li>
<p>Production of erythropoietin The substance that is necessary for the normal production of red blood cells in the bone marrow is the erythropoietin. It is produced by the kidneys.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Reabsorption Desirable elements in the filtrate such as glucose and amino acids are reabsorbed. This reabsorption occurs mainly in the proximal convoluted tubules.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Concentration of urine A large amount of water is filtered out through the kidneys each day. About 180 litres of glomerular filtrate is produced daily, while only 1 or 2 litres is excreted as urine from the body. Most of the water is reabsorbed in the distal and collecting tubules.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="renal-function-tests">RENAL FUNCTION TESTS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#renal-function-tests" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="non-protein-nitrogen-npn">Non-Protein Nitrogen (NPN)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#non-protein-nitrogen-npn" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Renal function is traditionally monitored by the determination of non-protein nitrogenous substances. The term non-protein nitrogen (NPN) originated from early days of clinical chemistry when analytical methods required protein to be removed before analysis. There are about 15 components of NPN and majority of them arise from the catabolism of proteins and nucleic acids. The important components are urea, amino acids, uric acid, creatinine, creatine and ammonia.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="urea">UREA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#urea" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Urea constitutes almost half the total of the non-protein nitrogenous substances of the blood. It is manufactured in the liver from carbon dioxide and ammonia resulting from the breakdown of amino acids. It is the major excretory product of protein metabolism. Urea is carried by the plasma to the kidney where it is filtered from the plasma by the glomerulus. About 40% of the urea in the glomerular filtrate is reabsorbed by the renal tubules. Most of the urea in the filtrate is excreted in urine while small amounts are excreted through the gastrointestinal tract and the skin.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="estimation-of-blood-urea">Estimation of Blood Urea<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#estimation-of-blood-urea" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Measurements of urea were initially done on a protein free filtrate of whole blood and so, early analytical methods were based on measuring the amount of nitrogen. This analysis was commonly referred to as Blood Urea Nitrogen (BUN). Though current methods of urea estimation use whole blood, plasma or serum, the term BUN is still used by some workers.</p>
<p>The nitrogen concentration of urea can be converted to urea concentration by multiplying it by 2.14.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>114 Clinical Chemistry</p>
<p>One molecule of urea <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex-error" title="ParseError: KaTeX parse error: Unexpected end of input in a macro argument, expected '}' at end of input: …NH}_2}{\right}]" style="color: rgb(204, 0, 0);">\left[\mathrm{CO} \underset{\mathrm{NH}_2}{\overset{\mathrm{NH}_2}{\right}]</span></span></p>
<p>corresponds to two atoms of nitrogen.</p>
<p>Therefore, concentration of urea =</p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mfrac><mtext>Mol.&nbsp;wt.&nbsp;of&nbsp;urea</mtext><mrow><mtext>Atomic&nbsp;wt.&nbsp;of&nbsp;N</mtext><mo>×</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>60</mn><mrow><mn>14</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>2.14</mn><mo>×</mo><mtext>concentration&nbsp;of&nbsp;BUN</mtext></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\frac{\text{Mol. wt. of urea}}{\text{Atomic wt. of N} \times 2} = \frac{60}{14 \times 2} = 2.14 \times \text{concentration of BUN}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.1408em; vertical-align: -0.7693em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3714em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Atomic&nbsp;wt.&nbsp;of&nbsp;N</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mord">2</span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Mol.&nbsp;wt.&nbsp;of&nbsp;urea</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7693em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.0908em; vertical-align: -0.7693em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3214em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">14</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mord">2</span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">60</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7693em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">2.14</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">concentration&nbsp;of&nbsp;BUN</span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p>The concentration of urea nitrogen in mg/dl can be converted to mmol/l of urea by multiplying by 0.36.</p>
<p><strong>Collection of specimens</strong> Since urea estimation can be performed on whole blood, plasma or serum, any routine anticoagulant such as EDTA can be used except</p>
<p>(i) Sodium fluoride, because it is an enzyme inhibitor, and therefore, unsuitable for enzyme methods.
(ii) Ammonium oxalate, because some methods of estimation of urea depend on the measurement of ammonia.</p>
<p><strong>Choice of methods</strong> There are three commonly used methods for the estimation of blood urea.</p>
<ol>
<li><strong>Urease method using Nessler’s reaction</strong> The enzyme urease hydrolyses urea to form ammonium carbonate. The ammonium ions produced are measured by using Nessler’s reagent</li>
</ol>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mtable rowspacing="0.16em" columnalign="left" columnspacing="1em"><mtr><mtd><mstyle scriptlevel="0" displaystyle="false"><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mi><munder><mo><mo><mover><mo><mo>⇌</mo></mo><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msub></mover></mo></mo><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msub></munder></mi><mo>+</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mo>⟶</mo><mn>2</mn><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mn>3</mn></msub><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow></mstyle></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mstyle scriptlevel="0" displaystyle="false"><mrow><mo>⟶</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mo>→</mo><msub><mrow><mo fence="true">(</mo><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mn>4</mn></msub><mo fence="true">)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mn>3</mn></msub><mo>⟶</mo><mn>2</mn><msubsup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mn>4</mn><mo>+</mo></msubsup><mo>+</mo><msubsup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>−</mo></msubsup></mrow></mstyle></mtd></mtr></mtable><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\begin{array}{l}
\mathrm{CO} \underset{\mathrm{NH}_2}{\overset{\mathrm{NH}_2}{\rightleftharpoons}} + \mathrm{H}_2\mathrm{O} \longrightarrow 2\mathrm{NH}_3 + \mathrm{CO}_2 \\
\longrightarrow \mathrm{H}_2\mathrm{O} \rightarrow \left(\mathrm{NH}_4\right)_2\mathrm{CO}_3 \longrightarrow 2\mathrm{NH}_4^+ + \mathrm{CO}_3^- \\
\end{array}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 3.5204em; vertical-align: -1.5102em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mtable"><span class="arraycolsep" style="width: 0.5em;"></span><span class="col-align-l"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 2.0102em;"><span style="top: -4.0102em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3.4604em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">CO</span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mop op-limits"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.4604em;"><span style="top: -2.8051em; margin-left: 0em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3.4604em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathrm mtight">NH</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3173em;"><span style="top: -2.357em; margin-right: 0.0714em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.5em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size3 size1 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.143em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.4604em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3.4604em;"></span><span><span class="mop"><span class="mrel"><span class="mop op-limits"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.4604em;"><span style="top: -3em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span><span class="mop">⇌</span></span></span><span style="top: -3.8821em; margin-left: 0em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathrm mtight">NH</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3173em;"><span style="top: -2.357em; margin-right: 0.0714em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.5em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size3 size1 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.143em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.011em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8554em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">+</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">H</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">O</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">⟶</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mord">2</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">NH</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">3</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">+</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">CO</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span style="top: -2.3102em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3.4604em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mrel">⟶</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">H</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">O</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="minner"><span class="minner"><span class="mopen delimcenter" style="top: 0em;">(</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">NH</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">4</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose delimcenter" style="top: 0em;">)</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.1514em;"><span style="top: -2.4003em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.2997em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">CO</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">3</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">⟶</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mord">2</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">NH</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8446em;"><span style="top: -2.453em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">4</span></span></span><span style="top: -3.1362em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mbin mtight">+</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.247em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">+</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">CO</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8446em;"><span style="top: -2.453em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">3</span></span></span><span style="top: -3.1362em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mbin mtight">−</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.247em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.5102em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="arraycolsep" style="width: 0.5em;"></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<ol start="2">
<li><strong>Urease method using Berthelot reaction</strong> In this method, the ammonia produced by the action of urease on urea is estimated by measuring the blue colour of indophenol formed with phenol and hypochlorite. Sodium nitroprusside is used as a catalyst.</li>
<li><strong>Diacetyl monoxime method</strong> Urea is heated with diacetyl monoxime in the presence of a strong acid and an oxidizing agent to form a yellow diazine derivative. Thiosemicarbazide is added to the mixture to enhance and stabilise the colour. Methods (2) and (3) will be described in detail.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="estimation-of-plasma-urea-by-berthelot-reaction">Estimation of Plasma Urea by Berthelot Reaction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#estimation-of-plasma-urea-by-berthelot-reaction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="reagents">Reagents<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#reagents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>(i) <strong>Buffered urease reagent</strong>: 1.0 g ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA) and 150 mg urease are mixed and shaken in about 70 ml of distilled water. Adjust pH to 6.5 and make up volume to 100 ml. When stored in a plastic bottle at 4°C, the reagent is stable for one month.</p>
<p>(ii) <strong>Phenol colour reagent</strong> Dissolve 50 g analytical grade phenol in 400 ml distilled water in a volumetric flask. Dissolve separately 250 mg analytical grade sodium nitroprusside in 50 ml of distilled water. Mix the two solutions together and make the volume up to 1 litre with distilled water. Store in a dark brown bottle away from light at 4°C. Stability is for about 2 months.</p>
<p>(iii) <strong>Alkaline hypochlorite reagent</strong> Dissolve 25 g sodium hydroxide in 400 ml distilled water. Dissolve 2.1 g sodium hypochlorite in 100 ml of distilled water; mix the two solutions and make up the volume to 1 litre. Storage is same as for the phenol colour reagent.</p>
<p>(iv) <strong>Urea standard solution (10 mmol/l)</strong> Dissolve 600 mg urea in distilled water and make up to 1 litre. Add a few drops of chloroform as a preservative. Store at 4°C.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="method">Method<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#method" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>(a) Set up test tubes as follows:</p>
<table><thead><tr><th></th><th>Blank</th><th>Test</th><th>Standard</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Buffered urease reagent</td><td>200 μl</td><td>200 μl</td><td>200 μl</td></tr><tr><td>Test plasma</td><td>-</td><td>20 μl</td><td>-</td></tr><tr><td>Standard</td><td>-</td><td>-</td><td>20 μl</td></tr><tr><td>Distilled water</td><td>20 μl</td><td>-</td><td>-</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Renal Function Tests and Urine Analysis 115</p>
<p>(b) Incubate all tubes at 37°C for 15 min.
(c) Remove all tubes from the water bath; add 1.0 ml phenol colour reagent to each tube. Shake gently to mix.
(d) Add 1.0 ml hypochlorite reagent to each tube and mix.
(e) Incubate all tubes at 37°C for 20 minutes.
(f) Remove all the tubes from water bath; add 5 ml distilled water to each tube.
(g) Read absorbances of the standard and test against the blank at 630 nm to 650 nm or with red filter.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="calculations">Calculations<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#calculations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The plasma urea concentration in mmol/L =</p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mfrac><mtext>Ab.&nbsp;Test</mtext><mtext>Ab.&nbsp;Standard</mtext></mfrac><mo>×</mo><mn>10</mn><mtext>&nbsp;mmol/L</mtext></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\frac{\text{Ab. Test}}{\text{Ab. Standard}} \times 10 \text{ mmol/L}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.0574em; vertical-align: -0.686em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3714em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Ab.&nbsp;Standard</span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Ab.&nbsp;Test</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.686em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">10</span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">&nbsp;mmol/L</span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="estimation-of-blood-urea-by-diacetyl-monoxime-method">Estimation of Blood Urea by Diacetyl Monoxime Method<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#estimation-of-blood-urea-by-diacetyl-monoxime-method" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="reagents">Reagents<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#reagents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>(i) Sodium tungstate (10 %)
(ii) 2/3 N sulphuric acid Add 2 ml of conc. H₂SO₄ to about 50 ml distilled water and dilute up to 100 ml.
(iii) Colour reagent</p>
<p><strong>Solution A</strong> Dissolve 1 g diacetyl monoxime, 0.2 g thiosemicarbazide and 9 g sodium chloride in distilled water. Dilute up to 1 litre.</p>
<p><strong>Solution B</strong> Add 60 ml conc. H₂SO₄ and 10 ml of 85% phosphoric acid to 800 ml of distilled water. Dissolve 0.1 g ferric chloride in the acid mixture; cool and make up to 1 litre.</p>
<p><strong>Reagent mixture</strong> Mix solution A and solution B in equal volumes just before use.
(iv) Urea standard solution (5 mmol/L) Dissolve 300 mg urea in distilled water and make up to 1 litre.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="method">Method<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#method" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>(i) Prepare protein-free filtrate by mixing 1.0 ml of blood, 7.0 ml of distilled water. Mix and add 1.0 ml of sodium tungstate and 1.0 ml of 2/3 N H₂SO₄. Mix and allow to stand for 5 minutes. Filter or centrifuge.
(ii) Set up 3 tubes as follows:</p>
<table><thead><tr><th></th><th>Blank</th><th>Standard</th><th>Test</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Colour reagent</td><td>5.0 ml</td><td>5.0 ml</td><td>5.0 ml</td></tr><tr><td>Distilled water</td><td>0.5 ml</td><td>-</td><td>-</td></tr><tr><td>Urea standard</td><td>-</td><td>0.5 ml</td><td>-</td></tr><tr><td>Specimen (filtrate)</td><td>-</td><td>-</td><td>0.5 ml</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>(iii) Heat all the tubes in boiling water bath for exactly 15 minutes.
(iv) Cool and read the absorbance at 520 nm or using green filter.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="calculations">Calculations<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#calculations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mtable rowspacing="0.16em" columnalign="left" columnspacing="1em"><mtr><mtd><mstyle scriptlevel="0" displaystyle="false"><mrow><mtext>mmol/L&nbsp;of&nbsp;Blood&nbsp;urea</mtext><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mtext>Ab.&nbsp;test</mtext><mtext>Ab.&nbsp;standard</mtext></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mstyle scriptlevel="0" displaystyle="false"><mrow><mo>×</mo><mtext>Conc.&nbsp;of&nbsp;std</mtext><mo>×</mo><mfrac><mn>100</mn><mtext>Amount&nbsp;of&nbsp;blood</mtext></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mstyle scriptlevel="0" displaystyle="false"><mrow><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mtext>Ab.&nbsp;test</mtext><mtext>Ab.&nbsp;std</mtext></mfrac><mo>×</mo><mn>0.025</mn><mo>×</mo><mfrac><mn>100</mn><mn>0.05</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mtext>Ab.&nbsp;test</mtext><mtext>Ab.&nbsp;std</mtext></mfrac><mo>×</mo><mn>50</mn></mrow></mstyle></mtd></mtr></mtable><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\begin{array}{l}
\text{mmol/L of Blood urea} = \frac{\text{Ab. test}}{\text{Ab. standard}} \\
\times \text{Conc. of std} \times \frac{100}{\text{Amount of blood}} \\
= \frac{\text{Ab. test}}{\text{Ab. std}} \times 0.025 \times \frac{100}{0.05} = \frac{\text{Ab. test}}{\text{Ab. std}} \times 50 \\
\end{array}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 3.6853em; vertical-align: -1.5927em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mtable"><span class="arraycolsep" style="width: 0.5em;"></span><span class="col-align-l"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 2.0927em;"><span style="top: -4.2126em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">mmol/L&nbsp;of&nbsp;Blood&nbsp;urea</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8801em;"><span style="top: -2.655em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord mtight">Ab.&nbsp;standard</span></span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.394em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord mtight">Ab.&nbsp;test</span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.345em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.0074em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">×</span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Conc.&nbsp;of&nbsp;std</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8451em;"><span style="top: -2.655em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord mtight">Amount&nbsp;of&nbsp;blood</span></span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.394em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">100</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.345em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span></span></span><span style="top: -1.7673em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8801em;"><span style="top: -2.655em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord mtight">Ab.&nbsp;std</span></span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.394em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord mtight">Ab.&nbsp;test</span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.345em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mord">0.025</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8451em;"><span style="top: -2.655em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">0.05</span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.394em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">100</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.345em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8801em;"><span style="top: -2.655em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord mtight">Ab.&nbsp;std</span></span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.394em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord mtight">Ab.&nbsp;test</span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.345em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mord">50</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.5927em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="arraycolsep" style="width: 0.5em;"></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p>Alternatively, a calibration curve can be prepared and a graph of absorbance against concentration plotted to determine the amount of urea in the test sample.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="normal-range-of-blood-urea">Normal Range of Blood Urea<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#normal-range-of-blood-urea" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Adults: <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>2.5</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>7.0</mn><mtext>&nbsp;mmol/L</mtext></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">2.5 - 7.0 \text{ mmol/L}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">2.5</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">7.0</span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">&nbsp;mmol/L</span></span></span></span></span></span> (15 - 40 mg/dl)</p>
<p>Mg/dl of urea = mmol/L × 6</p>
<p>&gt; <strong>Note</strong>
&gt; Urea concentration is often expressed as units of urea nitrogen in blood (BUN) in mg/dl. The molecular weight of urea is 60. Each molecule of urea contains two nitrogen atoms with a weight of 14 × 2 = 28. Therefore blood urea can be converted to BUN by the factor 28/60, i.e., 0.467. Conversely, BUN can be converted to urea by multiplying by 60/28, i.e., 2.14.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>116 Clinical Chemistry</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="interpretation-of-blood-urea-results">Interpretation of Blood Urea Results<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#interpretation-of-blood-urea-results" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Blood normally contains a small amount of urea; and the amount may vary with the amount of protein in the diet. When the amount of urea in the blood becomes excessive, the condition is known as <em>uraemia</em>. This condition is usually a result of impaired kidney function. In the elderly, the level of urea may be a little higher than normal; and low values may be found during pregnancy and in full term infants, whereas premature infants may have slightly higher values than the adult range.</p>
