<p>A considerable rise in the blood NPN level particularly due to urea and creatinine in a kidney insufficiency is called <em>azotaemia</em>. The cause of azotaemia can be pre-renal, renal, or post-renal.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pre-renal-azotaemia">Pre-renal azotaemia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pre-renal-azotaemia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is due to poor perfusion of the kidneys resulting in diminished glomerular filtration. Poor perfusion can be due to:</p>
<p>(a) Reduced blood flow to the kidney as a result of shock, dehydration, blood loss or congestive heart failure.
(b) Increased protein catabolism as in fever, severe burns, stress, crush injury or bleeding into soft tissues.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="renal-azotaemia">Renal azotaemia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#renal-azotaemia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is when urea is retained primarily due to impaired glomerular filtration which results in acute or chronic renal disease. The acute state may be due to glomerulonephritis, nephrotoxic drugs, or renal cortical necrosis. The chronic condition may be due to glomerulonephritis, pyelonephritis, diabetes mellitus or renal tubular diseases.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="post-renal-azotaemia">Post-renal azotaemia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#post-renal-azotaemia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is due to the obstruction of where urea is reabsorbed into circulation. The obstruction can be due to ureteral destruction by stone, tumour, inflammation or surgical trauma. It can also be due to obstruction of bladder neck or urethra by enlarged prostate gland, tumour, inflammation or stones.</p>
<p>&gt; <strong>Note</strong> Semi-quantitative methods for the estimation of urea are available. One of such methods is the <em>Urastrat</em> which is based on a test strip coated with the urease reagent. The methods are useful in emergencies, small clinics or as screening procedures.</p>
<p>Apart from the measurement of the amount of urea in the blood, there are many methods for determining the impairment of the kidneys. But because most of the methods are cumbersome, they are not used routinely.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="determination-of-urine-urea">Determination of Urine Urea<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#determination-of-urine-urea" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Collect a 24 hour specimen of urine, which is preserved with thymol or toluene. Dilute the urine 1:20 and determine the urea concentration of the diluted urine using any method described for blood urea. Multiply the results by the dilution factor (<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>×</mo><mn>20</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\times 20</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">×</span><span class="mord">20</span></span></span></span></span>) to obtain the concentration in mmol/L or g/dl.</p>
<p><strong>Normal range</strong> 250–600 mmol/L or 15–35 g/dl</p>
<p><strong>Urea clearance test</strong> The average urea clearance over a 24 hour period can be determined by collecting a 24 hour urine specimen and taking a blood sample around mid-day. Determine the plasma and urine urea concentrations and calculate average urea clearance in the same manner as the creatinine clearance (see below).</p>
<p><strong>Normal range</strong> 40–65 ml/min.</p>
<p>It may fall to about 10 ml/min during renal failure and may reach to 2–3 ml/min in terminal cases.</p>
<p>&gt; <strong>Note</strong> Urea clearance test is no longer used as a measure of glomerular filtration rate (GFR) because it underestimates GFR.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ff7a7101">♦ CREATININE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ff7a7101" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Creatinine is a nitrogenous product which is produced from the metabolism of creatine in the skeletal muscles. It is filtered by the kidneys and excreted in the urine. Unlike urea, creatinine level in the blood is not linked to protein intake. But like urea, the measurement of creatinine level is a test</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Renal Function Tests and Urine Analysis 117</p>
<p>of renal function. The formation of creatinine is constant, and has direct relationship to muscle mass. For this reason, it varies with age and sex.</p>
<p>The assay of the creatinine level is a good screening index of renal function. One such useful index relates creatinine excretion to muscle mass or lean body weight. This index is known as Creatinine clearance. There are several tests available to determine impairment of renal function, but most of them are not routinely performed because of their cumbersome nature. However, the clearance test is in vogue.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="creatinine-clearance-test">Creatinine Clearance Test<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#creatinine-clearance-test" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The clearance test is done to assess the glomerular filtration capabilities of the kidneys. The creatinine clearance is defined as the millilitres of blood (plasma) that are cleared of creatinine by the kidneys per unit time. The clearance is calculated with this formula:</p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mtext>Average&nbsp;creatinine&nbsp;clearance&nbsp;(ml/min)</mtext><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>U</mi><mo>×</mo><mi>V</mi></mrow><mi>P</mi></mfrac></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\text{Average creatinine clearance (ml/min)} = \frac{U \times V}{P}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Average&nbsp;creatinine&nbsp;clearance&nbsp;(ml/min)</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.0463em; vertical-align: -0.686em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3603em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.13889em;">P</span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.10903em;">U</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.22222em;">V</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.686em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p>where
U = concentration of creatinine in urine (mg/dl)
P = concentration of creatinine in plasma (mg/dl)
V = volume in millilitres of urine excreted per minute, i.e., 24 hour urine volume (ml) divided by 1440, the number of minutes in 24 hours.</p>
<p>The standard body surface area is 1.73 square metres. A normogram can be used to determine a patient's body surface area. Most autoanalysers are capable of calculating this value if the patient's height and weight are entered in the system.</p>
<p><strong>Method</strong> It is usual to determine a 24 hour creatinine clearance, but in some cases, it is possible to test for a two to six hour clearance period.</p>
<p><strong>Specimen</strong> For creatinine analysis, serum or plasma and diluted urine can be used. Usually, urine is diluted 1:100 or 1:200; and it is preserved with thymol or toluene only. Urine stored in the refrigerator for up to 5 days is also suitable. Serum or plasma, promptly separated, is suitable for up to 1 week if refrigerated. Fluoride and heparin are good anticoagulants if plasma is to be used.</p>
<p>To perform the test, the total volume of urine during the entire 24 hours period is collected and carefully measured. Blood is collected about 12 hours into the urine collection (roughly mid-day) on the day of the test. The creatinine levels of the plasma (or serum) and urine are then determined. The clearance is obtained with the formula given above.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="quantitative-estimation-of-creatinine">Quantitative Estimation of Creatinine<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#quantitative-estimation-of-creatinine" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Most of the commonly used methods for the estimation of creatinine level are based on the reaction of creatinine present in the specimen with an alkaline picrate reagent to produce a bright orange-red complex. But unfortunately, a number of other substances give similar reaction, thus giving falsely high values. There are various modifications now developed to give a more specific test for creatinine. One of these modifications is the use of aluminium silicate to separate creatinine from non-specific chromogens. This particular modification is now the reference method for "true" creatinine. A popular modification includes an acidification step whereby the impact of acidification of colour development is measured colorimetrically and the difference noted.</p>
<p><strong>Principle</strong> Creatinine reacts with alkaline picrate reagent to form an orange-red colour which is measured in a spectrophotometer.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="reagents">Reagents<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#reagents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>(i) Saturated picric acid solution. Place an excess of picric acid in an amber coloured glass bottle containing distilled water. Leave for a few days and the supernatant is the saturated solution.</p>
<p>*Note that dry picric acid is explosive and so, it must always be stored damp.</p>
<p>(ii) 10% w/v sodium hydroxide solution in distilled water.</p>
<p>(iii) Creatinine working reagent. Mix 10 ml of the saturated picric acid solution and 2.0 ml of the</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>118 Clinical Chemistry</p>
<p>10% sodium hydroxide solution together. This reagent should be prepared fresh for use.</p>
<p>(iv) Stock creatinine standard, 10 mmol/L. Weigh 0.113 g of pure creatinine, or 0.602 g of creatinine zinc chloride; dissolve in, and make up the volume to 100 ml with 100 mmol/L (0.1N) hydrochloric acid. This concentration is 10 mmol/L (i.e. 10,000 μmol/L).</p>
<p>This solution is stable for 2 months when stored at 2–8°C.</p>
<p>(v) Working creatinine standard. Dilute the stock standard 1:50 to 200 μmol/L. This is stable for about 1 month at 2–8°C.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="method">Method<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#method" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>(i) Set up two sets of three test tubes and label each as follows:</p>
<p>(ii) Add reagents as shown</p>
<table><thead><tr><th></th><th>Blank</th><th>Standard</th><th>Test</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Working reagent</td><td>2.0 ml</td><td>2.0 ml</td><td>2.0 ml</td></tr><tr><td>Distilled water</td><td>0.2 ml</td><td>-</td><td>-</td></tr><tr><td>Standard (200 μmol/L)</td><td>-</td><td>0.2 ml</td><td>-</td></tr><tr><td>Test sample</td><td>-</td><td>-</td><td>0.2 ml</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>(iii) Mix well and leave at room temperature for 90 minutes.</p>
<p>(iv) First reading. Read absorbance of the first set of tubes with blue-green filter; or at 490 nm.</p>
<p>Zero the instrument with the blank, (first set of tubes)</p>
<p>(v) Second reading. Into the second set of tubes, add 50 μl (0.05 ml) acetic acid, 60% v/v, to all the tubes. Leave at room temperature for 6–10 minutes. Read absorbance of the second set of tubes with blue-green filter; or at 490 nm. Zero the instrument with the blank, (second set of tubes)</p>
<p>(vi) Final reading. Subtract second reading from the first reading to eliminate the colour developed due to non-specific chromogens.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="calculation">Calculation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#calculation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mtext>Creatinine&nbsp;</mtext><mi>μ</mi><mtext>mol/L</mtext><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mtext>Ab.&nbsp;test</mtext><mtext>Ab.&nbsp;std</mtext></mfrac><mo>×</mo><mn>200</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\text{Creatinine } \mu \text{mol/L} = \frac{\text{Ab. test}}{\text{Ab. std}} \times 200</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Creatinine&nbsp;</span></span><span class="mord mathnormal">μ</span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">mol/L</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.0574em; vertical-align: -0.686em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3714em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Ab.&nbsp;std</span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Ab.&nbsp;test</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.686em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">200</span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p><strong>Note</strong>: Alternatively, a calibration curve for creatinine can be prepared and from it the value of the creatinine can be obtained, if the reading of the 200 μmol/L standard agrees with the calibration.</p>
<p>When the creatinine result is over 500 μmol/L, the assay should be repeated with a 1 in 3 dilution of specimen in distilled water. The result is then multiplied by 3.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="creatinine-test-kits">Creatinine test kits<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#creatinine-test-kits" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>There are various brands of test kits for creatinine in the market. Majority of them are based on the principle of the alkaline picrate method before and after adding acid (to give 'true' creatinine value). The important rule of using any test kit is to follow the manufacturer's instructions and the creatinine test kit is no exception.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="reference-values">Reference Values<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#reference-values" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="creatinine-serum-plasma">Creatinine Serum/Plasma<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#creatinine-serum-plasma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Adult men 88–135 μmol/L (0.9–1.5 mg/dl)</p>
<p>Adult women 62–115 μmol/L (0.7–1.3 mg/dl)</p>
<p>mg/dl of creatinine = μmol/L × 0.011</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="creatinine-clearance">Creatinine clearance<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#creatinine-clearance" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Adult men 97–137 ml/min</p>
<p>Adult women 88–128 ml/min</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="interpretation-of-creatinine-results">Interpretation of Creatinine Results<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#interpretation-of-creatinine-results" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>High serum or plasma creatinine levels are all attributed to renal causes of uraemia. But while the urea level will continue to rise in cases of severe permanent renal dysfunction, the creatinine level tends to plateau.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="uric-acid">URIC ACID<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#uric-acid" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Uric acid is the final breakdown product of purine metabolism. Purines such as adenosine and</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Renal Function Tests and Urine Analysis 119</p>
<p>guanine result from the breakdown of nucleic acids. They are either ingested or come from the destruction of tissue cells, and are converted mainly in the liver into uric acid. From the liver, uric acid is transported to the kidneys where it is filtered by the glomeruli. Nearly all the filtered uric acid is reabsorbed in the proximal tubules; and small amounts are then secreted by the distal tubules and ultimately appear in the urine.</p>
<p>Nearly all of the uric acid in the plasma is in the form of monosodium urate. Urates in this form are relatively insoluble. At high levels (&gt;6.4 mg/dl), the plasma is saturated; urate crystals may form and precipitate in the tissues.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="assay-methods-for-serum-plasma-uric-acid">Assay Methods for Serum/Plasma Uric Acid<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#assay-methods-for-serum-plasma-uric-acid" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Uric acid is readily oxidised to allantoin and so can function as a reducing agent in many chemical reactions. The Caraway method is the most popular method for determining uric acid level. This method is based on the oxidation of uric acid in a protein-free solution, with the eventual reduction of phosphotungstic acid to tungsten blue. Sodium carbonate is used to provide the alkaline pH necessary for colour development. Unfortunately, this method is relatively non-specific, and so several methods that make use of the specific enzyme, uricase, have been developed. This enzyme catalyses the oxidation of uric acid to allantoin with the subsequent production of hydrogen peroxide (H₂O₂). The uricase method is based on the fact that uric acid has a significant UV absorbance with a peak at 293 nm, whereas allantoin does not have. Therefore, the difference in absorbance in an ultraviolet spectrophotometer before and after incubation with uricase is proportional to the concentration of uric acid.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="caraway-method">Caraway Method<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#caraway-method" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="reagents">Reagents<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#reagents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>(i) Phosphotungstic acid reagent Dissolve 40.0 g of high grade sodium tungstate in about 300 ml of distilled water. Add 32 ml of orthophosphoric acid (H₃PO₄, 85% w/v). Reflux for 4 hours under a vertical condenser. Cool to room temperature, and add about 300 ml of distilled water. In this solution, dissolve 32.0 g lithium sulphate monohydrate and make volume up to 1 litre. Add 81.0 ml of 2 M sodium hydroxide solution and mix. The final pH is adjusted to 2.5; and the colour should be pale greenish-yellow.</p>
<p>(ii) Sodium carbonate solution Dissolve 140 g anhydrous sodium carbonate in, and make up to 1 litre with distilled water. Mix well and store in a plastic bottle.</p>
<p>(iii) Uric acid standard (stock) 50 mg/dl Add 1.0 g of lithium carbonate to about 500 ml distilled water. Warm to 60°C to dissolve. Place 500 mg of pure uric acid in a 1 litre volumetric flask and add the lithium carbonate solution to it. Warm to 60°C to dissolve. Cool and add 5.0 ml formalin. Add 400 ml distilled water and 10 ml of 50% acetic acid. Dilute to 1 litre with distilled water.</p>
<p>(iv) Uric acid standard, working (5 mg/dl) Dilute the stock standard 1:10 by diluting 10 ml to 100 ml with distilled water.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="technique">Technique<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#technique" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Prepare a set of 3 tubes as follows:</p>
<table><thead><tr><th></th><th>Test</th><th>Standard</th><th>Blank</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Phosphotungstic acid reagent</td><td>2 ml</td><td>2 ml</td><td>2 ml</td></tr><tr><td>Sample</td><td>0.2 ml</td><td>-</td><td>-</td></tr><tr><td>Working standard uric acid (5 mg/dl)</td><td>-</td><td>0.2 ml</td><td>-</td></tr><tr><td>Distilled water</td><td>-</td><td>-</td><td>0.2 ml</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>(i) Add the reagents as shown above
(ii) Mix well and leave at room temperature for 15 minutes.
(iii) Centrifuge all tubes at 3000 rpm for 10 minutes.
(iv) Decant the supernatant directly into 3 separate correspondingly labelled tubes
(v) Add 1.0 ml of sodium carbonate solution to each tube.
(vi) Leave at room temperature for 15 minutes.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>120 Clinical Chemistry</p>
<p>(vii) Read the absorbances at 650–700 nm, setting the zero with the blank.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="calculation">Calculation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#calculation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>A</mi><mi>b</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">.</mi><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi>t</mi><mi>e</mi><mi>s</mi><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>A</mi><mi>b</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">.</mi><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi>s</mi><mi>t</mi><mi>d</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>×</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>=</mo><mtext>Serum&nbsp;uric&nbsp;acid&nbsp;in&nbsp;mg/dl</mtext></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\frac{Ab.\ test}{Ab.\ std} \times 5 = \text{Serum uric acid in mg/dl}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.0574em; vertical-align: -0.686em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3714em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal">A</span><span class="mord mathnormal">b</span><span class="mord">.</span><span class="mspace">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathnormal">s</span><span class="mord mathnormal">t</span><span class="mord mathnormal">d</span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal">A</span><span class="mord mathnormal">b</span><span class="mord">.</span><span class="mspace">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathnormal">t</span><span class="mord mathnormal">es</span><span class="mord mathnormal">t</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.686em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">5</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Serum&nbsp;uric&nbsp;acid&nbsp;in&nbsp;mg/dl</span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p>Serum uric acid mg/dl × 0.059 = mmol/L</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="kit-systems">Kit systems<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#kit-systems" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Nearly all the kit systems are based on the enzyme uricase method. They are specific, and the manufacturer’s leaflet clearly states in simple language, the method of assay.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="reference-ranges-for-uric-acid">Reference Ranges for Uric Acid<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#reference-ranges-for-uric-acid" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Children: 2–5.5 mg/dl (0.12–0.32 mmol/L)
Adult males: 3.5–7.2 mg/dl (0.21–0.42 mmol/L)
Adult females: 2.6–6.0 mg/dl (0.15–0.35 mmol/L)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="interpretation">Interpretation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#interpretation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="factors-affecting-uric-acid-levels-in-the-blood">Factors affecting uric acid levels in the blood<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#factors-affecting-uric-acid-levels-in-the-blood" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Increased production, raised serum levels (hyperuricaemia)
(i) Idiopathic primary gout
(ii) Excessive dietary purines (liver, kidney, legumes, etc.)
(iii) Cytotoxic treatment of malignancies such as leukaemias and lymphomas
(iv) Polycythaemia
(v) Multiple myeloma
(vi) Sickle cell anaemia.</p>
<p>Decreased excretion, raised serum levels
(i) Alcohol ingestion
(ii) Ketoacidosis
(iii) Lactic acidosis
(iv) Thiazid diuretics
(v) Renal dysfunction</p>
<p>Decreased level of uric acid (hypouricaemia)</p>
<p>It is not very common but can be caused by:
(i) Over treatment with allopurinol
(ii) Ingestion of drugs like aspirin with doses above 4 g a day
(iii) Corticosteroids
(iv) Estrogens</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="urine-analysis">URINE ANALYSIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#urine-analysis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The physical, chemical and microscopic examination of urine is known as urinalysis or routine urine analysis. Urinalysis is an important part of the initial examination of a patient and the results provide a valuable picture of the patient’s general health pattern. Generally, urinalysis will indicate:
(i) The state of the kidneys and the urinary tract — Chemical tests for the presence of protein or blood; together with physical properties and microscopic examination for casts, cells and certain crystals are very helpful in assessing and treating renal and urinary tract disease.
(ii) Information about metabolic and systemic (nonrenal) abnormalities — Tests for glucose, ketone bodies, bilirubin and urobilinogen are useful parameters in the diagnosis of metabolic and systemic disorders such as diabetes and jaundice.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="composition-of-urine">Composition of Urine<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#composition-of-urine" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Urine is the fluid containing water soluble waste products excreted from the blood via the kidneys. Urine is mainly composed of 95% water and the rest being made up of urea, uric acid, creatinine, sodium, potassium, chloride, calcium, phosphates, etc. The composition of urine varies a great deal and is affected by three factors:
(i) Nutritional status of the individual
(ii) State of metabolic processes
(iii) Ability of the kidneys to selectively handle the material presented to them.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="properties-of-normal-urine">Properties of Normal Urine<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#properties-of-normal-urine" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<table><thead><tr><th>Dry weight</th><th>: 55–70 g/24 hours</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>pH</td><td>: 4.6–8.0 (mean: 6.1)</td></tr><tr><td>Specific gravity</td><td>:</td></tr><tr><td>Neonates</td><td>: 1.012</td></tr><tr><td>Infants</td><td>: 1.002–1.006</td></tr><tr><td>Adults</td><td>: 1.003–1.030</td></tr><tr><td>Volume per day</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Neonates</td><td>: 30–60 ml</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Renal Function Tests and Urine Analysis 121</p>
<p>Children 400–1400 ml
Adults 600–2500 ml
Organic constituents/ 24 hours
Urea : 15–30 g
Creatinine : 1.0–1.8 g
Uric acid : 0.3–0.6 g
Protein (Albumin) : 0–0.1 g
Glucose : &lt; 0.5 g</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="collection-and-preservation-of-urine">Collection and Preservation of Urine<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#collection-and-preservation-of-urine" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Urine sample for analysis should be collected in a clean, dry container and examined as soon as possible. In most cases, the first specimen freely voided in the morning is preferred although specimen collected 2 to 3 hours after eating is suitable when testing for glucose. On standing, red blood cells and white blood cells are destroyed; casts are decomposed; glucose is lost and bacterial contamination of urine takes place causing alkalisation of the sample. Therefore, the specimen must be examined when fresh, ideally within 30 minutes of collection. If there is any delay in processing, it should be suitably preserved as described in Chapter 2 of this section.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="routine-tests-for-urine-analysis">ROUTINE TESTS FOR URINE ANALYSIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#routine-tests-for-urine-analysis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The routine tests for urine analysis are grouped in three parts; physical, chemical and microscopic examinations. Table 4.1 shows the tests routinely performed under each section. Certain tests are graded according to their degree of accuracy: screening or qualitative tests; semi-quantitative tests; and quantitative tests. The results of qualitative tests are reported as positive or negative; or, present or absent. For semiquantitative tests, results are graded as negative, trace, 1+, 2+, 3+, or 4+; or sometimes results are given as small, moderate or large quantities. The quantitative tests, on the other hand, determine accurately the amount of substance that they detect.</p>
<p>|  Physical properties | Colour
Transparency
Odour
Specific gravity (urinometer)  |
| --- | --- |
|  Chemical screening tests (reagent strips) | pH
Specific gravity (reagent strip)
Protein
Blood
Glucose
Ketones
Bilirubin
Urobilinogen  |
|  Microscopic examination of urinary sediment | Red blood cells
White blood cells
Epithelial Cells
Casts
Bacteria and other microorganisms
Crystals
Other components  |</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>122 Clinical Chemistry</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="i-physical-examination">I. Physical Examination<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-physical-examination" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Physical examination of urine is also referred to as macroscopic examination and this involves the assessment of physical properties such as volume, colour, appearance, odour, foam, specific gravity and pH.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="1-volume">1. Volume<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-volume" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Under normal conditions, a direct relationship exists between urine volume and water intake of a person. Thus, if water intake is increased, the kidney will eliminate a larger volume of urine than normal. Likewise, if water intake is decreased, the kidney will eliminate a smaller volume of urine.</p>
<p>Certain situations, however, give rise to abnormal urine volumes. Here are some terms to describe such volumes:</p>
<p><strong>Polyuria</strong> This term refers to consistent elimination of an abnormally large volume of urine (&gt; 2000 ml) in 24 hours.</p>
<p><strong>Causes:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Diabetes mellitus</li>
<li>Neurotic polydipsia (abnormal thirst)</li>
<li>Chronic renal failure</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Diuresis</strong> This is a term that describes any increase in urine volume, even if the increase is only temporary.</p>
<p><strong>Causes:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Excessive fluid intake</li>
<li>Diuretic drugs</li>
<li>Intravenous saline/glucose</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Oliguria</strong> The term refers to the excretion of an abnormally small volume of urine (&lt; 200 ml) in 24 hours.</p>
<p><strong>Causes:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Dehydration due to vomiting, diarrhoea, excessive sweating</li>
<li>Renal ischemia</li>
<li>Acute renal tubular necrosis</li>
<li>Acute glomerulonephritis</li>
<li>Obstruction to urine flow</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Anuria</strong> This is the complete absence of urine formation.</p>
<p><strong>Causes:</strong> Same as for oliguria</p>
<p><strong>Nocturia</strong> The excretion, by an adult, of urine more than 500 ml at night is called nocturia.</p>
<p><strong>Cause:</strong> Chronic glomerulonephritis</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-colour">2. Colour<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-colour" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The colour of normal urine varies greatly, even in one person, in a single day. In general, the normal urine colour is described as strawy yellow or amber. This colour of normal urine is due to the presence of three pigments: urochrome (a yellow pigment present in large concentrations); uroerythrin (a by-product of red blood cell degradation); and urobilin (another pigment resulting from red blood cell degradation).</p>
<p>There are several abnormal colours of urine of pathological significance and require special attention.</p>
<p><strong>Pale</strong> Pale urine suggests that the urine is dilute and may result from conditions such as diabetes mellitus or diabetes insipidus; and in nephrotic syndrome.</p>
<p><strong>Dark yellow</strong> This colour indicates very concentrated constituents in a comparatively low volume and is commonly associated with a febrile condition.</p>
<p><strong>Yellow-brown or green-brown</strong> This is a very characteristic colour indicating the presence of bilirubin, which is related to the clinical condition called jaundice. Such specimens foam considerably when shaken, forming a distinct yellow coloured foam. On standing, bilirubin may be oxidized to biliverdin, a green pigment, imparting a greenish tinge to the urine.</p>
<p><strong>Orange-red or orange-brown</strong> This colour is derived from the pigment, urobilin. The urine slowly takes on the colour on standing due to the oxidation of urobilinogen to urobilin. When shaken, such a urine sample will produce a coloured foam.</p>
<p>A similar colour may be seen after the administration of certain drugs such as aminopyrines.</p>
<p><strong>Clear red</strong> A clear red colour of urine is indicative of the presence of haemoglobin (haemoglobinuria), the colour pigment of red blood cells. This is due to the increased red blood cell destruction in the body resulting from conditions such as incompatible blood transfusion reaction, autoimmune haemolytic anaemia, paroxysmal nocturnal haemoglobinuria.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Renal Function Tests and Urine Analysis 123</p>
<p>glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency, and certain infections and drugs. Haemoglobin/blood in urine can be detected by occult blood test (refer to Chapter 9) or reagent strips.</p>
<p><strong>Cloudy red</strong> This colour is caused by the presence of intact red blood cells rather than haemoglobin. This condition is called haematuria and is differentiated from haemoglobinuria by microscopic examination.</p>
<p><strong>Black or dark brown</strong> This colour may result from melanin or homogentisic acid. Initially, the urine is colourless when voided, but becomes black on standing. This colour should not be overlooked as it may suggest very serious conditions. Melanin is associated with melanoma, a type of tumour; and homogentisic acid is associated with alkaptonuria or phenylketonuria, a result of an inborn error in the metabolism of tyrosine. Black colour of urine may also be due to phenol poisoning or as a result of conversion of haemoglobin to methaemoglobin.</p>
<p><strong>Milky-white</strong> The urine may appear milky white in a condition known as Chyluria. This is seen in a chronic infection by a filarial worm <em>Wuchereria bancrofti</em>. The chyle consists of lymph mixed with particles of digested fat. The urinary sediment may show motile microfilariae.</p>
<p><strong>Miscellaneous colours</strong> There are various bizarre urine colours such as pink, blue, green and brown that may result from the ingestion of certain substances such as vitamins, vegetables, fruits, certain chemicals and dyes. They have no clinical significance, but may interfere in some chemical tests.</p>
<ol start="3">
<li><strong>Appearance/transparency</strong> Normally, urine is clear when freshly voided; but it often becomes cloudy when allowed to stand for a certain length of time. This cloudiness is usually due to precipitation of chemical substances (crystals, or amorphous phosphates and urates) in urine or due to growth of bacteria. However, cloudiness in a freshly voided urine is usually of clinical significance and may be due to the presence of mucus, bacteria, white blood cells or red blood cells, etc.</li>
</ol>
<p>The degree of transparency of a urine specimen is expressed as clear, hazy, cloudy or turbid.</p>
<ol start="4">
<li><strong>Odour</strong> Normal, freshly voided urine has a characteristic faintly aromatic odour due to the presence of certain volatile acids.</li>
</ol>
<p>Bacterial action occurs when the urine is allowed to stand and this produces ammoniacal odour. The presence of ketone bodies is indicated by the so called fruity or sweet odour of urine.</p>
<ol start="5">
<li><strong>Foam</strong> Normal urine will produce a moderate amount of white foam when shaken. A urine sample with a high protein concentration produces a large amount of white foam on shaking, for example, in nephrotic syndrome. A characteristic yellow coloured foam is seen in urine samples containing bile pigments.</li>
</ol>
<p>A summary of the physical properties of urine is shown in Table 4.2.</p>
<ol start="6">
<li><strong>Specific gravity</strong> Specific gravity (Sp.gr.) of urine is a measure of the amount of dissolved substances in the urine. It is the weight of the urine compared to the weight of an equal volume of distilled water at a constant temperature.</li>
</ol>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mtext>e.g.,&nbsp;</mtext><mspace width="1em"></mspace><mtext>Sp.gr.</mtext><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mtext>Weight&nbsp;of&nbsp;urine</mtext><mtext>Weight&nbsp;of&nbsp;same&nbsp;volume&nbsp;of&nbsp;distilled&nbsp;water</mtext></mfrac></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\text{e.g., } \quad \text{Sp.gr.} = \frac{\text{Weight of urine}}{\text{Weight of same volume of distilled water}}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8778em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">e.g.,&nbsp;</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 1em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Sp.gr.</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.2519em; vertical-align: -0.8804em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3714em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Weight&nbsp;of&nbsp;same&nbsp;volume&nbsp;of&nbsp;distilled&nbsp;water</span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Weight&nbsp;of&nbsp;urine</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8804em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p>Urines of low specific gravity are called hyposthenuric (&lt;1.007), and those of fixed specific gravity of about 1.010 are called isothenuric.</p>
<p>Specific gravity is measured in several ways.</p>
<p><strong>Urinometer</strong> The urinometer is specifically designed for the measurement of urine specific gravity. It is calibrated in such a way that it sinks in distilled water until the "0" mark on the stem is in level with the surface of the water. This indicates specific gravity of 1.000. In about <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>70</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>80</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">70 - 80\mathrm{ml}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">70</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord">80</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">ml</span></span></span></span></span></span> of foamless urine in a measuring cylinder supplied with the instrument, the urinometer is more buoyant than it is in distilled water; and therefore, the specific gravity is read off the mark on the scale at the level of the surface of the urine. The instrument</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>124 Clinical Chemistry</p>
<p>Table 4.2 Physical properties of urine</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Property</th><th>Description</th><th>Comments</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Colour</td><td>Straw yellow Amber</td><td>Normal colour due to urochrome, the chief pigment in urine, with urobolin</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>Pale</td><td>Dilute urine</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>Dark yellow or reddish brown</td><td>Concentrated urine</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>Yellowish brown</td><td>Presence of bilirubin or biliverdin</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>Greenish brown</td><td>Melanin, homogenetistic acid, phenol poisoning</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>Dark brown and black (on standing)</td><td>Increased urobilin (excreted as urobilinogen)</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>Orange-red or orange-brown</td><td>Haemoglobinuria (haemoglobin in urine)</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>Clear red</td><td>Haematuria (red blood cells in urine)</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>Cloudy red</td><td>Drugs, foodstuffs</td></tr><tr><td>Transparency</td><td>Green, blue or orange</td><td>Normal</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>Clear</td><td>Presence of pus cells, bacteria, crystals, casts, mucus, fat</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>Hazy, cloudy or turbid</td><td>Normal, due to volatile acids</td></tr><tr><td>Odour</td><td>Aromatic</td><td>Ketone bodies</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>Sweet or fruity</td><td>Breakdown of urea by bacteria on standing</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>Ammoniacal</td><td>Urinary tract infection</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>Foul</td><td>Normal</td></tr><tr><td>Foaming</td><td>White, small amount</td><td>Bilirubin or bile pigments</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>Yellow, large amount</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>must float centrally in the urine without touching the sides of the cylinder. The reading is taken at the lower meniscus at the eye level (Fig. 4.2(a)).</p>
<p><strong>Correction factor for temperature</strong> Since the urinometer is usually calibrated at 15°C, add 0.001 for every 3°C above 15°C and subtract 0.001 for every 3°C below 15°C.</p>
<p><strong>Refractometer (Fig. 4.2(b))</strong> The specific gravity and refractive index of urine are closely correlated. The refractometer measures refractive index. The greater the concentration of dissolved particles in the urine, the greater is the increase in refractive index (refraction). From the measurement of refractive index, a scale of specific gravity can be prepared. The advantage of this method is that it requires a small volume of urine.</p>
<p>Place a small drop of urine on the exposed portion of the measuring prism on the refractometer. It will be drawn into the space between the prism. Hold the instrument up towards a light source. Look through the eye piece. Read the specific gravity on the scale where the dividing line between bright and dark fields crosses the scale.</p>
<p><strong>Weighing method</strong> This method is simple but not very sensitive. A known volume of urine is weighed in a clean, dry container. An equal volume</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Renal Function Tests and Urine Analysis 125</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-abb82bab.jpeg" alt="img-18.jpeg">
Fig. 4.2 (a) Urinometer</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-cca98cf1.jpeg" alt="img-19.jpeg">
Fig. 4.2 (b) Refractometer</p>
<p>ume of distilled water is also weighed in the same manner. The weight of the urine is divided by the weight of the distilled water to give the specific gravity of urine. This method is ideal even for very small quantity of urine.</p>
<p>Reagent strips There are reagent strips commercially available for the determination of specific gravity of urine. These are multiple test strips with a test area for specific gravity.</p>
<p>Osmometric method The osmometric method of measuring osmolality of urine is another technique. It is a technique that measures the total solute content of body fluids such as urine. The instrument is called osmometer. The osmotic pressure depends upon the total concentration of molecules and ions in solution. The unit of expressing this concentration is the osmol. An osmol is the quantity of substance in <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1000</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1000\mathrm{ml}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord">1000</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">ml</span></span></span></span></span></span> of solution which exerts an osmotic pressure of 2262 kPa (22.4 atmospheres). Under ideal conditions this will depress the freezing point by <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>1.86</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∘</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1.86^{\circ}\mathrm{C}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">1.8</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">6</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∘</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">C</span></span></span></span></span>. A millismol (mosmol) is one thousandth of an osmol. The total osmotic pressure (osmolality) of urine is equivalent to the depression of freezing point below that of pure water. Osmolality of normal urine is about <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>500</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>800</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">500 - 800\mathrm{mOsm / kg}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">500</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">800</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">mOsm/kg</span></span></span></span></span></span> water.</p>
<p>Osmolality is a measure of the number of dissolved particles in solution whereas specific gravity is the ratio of the mass of a solution compared with the mass of an equal volume of water. Under most circumstances, there is a good correlation between specific gravity and osmolality.</p>
<p>Causes of high specific gravity The most common causes of high specific gravity of urine are:</p>
<p>(i) Excessive sweating
(ii) Glycosuria
(iii) Acute nephritis
(iv) Albuminuria
(v) All causes of oliguria</p>
<p>Causes of low specific gravity Generally low specific gravity of urine is caused by</p>
<p>(i) Excessive fluid intake
(ii) Chronic nephritis
(iii) Diabetes insipidus
(iv) All causes of polyuria except diabetes mellitus.</p>
<ol start="7">
<li>pH Regulation of acidity in extracellular fluid is one of the important functions of the kidney. By checking the pH of the urine, this aspect of the</li>
</ol>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Renal Function Tests and Urine Analysis 127</p>
<p>moglobin and other related products of red cells. If urine is contaminated with semen, vaginal secretion, pus or mucus, protein may be found. It is therefore essential to collect a mid-stream specimen of urine or a catheterised specimen if necessary. Urine may also contain an abnormal protein like Bence-Jones protein.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="qualitative-test-for-urinary-protein">Qualitative Test for Urinary Protein<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#qualitative-test-for-urinary-protein" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="1-boiling-and-acetic-acid-test">1. Boiling and acetic acid test<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-boiling-and-acetic-acid-test" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p><strong>Principle</strong> Proteins are coagulated by heat in acidic urine and do not dissolve on acidification. Whereas, phosphates and carbonates which are also precipitated by heat, dissolve in acid.</p>
<p><strong>Method</strong> If urine is not clear, filter or centrifuge; and if alkaline, make slightly acid with 2-3 drops of 5% acetic acid. Fill a test tube about 2/3 full with clear urine. Hold the test tube at an angle away from you, and heat the upper portion of the urine until it just starts boiling.</p>
<p>Turbidity or cloudiness will arise in the presence of protein, phosphates and carbonates. Add a few drops of 5% acetic acid and boil again. Persistence or development of turbidity indicates proteinuria. Turbidity will disappear if it is due to the phosphates or carbonates.</p>
<p>&gt; <strong>Note</strong> Occasionally the precipitate may develop only after the addition of acetic acid and reboiling; therefore this must be done even if no precipitate appears after the first boiling.</p>
<p>Avoid the addition of excess acid as it keeps the protein in solution, thus preventing its coagulation. If the precipitate disappears on further heating and reappears on cooling, it is likely to be due to Bence-Jones protein.</p>
<p><strong>Reading of results</strong> As this method gives only qualitative estimates of the protein present, results are reported as follows:</p>
<ul>
<li>No cloudiness
+/- Trace, cloudiness barely visible</li>
</ul>
<ul>
<li>Definite cloudiness with no flocculation and no granularity.
++ Granular cloudiness but no flocculation
+++ Dense, opaque cloudiness, clear flocculation
++++ Very thick precipitation, almost a solid.</li>
</ul>
<p>&gt; <strong>Note</strong> Compare the turbidity with clear, unheated urine in another test tube.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="2-sulphosalicylic-acid-test">2. Sulphosalicylic acid test<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-sulphosalicylic-acid-test" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p><strong>Principle</strong> Sulphosalicylic acid, being an anionic precipitant, neutralises the protein cation, thus resulting in the precipitation of proteins.</p>
<p><strong>Method</strong> To 1 ml of clear urine, add 3 drops of 25% sulphosalicylic acid. A precipitate is formed if protein is present.</p>
<p>False positive results may be obtained after the use of certain radio-opaque substances for pyelograms; or if urine contains a high concentration of penicillin.</p>
<p><strong>Reading of results</strong> Results are recorded in the same way as for the heat test (Method 1).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="3-test-strip-for-protein">3. Test strip for protein<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-test-strip-for-protein" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="i-albustix">(i) Albustix<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-albustix" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<p><strong>Principle</strong> Tetrabromophenol blue is yellow at pH 3.0, but changes to bluish-green in the presence of protein at the same pH.</p>
<p><strong>Method</strong> Dip the test end of the strip into freshly voided urine for about 1 second, drain off excess urine along the edge of the container. Compare the colour of the strip with the colour chart within 60 seconds.</p>
<p>Presence of protein is indicated by a change of colour from yellow to bluish green. The test is also available in tablet form. It does not give false positive results.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="ii-albym-method">(ii) Albym method<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-albym-method" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<p><strong>Principle</strong> The indicator used is tetrabromophenol-phthalein ethyl ester. It produces green colour even in the presence of low concentrations of protein.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>128 Clinical Chemistry</p>
<p>Method Same as method (i)</p>
<p><strong>Role</strong> False positive reaction may occur if the urine is contaminated with disinfectants such as cetrimide or quaternary ammonium compounds.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="quantitative-test-for-proteins-in-urine">Quantitative Test for Proteins in Urine<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#quantitative-test-for-proteins-in-urine" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Urinary protein can be estimated quantitatively. The most common method makes use of 3% trichloroacetic acid whereby the turbidity is measured colorimetrically. Collect a 24-hour specimen of urine. The method of estimation is similar to that given for cerebrospinal fluid (Chapter 10). Multiply the quantity of protein per 100 ml by the total volume of urine excreted in 24 hours.</p>
<p>Bence-Jones protein Bence-Jones protein is an abnormal, low molecular weight protein, which is found in the urine of patients suffering from the malignant disease known as multiple myeloma.</p>
<p>A distinguishing property of Bence-Jones protein is that, at a temperature of between 40° and 60°C, the protein is precipitated. Other proteins precipitate between 60° and 70°C. At boiling point, Bence-Jones protein will redissolve, while other proteins will not. Again, on cooling to 60°C, the Bence-Jones proteins reappear. This protein is not well detected by reagent strips, but gives a positive reaction with sulphosalicylic acid.</p>
<p>Method 1 Place about 5 ml of clear urine into each of three tubes. Add one drop of 5% acetic acid to one tube and two drops to the second tube. Place the tubes in a beaker of water with a thermometer inserted into one of the test tubes. Heat the beaker with a gentle flame. If Bence-Jones protein is present, a precipitate will appear between 40° and 60°C. At 100°C the precipitate will redissolve and disappear.</p>
<p>Frequently, other proteins are present and will give positive result if present in considerable amounts. To confirm that the precipitate is due to Bence-Jones protein, filter the heated urine while still hot, and retest the filtrate. Alternatively, dilute the urine with distilled water and retest. While other proteins will disappear, true Bence-Jones protein remains positive.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="method-2">Method 2<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#method-2" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Bradshaw's test Into a test tube place about 5 ml of concentrated hydrochloric acid. Carefully layer a few ml of urine over the acid so as to preserve a sharp junction between the two liquids.</p>
<p>If Bence-Jones protein is present, a white, thick precipitate will appear at the interface. The test may be positive for other proteins. But if the urine is diluted with distilled water, a true Bence-Jones protein often remains positive.</p>
<p>Method 3: Electrophoresis This is a complex but the most sensitive method for the identification of protein in urine. It should be done before excluding Bence-Jones protein.</p>
<p>The urine sample needs to be concentrated due to the fact that there is usually a small amount of protein in urine. There are two methods for concentrating urine: Lyphogel method and Minicon method.</p>
<p>(i) Lyphogel method Lyphogel is a polyacrylamide hydrogel which absorbs water and low molecular weight substances from biological fluids. Add 1.48 g lyphogel to 10 ml of urine in a test tube. Cover the test tube and leave for at least 5 hours. Remove the gel pellet from the solution using forceps.</p>
<p>(ii) Minicon method This method uses a chamber lined with an ultrafiltration membrane. The membrane allows passage of solids up to a molecular weight of about 15000.</p>
<p>Place 5 ml of clear urine through the hole in the top of the chamber using a pasteur pipette. Within 4 to 5 hours, the urine will be concentrated to about 200 times.</p>
<p>After concentrating the urine sample electrophoresis is performed using agarose. If Bence-Jones protein is present, it will appear between beta and gamma globulin positions. (See Chapter 5 for protein electrophoresis.)</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Renal Function Tests and Urine Analysis 129</p>
