<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="interpretation-of-proteinuria">Interpretation of proteinuria<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#interpretation-of-proteinuria" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Minimal proteinuria</strong> (&lt; 500 mg/24 hours)</p>
<ul>
<li>Urinary tract infections</li>
<li>Renal tubular dysfunction</li>
<li>Hypertension</li>
<li>Haemoglobinuria</li>
</ul>
<p>Fever or severe emotional stress in otherwise healthy individuals.</p>
<p>After exercise or in highly concentrated urine samples.</p>
<p><strong>Moderate proteinuria</strong> (500 mg to 3.0 g/24 hours)</p>
<ul>
<li>Chronic glomerulonephritis</li>
<li>Multiple myeloma</li>
<li>Pyelonephritis</li>
<li>Pre-eclampsia</li>
<li>Congestive cardiac failure</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Marked proteinuria</strong> (&gt; 3.0 g/24 hours)</p>
<ul>
<li>Acute glomerulonephritis</li>
<li>Chronic glomerulonephritis (severe)</li>
<li>Nephrotic syndrome</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="reducing-substances">REDUCING SUBSTANCES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#reducing-substances" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>By definition, reducing substances are capable of reducing a heavy metal, such as copper, from a higher to a lower oxidation state. For example, they reduce blue cupric sulphate to red cuprous oxide. Reducing substances found in urine include glucose, lactose, fructose, galactose, pentoses (xylose, ribose, arabinose), sucrose, ascorbic acid, homogentisic acid, etc.</p>
<p><strong>Glucose</strong> In normal urine, glucose may be present only in trace amounts. In the kidneys, glucose is filtered by the glomeruli and reabsorbed by the tubules. However, when the blood glucose concentration rises above 10.0 mmol/L (renal threshold), the tubules cannot reabsorb all the glucose. The surplus glucose appears in urine and this is glycosuria. In pathological conditions, glucose is about the only carbohydrate found in urine. Diabetes mellitus is the most important of these conditions when as much as 280 mmol/L of glucose can be found in urine. Glycosuria can also occur in severe liver disease and in endocrine hyperactivity.</p>
<p><strong>Lactose</strong> Towards the end of pregnancy and during lactation lactose is sometimes found in urine (lactosuria). It is of no pathological significance.</p>
<p><strong>Fructose</strong> Following a meal rich in fruits, honey, and jams, fructose may be present in the urine (fructosuria). If it is present in conjunction with glucose, it is indicative of diabetes. It is important to identify fructosuria so as not to wrongly classify it as glycosuria.</p>
<p><strong>Pentoses</strong> Pentosuria occurs under similar conditions as fructosuria.</p>
<p><strong>Galactose</strong> Galactose in urine (galactosuria) may be harmless following heavy consumption of galactose or lactose. But galactosuria in infants can be due to a deficiency of an enzyme necessary for the conversion of lactose to glucose. This is a pathological condition that may result in mental retardation.</p>
<p><strong>Sucrose</strong> Sucrose appears in the urine (sucrosuria) of patients suffering from pancreatitis. It is also found in the urine of some infants suffering from gastroenteritis. Although it is a reducing substance, it gives a negative result with Benedict’s solution.</p>
<p>There are some tests which specifically detect glucose and others are designed to detect reducing substances. The reducing substances are also commonly known as “sugars”.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="e2a58560">Benedict’s Test (Qualitative)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#e2a58560" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Principle</strong> The test is based on the reduction of alkaline blue cupric sulphate to yellow or red cuprous oxide by the aldehyde or ketone group of carbohydrates. In the absence of reducing substances in urine, the colour of the reagent remains blue-green.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="777b85f1">Benedict’s qualitative reagent<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#777b85f1" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Solution A</strong> 173 g sodium citrate and 100 g anhydrous sodium carbonate are dissolved with the aid of heat in about 600 ml of distilled water.</p>
<p><strong>Solution B</strong> 17.3 g copper sulphate is dissolved in 100 ml distilled water.</p>
<p>Add solution B, slowly with constant stirring, to solution A. After cooling, transfer to a one litre volumetric flask and make up the volume to the mark with distilled water.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>130 Clinical Chemistry</p>
<p>Method Place about 0.5 ml of urine in a large test tube. Add 5 ml of Benedict’s reagent to the urine. Mix well and place in a boiling water bath for 5 minutes. Allow to cool and observe for colour change due to precipitation of cuprous oxide.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="reporting-of-results">Reporting of results<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#reporting-of-results" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<table><thead><tr><th>Green colour</th><th>Negative</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Yellow-green precipitate</td><td>+ (&lt; 0.5 g/dl)</td></tr><tr><td>Greenish-yellow precipitate</td><td>++ (0.5 to 1 g/dl)</td></tr><tr><td>Yellow precipitate</td><td>+++ (1 to 2 g/dl)</td></tr><tr><td>Orange to brick-red precipitate</td><td>++++ (&gt; 2 g/dl)</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><strong>Note</strong>: White precipitate due to phosphates or development of any other colour should be ignored.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ec290576">Benedict’s Quantitative Glucose Test<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ec290576" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Principle</strong>: Glucose reduces cupric ions to cuprous ions. These react with potassium thiocyanate to produce a white precipitate of cuprous thiocyanate. The blue colour disappears as the white precipitate is formed. This indicates complete reduction of cupric ions which is the end point.</p>
<p><strong>Benedict’s quantitative reagent</strong>: Dissolve 200 g of sodium citrate, 75 g of anhydrous sodium carbonate and 125 g of potassium thiocyanate in 600 ml of distilled water. Heat to dissolve completely, cool to room temperature and filter with ordinary filter paper.</p>
<p>To the mixture, add 18 g of copper sulphate dissolved in about 100 ml of distilled water, slowly with constant stirring. Add 5 ml of 5% potassium ferrocyanide. Mix well and make final volume to 1 litre with distilled water. The reagent is stable at room temperature.</p>
<p><strong>Method</strong>: To 25 ml of Benedict’s quantitative solution in a 250 ml beaker, add about 10 g of anhydrous sodium carbonate.</p>
<p>Bring the mixture to the boil, and slowly run in the urine sample from a pipette, while the mixture is still boiling. When the blue colour of the reagent begins to fade, add the urine drop by drop until all the blue colour has disappeared. (All the cupric ions in the reagent are now reduced.)</p>
<p><strong>Note</strong>: The volume of urine used</p>
<p><strong>Calculation</strong>: 25 ml of Benedict’s quantitative reagent are reduced by 0.05 g of glucose.</p>
<p>Therefore, g of sugar per 100 ml of urine =</p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>0.05</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>100</mn></mrow><mtext>volume&nbsp;of&nbsp;urine&nbsp;used</mtext></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>5</mn><mtext>volume&nbsp;of&nbsp;urine&nbsp;used</mtext></mfrac></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\frac{0.05 \times 100}{\text{volume of urine used}} = \frac{5}{\text{volume of urine used}}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.0074em; vertical-align: -0.686em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3214em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">volume&nbsp;of&nbsp;urine&nbsp;used</span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0.05</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mord">100</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.686em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.0074em; vertical-align: -0.686em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3214em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">volume&nbsp;of&nbsp;urine&nbsp;used</span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">5</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.686em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p><strong>Note</strong>: The test can also be performed by using 5.0 ml of Benedict’s quantitative reagent and 2.0 g of anhydrous sodium carbonate. g of sugar per 100 ml of urine =</p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mtext>volume&nbsp;of&nbsp;urine&nbsp;used</mtext></mfrac></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\frac{1}{\text{volume of urine used}}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.0074em; vertical-align: -0.686em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3214em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">volume&nbsp;of&nbsp;urine&nbsp;used</span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">1</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.686em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="commercial-strips-for-glucose">Commercial Strips for Glucose<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#commercial-strips-for-glucose" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>There are various brands of commercial test strips available. The most popular ones include: (a) Clinistix (Ames), (b) BM test (BCL), (c) Gluco-strips (Hi Tech) and (d) Diabur (Boehringer). They are all based on similar principles.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="clinistix">Clinistix<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#clinistix" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p><strong>Principle</strong>: The test is based on the principle that glucose is oxidised by atmospheric oxygen in the presence of glucose oxidase to gluconic acid and hydrogen peroxide. The hydrogen peroxide, in the presence of peroxidase, oxidises the chromogen to various shades of purple.</p>
<p><strong>Method</strong>: Dip the reagent end of the strip into fresh urine and remove immediately. Compare the test colour with the colour chart within 10 seconds. Read carefully in good light. The test is no longer valid after 10 seconds.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="interpretation-of-the-results">Interpretation of the results<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#interpretation-of-the-results" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Purple within 10 seconds = Presence of glucose.</li>
<li>Cream after 10 seconds = Absence of glucose.</li>
</ul>
<p>The sensitivity of the test is as high as 0.01 g/100ml.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Renal Function Tests and Urine Analysis 131</p>
<p>Some test strips such as Diabur test 500, measure glucose semiquantitatively.</p>
<p><strong>Note</strong>
False negative or false positive test results do occur with reagent strips. For example,
(i) Oxidation of certain substances such as ascorbic acid or some drug products, in preference to the chromogen may give false negative result.
(ii) A false negative result may also be obtained due to a high concentration of catalase, as in E.coli infection, when hydrogen peroxide is destroyed.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="82e53a0d">Test for Fructose—Sellwanoff’s Test<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#82e53a0d" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Principle</strong> When fructose is boiled in the presence of hydrochloric acid, a derivative of furfuraldehyde is given off. This condenses with resorcinol to form a red coloured complex.</p>
<p><strong>Reagent</strong>
Resorcinol 0.05 g
Conc. HCl 33 ml</p>
<p>Make up to 100 ml with distilled water. This reagent is stable for about 6 to 8 weeks.</p>
<p><strong>Method</strong> Add 0.5 ml urine to 5 ml of the reagent in a test tube. Mix well and boil.</p>
<p><strong>Result</strong> Within 30 seconds fructose gives a red colour. The time factor is important as glucose also gives red colour, but never within 30 seconds.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="4a9edf3f">Test for Pentose—Bial’s test<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#4a9edf3f" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Principle</strong> When a pentose is boiled in the presence of hydrochloric acid, furfuraldehydes are given off, which in the presence of orcinol condense to form a green coloured compound.</p>
<p><strong>Reagent</strong>
Orcinol (m-dihydroxytoluene) 300 mg
Conc. HCl 100 ml</p>
<p>Dissolve and add 5 drops of 10% ferric chloride. The reagent is stable for 10 days.</p>
<p><strong>Method</strong> Add 0.5 ml of urine to 5 ml of the reagent in a test tube. Mix well and place in boiling water for the solution to boil.</p>
<p><strong>Result</strong> Pentoses give a green colour. If fructose is present, it gives a red colour. The boiling should not be prolonged, otherwise glucuronates will give similar greenish colour.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ac4ddcf2">Test for Lactose: Fearon’s Methylamine Test<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ac4ddcf2" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Principle</strong> The disaccharides lactose and maltose, when hydrolysed under alkaline conditions, form enediol due to rearrangement of either the ketone or the aldehyde group. This enediol reacts with methylamine hydrochloride to form a red complex. Since maltose is very rarely found in urine, this test can be considered to be specific for urinary lactose.</p>
<p><strong>Reagents</strong> 0.2 % Methylamine hydrochloride; 10 % Sodium hydroxide.</p>
<p><strong>Method</strong> Add 1 ml methylamine hydrochloride solution and 0.2 ml sodium hydroxide solution to 5 ml urine. Mix well and place the tube in a water bath at 56°C for 30 minutes. Remove the tube from the water bath and allow it to stand at room temperature to cool. Prepare a blank consisting of the reagents with unheated urine and compare the colour of the test with the blank.</p>
<p><strong>Result</strong> Development of a red colour within 30 minutes indicates presence of lactose. Other sugars such as glucose, fructose, galactose, xylose and sucrose, when present in large amounts, give a yellow colour.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="chromatography-of-urine-sugars">Chromatography of Urine Sugars<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chromatography-of-urine-sugars" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Chromatography is considered a superior method for identification of urine sugars. Thin layer chromatography is quick and sensitive; and therefore it is the method of choice.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>132 Clinical Chemistry</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="thin-layer-chromatography">Thin layer chromatography<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#thin-layer-chromatography" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="reagents-solvent-mixture">Reagents Solvent mixture<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#reagents-solvent-mixture" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>n-butanol 75 ml
Acetic acid 25 ml
Distilled water 6 ml</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="aniline-diphenylamine-locating-reagent">Aniline-diphenylamine locating reagent<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#aniline-diphenylamine-locating-reagent" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="solution-i">Solution I:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#solution-i" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Aniline 1 ml
Diphenylamine 1 g
Acetone 99 ml</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="solution-ii">Solution II:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#solution-ii" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>85 % phosphoric acid</p>
<p>For use, 10 volumes of solution I are mixed with 1 volume of solution II.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="standards">Standards<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#standards" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Prepare standard solutions of glucose, lactose, fructose, galactose and xylose in 10% aqueous isopropanol. The concentration should be such that 5 microlitres contain 5 micrograms of the sugar. (1mg/ml)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="silica-gel">Silica gel<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#silica-gel" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Use 20 × 10 cm plates with 250 µm thickness.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="method">Method<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#method" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The optimum amount of urine sample used will vary with the concentration of the sugars present. The reagent strips can be used to roughly estimate the amount of sugars in the urine. Determine the volume of the sample required in such a way that 5 µl will contain 5–10 µg of sugar. Apply the sample and the standards 1 cm apart along the line of application. Place the plate in the chromatography tank. Let the solvent rise to 12 to 15 cm for about 2 to 3 hours. Remove the plate from the tank. Dry it under hot air in a fume cupboard. Spray with the locating agent and heat for 5 minutes in hot air oven at 120°C. Figure 4.3 shows position of various sugars, and Table 4.3 shows their Rf values.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-ec9c0340.jpeg" alt="img-20.jpeg">
Fig. 4.3 Chromatography of urine sugars</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ketone-bodies-ketones">KETONE BODIES (KETONES)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ketone-bodies-ketones" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Ketone bodies belong to a group of three related substances—acetone, acetoacetic acid (acetoacetate) and β-hydroxybutyric acid (hydroxybutyrate). Their structural similarity is shown in Fig. 4.4. They are not found in normal urine or blood. The presence of ketones in the urine is called ketonuria and in the blood it is called ketonemia. An increased level of ketones in blood and urine is referred to as ketosis.</p>
<p>Table 4.3 Approximate Rf values of urinary sugars</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Sugar</th><th>Characteristic colour</th><th>Approx. Rf</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Lactose</td><td>Grey</td><td>0.14</td></tr><tr><td>Galactose</td><td>Grey</td><td>0.34</td></tr><tr><td>Fructose</td><td>Pink</td><td>0.39</td></tr><tr><td>Glucose</td><td>Grey</td><td>0.42</td></tr><tr><td>Pentoses</td><td>Greybrown</td><td>&gt; 0.5</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>B</p>
<p>Renal Function Tests and Urine Analysis 133</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-32772874.jpeg" alt="img-21.jpeg">
Fig. 4.4 Structural similarity in ketone bodies</p>
<p>Ketones are products of fat metabolism when fat is broken down to serve as a source of energy as in the cases of untreated or uncontrolled diabetes (lack of insulin), starvation or dehydration (vomiting and diarrhoea). When there is absence of or insufficient glucose metabolism, the result is an accumulation of ketones in blood. Ketosis may also result in an individual who is on a ketogenic diet, that is, diet high in fat and low in carbohydrate.</p>
<p>Ketosis is a serious physiological condition. Acetoacetic acid and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>β</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\beta</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05278em;">β</span></span></span></span></span>-hydroxybutyric acid cause lowering of the blood pH by transferring excess hydrogen ion to the blood. This results in acidosis such as seen in coma found in diabetic ketoacidosis. Acetone and acetoacetic acid, more specially acetone, are toxic to the brain when present in sufficiently high concentration in the blood. In the presence of high level of ketone in the blood, the body,</p>
<p>in order to maintain the buffering system, excretes excess acid through urine. The urine pH can be as low as 4.5. The presence of ketone bodies in the urine is therefore associated with low urinary pH.</p>
<p>In the normal formation of the ketones, acetoacetic acid is produced first and then converted to <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>β</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\beta</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05278em;">β</span></span></span></span></span>-hydroxybytyric acid and acetone. If urine containing the three ketone bodies is allowed to stand at room temperature after collection, the acetoacetic acid and the <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>β</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\beta</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05278em;">β</span></span></span></span></span>-hydroxybutyric acid are converted to acetone. The acetone being volatile, may disappear from the urine specimen. For this reason, freshly voided urine is used to detect ketone bodies.</p>
<p>Most of the laboratory tests for ketones detect acetone and acetoacetic acid or only acetoacetic acid. There is no simple laboratory test for <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>β</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\beta</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05278em;">β</span></span></span></span></span>-hydroxybutyric acid. The commonly used methods for ketonuria are based on the principle of Rothera's nitroprusside test. These methods are available in the form of dry reagent strips, tablet tests (Acetest) and tube method.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="reagent-strip-tests-for-ketones">Reagent Strip Tests for Ketones<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#reagent-strip-tests-for-ketones" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Specimen requirements for the tests The test for ketonuria must be performed on freshly voided urine. Keep urine refrigerated if delay is envisaged. This will eliminate false negative result.</p>
<p>Principle Acetoacetate will react with sodium nitroprusside (sodium pentacyanonitrosyl ferrate or nitroferricyanide) in alkaline medium to produce a purple colour. The strips are formulated to detect acetoacetic acid and not acetone. However, it can be made to detect acetone if glycine is incorporated into it.</p>
<p>The test strips are plastic strips, one end of which is impregnated with buffered sodium nitroprusside. The concentration of the ketone is graded, based on the intensity and rate of production of colour. The result are read from a colour chart.</p>
<p>Several test strips are commercially available. The commonest ones include:</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>134 Clinical Chemistry</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ketostix-ames">Ketostix (Ames)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ketostix-ames" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This test strip will detect 0.5–1.0 mmol/L (5–10 mg/dl) of acetoacetic acid.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="procedure">Procedure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#procedure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Dip test end of the reagent strip in fresh urine and remove immediately.</li>
<li>Touch tip of strip on the container to remove excess fluid.</li>
<li>Compare colour of test with a colour chart 15 seconds later.</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>Scale</strong> The colour chart represents negative, trace (5 mg/dl), small (15 mg/dl), moderate (40 mg/dl) and large (80–160 mg/dl).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ketone-test-boehringer">Ketone Test (Boehringer)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ketone-test-boehringer" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is similar to the ketostix and has similar sensitivity. The results are also read in the same way as the ketostix.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="chemstrip">Chemstrip<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chemstrip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The chemstrip test contains glycine and so detects acetone as well as acetoacetic acid. The test is performed in the same way as the ketostix. The results are read and graded from the colour chart. It detects up to 9 mg/dl acetoacetic acid and 70 mg/dl acetone.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="acetest-tablet-test-ames">Acetest Tablet Test (Ames)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#acetest-tablet-test-ames" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Acetest tablet contains sodium nitroprusside, glycine and lactose in alkaline buffer. The principle is virtually the same as the strip tests. Acetest can however be used to test whole blood, plasma or serum. The test kit is supplied with the manufacturer’s instructions which should be followed. The addition of lactose enhances the colour.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="procedure">Procedure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#procedure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Place the tablet on a clean surface preferably a piece of white paper.</li>
<li>Place one drop of urine, serum, plasma or whole blood on the tablet.</li>
<li>Compare the colour of the tablet with the colour chart 30 seconds after the application of urine or 2 minutes after the application of plasma, or serum or 10 minutes after the application of whole blood.</li>
</ol>
<p>In the presence of acetoacetic acid and acetone the tablet will show varying shades of colour purple. Report as negative, small, moderate or large depending on the manufacturer’s direction.</p>
<p>Acetest detects 5 to 10 mg/dl of acetoacetic acid and 20–25 mg/dl of acetone.</p>
<p>&gt; <strong>Note</strong>
&gt; 1. Urine specimens containing large amounts of phethaleins, phenylketones or the preservative &amp; hydroxyquinoline may give colour ranging from orange-red to mauve which may be mistaken for the ketones. This is a false positive reaction.
&gt; 2. Urine specimens containing various pigments, drugs or substances causing abnormally brightly coloured urine may pose a problem in reading the ketone tests.
&gt; 3. False negative or reduced reactions may be seen in improperly preserved urine due to the conversion of acetoacetic acid to acetone.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="632f36bb">Nitroprusside Tube Test (Modified Rothera’s Test)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#632f36bb" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This test is sensitive for ketones in urine. This is the original nitroprusside method for ketone bodies. The same principle is applied in this test as in the above tests: Nitroprusside in alkaline solution reacts with a ketone body to form purple colour.</p>
<p><strong>Reagent</strong> Mix and grind together 100 g ammonium sulphate, 3 g sodium nitroprusside and 50 g sodium carbonate (anhydrous).</p>
<p>&gt; <strong>Note</strong> Sodium nitroprusside is toxic and should be handled with care.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="procedure">Procedure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#procedure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Add about 0.5–1.0 g sodium nitroprusside mixture to the bottom of a small test tube.</li>
<li>Add 1 drop of fresh urine (enough to moisten the dry reagent).</li>
<li>Observe the colour change within 1–2 minutes.</li>
</ol>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Renal Function Tests and Urine Analysis 135</p>
<p>Note
This procedure can be done on a porcelain tile.</p>
<p>Gerhardt's Test for Acetoacetic Acid and Salicylates</p>
<p>Gerhardt's test is specific for the detection of large amounts of acetoacetic acid. It also detects salicylates in urine.</p>
<p>Principle Ferric chloride reacts with acetoacetic acid and salicylates to form the characteristic colours.</p>
<p>Reagents 10% ferric chloride
Procedure</p>
<ol>
<li>Add 5ml ferric chloride drop by drop to 5 ml of urine in a test tube.</li>
<li>A red-brown colour is formed by acetoacetic acid or salicylates.</li>
<li>In the presence of large amount of phosphates, ferric phosphates precipitates are produced.</li>
<li>To confirm the presence of salicylates or acetoacetic acid, divide the test solution in half and boil one part for 5 minutes. If the colour disappears, then acetoacetic acid is present. If the colour persists, salicylates are present. The acetoacetic acid on boiling loses carbon dioxide and is converted to acetone. Acetone does not react with ferric chloride.</li>
</ol>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mo>⋅</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mover><mo stretchy="true" minsize="3.0em">→</mo><mpadded width="+0.6em" lspace="0.3em"><mtext>Heat</mtext></mpadded></mover><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mo>⋅</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mo>⋅</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>↑</mo></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{CH_3CO \cdot CH_2COOH} \xrightarrow{\text{Heat}} \mathrm{CH_3 \cdot CO \cdot CH_3} + \mathrm{CO_2 \uparrow}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.2503em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathrm mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">COOH</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel x-arrow"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.1003em;"><span style="top: -3.322em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight x-arrow-pad"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord mtight">Heat</span></span></span></span></span><span class="svg-align" style="top: -2.689em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="hide-tail" style="height: 0.522em; -16.7 32-27.7 63.7-33 95 0 1.3-.2 2.7-.5 4-.3 1.3-.5 2.3-.5 3 0 7.3 6.7 11 20
