vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">C</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">H</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathrm mtight">3</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">⋅</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mord mathrm">CO</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">⋅</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mord mathrm">C</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">H</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathrm mtight">3</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">+</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">C</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">O</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathrm mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p>Test for β-hydroxybutyric acid</p>
<p>There is no direct routine test for this ketone body. Its presence in urine can be detected indirectly by first getting rid of the acetone and acetoacetic acid. Determine the urine pH; if acid, then boil to remove the acetone and acetoacetic acid.</p>
<p>Treat the urine with hydrogen peroxide to oxidise β-hydroxybutyric acid to acetoacetic acid.</p>
<p>Perform the nitroprusside test. A positive reaction is indicative of the presence of β-hydroxybutyric acid.</p>
<p>Causes of Ketonuria</p>
<ol>
<li>Diabetes indicates ketoacidosis which may lead to coma if unchecked.</li>
<li>Acute febrile states especially in infants.</li>
<li>Excessive vomiting and diarrhoea.</li>
<li>Glycogen storage impairment.</li>
</ol>
<p>BILIRUBIN AND UROBILINOGEN</p>
<p>Urinalysis provides useful information on the state of not only the kidney, but also of other urinary tract organs and liver. Tests for urine bilirubin and urobilinogen are good indicators of liver function.</p>
<p>Bilirubin is a normal breakdown product of red blood cells. It is a vivid yellow pigment. It is excreted by the liver through the intestine. The bilirubin reaches the liver as water insoluble bilirubin-albumin complex (free bilirubin or unconjugated bilirubin). In the liver, it is converted to a water soluble product by the Kupffer cells by conjugation with glucuronic acid. This water soluble bilirubin (conjugated bilirubin) is excreted by the liver into the bile and from there to the gall bladder where it is concentrated and emptied into the small intestine.</p>
<p>In the intestine, most of the bilirubin is reduced to urobilinogen. Most of urobilinogen enters the blood circulation, returns to the liver and begins the cycle again. However, a small amount of urobilinogen does not return to the liver but instead is excreted via urine. Urobilinogen is excreted through the intestine unchanged or oxidised to form the brown coloured complex, urobilin. In effect about 99% of urobilinogen formed from bilirubin is excreted along with faeces (as stercobilin) while only 1% by the urine. This means that normal urine contains no bilirubin but only a small amount of urobilinogen.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>136 Clinical Chemistry</p>
<p>While the free or unconjugated bilirubin is not excreted by the kidney (because it cannot pass through the glomerular capsule), conjugated bilirubin can pass through the renal glomerulus. Abnormal concentration of bilirubin in blood will be excreted by the kidney.</p>
<p>Excretion of urobilinogen is of value in assessing or monitoring jaundice. Urobilinogen is colourless but the oxidised form, urobilin is orange-yellow in appearance. Urine containing bilirubin is yellow-brown in colour and produces yellow foam when shaken.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="detection-of-bilirubin-in-urine">Detection of Bilirubin in Urine<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#detection-of-bilirubin-in-urine" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The presence of bilirubin in urine is known as bilirubinuria.</p>
<p>There are several methods available for the detection of bilirubin in urine. One of the oldest methods is the foam test. It is a method of simply shaking the urine and looking for the presence of a yellow foam.</p>
<p>There are the reagent strip tests, most of which are based on a diazo reaction. Bilirubin is coupled with a diazonium salt in an acid medium to form azobilirubin. A positive reaction is indicated by the formation of coloured complexes. The tests use different diazonium salts and so different coloured compounds are formed. The tests are specific for bilirubin but the presence of other highly coloured substances in the urine may result in false positive tests.</p>
<p>The reagent strips are firm plastic strips with the reagent impregnated into a test area at the tip of the strip. The tests are rapid and convenient to use. The test strip may be a single test trip for bilirubin or may be part of a multi-test strip. The produced colour is compared with a colour chart.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="procedure-for-reagent-strip-test">Procedure for reagent strip test<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#procedure-for-reagent-strip-test" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Dip the test area of the strip in fresh well-mixed uncentrifugated urine.</li>
<li>Remove the strip from urine. Remove excess fluid by tapping the strip edge against the urine container.</li>
<li>Allow to stand for the reaction to occur for the length of time specified by the manufacturers.</li>
<li>Immediately, compare colour of test with colour chart. Hold the strip close to the colour chart.</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>Result</strong> The tests are usually read as trace, small (+), moderate (++) or large (+++) which can be quantified according to the manufacturer's direction. Some of the common reagent strips are described below.</p>
<p><strong>Multistix (Ames)</strong> This multitest strip for bilirubin uses 2,4 dichloroanilinediazonium salt buffered to acid pH. The colour produced is brownish to purple. Results are read as small (+), moderate (++) or large (+++) by comparison with the colour chart. The test will detect 0.4 to 0.8 mg/dl bilirubin.</p>
<p><strong>Chemstrip</strong> This reagent strip uses 2,6 dichlorobenzene diazonium-tetra fluoroborate. The result is seen as change of colour from white to pink or light red. It is reported as for the multistix. It will detect up to 0.5 mg/dl bilirubin.</p>
<p><strong>Ictotest tablet test (Ames)</strong> The ictotest tablet test is used to confirm positive reagent strip test since it is more sensitive than all of them. The test is a quick, simple and standardised colour test.</p>
<p><strong>Principle</strong> Bilirubin in urine reacts with a solid diazonium salt in the presence of salicylsulphonic acid to form a blue or purple colour. The tablet contains p-nitrobenzene diazonium p-toluene sulphonate, salicylsulphonic acid and sodium hydrogen carbonate.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="procedure">Procedure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#procedure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Place 5 drops of urine on a special test mat supplied with the kit.</li>
<li>Place a tablet in the middle of moist area on the mat.</li>
<li>Add 2 drops of water on the tablet.</li>
<li>Observe the colour of the mat within 30 seconds.</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>Results</strong> No colour change around the tablet on the mat, or there is slight red or pink within 30 sec.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Renal Function Tests and Urine Analysis 137</p>
<p>onds is a negative test. Colour change to bluish-purple around the tablet indicates a positive test. The concentration of bilirubin in the urine is proportional to the intensity of the colour and rate at which colour is developed.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="fouchet-s-test">Fouchet's test<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fouchet-s-test" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Principle</strong> Barium chloride reacts with sulphate radicals in the urine to form a precipitate of barium sulphate. Available bile pigments adhere to the precipitate and are detected by oxidation of bilirubin which is yellow, to biliverdin which is green, on treatment with ferric chloride in the presence of trichloroacetic acid.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="reagents">Reagents<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#reagents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>10% barium chloride (w/v)</li>
<li>Fouchet's reagent</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Trichloroacetic acid 25 g</li>
<li>Distilled water 50 ml</li>
<li>10% ferric chloride 10 ml</li>
<li>Diluted to 100 ml with distilled water.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="procedure">Procedure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#procedure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Determine the pH of the urine. If alkaline, acidify with 33% acetic acid.</li>
<li>Add 5 ml of 10% barium chloride to 10 ml of urine. Mix well. If the precipitate produced is insufficient, add a drop of dilute sulphuric acid or ammonium sulphate solution.</li>
<li>Filter through Whatman no. 1 filter paper.</li>
<li>Carefully unfold the filter paper and place it on the top of a dry filter paper. Add 1 drop of Fouchet's reagent on the precipitate in the centre of the wet filter paper. A green colour is produced if bile is present. The amount of bilirubin in the urine is proportional to the intensity of the green colour.</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>Note</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Salicylates will produce pink or mauve colour, so ignore such colour.</li>
<li>Bilicyanin will form a blue colour.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="urine-urobilinogen">Urine Urobilinogen<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#urine-urobilinogen" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The measurement of the amount of urobilinogen in urine is a good index for assessing jaundice and monitoring liver function impairment.</p>
<p>Small traces of urobilinogen are found in normal urine. This is a part of urobilinogen which is reabsorbed from the intestine. The amount of urobilinogen in urine depends on the ability of the liver to excrete urobilinogen from the intestine. This in turn will depend on the amount of bilirubin being produced and being transported to the intestine.</p>
<p>Urobilinogen which is colourless in freshly passed urine, is oxidised on standing to urobilin, an orange-pink pigment. This pigment and urochrome impart the normal colour of urine. Urine itself becomes orange-yellow when there is excess of urobilin pigment.</p>
<p>Two tests are commonly employed to detect urobilinogen</p>
<p>(1) Ehrlich's test
(2) Urobilinogen reagent strip tests.</p>
<p><strong>Ehrlich's test</strong> Urobilinogen reacts with p-dimethylamino-benzaldehyde to form a red colour. The intensity of the red colour is proportional to the concentration of urobilinogen in the urine.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="reagents">Reagents<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#reagents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Ehrlich's reagent</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>p-dimethylaminobenzaldehyde 2.0 g</li>
<li>Hydrochloric acid (conc.) 20 ml</li>
<li>Distilled water 80 ml</li>
</ul>
<ol start="2">
<li>20% v/v hydrochloric acid (HCl)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="procedure">Procedure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#procedure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Add 1 ml of Ehrlich's reagent to 10 ml of urine in a test tube labelled 'T' (test)</li>
<li>Add 1 ml 20% HCl to another 10 ml of urine in a test tube labelled C (control)</li>
<li>Mix each by inversion. Leave for 3-5 minutes at room temperature.</li>
<li>Note the colour produced, if there is no colour formed warm it to 50°C</li>
</ol>
<p>It is easier to detect the colour if viewed from the top.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="results">Results<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#results" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Normal urine + Ehrlich's reagent:</p>
<ul>
<li>pink or faint red colour</li>
</ul>
<p>Normal urine + 20% HCl:</p>
<ul>
<li>no pink colour</li>
</ul>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>138 Clinical Chemistry</p>
<p>no colour at room temperature
Urobilinogen absent in urine:
no colour in 20% HCl
Excess urobilinogen in urine:
distinct red colour at room temperature.</p>
<p><strong>Note</strong></p>
<ol>
<li><em>Porphobilinogen will give faint red or pink colour with Ehrlich’s reagent. It should be differentiated from urobilinogen.</em></li>
<li>A red colour with 20% HCl is probably due to a dye such as methyl red.</li>
<li>If bilirubin is present in the urine, remove it before doing the test for urobilinogen. Use either the filtrate from Fouchet’s test, or mix 1 ml of 10% barium chloride with 5 ml of urine, or equal volumes of urine and 0.48mol/L barium chloride; mix well and centrifuge or filter through Whatman no. 1 filter paper. Use the clear filtrate for Ehrlich’s test.</li>
<li>Perform a quantitative test by preparing serial dilutions of urine ranging from 1:10 to 1:100. Perform Ehrlich’s test on each dilution. Abnormal concentrations of urobilinogen may give positive result up to 1:100 dilution or more. Normal urine is not positive beyond 1:20 dilution.</li>
</ol>
<p>Urobilinogen strip tests There are several commercial reagent test strips available from different manufacturers.</p>
<p>The Ames strips tests are modifications of the Ehrlich’s test. In the tests, p-dimethylaminobenzaldehyde reacts with urobilinogen in acid medium to produce brown-orange colour. The tests are not specific for urobilinogen. The strip tests of Boehringer are specific for urobilinogen. In the tests, urobilinogen reacts with p-methoxybenzenediazonium tetrafluoroborate to form pink-red azo dye.</p>
<p>The strip tests detect normal and increased level of urobilinogen but not the absence of it. They give results semiquantitatively. The test procedure is the same for all. They may be single, dual or multi strip tests.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="procedure">Procedure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#procedure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Dip test area of strip in fresh well-mixed freshly voided urine.</li>
<li>Remove strip from urine, remove excess fluid by tapping edge of strip against urine container.</li>
<li>Leave for the specified length of time (manufacturer’s direction)</li>
<li>Compare the colour produced with the colour chart.</li>
</ol>
<p>The most common reagent strips are</p>
<p>Urobilistix (Ames) This is a single strip test with reagent impregnated into the absorbent that area of the plastic strip. It is not specific for urobilinogen but provides a rapid convenient test for urobilinogen. It has a scale corresponding to 1.6, 16, 33, 66, 131, 197 µmol/L. A normal result will give up to 16 µmol/L of urobilinogen. The reaction is read after 60 seconds.</p>
<p>Bilugen (Boehringer) This is a double test strip. It measures urobilinogen and also detects bilirubin. The reaction is read after 10 seconds. The scale is graded to correspond to 17, 70, 149 and 200 µmol/L. Normal urine will show no colour or a reading not exceeding 16 µmol/L. In the presence of high concentration of formaldehyde (over 200 mg/100 ml), the Boehringer strips may give false negative result.</p>
<p>Clinical significance High concentration of urobilinogen may be due to</p>
<ol>
<li>Haemolytic disease when the amount of bilirubin produced is raised resulting in the production of greater amount of urobilinogen.</li>
<li>Paralytic enterocolitis in which large amount of urobilinogen is produced in the intestine.</li>
<li>Cirrhosis of the liver.</li>
<li>Hepatic congestion leading to less urobilinogen being excreted by the liver. It passes into the general circulation resulting in larger quantity being excreted by the kidneys.</li>
</ol>
<p>Low concentration may be caused by</p>
<ol>
<li>Obstruction of bile ducts blocking the flow.</li>
</ol>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Renal Function Tests and Urine Analysis 139</p>
<p>of bilirubin to the intestine. Thus, there is no bilirubin to be converted to urobilinogen.</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>Destruction of normal bacterial flora of the intestine when urobilinogen cannot be produced.</li>
<li>Inability of liver cells to conjugate bilirubin into a soluble form, in which case it cannot be excreted in urine.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="porphobilinogen">PORPHOBILINOGEN<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#porphobilinogen" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Porphobilinogen is an intermediate by-product in the biosynthesis of haem. It is absent in normal urine but may be present in some errors of metabolism of porphyrin. The Watson-Schwartz test can detect both urobilinogen and porphobilinogen in urine; where as Hoesch test is specific for porphobilinogen.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="watson-schwartz-test-for-urobilinogen-and-porphobilinogen">Watson-Schwartz Test for Urobilinogen and Porphobilinogen<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#watson-schwartz-test-for-urobilinogen-and-porphobilinogen" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Principle</strong> The Watson-Schwartz test provides differentiation between urobilinogen, porphobilinogen and other intermediate Ehrlich's reagent reacting compounds. All the three compounds give the characteristic cherry-red colour with Ehrlich's reagent. The colour is enhanced in the presence of saturated sodium acetate. They can be differentiated from each other by their solubility in organic solvents such as chloroform and butanol. Urobilinogen is soluble in both the solvents, intermediate Ehrlich-reactive compounds are soluble only in butanol where as porphobilinogen is soluble in neither of the solvents.</p>
<p>&gt; <strong>Note</strong> The urine specimen must be examined while it is very fresh.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="reagents">Reagents<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#reagents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Ehrlich's reagent (modified)
p-dimethyl aminobenzaldehyde 0.7 g
Hydrochloric acid (conc.) 150 ml</li>
</ol>
<p>Distilled water 100 ml
2. Sodium acetate, saturated solution in distilled water
3. Chloroform
4. Butanol</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="procedure">Procedure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#procedure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Place approximately 3 ml of urine in a test tube</li>
<li>Add equal volume of Ehrlich's reagent, mix.</li>
<li>Add 6.0 ml of saturated sodium acetate and mix.</li>
<li>Development of cherry-red colour indicates the presence of either urobilinogen, porphobilinogen or intermediate Ehrlich-reactive compounds.</li>
<li>If the test is positive in Step 4, divide the coloured solution into two parts.</li>
<li>To one portion, add 2–3 ml of chloroform and shake vigorously. Check whether the lower chloroform layer shows a pink or red colour. If the colour is extracted in the chloroform layer, the urine specimen contains urobilinogen.</li>
<li>If the colour is not extracted in chloroform, add 2–3 ml of butanol to the second portion from Step 5. Shake again</li>
<li>Colour produced by urobilinogen and Ehrlich-reactive substances will be extracted in the upper butanol layer. The test is positive for porphobilinogen if the colour is not extracted in both the chloroform and butanol.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="hoesch-test-for-porphobilinogen">Hoesch Test for Porphobilinogen<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hoesch-test-for-porphobilinogen" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Principle</strong> This is a specific test for porphobilinogen. In a strongly acidic solution, Ehrlich's reagent can react only with porphobilinogen to give a red colour.</p>
<p><strong>Reagent</strong> Dilute conc. HCl 1:2 with distilled water (6 mol/L). Dissolve 2.0 g p-dimethylaminobenzaldehyde in 100 ml of 6 mol/L HCl.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>140 Clinical Chemistry</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="procedure">Procedure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#procedure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Place approximately 2.0 ml of Hoesch reagent in a test tube.</li>
<li>Add 2 drops of urine on top</li>
<li>Appearance of a cherry red colour on top of the solution indicates a positive test for porphobilinogen.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="clinical-significance">Clinical significance<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#clinical-significance" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Porphobilinogen appears in urine in some metabolic disorders such as acute intermittent porphyria.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="urobilin">UROBILIN<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#urobilin" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Urobilins are oxidation products of urobilinogen. Urobilins are orange-coloured and are responsible for the normal colour of the urine, whereas urobilinogen is colourless. Urobilin does not react with Ehrlich’s reagent, but reacts with Schlesinger’s zinc acetate reagent.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="baba2010">Schlesinger’s Test for Urobilin (Urobilinogen + Urobilin)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#baba2010" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="principle">Principle<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#principle" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Urobilinogen is oxidised to urobilin with tincture of iodine. When mixed with alcoholic zinc-acetate solution, zinc-urobilin is formed which shows a green fluorescence.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="reagent">Reagent<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#reagent" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Tincture of iodine Prepare a saturated solution of iodine in 70 % ethanol</li>
<li>Zinc-acetate reagent Prepare a saturated solution of zinc-acetate in absolute ethanol.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="procedure">Procedure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#procedure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>To about 10 ml of urine in a test tube add a few drops of tincture of iodine</li>
<li>In another test tube, place about 10 ml of zinc-acetate reagent.</li>
<li>Mix the two solution by pouring from one tube to another, backwards and forwards, several times (10–12 times)</li>
<li>Filter the mixed solution through Whatman No. 1 filter paper.</li>
<li>Examine the filtrate for green fluorescence by viewing from above against a dark background and passing through the direct rays of a fairly strong light. The fluorescence is more easily detectable under ultraviolet light.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="results">Results<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#results" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Normal urine gives a very mild fluorescence. The test is reported as positive, negative or increased.</p>
<p>&gt; <strong>Note</strong>
&gt; 1. Bilirubin, if present, must be removed from the urine as for the urobilinogen test.
&gt; 2. The test can be performed for the detection of urobilin only, if the first step of oxidization with iodine is omitted.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="leukocyte-esterase">LEUKOCYTE ESTERASE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#leukocyte-esterase" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The azurophilic or primary granules of granulocytes, mainly neutrophils, demonstrate esterase activity. Therefore, detection of esterase activity in urine provides an indirect evidence of the presence of leukocytes in urine which is indicative of urinary tract infection. The test is more useful when intact leukocytes are not visible microscopically after their disintegration due to phagocytic activity. The leukocyte esterase test is positive with both lysed and intact leukocytes.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="reagent-strip-tests-for-leukocyte-esterase">Reagent strip tests for leukocyte esterase<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#reagent-strip-tests-for-leukocyte-esterase" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="principle">Principle<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#principle" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<p>The test area contains an ester which is hydrolysed by leukocyte esterase to form an alcohol. The aromatic ring in the alcohol molecule reacts with a diazonium salt to form a purple azo dye. The bacteria and red cells in the urine do not affect the reaction.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="multistix-reagent-strips">Multistix reagent strips<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#multistix-reagent-strips" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<p>The ester used in this strip is a derivative of a pyrrole amino acid ester. A positive reaction is indicated by a purple colour of the azo dye. About 5–15 leucocytes/hpf should be present in the urine to give a positive test.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="chemstrip-reagent-strips">Chemstrip reagent strips<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chemstrip-reagent-strips" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<p>The ester used in this strip is indoxylcarbonic acid ester, which forms a purple compound in the presence of leukocyte</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Renal Function Tests and Urine Analysis 141</p>
<p>esterase and a diazonium salt. At least 10 leucocytes/μl should be present for a visible positive reaction.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="clinical-significance">Clinical Significance<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#clinical-significance" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Detectable amount of leukocyte esterase indicates increased number of leukocytes in urine. It is indicative of bacterial infection. In the absence of bacteria, other inflammatory conditions without bacterial infection, treatment with antibiotics, or infections with organisms such as chlamydia may be suspected.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="nitrite">NITRITE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#nitrite" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Detection of nitrite in urine, coupled with leukocyte esterase, is a rapid method for detecting asymptomatic urinary tract infection. Some bacteria such as <em>Escherichia coli</em>, can convert urinary nitrate into nitrite. Urine must be retained in the bladder for at least 4 hours for this conversion to occur. The first morning specimen is ideal for the test. The intensity of the colour produced is related to the amount of nitrates in urine; and not to the number of bacteria.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="reagent-strip-tests">Reagent Strip Tests<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#reagent-strip-tests" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Principle</strong> Nitrite reacts with an aromatic amine such as sulphanilic acid or arsanilic acid in an acid medium to form a diazonium salt. This salt is then reacted with another aromatic ring such as quinolin to give a pink or red colour. A false negative reaction may occur.</p>
<p><strong>Multistix strips</strong> The reagents used in this strip are p-arsanilic acid and 1, 2, 3, 4-tetrahydro benzo-(h)-quinolin-3-01. It can detect 0.06 - 1 mg/dl nitrite in urine.</p>
<p><strong>Chemstrip strips</strong> This strip contains sulphanilamide and 3-hydroxy-1,2,3,4-tetrahydro-7,8-benzoquinoline. It can detect 0.05 mg/dl nitrite in most specimens.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="microscopic-examination-of-urine">MICROSCOPIC EXAMINATION OF URINE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#microscopic-examination-of-urine" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The most common laboratory procedure utilised for the detection of renal or urinary tract disease is the microscopic examination of urine. This can be done in various ways, but is generally carried out by taking a standard amount of urine, centrifuging the specimen for a fixed period of time, removing the supernatant fluid, resuspending the sediment in a standard volume (usually 1 ml), and examining the sediment under the microscope. For semiquantitative or standardised analysis of the urinary sediment, a constant volume of urine must be centrifuged and a constant volume of supernatant removed. For example, 12 ml of urine should be centrifuged and finally resuspended in 1 ml. Examination of a urinary sediment enables assessment of the number of cells (white cells, red cells, epithelial cells, and tumour cells), casts, crystals and parasites in urine to be done. Each of these constituents can be a valuable indicator of pathology.</p>
<p>There are various ways in which a urinary sediment can be examined. With a proper level of professional expertise, bright-field microscopy of unstained urine can identify all clinically important and relevant structures in the sediment. It is necessary to adjust the amount of light entering the objective by carefully positioning the condenser and iris diaphragm. Other methods of examination include phase-contrast, interference or polarised microscopy or use of staining methods such as amonochrome staining, gram staining or supra-vital staining.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="constituents-of-urinary-sediment">Constituents of Urinary Sediment<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#constituents-of-urinary-sediment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The constituents of urinary sediment can be broadly divided into two groups:</p>
<ol>
<li><strong>Organised sediment</strong> This represents the biological part and includes various types of cells, casts, bacteria, parasites and spermatozoa. Cells in the urine are either from the kidney or urinary tract, or from circulating blood. Organisms and tumour cells do not originally belong to the urinary system (Fig. 4.5).</li>
</ol>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>142 Clinical Chemistry</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-7c401853.jpeg" alt="img-22.jpeg">
(a) Normal red cells</p>

(c) Enlarged red cells in hypotonic urine</p>

(e) Squamous epithelial cells, pus cells and red cells</p>

<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-1a25043c.jpeg" alt="img-28.jpeg">

<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-4fc0164c.jpeg" alt="img-30.jpeg">

<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Renal Function Tests and Urine Analysis 143</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>Unorganised sediment This represents the chemical portion and consists of chemical crystals and amorphous material. Their presence is generally less significant with the exception of some crystals (Fig. 4.6).</li>
</ol>
<p>Some of the prominent organised urinary sediment are as follows.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="organised-sediment">Organised Sediment<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#organised-sediment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="1-red-blood-cells">1. Red blood cells<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-red-blood-cells" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Microscopic appearance In fresh urine, under high power objective, unstained erythrocytes (red blood cells) appear as pale bluish-green biconcave discs, about 7 µm in size, with a smooth appearance, as opposed to the granular appearance of white cells. However, their appearance varies according to the constitution of urine. In a concentrated, hypertonic urine, the red cells appear crenated or shrunken due to loss of fluid. When urine is dilute or hypotonic, they appear swollen or rounded due to intake of more fluid. If the specimen is not fresh, the red cells appear as faint, colourless circles with a thin rim (shadow or ghost cells due to dissolution of haemoglobin from them.</p>
<p>Dysmorphic red cells are distorted red cells which are fragmented or have cellular protrusions. The presence of more than 20% dysmorphic red cells indicates glomerular disease.</p>
<p>&gt; <strong>Note</strong>
&gt; An inexperienced eye may confuse air bubbles, oil droplets or yeast cells with red cells. Introducing 2% acetic acid under coverglass of the wet preparation will lyse the red cells, leaving the other structures intact. Alternatively, occult blood test may be performed on the urine specimen. The test will be positive in the presence of red cells. For occult blood test, refer to Chapter 9.</p>
<p>Clinical significance In a normal urine sample, occasional red cell (0–2/hpf or 3–12/µl) may be</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-5b3482c4.jpeg" alt="img-34.jpeg">
(a) Cystine</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-7933cba7.jpeg" alt="img-35.jpeg">
(b) Tyrosine</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-e7a34d22.jpeg" alt="img-36.jpeg">
(c) Cholesterol</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-60105962.jpeg" alt="img-37.jpeg">
(d) Uric acid</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-d5dde796.jpeg" alt="img-38.jpeg">
(e) Calcium oxalate</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-fb61ee10.jpeg" alt="img-39.jpeg">
(f) Triple phosphate</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-335e6389.jpeg" alt="img-40.jpeg">
(g) Calcium phosphate</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-188a77f4.jpeg" alt="img-41.jpeg">
(h) Ammonium biurate</p>
<p>Fig. 4.6 Crystals in Urine
(a) Cystine; (b) Tyrosine; (c) Cholesterol; (d) Uric acid; (e) Calcium oxalate; (f) Triple phosphate
(g) Calcium phosphate; (h) Ammonium biurate</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>144 Clinical Chemistry</p>
<p>present in the sediment. When more red cells are detected in urine, the condition is known as haematuria (If there are no red cells in the sediment, but the occult blood test is positive, the condition is known as haemoglobinuria). The degree of haematuria may vary from a grossly bloody specimen to a normal appearing specimen showing a few red cells microscopically.</p>
<p>Increased number of red cells in urine may be seen in:</p>
<p>(i) Renal disease such as glomerulonephritis, calculus, acute infection, tuberculosis or tumour.
(ii) Lower urinary tract disease such as acute or chronic infection, calculus, tumour or cystitis.
(iii) Extra-renal disease such as acute appendicitis, tumours of the colon, rectum or pelvis, malaria and subacute bacterial endocarditis.
(iv) Toxic reactions due to drugs such as sulphonamides.</p>
<p><strong>Note</strong> Haematuria due to renal disease will also show the presence of casts in urine with the presence of urine protein.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-leukocytes-pus-cells">2. Leukocytes (Pus cells)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-leukocytes-pus-cells" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="microscopic-appearance">Microscopic appearance<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#microscopic-appearance" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p><strong>Neutrophils</strong> Neutrophils or polymorphonuclear neutrophils (PMN) are the most commonly seen leukocytes in the urine. They appear as granular spheres about 10–12 μm in diameter. Nuclear segments are fairly visible in a freshly voided urine, but may be lost when cellular degeneration begins. They can be differentiated from red cells by their larger size and granular cytoplasm. Leukocytes are rapidly lysed in hypotonic or alkaline urine. Therefore it is necessary to examine the urinary sediment promptly after collection.</p>
<p><strong>Glitter cells</strong> In a hypotonic urine with specific gravity lower than 1.010, neutrophils swell and appear larger in size. In the dilute urine, the cytoplasmic granules show continuous brownian movement which gives them a glittering appearance.</p>
<p><strong>Other leukocytes</strong> Eosinophils, lymphocytes and monocytes may occasionally appear in urine. Eosinophils are difficult to distinguish from neutrophils in an unstained preparation, but are larger in size and show a bilobed nucleus.</p>
<p>A normal urine may contain a few lymphocytes but are difficult to recognise in an unstained preparation. They appear slightly larger than red cells, and with a single nucleus. Mononuclear cells (mono-cytes, histiocytes and macrophages) are larger than neutrophils, with a single nucleus, and abundant, granular and vacuolated cytoplasm. Their identification should be confirmed by staining.</p>
<p><strong>Clinical significance</strong> A normal urine sediment may contain less than 5 leukocyte per high power field (&lt;5/hpf).</p>
<p><strong>Neutrophils</strong> Their presence in urine may be due to various factors.</p>
<p>(i) Increased number of neutrophils in urine indicates inflammation in the urinary tract. This condition is known as pyuria. Increased neutrophils (pus cells) are generally associated with bacterial infection.
(ii) Moderate number of pus cells together with pus cell casts may reflect acute or chronic bacterial pyelonephritis, or acute non-bacterial glomerulonephritis.
(iii) Calculi at any site in the urinary tract may give rise to increased leukocytes due to mucosal inflammatory reaction.
(iv) A variety of acute or chronic inflammatory processes, such as cystitis, urethritis, prostatitis or bladder tumours lead to increased number of leukocytes in urine.
(v) Pyuria with sterile culture may be present in renal tuberculosis, gonococcal urethritis, leptospirosis or antibiotic treatment.</p>
<p><strong>Glitter cells</strong> These are present in pyelonephritis or when the specific gravity of urine is low.</p>
<p><strong>Eosinophils</strong> Eosinophils may appear in large numbers in urine in allergic interstitial nephritis.</p>
<p><strong>Lymphocytes</strong> In case of renal transplant rejection, lymphocytes appear in the urine in significant numbers.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Renal Function Tests and Urine Analysis 145</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="monocytes-and-histiocytes">Monocytes and histiocytes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#monocytes-and-histiocytes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These cells in urine are generally due to chronic inflammation or radiation therapy.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="3-epithelial-cells">3. Epithelial cells<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-epithelial-cells" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="microscopic-appearance">Microscopic appearance<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#microscopic-appearance" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>The three major types of epithelial cells found in urine are squamous, transitional and renal tubular cells.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="squamous-epithelial-cells">Squamous epithelial cells<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#squamous-epithelial-cells" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>In urine, these cells are large, flat cells with abundant cytoplasm and small round nucleus. The distal one third of the urethra and female vagina is lined with squamous epithelial cells.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="transitional-or-urethral-epithelial-cells">Transitional or urethral epithelial cells<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#transitional-or-urethral-epithelial-cells" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>These cells line the urinary tract from the proximal two thirds of the urethra up to the renal pelvis. They are round or pear shaped, their size varying from 40–200 μm. The nucleus is centrally located.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="renal-tubular-epithelial-cells">Renal tubular epithelial cells<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#renal-tubular-epithelial-cells" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>These cells form a single layer epithelial lining from the proximal and distal convoluted tubules and the cells lining the collecting ducts up to the pelvis of the kidney. Identification in unstained preparation is difficult. The cells lining the convoluted tubules occur singly. They are oval cells measuring 14–60 μm with characteristic coarsely granular cytoplasm with one or two dense nuclei. Epithelial cells from the collecting ducts measure 12–20 μm, are cuboidal in shape and contain a large nucleus which is usually eccentric. Some renal epithelial cells may contain fat bodies in their cytoplasm. Their presence is clinically significant and should be reported. These fat containing cells may be associated with fat globules of various sizes. Occasionally renal epithelial cells may also contain haemosiderin pigment or inclusion bodies of viruses such as cytomegalovirus. The presence of the above structures in a wet preparation should be confirmed with appropriate staining (Sudan Black B for fat, Prussian blue for haemosiderin, Papnicolaou for inclusion bodies).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="clinical-significance">Clinical significance<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#clinical-significance" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>A small number of epithelial cells in urine is a normal finding due to sloughing of ageing cells. Increased number of squamous epithelial cells in female urine is not significant and is due to contamination of urine by vaginal secretions. A presence of large clumps or sheets of transitional epithelial cells is either due to instrumentation such as catheterisation or due to urinary tract lesions or tumours.</p>
<p>The renal epithelial cells from proximal or distal convoluted tubules are seen in large numbers in acute tubular necrosis and toxicity due to certain drugs and metals. The increased number of collecting duct epithelial cells is seen in acute glomerulonephritis and malignancy.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="4-casts">4. Casts<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#4-casts" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Casts represent a collection of protein and cellular debris in a kidney tubule, especially during low fluid flow. In a normal urine albumin, globulins form about two-thirds of urine proteins; the rest is a glycoprotein produced by the distal part of the convoluted tubule in the nephron. This is known as Tamm Horsfall (TH) protein. The TH protein forms the matrix of all the casts. An occasional cast may be found in normal urine.</p>
<p>When larger amounts of plasma proteins such as albumin or abnormal proteins such as Bence Jones proteins enter the renal tubules, the formation of casts is increased. The plasma proteins combine with the TH protein. These proteins are precipitated in an acidic pH, trapping the cellular debris in them. The size and shape of casts depends on the site of formation. Narrow casts are formed in the renal tubules whereas wider casts are produced in the collecting ducts. They have parallel sides and usually, blunt ends. When the casts begin to disintegrate, they may show tapering ends and are called cylinderoids.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="microscopic-appearance-and-clinical-significance">Microscopic appearance and clinical significance<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#microscopic-appearance-and-clinical-significance" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Casts are very difficult to visualise in an unstained preparation and may be completely missed if the light is not sufficiently reduced. They should be detected under the low power (10X) objective and identified using the high power (40X) objective. A phase contrast microscope is more useful for their detection. Casts can be classified according to their morphological appearance, depending on their matrix, cells, pigments and inclu</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>146 Clinical Chemistry</p>
<p>sions. The presence of casts in urine is indicative of renal involvement.</p>
<p><strong>Hyaline casts</strong> Hyaline casts are semitranslucent, non-refractive, homogenous structures and need special care for their detection.</p>
<p>An occasional hyaline cast may be present in normal urine but their number is increased in renal diseases. A transient increase is seen after exercise, congestive heart failure, diuretic therapy and in fever.</p>
<p><strong>Cellular casts</strong> These are the casts in which one or more types of cells are trapped during their formation. They are white cell (pus cell) casts, red cell casts and epithelial casts. Mixed cellular casts may be seen occasionally.</p>
<p><strong>White cell casts</strong> The white cells enter the renal tubules through the interstitial spaces between the renal tubular epithelium. The number of white cells trapped in a cast may vary. White cell casts are seen in the inflammations of the kidney, in conditions such as pyelonephritis and nephrotic syndrome.</p>
<p><strong>Red cell casts</strong> Red cell casts appear yellow under the low power objective. Under higher magnification, the trapped red cells may be seen. When these casts are formed in a nephron, the red cells may degenerate and appear in urine as reddish brown cast with coarse granules. Such a cast is known as blood or haemoglobin cast.</p>
<p>Red cell casts may be seen in serious conditions with renal involvement where glomeruli, tubules or renal capillaries are damaged. They are commonly observed in glomerulonephritis, subacute bacterial or infective endocarditis and renal infarction.</p>
<p><strong>Epithelial casts</strong> Epithelial casts containing renal tubular epithelial cells are difficult to distinguish from the white cell casts. Phase contrast microscopy or Papanicolaou stain are useful in differentiation.</p>
<p>The epithelial casts are seen in acute tubular necrosis, viral infections especially with cytomegalovirus, exposure to toxic drugs and heavy metals.</p>
<p><strong>Granular casts</strong> These casts which contain coarse or fine granules may form as a result of aggregation of plasma proteins in Tamm Horsfall (TH) matrix or more commonly due to disintegration of cells within the cast.</p>
<p>Granular casts appear in a variety of glomerular, tubular and interstitial diseases; and also in renal allograft rejection.</p>
<p><strong>Waxy casts</strong> Waxy casts are homogeneous, with sharp margins and blunt ends. They resemble hyaline casts, but are more refractile, and show cracks and convolutions along the lateral margins. Waxy casts are associated with chronic renal failure, renal allograft rejection and indicate tubular inflammation and degeneration. Sometimes waxy casts are unusually broad due to tubular atrophy and dilatation. They are called renal failure casts indicating a terminal stage of renal disease.</p>
<p><strong>Fatty casts</strong> Fatty material such as cholesterol and triglycerides can be trapped into cast matrix when there is heavy proteinuria. They are highly refractile due to the presence of fat droplets.</p>
<p>Their presence in urine represents fatty degeneration and desquamation of renal tubular epithelium. They are seen in nephrotic syndrome, diabetes mellitus with renal involvement and due to toxic drugs such as ethylene glycol.</p>
<p><strong>Miscellaneous casts</strong> Other miscellaneous structures such as crystals or various pigment granules such as haemosiderin or bilirubin may get trapped into the TH matrix to form casts.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-bacteria">5. Bacteria<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-bacteria" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A properly collected urine specimen from a healthy individual should be free from bacteria. Presence of bacteria in a fresh urine indicates infection. Urine is a very good medium for the growth of bacteria. Therefore, even a few bacteria, whether as a result of infection or contamination, can grow into large numbers if unpreserved urine is allowed to stand at room temperature for a long time. Bacterial infection is generally associated with increased number of leukocytes.</p>
<p>Most bacteria causing urinary tract infection are bacilli, which are rod shaped organisms measuring <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>0.5</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>1.0</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn><mi>μ</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">0.5 - 1.0 \times 2 - 5 \mu \mathrm{m}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">0.5</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">1.0</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">2</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8389em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">5</span><span class="mord mathnormal">μ</span><span class="mord mathrm">m</span></span></span></span></span> in size. Sometimes cocci may also cause infection. They are spherical bacteria and measure about <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1.0</mn><mi>μ</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1.0 \mu \mathrm{m}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8389em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">1.0</span><span class="mord mathnormal">μ</span><span class="mord mathrm">m</span></span></span></span></span> in diameter.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Renal Function Tests and Urine Analysis 147</p>
<p>For bacteriological examination of urine, refer to Bacteriology in Microbiology section.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="6-yeasts">6. Yeasts<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#6-yeasts" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Yeast cells are oval cells, some of which may show budding. They are about the same size as red cells and can be mistaken for them. To differentiate, a drop of 2% acetic acid should be added to the sediment and only the red cells will be lysed.</p>
<p>Yeast cells appear in urine as a result of contamination from women with vaginal candidiasis. They may also be seen in the urine of diabetic patients due to the presence of sugar in the urine. They may cause recurrent infections in debilitated and immunocompromised patients. A fresh, properly collected specimen of urine should be examined to differentiate between an infection and contamination.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="7-parasites">7. Parasites<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#7-parasites" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Except for the ova of the trematode parasite Schistosoma haematobium, all other parasites or ova appearing in urine are a result of faecal or vaginal contamination. These include Trichomonas, a flagellated protozoan slightly larger than leukocytes showing a typical motility; amoebae such as Entamoeba histolytica and adult worms such as Enterobius vermicularis.</p>
<p>The eggs of Schistosoma haematobium are elongated measuring 110–180 × 40–70 μm, and have a distinctive terminal spine. The ova are usually accompanied by red cells from the urinary bladder. Microfilariae of Wuchereria bancrofti may appear in urine rarely, especially when the urine is milky white (chyluria)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="8-spermatozoa">8. Spermatozoa<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#8-spermatozoa" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Spermatozoa may also be present as urinary contaminants. They have oval heads with long delicate tails.</p>
<p><strong>Note</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Mucus strands Strands of mucus may appear in urine and can be mistaken for casts. Unlike casts, they have undefined edges and pointed or split ends.</li>
<li>Artefacts Cotton fibres, hair, fibres from diapers, wood fibres from applic-</li>
</ol>
<p>cator or mixing sticks and starch granules can be mistaken for various formed elements of urine. Careful examination can distinguish them.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="unorganised-sediment">Unorganised Sediment<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#unorganised-sediment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Crystals and other amorphous chemical substances form the unorganised sediment of urine. Normal urine contains many chemicals from which crystals or amorphous precipitation can be formed. Some remain in solution and appear in the sediment when the urine is allowed to stand at room temperature, and more so, if refrigerated. The crystals have a refractile striking appearance, but most of the times are clinically insignificant. However, it is necessary to identify the crystals and the amorphous material because:</p>
<p>(i) If present in large numbers the crystals can obscure the more important organised sediments such as leukocytes, red cells and casts.
(ii) Presence of some crystals is associated with the formation of renal calculi (kidney stones). Formation of sulphonamide crystals in the kidney may result in renal damage.
