(iii) Some crystals such as cystine, leucine and tyrosine indicate serious metabolic disorders. If detected in urine microscopy they should be identified by confirmatory tests. Table 4.4 shows characteristics of crystals and amorphous deposits in urine.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="1-crystals-associated-with-metabolic-disorders">1. Crystals associated with metabolic disorders<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-crystals-associated-with-metabolic-disorders" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>These crystals are found in the urine of an acidic pH.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="i-cystine-crystals">(i) Cystine crystals<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-cystine-crystals" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<p>These crystals are insoluble in acid pH and therefore, appear in acid urine. They are refractile, colourless, hexagonal crystals. These crystals may be mistaken for hexagonal forms of uric acid. Cystine crystals are soluble in 30% hydrochloric acid where as uric acid is insoluble in it. Both are soluble in alkali. Confirmation of cystine crystals is done by cyanide-nitroprusside reaction. Presence of cystine in urine (cystinuria) is an amino acid disorder. It may lead to formation of renal stones and kidney damage.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>148 Clinical Chemistry</p>
<p>Table 4.4 Characteristics of crystals and amorphous deposits in urine</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Substance</th><th>Description</th><th>Urine pH where found</th><th></th><th></th><th>Solubility characteristics and comments</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td></td><td></td><td>Acid</td><td>Neutral</td><td>Alkaline</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Cystine</td><td>Colourless; hexagonal plates often laminated, soluble in dilute hydrochloric acid</td><td>+</td><td>-</td><td>-</td><td>Soluble in alkali (especially ammonia) and dilute hydrochloric acid; insoluble in boiling water, acetic acid, alcohol, ether</td></tr><tr><td>Tyosine</td><td>Rare: colourless or yellow, appears black with focussing; fine silky needles in sheaves or rosettes</td><td>+</td><td>-</td><td>-</td><td>Soluble in alkali, dilute mineral acid, relatively heat soluble; insoluble in alcohol, ether</td></tr><tr><td>Cholesterol</td><td>Rare, colourless; flat plate with corner notch, accompanies fatty casts and oval fat bodies</td><td>+</td><td>+</td><td>-</td><td>Soluble in chloroform, ether and hot alcohol</td></tr><tr><td>Uric acid</td><td>Common: Yellow, red-brown, brown; large variety of shapes; rhombic, four sided plates, rosettes</td><td>+</td><td>-</td><td>-</td><td>Soluble in alkali; insoluble in alcohol and acids</td></tr><tr><td>Triple phosphate (ammonium, magnesium)</td><td>Common form: colourless; three-to-six sided prisms, "coffin lids" Less often; flat, fern leaf form, sheets, flakes</td><td>-</td><td>+</td><td>+</td><td>Soluble in dilute acetic acid</td></tr><tr><td>Calcium oxalate</td><td>Most common, colourless, octahedron (envelope) shaped, rarely dumb bell or oval in shape</td><td>-</td><td>+</td><td>-</td><td>Insoluble in dilute acetic acid</td></tr><tr><td>Ammonium biurate</td><td>Common in "old" urine; dark yellow or brown; spheres or "thorn apples" (spheres with horns)</td><td>-</td><td>+</td><td>+</td><td>Soluble at 60°C with acetic acid; soluble in strong alkali; change to uric acid with concentrated hydrochloric or acetic acid</td></tr><tr><td>Calcium carbonate</td><td>Colourless, small granules in pairs, fours, spheres, rarely needles</td><td>-</td><td>+</td><td>+</td><td>Soluble in acetic acid with effervescence</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>(Contd.)</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Renal Function Tests and Urine Analysis 149</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Substance</th><th>Description</th><th>Urine pH where found</th><th></th><th></th><th>Solubility characteristics and comments</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td></td><td></td><td>Acid</td><td>Neutral</td><td>Alkaline</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Amorphous urates (calcium, magnesium, sodium, potassium)</td><td>Common; colourless to yellow brown; amorphous, granular precipitate</td><td>+</td><td>+</td><td>-</td><td>Soluble in dilute alkali; soluble at 60°C or lower; acid crystals with concentrated HCl or acetic acid</td></tr><tr><td>Sulphona-mides</td><td>Wheat sheaves with eccentric binding or irregular divided spheres or brown dense globules;</td><td>+</td><td>-</td><td>-</td><td>-</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>(ii) Leucine crystals These are yellow spherical crystals with radial and concentric striations. They may appear like fat globules but unlike fat, they are insoluble in ether. They usually occur with tyrosine crystals in severe liver disease. Both are precipitated if alcohol is added to the urine.</p>
<p>(iii) Tyrosine crystals These are colourless or yellow (appear black while focusing) fine, silky needles arranged in sheaves or clumps. They are precipitated with alcohol. Tyrosine crystals are very rarely seen in severe liver disease.</p>
<p>(iv) Cholesterol crystals These are large, flat rectangular plates with cut-out corners, which are soluble in chloroform, ether and alcohol. They are insoluble in acid or alkali. They are rarely found in urine in severe kidney disease.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-crystals-in-normal-acid-urine">2. Crystals in normal acid urine<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-crystals-in-normal-acid-urine" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>(i) Uric acid crystals Uric acid crystals form a variety of shapes and are usually yellow or yellowish brown in colour. The most common form is four sided, flat or laminated. They also occur as rhombic plates, oval forms with pointed ends, rosettes, wedges or irregular plates. Sometimes they appear as colourless plates, resembling cystine. They can be differentiated by the non-solubility of uric acid in dilute HCl.</p>
<p>(ii) Calcium oxalate crystals These are small colourless, octahedron crystals appearing like envelopes of varying sizes. Rarely they may take dumb bell shape or oval shape which may resemble red cells. They are insoluble in acetic acid unlike red cells. They are the most common type of crystal seen in normal urine at neutral or slightly acidic pH.</p>
<p>(iii) Amorphous urates (sodium, potassium, calcium, magnesium) These are small amorphous granules which may appear in a slightly acidic urine. The urine appears pinkish or reddish brown in colour. They dissolve, clearing the urine, when it is heated to about 60°C. They are also soluble in dilute alkali. On addition of acetic acid the amorphous urates are converted to uric acid.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="3-crystals-in-normal-alkaline-urine">3. Crystals in normal alkaline urine<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-crystals-in-normal-alkaline-urine" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>(i) Triple phosphate crystals These are ammonium magnesium phosphate crystals which are referred to as 'coffin lids'. They are colourless, 3–6 sided prisms with oblique edges and show a large variation in size. Occasionally they appear as flat fern forms when going in solution.</p>
<p>(ii) Calcium hydrogen phosphate crystals These are colourless crystals which may appear as flat plates or slender wedges occurring singly or in rosettes or clusters.</p>
<p>(iii) Calcium carbonate crystals These are very tiny, colourless, spherical crystals which may appear singly or in pairs as dumb bells. They dissolve in dilute acids with effervescence giving away carbon dioxide.</p>
<p>(iv) Ammonium biurate crystals These are spherical yellowish-brown crystals with radial or</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>150 Clinical Chemistry</p>
<p>concentric striations and irregular projections on the surface which gives them the name of a 'thorn apple'. They dissolve when heated and in acetic acid they are slowly converted to uric acid.</p>
<p>(v) Amorphous phosphates (calcium and magnesium) These are fine, colourless amorphous granules and the most common cause of turbidity in alkaline pH. They do not dissolve on heating but are soluble in dilute acids.</p>
<ol start="4">
<li>Crystals of drugs in urine Drugs such as sulphonamides or ampicillin and radiographic media may appear in urine. Sulphonamides and ampicillin administered in high doses may crystallise in kidneys and lead to haematuria.</li>
</ol>
<p>Sulphonamide crystals appear in acid urine in various forms such as large colourless or brownish needles with central or eccentric binding, rosettes, arrowheads or round with radial striations. Ampicillin forms long, fine, colourless crystals. Radiographic contrast media may appear as colourless, slender rectangles or notched rhombic plates.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="method-for-microscopic-examination-of-urine">Method for Microscopic Examination of Urine<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#method-for-microscopic-examination-of-urine" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>For standardisation of reporting the urinary sediment is concentrated 12:1, that is 12 volumes of urine is centrifuged, supernatant removed and the sediment resuspended in 1ml of urine before examination. Any fraction of this ratio may be used (e.g., 6 ml to 0.5 ml, 3 ml to 0.25 ml).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="method">Method<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#method" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Pour 12 volumes (ml) of well-mixed urine in a centrifuge tube and centrifuge at 450 g (approx. 1500–2000 rpm) for 5 minutes.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Decant 11 volumes (ml) of urine without disturbing the sediment, leaving 1 volume (ml) in the tube.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Gently resuspend the sediment. Deliver one drop on a slide. Cover with a coverslip.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Examine the slide using low power (10 X) objective. Reduce the light intensity to minimum and scan several fields for casts. If present, report the number of cast per low power field. Identify the cast type by using high power (40 X) objective.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Using high power objective with slightly increased light intensity, identify and count red cells, leukocytes and renal epithelial cells. Examine at least 10 fields. Report each cell type as cells/hpf.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Report on</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>(i) Bacteria, yeast, parasites, fat globules if present as few, moderate, many or abundant. Spermatozoa should be reported if present in large numbers.
(ii) Crystals: Identify and quantitate as few, moderate or many. Presence of abnormal crystals should be confirmed chemically before reporting.
(iii) Squamous and transitional epithelial cells if present in large numbers.
(iv) Large amounts of mucus.
(v) Any other abnormal finding.</p>
<p><strong>Note</strong>
0–5 leukocytes per hpf, 0–2 red cells per hpf, and 0–2 hyaline casts per lpf are considered to be within normal limits.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="urinary-calculi">URINARY CALCULI<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#urinary-calculi" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A calculus is an abnormal, solid concretion of minerals and salts formed around organic materials and found chiefly in ducts and cysts. Urinary calculi of varying sizes can form in any part of the urinary tract. It requires a nucleus on which the crystals are deposited. Increased excretion of a substance coupled with concentrated urine can be a predisposing factor.</p>
<p>The presence of calculus in the urinary tract can obstruct urinary flow, and can cause infection and haematuria which can be associated with renal colic. The calculi may be composed of one or more crystals in the urine with a nucleus made of an organic or a foreign body.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="qualitative-analysis-of-renal-calculus">Qualitative Analysis of Renal Calculus<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#qualitative-analysis-of-renal-calculus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="reagents">Reagents<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#reagents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Concentrated nitric acid</li>
<li>Concentrated ammonia solution</li>
</ol>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Renal Function Tests and Urine Analysis 151</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>Dilute ammonium hydroxide: Dilute reagent (2) 1:5 with water.</li>
<li>Sodium cyanide 10%</li>
<li>Sodium nitroprusside, 5%. Prepare fresh.</li>
<li>Dilute hydrochloric acid (approx. 2N)</li>
<li>Dilute sulphuric acid (approx. 2N)</li>
<li>Potassium permanganate solution, 0.3%</li>
<li>Ammonium molybdate, 5%. Prepare fresh.</li>
<li>Potassium hydroxide solution (approx. 2N)</li>
<li>Ammonium oxalate, saturated.</li>
<li>Titan yellow, 0.1%</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="method">Method<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#method" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Wash the stone with water and dry in incubator. Note the size, appearance and hardness of the stone. Cut the stone to see if layers and nucleus are present. Powder the stone finely.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Heat a small amount of the powder in a small crucible or on a foil and observe.
(i) Organic crystal such as uric acid or cystine will burn away entirely, leaving a trace of ash.
(ii) Cystine gives a blue flame with a sharp smell.
(iii) Fibrin gives a yellow flame with a smell of burnt feathers.
(iv) Uric acid, ammonium urate and xanthine burn away without flame.
(v) If the stone burns away completely, oxalate phosphate and carbonate are absent.
(vi) If the stone leaves a residue, proceed for inorganic components from step 5.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Murexide test</strong>: In a small crucible, add small amount of powder and 2–3 drops of conc. nitric acid. Heat carefully over a flame.
(i) Uric acid or ammonium biurate is present if red or yellow residue is obtained. When cool, add 2–3 drops of dilute ammonium hydroxide. The colour changes to purple-red.
(ii) Xanthine dissolves in nitric acid giving a yellow residue and changes to orange-red on addition of dilute ammonium hydroxide.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Cyanide-nitroprusside test for cystine</strong>: If a blue flame is seen in Step 2, dissolve a small amount of powder in a few drops of concentrated ammonia. Remove the supernatant, dilute with 2 ml water and add 1 ml sodium cyanide. Stand for 5 minutes and add a few drops of sodium nitroprusside solution. A deep magenta colour indicates cystine.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>If a residue remains in Step 2, inorganic material is present. Proceed as follows:
(i) To small amount of powder, add a few drops of dilute hydrochloric acid. Effervescence indicates carbonates.
(ii) Add 2 ml of dilute sulphuric acid to a small amount of powder. Heat for 1 minute. Cool to 60–70°C and add potassium permanganate solution dropwise. Prompt decolourisation with effervescence indicates oxalate.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Dissolve a small amount of the powder in a few ml of concentrated nitric acid. Add equal volume of ammonium molybdate solution and heat to boil. A yellow precipitate indicates presence of phosphates.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Heat a small amount of the powder with 1–2 ml of potassium hydroxide solution. Hold a moist red litmus paper in the vapour. If it turns blue, ammonia is produced which indicates the presence of triple phosphate or ammonium urate.
8.(i) Add a small amount of the powder to dilute hydrochloric acid and heat to dissolve. To the supernatant add 1 ml of the ammonium oxalate and enough concentrated ammonia till the solution becomes just alkaline. Add acetic acid till the pH is 5.0. A white precipitate of calcium oxalate indicates the presence of calcium.
(ii) Filter the precipitate and to the filtrate add a few drops of Titan yellow. Add potassium hydroxide till it becomes strongly alkaline. Red flocculent precipitate of magnesium hydroxide indicates presence of magnesium.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Chapter 5
Liver Function Tests</p>
<p>The liver is the largest organ in the body. It weighs about 1.5 kg in an adult. It is also the most active and most complex organ. It lies in the upper right side of the abdomen beneath the diaphragm. It has four lobes, the right one being the largest while the left one is smaller and wedge shaped (Fig. 5.1). The other two lobes are very small and can only be seen on the under surface of the liver.</p>
<p>The portal vein which enters the liver through the portal tissue carries blood from the stomach, spleen, pancreas and intestines. The hepatic artery carries the arterial blood to the liver. The hepatic vein leaves the liver to carry blood to the inferior vena cava. The right and left hepatic ducts carry bile to the gall bladder.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-49f210cd.jpeg" alt="img-42.jpeg">
Fig. 5.1 Structure of liver</p>
<p>The liver is divided into many small circular units—lobules. Each lobule is made of rows of cells—the hepatocytes, radiating from the central vein.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="secretion-of-bile">SECRETION OF BILE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#secretion-of-bile" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Bile is secreted by the liver cells, stored and concentrated in the gall bladder, and then released into the duodenum where it helps to emulsify dietary fat. Between meals the sphincter of Oddi in the gall bladder is closed and it is opened at the sight, taste or smell of food. When the gastric contents enter the duodenum, a hormone known as cholecystokinin and which is secreted by the intestinal mucosa, causes the gall bladder to contract, thereby making bile enter the duodenum. Here the bile is essential for adequate reabsorption of fats and of vitamin K. Reduction of bile by bacteria produces bile salts (usually sodium or potassium) such as deoxycholic acid and lithocholic acids conjugated with glycine and taurine.</p>
<p>Bile is golden yellow or greenish coloured fluid that contains cholesterol, bilirubin and bile salts. Much of the bile secreted into the intestine is reabsorbed into the hepatic portal circulation, recycled in the liver and re-excreted in the duodenum. Only small amount of bile is normally excreted in the faeces.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Liver Function Tests 153</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="functions-of-the-liver">FUNCTIONS OF THE LIVER<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions-of-the-liver" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Excretion of bile The liver produces and excretes bile into the intestine</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Carbohydrate metabolism The main monosaccharides obtained during digestive processes are converted into glycogen and stored in the liver. When required, the glycogen is re-converted to glucose (Glycogenolysis). Thus blood glucose level is maintained. But if the liver has used all the stored glycogen and blood glucose is below normal, the liver can convert protein and fat into glucose (gluconeogenesis).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Protein production Plasma proteins, namely, fibrinogen, albumin and globulin (except gamma globulin) are manufactured in the liver. The liver also produces transport proteins such as transferrin which binds and transports iron, and haptoglobin which combines with free haemoglobin.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Synthesis of blood clotting factors Many of blood coagulation factors, fibrinogen, prothrombin, factors V, VII, IX, X, XI and XII are synthesised in the liver.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Storage In addition to glycogen and many vitamins, the liver is the main organ of storage for iron.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Detoxication The ammonia released from amino-acid deamination is detoxicated by being converted to urea for excretion by the kidney. The liver also detoxicates drugs, metabolic products, hormones and alcohols by oxidation, conjugation, methylation or reduction.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Metabolism of lipid The synthesis of cholesterol, phospholipids, endogenous triglycerides and lipoprotein occurs mainly in the liver, including the esterification of cholesterol.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Phagocytic activity Worn out red blood cells as well as micro-organisms are removed by the Kupffer cells which form a part of mononuclear phagocytic defence system (a part of reticuloendothelial system, (RES)) of the body.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="metabolism-of-bilirubin">METABOLISM OF BILIRUBIN<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#metabolism-of-bilirubin" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Bilirubin is mainly formed from the breakdown of haemoglobin in the cells of the liver, spleen and bone marrow. The haem (iron porphyrin) of the haemoglobin molecule is firstly removed from the globin. The porphyrin portion is then converted to biliverdin which is reduced to bilirubin. The bilirubin is insoluble in water, it is carried in the blood attached to albumin and it cannot be excreted by the kidney. This bilirubin is referred to as unconjugated (indirect) bilirubin.</p>
<p>The enzyme glucuronosyl transferase in the liver cells joins (conjugates) glucuronic acid to bilirubin to form bilirubin glucuronides. This bilirubin is called conjugated (direct) bilirubin and it is water-soluble and non-toxic.</p>
<p>Conjugated bilirubin is passed from the liver into the gall bladder through the bile duct, and into the intestine. Here the bilirubin is deconjugated and reduced by bacterial enzymes to a colourless compound, stercobilinogen (faecal urobilinogen). This is oxidised to a brown pigmen, stercobilin, the main pigment of faeces. Some of the stercobilinogen is re-absorbed via the portal vein back to the liver from where it re-enters the intestine in the bile and is excreted in the faeces. A small amount of the reabsorbed urobilinogen is carried in the blood through the liver and transported to the kidneys where it is excreted in the urine. Figure 5.2 summarises the metabolism of bilirubin.</p>
<p>Bile salt Together with the bile, bile salts enter the duodenum and are found in small amounts in faeces and very little in urine. The bile salts are reabsorbed via the portal vein, removed by the liver and excreted in the bile. In obstructive jaundice, bile salts are present along with bile pigments in the urine.</p>
<p>Jaundice (Icterus) This is the condition during which the patient has a yellow colouration of the eyes and some parts of the skin. The yellow pigmentation is due to a raised level of bilirubin which is normally present in small amounts in the plasma. Jaundice may be classified into three types.</p>
<ol>
<li>Prehepatic Due to an excessive breakdown of red blood cells as in haemolytic anaemia, the bilirubin load becomes too much for the liver to conjugate. The bilirubin is therefore mostly unconjugated or indirect.</li>
</ol>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>154 Clinical Chemistry</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-fdfa62e6.jpeg" alt="img-43.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 5.2 Bilirubin metabolism</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>
<p>Hepatic As a result of diminished function of the liver cells (due to damage) as in infective hepatitis, conjugation is inhibited; so initially the bilirubin is indirect. As the cell damage affects the structure of the liver, conjugated bilirubin becomes increased. Thus both types of bilirubin are present in the serum.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Post-hepatic When bilirubin which has been conjugated cannot be excreted due to obstruction in the bile duct by either gall stone within the lumen or by a tumour exerting pressure from outside, the bilirubin "spills over" into the blood. This bilirubin is water-soluble (conjugated) and can be excreted by the kidney. Table 5.1 shows the type of bilirubin present in various conditions.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="liver-function-tests">LIVER FUNCTION TESTS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#liver-function-tests" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These are routine tests performed in the investigation of a liver disease. They include serum of plasma and urine bilirubin, urine urobilinogen, plasma alkaline phosphatase, plasma alanine</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Liver Function Tests 155</p>
<p>Table 5.1 Changes in bilirubin concentrations in various conditions</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Condition</th><th>Serum</th><th></th><th>Urine</th><th></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td></td><td>Total Bilirubin</td><td>Conjugated bilirubin</td><td>Bilirubin</td><td>Urobilinogen</td></tr><tr><td>Normal</td><td>0.2–1.0 mg/dl</td><td>0–0.2 mg/dl</td><td>Negative</td><td>0.5–3.4 mg/day</td></tr><tr><td>Prehepatic jaundice</td><td>Increased</td><td>Normal</td><td>Negative</td><td>Increased</td></tr><tr><td>Hepatic jaundice:</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Hepatocellular disease</td><td>Increased</td><td>Increased</td><td>Positive</td><td>Decreased (normal)</td></tr><tr><td>Gilbert’s disease</td><td>Increased</td><td>Normal</td><td>Negative</td><td>Decreased (normal)</td></tr><tr><td>Crigler-Najjar syndrome</td><td>Increased</td><td>Decreased</td><td>Negative</td><td>Decreased</td></tr><tr><td>Posthepatic obstructive jaundice</td><td>Increased</td><td>Increased</td><td>Positive</td><td>Decreased</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>amino transferase and plasma albumin. These tests are non-specific and in most cases are not true indications of liver dysfunction. They are only suggestive of liver disease.</p>
<p>True liver function tests which include the bromosulphthalein (BSP) excretion test and plasma bile salt estimation, are not routinely performed. The following tests have been described in this chapter.</p>
<ol>
<li>Serum/plasma bilirubin</li>
<li>Serum/plasma proteins.</li>
</ol>
<p>The other tests, such as urine bile pigments and enzyme assays are described under urine analysis and enzymology respectively.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="estimation-of-serum-plasma-bilirubin">ESTIMATION OF SERUM/PLASMA BILIRUBIN<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#estimation-of-serum-plasma-bilirubin" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Principle Van den Bergh diazo reaction has been used for many years to determine bilirubin in the serum. This involves treating the serum with diazotised sulphanilic acid to form the azobilirubin complex. The conjugated bilirubin reacts directly with the diazo reagent while the unconjugated (indirect) bilirubin reacts with the diazoreagent only in the presence of an accelerator such as the caffeine-benzoate reagent, and takes about 10 minutes for the colour development. The azobilirubin is purple in the acid medium, and is converted to blue colour by the addition of alkaline tartarate solution. The diazo reaction is terminated at the end by the addition of ascorbic acid.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="reagents">Reagents<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#reagents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Sulphanilic acid reagent
Sulphanilic acid 5.0 g
Hydrochloric acid, concentrated 15 ml
Distilled water upto 1 litre</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Sodium nitrate solution
Sodium nitrate 5.0 g
Distilled water 100 ml
Keep at 4°C for 2 weeks.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Diazo reagent
Reagent 1 10.0 ml
Reagent 2 0.25 ml
This reagent is stable for 3 hours only so prepare fresh for each batch of tests.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Caffeine reagent
Sodium benzoate 75 g
Caffeine 50 g
Sodium acetate, anhydrous 75 g
Ethylene diamine tetra acetic acid 1 g
Distilled water up to 1 litre</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Alkaline tartrate reagent
Sodium hydroxide 100 g
Sodium potassium tartarate 350 g
Distilled water upto 1 litre</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Ascorbic acid solution
Ascorbic acid 0.20 g</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>156 Clinical Chemistry</p>
<p>Distilled water up to 5 ml
Make fresh each day
Make fresh each day</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="7660b875">7. Standard bilirubin solution - (200 μmol/L)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#7660b875" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A pool of Hepatitis antigen free, non icteric human serum is prepared and kept frozen within 72 hours of collection. Transfer 11.7 mg of pure bilirubin which has been dried for several days in a dessicator to a 100 ml stoppered flask by using 4 ml dimethylsulphoxide. Dissolve by warming at 35°C and shaking at intervals and keeping out of sunlight. With the pool of serum make up the volume of the bilirubin standard to 100 ml. Distribute in about 1ml amounts in small vials or containers and deep freeze until required.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="calculation">Calculation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#calculation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mi>μ</mi><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">o</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi><mtext>&nbsp;of&nbsp;total&nbsp;bilirubin</mtext><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mtext>Absorbance&nbsp;(TB)</mtext><mo>−</mo><mtext>Absorbance&nbsp;(B)</mtext></mrow><mrow><mtext>Absorbance&nbsp;(S)</mtext><mo>−</mo><mtext>Absorbance&nbsp;(SB)</mtext></mrow></mfrac><mo>×</mo><mn>200</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mu \mathrm{mol} / \mathrm{L} \text{ of total bilirubin} = \frac{\text{Absorbance (TB)} - \text{Absorbance (B)}}{\text{Absorbance (S)} - \text{Absorbance (SB)}} \times 200</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">μ</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mol</span></span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mord mathrm">L</span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">&nbsp;of&nbsp;total&nbsp;bilirubin</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.363em; vertical-align: -0.936em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.427em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Absorbance&nbsp;(S)</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Absorbance&nbsp;(SB)</span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Absorbance&nbsp;(TB)</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Absorbance&nbsp;(B)</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.936em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">200</span></span></span></span></span></div>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mi>μ</mi><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">o</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi><mtext>&nbsp;of&nbsp;conjugated&nbsp;(direct)&nbsp;bilirubin</mtext><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mtext>Absorbance&nbsp;(CB)</mtext><mo>−</mo><mtext>Absorbance&nbsp;(B)</mtext></mrow><mrow><mtext>Absorbance&nbsp;(S)</mtext><mo>−</mo><mtext>Absorbance&nbsp;(SB)</mtext></mrow></mfrac><mo>×</mo><mn>200</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mu \mathrm{mol} / \mathrm{L} \text{ of conjugated (direct) bilirubin} = \frac{\text{Absorbance (CB)} - \text{Absorbance (B)}}{\text{Absorbance (S)} - \text{Absorbance (SB)}} \times 200</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">μ</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mol</span></span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mord mathrm">L</span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">&nbsp;of&nbsp;conjugated&nbsp;(direct)&nbsp;bilirubin</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.363em; vertical-align: -0.936em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.427em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Absorbance&nbsp;(S)</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Absorbance&nbsp;(SB)</span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Absorbance&nbsp;(CB)</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Absorbance&nbsp;(B)</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.936em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">200</span></span></span></span></span></div>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mi>μ</mi><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">o</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi><mtext>&nbsp;of&nbsp;unconjugated&nbsp;(indirect)&nbsp;bilirubin</mtext><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>T</mi><mtext>total</mtext></msub><mtext>&nbsp;bilirubin</mtext><mo>−</mo><mtext>Conjugated&nbsp;bilirubin</mtext></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mu \mathrm{mol} / \mathrm{L} \text{ of unconjugated (indirect) bilirubin} = T_{\text{total}} \text{ bilirubin} - \text{Conjugated bilirubin}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">μ</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mol</span></span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mord mathrm">L</span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">&nbsp;of&nbsp;unconjugated&nbsp;(indirect)&nbsp;bilirubin</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8444em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.13889em;">T</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3361em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.1389em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord mtight">total</span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">&nbsp;bilirubin</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Conjugated&nbsp;bilirubin</span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p><strong>Method</strong>
Set up 4 tubes as shown in Table below, and add the reagents following the same sequence.</p>
<table><thead><tr><th></th><th>Total Bilirubin (TB)</th><th>Blank (B)</th><th>Standard (S)</th><th>Standard Blank (SB)</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>1. Serum</td><td>0.2 ml</td><td>—</td><td>—</td><td>—</td></tr><tr><td>2. Standard (200 μmol/L)</td><td>—</td><td>—</td><td>0.2 ml</td><td>—</td></tr><tr><td>3. Distilled water</td><td>0.8 ml</td><td>0.8 ml</td><td>0.8 ml</td><td>0.8 ml</td></tr><tr><td>4. Diazo reagent</td><td>0.5 ml</td><td>—</td><td>0.5 ml</td><td>—</td></tr><tr><td>5. Caffeine reagent</td><td>2.0 ml</td><td>—</td><td>2.0 ml</td><td>—</td></tr><tr><td>Stand at room temperature for 10 minutes</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>6. Ascorbic acid</td><td>0.1 ml</td><td>0.1 ml</td><td>0.1 ml</td><td>0.1 ml</td></tr><tr><td>7. Diazo reagent</td><td>—</td><td>0.5 ml</td><td>—</td><td>0.5 ml</td></tr><tr><td>8. Serum</td><td>—</td><td>0.2 ml</td><td>—</td><td>—</td></tr><tr><td>9. Standard (200 μmol/L)</td><td>—</td><td>—</td><td>—</td><td>0.2 ml</td></tr><tr><td>10. Caffeine reagent</td><td>—</td><td>2.0 ml</td><td>—</td><td>2.0 ml</td></tr><tr><td>11. Alkaline tartarate</td><td>1.5 ml</td><td>1.5 ml</td><td>1.5 ml</td><td>1.5 ml</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="direct-conjugated-bilirubin">Direct (Conjugated) Bilirubin<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#direct-conjugated-bilirubin" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Set up a tube (CB) for conjugated (direct) bilirubin and add 0.2 ml serum, 0.8 ml distilled water and 0.5 ml diazo reagent. Leave for 10 minutes for colour development. Add 0.1 ml ascorbic acid, 2.0 ml caffeine reagent and 1.5 ml of alkaline tartarate.</p>
<p>Read the absorbance of all the tubes at 600 nm within 30 minutes.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="normal-values">Normal values<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#normal-values" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>For adults</strong>
Bilirubin: up to 1.0 mg/dl (up to 17 μmol/L)
Conjugated (Direct)
bilirubin: up to 0.2 mg/dl (up to 3.5 μmol/L)</p>
<p><strong>Note</strong>
Bilirubin is unstable and direct sunlight can cause loss of half of the value in a hour.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Liver Function Tests 157</p>
<p>Direct bilirubin level, very rarely, may be higher than that of the total bilirubin. This is probably due to mild inhibition of diazotisation by caffeine.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="causes-of-hyperbilirubinemia">Causes of Hyperbilirubinemia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#causes-of-hyperbilirubinemia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="unconjugated-indirect-hyperbilirubinemia">Unconjugated (indirect) hyperbilirubinemia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#unconjugated-indirect-hyperbilirubinemia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="1-over-production-of-bilirubin">1. Over production of bilirubin<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-over-production-of-bilirubin" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<p>(i) Congenital (e.g., haemoglobinopathies)
(ii) Haemolytic anaemia
(iii) Liver disease (e.g., hepatitis and cirrhosis)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="2-decreased-excretion">2. Decreased excretion<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-decreased-excretion" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<p>(i) Hereditary, e.g., Gilbert’s syndrome
(ii) Acquired, e.g., post viral hepatitis
(iii) Drugs (e.g., flavispidic acid, novobiocin)
(iv) Crigler - Najjar syndrome</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="conjugated-direct-hyperbilirubinaemia">Conjugated (Direct) hyperbilirubinaemia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#conjugated-direct-hyperbilirubinaemia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="1-intrahepatic-cholestasia-obstruction-which-may-be-due-to">1. Intrahepatic cholestasia (obstruction) which may be due to<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-intrahepatic-cholestasia-obstruction-which-may-be-due-to" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<p>(i) Cirrhosis (occasional)
(ii) Hepatitis (often)
(iii) Alcoholic liver disease
(iv) Drugs (e.g., chlorpromazine)
(v) Primary biliary cirrhosis</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="2-extrahepatic-obstruction-which-may-be-due-to">2. Extrahepatic obstruction which may be due to<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-extrahepatic-obstruction-which-may-be-due-to" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<p>(i) Gall stones
(ii) Carcinoma of bile duct or pancreas
(iii) Bile duct stricture
(iv) Biliary atresia</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-plasma-serum-proteins">THE PLASMA (SERUM) PROTEINS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-plasma-serum-proteins" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Primarily, a molecule of protein is made up of amino acids joined to each other by peptide bonds and sequentially arranged to form a polypeptide chain. The sequence of amino acids in the chain determines the biological properties of the protein. Specific proteins are formed by joining of amino acids by hydrogen bonds, covalent bonds, or electrostatic bonds, resulting in winding of the polypeptide chain. Some proteins have only one polypeptide chain while others may have two or more. Proteins may conjugate with a non-protein group such as a carbohydrate (-mucoprotein, glycoprotein), a nucleic acid (-nucleoprotein), a lipid (-lipoprotein) or a metal ion (-metalloprotein). Proteins are found in almost all the cells and fluids of the body. They are synthesised within the cells of the body, released in the tissue fluid, and then into the plasma.</p>
<p>Plasma proteins are a very complex mixture of proteins with diverse properties. The number and kinds of amino acids, as well as their sequence in the polypeptide chain give each plasma protein its characteristic biological function. The main plasma protein fractions are albumin, globulin and fibrinogen. Most plasma proteins are synthesised in the liver. Immunoglobulins are formed by the reticuloendothelial system and plasma cells.</p>
<p>In normal healthy individuals, the various plasma proteins are present in delicately balanced concentrations, with a normal ratio of albumin to globulin (A/G ratio). This ratio may be altered in liver diseases. Fibrinogen is absent in serum, because during coagulation the fibrinogen is converted to fibrin to form a clot. Plasma, however, is obtained from anticoagulated blood and contains fibrinogen.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="functions-of-plasma-serum-proteins">Functions of Plasma/Serum Proteins<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions-of-plasma-serum-proteins" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Transport Plasma proteins act as carrier molecules for the transport of lipids and lipid-soluble substances such as bilirubin, steroid hormones, metals, vitamins and drugs.</li>
<li>Maintenance of osmotic pressure of blood Circulating blood volume is kept constant mainly by the colloid osmotic pressure exerted by albumin.</li>
<li>Tissue repair and growth Metabolism of proteins releases amino acids which can be used either for the synthesis of new proteins or for the generation of energy.</li>
<li>Protection Gamma globulin fraction of plasma proteins is immunoglobulins which provide a defence mechanism against infection.</li>
<li>Maintenance of blood pH Plasma proteins act as bases at the normal pH of blood and help in the pH regulations.</li>
</ol>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>158 Clinical Chemistry</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="6-enzymes-and-coagulation-factors">6. Enzymes and coagulation factors<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#6-enzymes-and-coagulation-factors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Most enzymes and some coagulation factors are proteins.</p>
<p>The estimation of plasma or serum protein is of great importance in diseases affecting the liver as well as in other conditions.</p>
<p>Oedema, an excess of fluid in cells, tissue spaces and serous cavities of the body, is a result of reduced amount of protein circulating in the plasma (hypoproteinemia) which causes disturbances of water balance in the body.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="methods-of-estimating-total-serum-proteins">Methods of Estimating Total Serum Proteins<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#methods-of-estimating-total-serum-proteins" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>There are several methods of estimating total serum proteins. Some of these methods are</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="1-kjeldahl-methods">1. Kjeldahl methods<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-kjeldahl-methods" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>By boiling in the presence of sulphuric acid and a catalyst, proteins are digested. The calculation is based on estimating the amount of nitrogen released either by the use of Nessler’s reagent or by titration with standard acid. Sixteen per cent of protein is said to be nitrogen so that the result of nitrogen is multiplied by the factor 6.5. The validity of this factor has been in dispute. The Kjeldahl methods which are time-consuming and of very little value in routine use are employed extensively as reference methods.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="2-biuret-methods">2. Biuret methods<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-biuret-methods" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Protein molecules are made up of amino acids which are arranged in long chains called peptide chains; and the links joining the amino acids together are called peptide bonds. The biuret methods are based on the reaction which occurs between cupric ions in the reagent and peptide bonds of the protein molecules in an alkaline solution to form blue-violet or purple coloured complexes. The absorbance of the colour is measured in a colorimeter (yellow-green filter) or in a spectrophotometer at 540 nm. One of the many Biuret methods is described below. The methods are not ideal for measuring protein in urine or cerebrospinal fluid.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="biuret-method-for-total-proteins">Biuret Method for Total Proteins<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#biuret-method-for-total-proteins" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Alkaline pH
Proteins + Copper ions →
Protein – Copper complex (Blue-violet)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="specimen">Specimen<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#specimen" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Serum or plasma</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="reagents">Reagents<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#reagents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Biuret reagent (stock solution) Dissolve 45 g of sodium potassium tartarate in 400 ml of 0.2N (0.8%) NaOH. Dissolve and add 15 g copper sulphate, 5.0 g potassium iodide and make the volume up to 1 litre with 0.2 N NaOH.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Biuret working solution Dilute 200 ml of the stock solution to 1 litre with 0.2 N NaOH containing 5 g/L potassium iodide.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Tartarate iodide solution Dissolve 9 g sodium potassium tartarate in 1 litre of 0.2 N NaOH containing 5 g/L potassium iodide.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Standard protein Collect haemolysis-free pooled sera of healthy individuals. Determine the protein content by Kjedahl’s method. Store at 2–8°C. Alternatively, protein standard of known concentration can be obtained commercially.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>&gt; <strong>Note</strong>: 5% Bovine albumin can also be used as standard.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="method-i-set-up-five-tubes-as-follows">Method (i) Set up five tubes as follows<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#method-i-set-up-five-tubes-as-follows" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<table><thead><tr><th></th><th>Test</th><th>Test Blank</th><th>Standard</th><th>Standard Blank</th><th>Blank</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Working biuret reagent</td><td>5.0 ml</td><td>–</td><td>5.0 ml</td><td>–</td><td>5.0 ml</td></tr><tr><td>Tartarate iodide solution</td><td>–</td><td>5.0 ml</td><td>–</td><td>–</td><td>5.0 ml</td></tr><tr><td>Serum</td><td>0.05 ml</td><td>0.05 ml</td><td>–</td><td>5.0 ml</td><td>–</td></tr><tr><td>Standard</td><td>–</td><td>–</td><td>0.05 ml</td><td>0.05 ml</td><td>–</td></tr><tr><td>Distilled water</td><td>–</td><td>–</td><td>–</td><td>–</td><td>0.05 ml</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Liver Function Tests 159</p>
<p>(ii) Mix well and leave at room temperature for 10 minutes.
(iii) Read absorbance (Ab) at 540 nm (green filter), setting the zero with the blank.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="calculations">Calculations<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#calculations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Gram of serum protein/dl =</p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mtext>Ab&nbsp;Test</mtext><mo>−</mo><mtext>Ab&nbsp;Test&nbsp;Blank</mtext></mrow><mrow><mtext>Ab&nbsp;Standard</mtext><mo>−</mo><mtext>Ab&nbsp;Standard&nbsp;Blank</mtext></mrow></mfrac><mo>×</mo><mtext>concentration&nbsp;of&nbsp;standard</mtext></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\frac{\text{Ab Test} - \text{Ab Test Blank}}{\text{Ab Standard} - \text{Ab Standard Blank}} \times \text{concentration of standard}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.1408em; vertical-align: -0.7693em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3714em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Ab&nbsp;Standard</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Ab&nbsp;Standard&nbsp;Blank</span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Ab&nbsp;Test</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Ab&nbsp;Test&nbsp;Blank</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7693em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">concentration&nbsp;of&nbsp;standard</span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="estimation-of-serum-plasma-albumin">Estimation of Serum/Plasma Albumin<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#estimation-of-serum-plasma-albumin" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Bromocresol green (BCG) method Under acidic conditions, serum albumin binds specifically with bromocresol green to form a green coloured complex. The absorbance is read at 640 nm (red filter)</p>
<p><strong>Specimen</strong> Serum or plasma</p>
<p><strong>Reagent</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>BCG reagent To about 900 ml distilled water, add the following</li>
</ol>
<p>Succinic acid 8.85 g
Bromocresol green 0.108 g
Sodium azide 0.100 g
Brij-35 4.0 ml</p>
<p>Adjust pH to 4.1 using 1N NaOH.
Make the final volume up to 1 litre.</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>Albumin standard (4%) Dissolve 4.0 g of bovine albumin in 100 ml of normal saline. Add 0.1 g sodium azide as preservative.</li>
<li>Blank reagent Prepare the blank reagent in the same way as the BCG reagent, without the bromocresol green.</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>Method</strong> (i) Set up three tubes as follows:</p>
<table><thead><tr><th></th><th>Tests</th><th>Standard</th><th>Blank</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>BCG Reagent</td><td>5.0 ml</td><td>5.0 ml</td><td>—</td></tr><tr><td>Blank reagent</td><td>—</td><td>—</td><td>5.0 ml</td></tr><tr><td>Serum</td><td>0.05 ml</td><td>—</td><td>—</td></tr><tr><td>Standard</td><td>—</td><td>0.05 ml</td><td>—</td></tr><tr><td>Distilled water</td><td>—</td><td>—</td><td>0.05 ml</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>(ii) Mix well and stand at room temperature for 10 minutes.
(iii) Read absorbance at 640 nm (red filter), setting the zero with blank.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="calculations">Calculations<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#calculations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Grams of serum albumin/dl =</p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mfrac><mtext>Ab&nbsp;Test</mtext><mtext>Ab&nbsp;Standard</mtext></mfrac><mo>×</mo><mtext>concentration&nbsp;of&nbsp;Standard</mtext><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mtext>Ab&nbsp;Test</mtext><mtext>Ab&nbsp;Standard</mtext></mfrac><mo>×</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\frac{\text{Ab Test}}{\text{Ab Standard}} \times \text{concentration of Standard} = \frac{\text{Ab Test}}{\text{Ab Standard}} \times 4</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.0574em; vertical-align: -0.686em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3714em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Ab&nbsp;Standard</span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Ab&nbsp;Test</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.686em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">concentration&nbsp;of&nbsp;Standard</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.0574em; vertical-align: -0.686em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3714em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Ab&nbsp;Standard</span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Ab&nbsp;Test</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.686em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">4</span></span></span></span></span></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="estimation-of-serum-plasma-globulin">Estimation of Serum/Plasma Globulin<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#estimation-of-serum-plasma-globulin" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Serum globulin is estimated indirectly by subtracting the albumin concentration from total protein concentration.</p>
<p>Serum globulin (g/dl) = Total protein (g/dl) - Serum albumin (g/dl)</p>
<p><strong>Albumin/globulin (A/G) ratio</strong></p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mfrac><mtext>A/G&nbsp;ratio</mtext><mrow></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mtext>Serum&nbsp;albumin&nbsp;g/dl</mtext><mtext>Serum&nbsp;globulin&nbsp;g/dl</mtext></mfrac></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\frac{\text{A/G ratio}}{} = \frac{\text{Serum albumin g/dl}}{\text{Serum globulin g/dl}}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.113em; vertical-align: -0.686em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.427em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">A/G&nbsp;ratio</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.686em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.363em;
