vertical-align: -0.686em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3214em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">30</span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">2000</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.686em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.1408em; vertical-align: -0.7693em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3714em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Ab.&nbsp;Standard</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Ab.&nbsp;Blank</span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Ab.&nbsp;Test</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Ab.&nbsp;Blank</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7693em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">66.7</span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p><strong>Note</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Patient should not undertake any strenuous exercise before collection of blood.</li>
<li>CPK activity is increased even after a minor tissue trauma.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5290523a">Normal range at 30°C<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5290523a" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>5–50 IU/litre (men)
5–30 IU/litre (women)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="method">Method<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#method" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Prepare three tubes as follows:</p>
<table><thead><tr><th></th><th>Test</th><th>Standard</th><th>Blank</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Creatine phosphate</td><td>0.4 ml</td><td>0.4 ml</td><td>0.4 ml</td></tr><tr><td>Serum</td><td>0.05 ml</td><td>—</td><td>—</td></tr><tr><td>Distilled water</td><td>—</td><td>—</td><td>0.05 ml</td></tr><tr><td>ADP</td><td>0.2 ml</td><td>0.2 ml</td><td>0.2 ml</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>Mix and incubate at 37°C for 30 minutes</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Creatine standard</td><td>—</td><td>0.05 ml</td><td>—</td></tr><tr><td>p-chloromercuric benzoic acid</td><td>0.5 ml</td><td>0.5 ml</td><td>0.5 ml</td></tr><tr><td>Alkaline EDTA</td><td>3.75 ml</td><td>3.75 ml</td><td>3.75 ml</td></tr><tr><td>α-naphthol</td><td>1.0 ml</td><td>1.0 ml</td><td>1.0 ml</td></tr><tr><td>Diacetyl (working reagent)</td><td>0.5 ml</td><td>0.5 ml</td><td>0.5 ml</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Mix and keep in the dark for 30 minutes at room temperature.</p>
<p>Read the absorbance at 520 nm (green filter)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="be148ed4">♦ AMINOTRANSFERASES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#be148ed4" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The two enzymes concerned with amino acid metabolism are the aspartate aminotransferase (AST)</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Enzymology 171</p>
<p>which was previously referred to as glutamate oxalacetate transaminase (GOT), and the alanine aminotransferase (ALT) also formerly called glutamate pyruvate transaminase (GPT). AST is found in the liver, kidneys, cardiac muscles and skeletal muscles in large amounts while small amounts can be found in brain, pancreas and lungs. ALT on the other hand is found mainly in the liver with only very small amount in other organs.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="measurement-of-serum-or-plasma-ast-sgot-and-alt-sgpt">Measurement of Serum or Plasma AST (SGOT) and ALT (SGPT)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#measurement-of-serum-or-plasma-ast-sgot-and-alt-sgpt" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>(The colorimetric method of Reitman and Frankel)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="method-for-ast-got">Method for AST (GOT)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#method-for-ast-got" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>AST
Aspartate + Ketoglutarate <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>⟷</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\longleftrightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.522em; vertical-align: -0.011em;"></span><span class="mrel">⟷</span></span></span></span></span> Glutamate + Oxalacetate</p>
<p>Oxaloacetate + 2, 4 dinitrophenylhydrazine
Alkaline pH <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span> 2, 4 dinitrophenylhydrazone (Red brown)</p>
<p>When AST is incubated at 37°C for exactly 60 minutes in a pH 7.5 buffered substrate containing</p>
<ol>
<li>Label 5 tubes, B (Blank) and 1-4.
Add reagents accurately into each as follows:</li>
</ol>
<table><thead><tr><th>Tube</th><th>Substrate</th><th>Pyruvate</th><th>AST U/L</th><th>ALT U/L</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>B</td><td>0.50 ml</td><td>-</td><td>0.00</td><td>0.00</td></tr><tr><td>1</td><td>0.45 ml</td><td>0.05 ml</td><td>11.5 (24)</td><td>13.4 (28)</td></tr><tr><td>2</td><td>0.40 ml</td><td>0.10 ml</td><td>29.3 (61)</td><td>27.4 (57)</td></tr><tr><td>3</td><td>0.35 ml</td><td>0.15 ml</td><td>54.7 (114)</td><td>46.6 (97)</td></tr><tr><td>4</td><td>0.30 ml</td><td>0.20 ml</td><td>91.2 (190)</td><td>72.0 (150)</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>aspartate and 2-Ketoglutarate, it catalyses the transfer of the amino acid group from aspartate to ketoglutarate, forming oxaloacetate and glutamate. The oxaloacetate reacts with 2,4 dinitrophenylhydrazine to form 2,4, dinitrophenylhydrazone, which in alkaline pH is red-brown. The absorbance of the colour produced is measured in a colorimeter at 505 nm (blue-green filter).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="calibration-curve">Calibration curve<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#calibration-curve" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>The AST method is calibrated from the pyruvate standard.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="reagents">Reagents<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#reagents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Phosphate buffer, pH 7.4, 0.1 M</li>
</ol>
<p>(a) M/15 Disodium hydrogen phosphate: Dissolve 11.88 g per litre distilled water.
(b) M/15 Potassium dihydrogen phosphate: Dissolve 9.08 g per litre distilled water.</p>
<p>Mix 840 ml of (a) and 160 ml of (b)</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>
<p>Substrate for AST Dissolve 0.3 g of L-aspartic acid and 50 mg α-ketoglutaric acid in about 20–30 ml of the phosphate buffer. Add 10% NaOH dropwise (about 1.1 ml) to bring the pH to 7.4. Make up to 100 ml with the phosphate buffer. Keep at 2–8°C with a few drops of chloroform. Store as long as the solution is clear.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Dinitrophenylhydrazine (DNPH) reagent Dissolve 200 mg of 2–4 DNPH in 85 ml of conc. HCl. Make up to a litre with distilled water.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>0.4 N sodium hydroxide.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Pyruvate standard Dissolve 22 mg of sodium pyruvate in 100 ml of distilled water. This is equivalent to 2 μmol/L of pyruvic acid.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<table><thead><tr><th><strong>Note</strong></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>1. The numbers in the bracket indicate Karmen units</td></tr><tr><td>2. 1.0 Karmen unit/ml is equivalent to 0.48 U/L</td></tr></tbody></table>
<ol start="2">
<li>Add 0.1 ml of distilled water to each tube and mix well.</li>
</ol>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>172 Clinical Chemistry</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>Add 0.5 ml of DNPH reagent to each tube mix well.</li>
<li>Leave at room temperature for 20 minutes for colour development.</li>
<li>Add 5 ml of 0.4 N sodium hydroxide solution to each tube. Mix well.</li>
<li>Leave at room temperature for 5 minutes</li>
<li>Read the absorbance of the pyruvate standard solutions at 505 nm (blue-green filter). Zero the instrument with the blank solution B.</li>
<li>On a sheet of graph paper, plot the absorbance of each standard solution (vertical axis) against its AST (GOT) activity (horizontal axis). Express in international units per litre (U/L)</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>Note</strong>
A new calibration curve should be prepared and checked against control sera every 2 months or whenever new reagents are introduced.</p>
<p>Determine the enzyme activity from the calibration curve.</p>
<p><strong>Normal values</strong> 7–21 Units/L (adults)
For abnormally high results, repeat the test using a 10 minute incubation time instead of 60 minutes and then multiply the result by six.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="interpretation">Interpretation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#interpretation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Very high level of AST is associated with acute hepatocellular damage, myocardial infarction, circulatory collapse (shock) and infectious mononucleosis. Moderately high results are obtained in cases of biliary tract obstruction, congestive heart failure, tumour in the liver, while mildly high values are seen in cases of severe bacterial infections, malaria, liver cirrhosis, pericarditis, cerebrovascular injury and some muscle disorders.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="method-for-alt-gpt">Method for ALT (GPT)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#method-for-alt-gpt" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="principle">Principle<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#principle" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Alanine + α-ketoglutarate <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>⇌</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightleftharpoons</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.682em; vertical-align: -0.011em;"></span><span class="mrel">⇌</span></span></span></span></span> Pyruvate + 1-glutamate</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="test-method-for-ast-got">Test method for AST (GOT)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#test-method-for-ast-got" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Set up two tubes as follows:</p>
<table><thead><tr><th></th><th>Test</th><th>Control</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Buffered substrate</td><td>0.5 ml</td><td>0.5 ml</td></tr><tr><td>Incubate at 37°C for 3 minutes</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Serum</td><td>0.1 ml</td><td>-</td></tr><tr><td>Incubate at 37°C for 60 minutes</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Serum</td><td>-</td><td>0.1 ml</td></tr><tr><td>DNPH</td><td>0.5 ml</td><td>0.5 ml</td></tr><tr><td>Incubate at room temperature for 20 minutes</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>0.4 N NaOH</td><td>5.0 ml</td><td>5.0 ml</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Stand at room temperature for 5–10 minutes. Read absorbance at 505 nm (yellow-green filter).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="enzyme-activity">Enzyme activity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#enzyme-activity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Pyruvate formed due to enzyme activity = Absorbance of Test – Absorbance of Control.</p>
<p>Pyruvate + DNPH → Pyruvate
dinitrophenylhydrazone</p>
<p>Alanine aminotransferase (ALT) catalyses the transfer of amino group between 1-alanine and</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Enzymology 173</p>
<p>1-glutamate; the corresponding α-Keto acids in this process are α-ketoglutarate and pyruvate.</p>
<p>The Reitman-Frankel method involves the measurement of ALT activity in the same way as that of AST, by conversion of the reaction product, pyruvate, to the red brown hydrazone after reaction with DNPH.</p>
<p>The absorbance of the red-brown colour produced is measured at 505 nm (blue-green filter).</p>
<p><strong>Method</strong> ALT is estimated in the same way as the AST except that it uses alanine as the substrate, and the incubation period is 30 minutes instead of 60 minutes. Use the calibration curve for the estimation of activity.</p>
<p><strong>Buffered alanine substrate for ALT</strong> Dissolve 5 g of D-L alanine and 20 mg α-ketoglutaric acid in 20–30 ml of phosphate buffer. Add 10% NaOH drop by drop (about 0.5 ml) till the pH is 7.4. Keep at 2–8°C with a few drops of chloroform.</p>
<p><strong>Normal values</strong> 6–21 U/L</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="interpretation">Interpretation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#interpretation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Tissues such as liver, kidney, heart, skeletal muscle and pancreas are rich in ALT.</p>
<p>Very high results are obtained in cases of liver necrosis and acute hepatitis. Moderately high results are seen in myocardial infarction, obstructive jaundice, chronic hepatitis, liver cirrhosis and infectious mononucleosis; and mildly high values are obtained in pancreatitis, alcoholic fatty liver and neoplastic liver diseases.</p>
<p>Table 6.1 shows enzyme levels in various liver diseases.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="bf6d543f">γ-GLUTAMYL TRANSFERASE (GGT)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bf6d543f" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>α-Glutamyl transferase (GGT) is the enzyme which catalyses the transfer of α-glutamyl group from peptides to water, amino acids or another peptide.</p>
<p>The enzyme is present in large amounts in the kidneys, followed by liver, pancreas and prostate. The other tissues contain negligible amounts of the enzyme.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="estimation-of-ggt-in-serum">Estimation of GGT in Serum<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#estimation-of-ggt-in-serum" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Principle</strong> The enzyme GGT transfers a γ-glutamyl group from the substrate L-γ-glutamyl-4-nitroaniline to glycylglycine at pH 7.8</p>
<p>L-γ-glutamyl-4-nitroaniline + glycylglycine</p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><munder accentunder="true"><munder accentunder="true"><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">G</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">G</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="true">‾</mo></munder><mo stretchy="true">‾</mo></munder><mo>→</mo><mn>4</mn><mtext>-nitroaniline</mtext><mo>+</mo><mi>γ</mi><mtext>-glutamylglycylglycine</mtext></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\underline{\underline{\mathrm{GGT}}} \rightarrow 4\text{-nitroaniline} + \gamma\text{-glutamyl} \text{glycylglycine}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0833em; vertical-align: -0.4em;"></span><span class="mord underline"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6833em;"><span style="top: -2.64em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="underline-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord underline"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6833em;"><span style="top: -2.84em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="underline-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">GGT</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.2em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.4em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7778em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">4</span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">-nitroaniline</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">+</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05556em;">γ</span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">-glutamyl</span></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">glycylglycine</span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p>At 405 nm (violet filter), the absorbance of the substrate is minimum while that of the product is maximum.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="reagents">Reagents<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#reagents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li><strong>Buffer</strong> Dissolve 14.54 g tris, 2.44 g magnesium chloride (MgCl₂·6H₂O) and 11.9 g glycylglycine in about 800 ml of distilled water. Adjust the pH to 7.8</li>
</ol>
<p>Table 6.1 Serum enzyme levels in various liver diseases</p>
<p>|  Condition | ALT
U/L | AST
U/L | LDH
U/L | ALP
U/L  |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
|  Normal values | 6–21 | 6–21 | 95–300 | 21–92  |
|  Acute viral hepatitis | &gt; 300 | &gt; 300 | &gt;800 | &gt; 100  |
|  Obstructive jaundice | &gt; 60 | &gt; 60 | &gt; 400 | &gt; 300  |
|  Cirrhosis of liver | &gt; 40 | &gt; 40 | &gt; 400 | &gt; 100  |
|  Secondary deposits in liver
(non-jaundice) | &gt; 20 | &gt; 20 | &gt; 300 | &gt; 150  |</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>174 Clinical Chemistry</p>
<p>and dilute to 1 litre with distilled water. Keep at 4°C (2 months).</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>Substrate Dissolve 1.28 g L-γ-glutamyl-4-nitroaniline (anhydrous) in 100 ml of 0.15 N HCl. Stir constantly till soluble.</li>
</ol>
<p>Dispense in small aliquots and store at –20°C or prepare fresh every day.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="method">Method<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#method" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>In a cuvette, mix 1.0 ml buffer and 0.1 ml serum
Incubate at 37°C for 5 minutes
Add 0.1 ml substrate and mix well.
Read the absorbance at 405 nm (violet filter) at the end of each minute for 5 minutes.
Calculate the average change in absorbance per minute.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="calculation">Calculation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#calculation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Serum GGT (IU/L) =</p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mtext>Absorbance</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mi>min</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo>×</mo><mfrac><mn>1000</mn><mn>0.1</mn></mfrac><mo>×</mo><mfrac><mn>1.2</mn><mn>9.9</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mtext>Absorbance</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mi>min</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo>×</mo><mn>1212</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\text{Absorbance} / \min \times \frac{1000}{0.1} \times \frac{1.2}{9.9} = \text{Absorbance} / \min \times 1212</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.0074em; vertical-align: -0.686em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Absorbance</span></span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mop">min</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord">×</span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3214em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0.1</span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">1000</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.686em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.0074em; vertical-align: -0.686em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3214em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">9.9</span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">1.2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.686em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Absorbance</span></span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mop">min</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord">×</span><span class="mord">1212</span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p>where 9.9 is the absorption coefficient of 4-nitroaniline at 405 nm, 1.2 ml is the final volume in the cuvette, and 0.1 ml is the volume of serum used.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="normal-values">Normal values<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#normal-values" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Serum GGT = 4–20 IU/L (men) and 4–13 IU/L (women).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="clinical-significance">Clinical significance<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#clinical-significance" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Serum GGT is a sensitive indicator of liver disease. Increased levels are observed in all types of liver diseases, and therefore, it does not help in the differential diagnosis of hepatic diseases. High values are seen in alcoholism, and liver cancer. GGT levels may also increase in acute pancreatitis, carcinoma, myocardial infarction and congestive heart failure.</p>
<p>Renal disorders do not cause increase in the serum GGT levels. Urinary GGT may increase.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="isoenzymes">ISOENZYMES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#isoenzymes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>An enzyme that is produced by more than one type of tissue can be separated by physical and chemical means into its isoenzymes - groups of proteins showing similar catalytic activity.</p>
<p>The commonly measured isoenzymes are given in Table 6.2.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="table-6-2-commonly-measured-isoenzymes">Table 6.2 Commonly measured isoenzymes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#table-6-2-commonly-measured-isoenzymes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<table><thead><tr><th>Enzymes</th><th>Isoenzymes</th><th>Most important organ of origin</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Creatine kinase</td><td>BB</td><td>Brain</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>MB</td><td>Heart muscle</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>MM</td><td>Skeletal muscle</td></tr><tr><td>Alkaline phosphatase</td><td>B</td><td>Bone</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>L</td><td>Liver</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>T</td><td>Intestine</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>P</td><td>Placenta</td></tr><tr><td>Lactate dehydrogenase</td><td>LD1</td><td>Heart</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>LD2</td><td>Kidney</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>LD3</td><td>Spleen</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>LD4</td><td>Small amount in most tissues</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>LD5</td><td>Liver</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="separation-and-differentiation-methods-for-isoenzymes">Separation and Differentiation Methods for Isoenzymes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#separation-and-differentiation-methods-for-isoenzymes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>There are several methods that can be employed to separate various isoenzymes. Some of these methods are:</p>
<ol>
<li>Electrophoresis The cellulose acetate or polyacrylamide electrophoresis can be used to separate isoenzymes of creatine kinase and alkaline phosphatase.</li>
</ol>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Enzymology 175</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-chromatography-on-deae-cellulose">2. Chromatography on DEAE-cellulose<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-chromatography-on-deae-cellulose" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Sometimes it is used for creatine kinase.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="3-heat-stability">3. Heat stability<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-heat-stability" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>When heated at 56°C for 30 minutes alkaline phosphatase from placenta is distinguished from that of liver and bone. The former is heat stable and the latter is heat labile.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="4-inhibition">4. Inhibition<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#4-inhibition" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>L-phenylamine is capable of inhibiting intestinal and placental alkaline phosphatase when other isoenzymes are not affected. Urea can also be used to inhibit the liver component.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-substrate">5. Substrate<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-substrate" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The specificity of substrate in relation to enzymatic reaction is used to separate isoenzymes. The reaction</p>
<p>Oxobutyrate + NADH₂ ⇌ α-hydroxybutyrate + NAD</p>
<p>will be more catalysed by LD1 than by LD2–5. Thus the use of α-Oxobutyrate as a substrate separates LD1 from the other isoenzymes.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="6-immunological-approach">6. Immunological approach<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#6-immunological-approach" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is a very useful tool for measuring loss of enzyme activity. It depends on antibodies to the enzymes which will prevent catalytic activity. For example, antibody to an isoenzyme will prevent a reaction due to that isoenzyme, thus enabling loss of activity to be measured.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="diagnostic-enzyme-activity">Diagnostic Enzyme Activity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#diagnostic-enzyme-activity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="myocardial-infarction">Myocardial infarction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#myocardial-infarction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>The diagnosis of this condition can be made on the basis of the changes in serum CPK, ALT (GOT) and LDH. Within 4–6 hours of infarction, CPK activity rises rapidly and reaches a peak at 24–36 hours. The ALT levels begin to rise too and peak at 2–3 days. LDH levels, slower to rise, peak at 2–3 days but stay high for over 10 days. Diagnosis and prognosis of an infarction can be established based on a daily estimation of these enzymes for 3 days following an episode of possible infarction.</p>
<p>A more accurate and quicker way of establishing diagnosis of infarction is to perform electrophoretic separation of combined LDH and CPK isoenzymes. The 3 days daily test is thus eliminated.</p>
<p>CPK and ALT levels remain more or less normal under other chest dysfunctions such as pneumonia, or pulmonary infarction but LDH level may rise and isoenzyme patterns may become a diagnostic tool.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="liver-diseases">Liver diseases<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#liver-diseases" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Enzyme levels are good indicators of any kind of hepatic malfunction though they may not always help in differential diagnosis. Table 6.1 shows expected enzyme levels in various liver diseases.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Chapter 7</p>
<p>Electrolytes and Blood Gases</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="electrolytes">ELECTROLYTES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#electrolytes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Electrolytes are compounds which when dissolved or melted, will conduct electricity. They form positively charged ions (cations) and negatively charged ions (anions). Electrolytes help to maintain the stability of body fluids. The electrolytes found in the body fluid include:</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="major-cations">Major cations<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#major-cations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Sodium (Na⁺)</li>
<li>Potassium (K⁺)</li>
<li>Magnesium (Mg²⁺)</li>
<li>Calcium (Ca²⁺)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="major-anions">Major anions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#major-anions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Chloride (Cl⁻)</li>
<li>Bicarbonate (HCO₃⁻)</li>
<li>Phosphate (PO₄³⁻)</li>
<li>Sulphate (SO₄²⁻)</li>
</ul>
<p>Usually sodium, potassium and (chlorides) are the electrolytes most frequently requested by the clinicians. A balanced proportion of cations and anions is essential for the maintenance of electrical neutrality in the body.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="functions-of-sodium-and-potassium">Functions of sodium and potassium:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions-of-sodium-and-potassium" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Sodium keeps the correct water balance in the body fluids. Sodium and potassium are useful for heart and other muscle activity.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="water-balance">Water Balance<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#water-balance" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The total volume of fluid in a normal adult is roughly 42 litres, 60% of which is water while the total volume of fluid in a normal infant is about 2 litres, and 70% of which is water.</p>
<p>Fluid which is found in the cells of the body is referred to as intracellular fluid while the fluid found in the spaces between the cells of the body is extracellular fluid. Plasma, which is the fluid part of blood and found in the blood vessels, is referred to as intravascular fluid. A selective permeable membrane separates the intracellular fluid from the extracellular fluid. Through this membrane, water, electrolytes, glucose, urea and amino acid filter to maintain the fluid balance.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="intracellular-fluid">Intracellular fluid<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#intracellular-fluid" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>It makes up about 28 litres of the body’s fluid in an adult and about 1 litre in an infant. It has the following electrolytes:</p>
<ul>
<li><strong>Cations</strong> The main cations are potassium and magnesium while calcium and sodium are in low concentrations.</li>
<li><strong>Anions</strong> The main anions are protein, phosphate with chloride, bicarbonate, sulphate and organic acids in low concentrations.</li>
<li><strong>Intravascular fluid (plasma)</strong> It is about 3–3.5 litres in an adult and about 250 ml in an infant. It consists of the following electrolytes:</li>
</ul>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Electrolytes and Blood Gases 177</p>
<p>Cations High concentration of sodium and low concentrations of potassium, calcium and magnesium.</p>
<p>Anions High concentration of chloride and lower concentrations of bicarbonate, inorganic acids, phosphate and sulphate. Ionisation of protein as anion occurs at pH 7.4.</p>
<p>Extracellular fluid It is composed of lymph, cerebrospinal fluid, pleural fluid, saliva, synovial fluid, amniotic fluid and aqueous humour and constitutes about 11 litres of fluid in adult and about 1 litre in an infant. It serves as a vehicle through which water, electrolytes, oxygen and nutritional substances pass from cell to plasma. It also prevents the cells from being directly affected by any alterations in plasma.</p>
<p>The total water intake is equal to total water output. The body's supply of water is through fluid drink, water in food and water from metabolic activity while the body's loss of water is though urine, faeces, sweat and expired air.</p>
<p>The maintenance of correct water distribution between the various body fluid components is very necessary for health and is made possible by the regulation of intra- and extra cellular electrolyte concentration.</p>
<p>Laboratory tests to investigate acid-base (electrolyte) disorders include the measurement of blood pH, carbon dioxide as <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{PCO}_2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">PCO</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> and bicarbonate. A blood gas analyser is used to measure the pH and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{PCO}_2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">PCO</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> and from these two, the bicarbonate can be calculated.</p>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{PCO}_2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> is the partial pressure (PI) of carbon dioxide in the gas phase in equilibrium with dissolved <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{CO}_2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">CO</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>. It is measured in kPa (SI units) or mmHg (non SI units).</p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn><mtext>&nbsp;kilopascal</mtext><mo>=</mo><mn>1000</mn><mtext>&nbsp;pascal</mtext><mo>=</mo><mn>7.5</mn><mtext>&nbsp;mm&nbsp;Hg</mtext></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{kPa} = 1 \text{ kilopascal} = 1000 \text{ pascal} = 7.5 \text{ mm Hg}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">kPa</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">&nbsp;kilopascal</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">1000</span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">&nbsp;pascal</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8778em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">7.5</span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">&nbsp;mm&nbsp;Hg</span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p>The pascal is the SI derived unit of pressure and it is equal to Newton per <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{m}^2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">m</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>.</p>
<p>Standard bicarbonate is the amount of bicarbonate in plasma after the blood has been fully oxygenated and equilibrated to <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{PCO}_2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">PCO</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> pf <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>3.3</mn><mtext> </mtext><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">3.3\,\mathrm{kPa}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord">3.3</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">kPa</span></span></span></span></span></span> (40 mm Hg) at <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>37</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∘</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">37^{\circ}\mathrm{C}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">3</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">7</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∘</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">C</span></span></span></span></span> before separation of the plasma. The measurements are expressed in mmol/L.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="measurement-of-sodium-and-potassium">MEASUREMENT OF SODIUM AND POTASSIUM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#measurement-of-sodium-and-potassium" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>There are three main techniques for measuring sodium and potassium in serum or plasma:</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Flame emission spectrometry This method makes use of a flame photometer. It is very reliable and the most popular method for routine investigations for sodium and potassium. The working and principle of photometry is discussed below.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Ion selective electrode (ISE) This is an ion analyser which measures the activity of sodium and potassium ions in mmol/L. It is expensive but reliable, quick and convenient.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Solid phase or dry reagent technique This technique involves the use of sodium and potassium slides and a reflectance meter to measure the concentration of sodium and potassium in mmol/L. This method is automated.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-flame-photometer">The Flame Photometer<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-flame-photometer" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>There are two methods of flame photometry—the emission and the atomic absorption. For routine sodium and potassium measurement the emission flame photometry is a method of choice.</p>
<p>Principle Using compressed air, diluted serum or plasma is sprayed as fine droplets into a non-luminous gas flame which becomes coloured by the characteristic emission of sodium or potassium metallic ions in the sample. Using a light filter or prism system, the light of wavelength corresponding to the metal being estimated, is selected. The amount of light emitted depends on the concentration of metallic ions present in the sample.</p>
<p>Some flame photometers make use of an internal lithium standard. The serum is diluted in a diluent that contains constant amount of lithium. The energy emitted in the flame by sodium or potassium is compared with the output from the lithium, thus enabling the sodium or potassium concentration to be calculated.</p>
<p>The basic component of a flame photometer are as follows:</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>178 Clinical Chemistry</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p><strong>Nebuliser</strong> It is a mechanism of mixing the sample with air and spraying it to the burner at a constant rate as a fine spray.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Mixing chamber with baffles</strong> The atomised sample and fuel are mixed in the mixing chamber. The baffles deflect any large droplets to waste while small droplets are allowed to get through to the flame.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Burner</strong> This is the means of reducing the metal to the atomic state, and exciting the atoms to emit light. The gas and air pressures have to be carefully controlled in order to maintain a steady blue flame.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Photosensitive element</strong> This is the means of detecting and recording the intensity of light emitted. A diode is used to convert the emitted light into an electric current.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Wavelength selector</strong> This is a device of selecting the wavelength of the emission to be measured. A lens focusses the light from the flame and a narrow band filter selects the wavelength.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>There are various models of flame photometer but the basic principle is the same. Figure 7.1 shows the working principle of a flame photometer. A typical system works as follows:</p>
<p>The sample and the standard are diluted manually or by a peristaltic pump which is part of the instrument. The diluent contains lithium. The diluted sample is drawn through a capillary tube by a stream of air supplied by a compressor. The current causes the sample to be split into a haze of tiny droplets (nebulisation). Large droplets fall to the bottom of the nebulising chamber and go to waste (drain). The remaining haze of small even-sized droplets is mixed with propane. The mixture, on passing through a baffle plate, the fuel, air stream is ignited and burns, thus converting the metals present to their atomic form.</p>
<p>Light from the flame is measured at appropriate wavelengths by the photodetector. The signals from sodium and potassium are compared with that from lithium, the concentration of which is constant. Any changes in the signal due to fluctuations in the flame are compensated for by a similar change in the lithium channel. The results are shown simultaneously on a digital display panel and are printed to provide a permanent record.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-d5b12e0f.jpeg" alt="img-51.jpeg">
Fig. 7.1 Working principle of a flame photometer</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Electrolytes and Blood Gases 179</p>
<p>Note</p>
<p>Flame The gas pressure and air pressure must be carefully regulated so as to give a constant steady flame which should be blue. Gases such as acetylene, propane, butane or coal gas can be used.</p>
<p>Nebulisation The rate of sampling should be constant. The chamber and capillary tube should always be clean and should be adequately washed after each use.</p>
<p>Standards When carrying out a series of determinations, insert an appropriate standard solution at frequent intervals to ensure consistency in reading. Never introduce a suction probe directly into a storage bottle as it will contaminate the standard solution. For instruments with built-in diluters, use standards which have the same viscosity as plasma or serum. Where an internal reference is used, standards and samples are diluted in a solution containing 15 mmol/litre of lithium nitrate.</p>
<p>Method</p>
<p>Step I: Preparation of standard solutions The most satisfactory dilution to use in the analysis should be established carefully. Modern instruments however give a linear response to sodium and potassium over physiological ranges. Usually plasma (or serum) is measured against a standard with 140 mmol/litre sodium and 5 mmol/litre potassium. Urines are usually analysed using a standard with 100 mmol/litre of each. It is however suggested to check this linearity of response at least once a month with standards of 120/2 and 160/8 mmol/litre sodium and potassium respectively.</p>
<p>Standard solutions are prepared as follows:</p>
<p>(a) Stock sodium standard (1.0M): 58.45 g sodium chloride dissolved in distilled water and made up to 1 litre.
(b) Stock potassium standard (1.0M): 74.55 g potassium chloride dissolved in distilled water and made up to 1 litre.</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>Mix well.</li>
<li>Switch on the air compressor and adjust the</li>
</ol>
<p>A series of stock standard solutions are made from these as follows:</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Std. No.</th><th>Sodium/potassium mmol/litre</th><th>Sodium stock Std. ml</th><th>Potassium stock Std. ml</th><th>Distilled water ml</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>1</td><td>120/2</td><td>120</td><td>2</td><td>878</td></tr><tr><td>2</td><td>140/5</td><td>140</td><td>5</td><td>855</td></tr><tr><td>3</td><td>160/8</td><td>160</td><td>8</td><td>832</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>These standards are treated the same way as test samples.</p>
<p>Step II: Estimation of sodium and potassium</p>
<ol>
<li>Set up 4 tubes as follows:</li>
</ol>
<table><thead><tr><th></th><th>Test</th><th>Std. 1</th><th>Std. 2</th><th>Std. 3</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Deionised water</td><td>10 ml</td><td>10 ml</td><td>10 ml</td><td>10 ml</td></tr><tr><td>Serum/plasma</td><td>0.1 ml</td><td>-</td><td>-</td><td>-</td></tr><tr><td>Standard 1</td><td>-</td><td>0.1 ml</td><td>-</td><td>-</td></tr><tr><td>Standard 2</td><td>-</td><td>-</td><td>0.1 ml</td><td>-</td></tr><tr><td>Standard 3</td><td>-</td><td>-</td><td>-</td><td>0.1 ml</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>180 Clinical Chemistry</p>
<p>air pressure.</p>
<ol start="4">
<li>Introduce deionised water through the atomiser.</li>
<li>Turn on the gas and adjust the flame to give fine sharp cones.</li>
<li>Place appropriate filters for simultaneous sodium and potassium estimation.</li>
<li>Set the zero with deionised water.</li>
<li>Introduce standard 1 (120/2) and adjust 120.0 for sodium and 2.0 for potassium.</li>
<li>Check that the standards 2 and 3 display the exact concentrations for both sodium and potassium.</li>
<li>Introduce the diluted test serum and note the readings for sodium and potassium</li>
</ol>
<p>&gt; <strong>Note</strong>
&gt; A blood sample left to stand for more than 4 hours prior to plasma or serum separation is unsuitable for estimation of electrolytes due to leakage of electrolytes, especially potassium from red cells.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="normal-values">Normal values<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#normal-values" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Serum sodium : 135–146 mmol/L
Serum potassium : 3.5–5.2 mmol/L</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="clinical-significance">Clinical Significance<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#clinical-significance" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Hyponatraemia (low sodium levels)</strong> Hyponatraemia can be either due to fluid loss with electrolytes or due to dilutional state. The most common causes of hyponatraemia are salt-losing nephritis, cirrhosis, gastrointestinal fluid loss, excessive sweating, adrenal insufficiency, burns, congestive heart failure and diuretic drugs.</p>
<p><strong>Hypernatraemia (high sodium levels)</strong> Hypernatraemia is not very common. It may be due to excessive sodium intake either by mouth or by intravenous infusion. It may also occur following sodium retention due to intrinsic renal disease or inadequate renal perfusion.</p>
<p><strong>Hypokalaemia (low potassium levels)</strong> Hypokalaemia usually indicates severe depletion of potassium. It can be due to decreased dietary intake, chronic alcoholism, chronic diarrhoea, renal disorders such as renal tubular acidosis, leukaemia, insulin therapy or hypersecretion and due to drugs such as gentamicin.</p>
<p><strong>Hyperkalaemia (increased potassium levels)</strong> Hyperkalaemia can be due to insulin deficiency, severe renal failure, ketoacidosis and systemic lupus erythematosus.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="estimation-of-sodium-and-potassium-in-urine">Estimation of Sodium and Potassium in Urine<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#estimation-of-sodium-and-potassium-in-urine" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The same method as for plasma can be used for urine. The most ideal dilution of each urine has to be established experimentally. This is because of the wide variations in concentration. The concentration of potassium in urine is usually higher than in serum or plasma.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="serum-plasma-chloride">SERUM/PLASMA CHLORIDE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#serum-plasma-chloride" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Chloride is a major extracellular anion and occurs in the body mainly as sodium chloride. It helps to maintain proper water distribution, osmotic pressure and acid-base balance in the extracellular fluid of the body.</p>
<p>There are many methods available for the estimation of plasma chloride. Two methods are described below.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="mercuric-nitrate-or-schales-and-schales-method">Mercuric Nitrate (or Schales and Schales) Method<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mercuric-nitrate-or-schales-and-schales-method" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="principle">Principle<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#principle" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>This method involves titrating Cl⁻ ions with HCl⁺ ions, forming soluble but non-ionised mercuric chloride. The endpoint is reached when excess Hg⁺⁺ forms a complex with an indicator such as diphenylcarbazone producing a pale violet colour.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="reagents">Reagents<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#reagents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Mercuric nitrate Dissolve 3.0 g mercuric nitrate [Hg(NO₃)₂] in 500 ml of distilled water. Add 20 ml of 2 M HNO₃ and make up to 1 litre with distilled water.</li>
</ol>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Electrolytes and Blood Gases 181</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>
<p>Standard chloride Dissolve 0.585 g of NaCl in about 50 ml of distilled water and make up to 1 litre with distilled water. This gives a solution of 10 mmol/litre.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Indicator Dissolve 0.5 g diphenylcarbazone in 50 ml of 95% ethanol. Store in the dark at 4°C.</p>
</li>
