<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="estimation-of-serum-inorganic-phosphate">Estimation of Serum inorganic Phosphate<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#estimation-of-serum-inorganic-phosphate" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Principle</strong> When a protein-free filtrate obtained with trichloroacetic acid (TCA) is treated with an acid phosphomolybdate reagent, it reacts with inorganic phosphate to form phosphomolybdic acid. This acid is reduced by the colour reagent metol to form a blue complex. The intensity of the colour is read colorimetrically at 680 nm (red filter).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="reagents">Reagents<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#reagents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li><strong>Trichloroacetic acid (TCA)</strong>: Dissolve 100 g of TCA in one litre distilled water.</li>
<li><strong>Sulphuric acid (5 mol/L)</strong>: Add 450 ml of concentrated H₂SO₄ slowly while cooling to 1300 ml of distilled water. Dilute 1 ml of the solution to 10 ml with distilled water and titrate with 1 mol/L NaOH. Make necessary adjustments to the bulk solution.</li>
<li><strong>Ammonium molybdate</strong>: Dissolve 7.5 g in about 200 ml of distilled water, add 100 ml of the 5 mol/L H₂SO₄ and make up to 400 ml with water.</li>
<li><strong>Metol (p-methylaminophenol sulphate) solution</strong>: Dissolve 1 g in 100 ml of 3% sodium bisulphate solution.</li>
<li><strong>Stock standard phosphate (20 mmol/L)</strong>: Dissolve 1.36 g potassium dihydrogen phosphate (KH₂PO₄) in about 300 ml distilled water. Make up to 500 ml.</li>
<li><strong>Working standard phosphate (2 mmol/L)</strong>: Dilute the stock standard 1:10 with distilled water.</li>
</ol>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Electrolytes and Blood Gases 187</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="method">Method<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#method" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Add 0.8 ml of serum to 7.2 ml TCA. Mix well and filter or centrifuge.</li>
<li>Set up three tubes as follows:</li>
</ol>
<table><thead><tr><th></th><th>Test</th><th>Standard</th><th>Blank</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Protein free filtrate of serum</td><td>5.0 ml</td><td>-</td><td>-</td></tr><tr><td>Working standard phosphate</td><td>-</td><td>0.5 ml</td><td>-</td></tr><tr><td>TCA</td><td>-</td><td>4.5 ml</td><td>5.0 ml</td></tr><tr><td>Ammonium molybdate</td><td>1.0 ml</td><td>1.0 ml</td><td>1.0 ml</td></tr><tr><td>Metol reagent</td><td>1.0 ml</td><td>1.0 ml</td><td>1.0 ml</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Allow to stand for 30 minutes.</p>
<p>Read absorbance at 680 nm (red filter) against the blank.</p>
<p>Serum inorganic phosphate mmol/L =</p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mfrac><mtext>Ab.&nbsp;Test</mtext><mtext>Ab.&nbsp;Standard</mtext></mfrac><mo>×</mo><mn>2.0</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\frac{\text{Ab. Test}}{\text{Ab. Standard}} \times 2.0</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.0574em; vertical-align: -0.686em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3714em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Ab.&nbsp;Standard</span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Ab.&nbsp;Test</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.686em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">2.0</span></span></span></span></span></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="note">Note<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#note" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>The serum should be separated as soon as possible in order to prevent the hydrolysis of ester phosphates in red blood cells which might give false high inorganic phosphate value.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="normal-values">Normal values<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#normal-values" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Adults: 0.8–1.5 mmol/L (2.3–4.7 mg/dl)
Children: 1.3–1.9 mmol/L (4–6 mg/dl)
Conversion to mg/dl = <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mfrac><mtext>mmol/L</mtext><mn>0.323</mn></mfrac></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\frac{\text{mmol/L}}{0.323}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.355em; vertical-align: -0.345em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.01em;"><span style="top: -2.655em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">0.323</span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.485em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord mtight">mmol/L</span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.345em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span></span></span></span></span></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="clinical-significance">Clinical Significance<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#clinical-significance" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Increase in serum phosphorus is found in chronic nephritis, hypoparathyroidism and excess of vitamin D. Decrease in serum phosphate is found in rickets, osteomalacia caused partly by hyperparathyroidism, renal impairment and increased carbohydrate utilisation.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Chapter 8</p>
<p>Lipids and Lipoproteins</p>
<p>Lipids, commonly known as fats, are a heterogeneous group of organic substances which are insoluble in water and are soluble in a group of organic solvents. The common fat solvents include chloroform, ether, benzene, hexane and light petroleum.</p>
<p>Lipids comprise a large number of diverse chemical substances. Figure 8.1 shows a broad classification of lipids. The major lipids in human plasma include cholesterol, triglycerides, phospholipids and non-esterified fatty acids (NEFA). Lipoproteins are lipids modified for their transport in plasma and tissues. Laboratory methods are generally available to analyse the above mentioned lipids.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="cholesterol">CHOLESTEROL<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cholesterol" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Cholesterol is an unsaturated steroid alcohol. About 70–80% of cholesterol in plasma is esterified with long chain saturated and unsaturated fatty acids (Fig. 8.2). About 20–30% exist as free unesterified cholesterol.</p>
<p>The major function of cholesterol is as a metabolic precursor for the biosynthesis of bile acids and steroid hormones which include male and</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-156d144b.jpeg" alt="img-53.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 8.1 Classification of lipids</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Lipids and Lipoproteins 189</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-77760e5a.jpeg" alt="img-54.jpeg">
Fig. 8.2 Structure of cholesterol, triglyceride and phospholipid</p>
<p>female sex steroids (androgens and oestrogens) and adrenal steroid hormones (aldosterones and corticosterone). Liver, ovaries, testes and adrenal glands synthesise these hormones using cholesterol as the main precursor. Cholesterol is also an important structural component of cell membranes. Being insoluble in water, cholesterol can control the flow of water soluble products in and out of cells.</p>
<p>In humans, 60–70% of cholesterol is transported by low density lipoproteins (LDL), 20–35% by high density lipoproteins (HDL) and 5–12% by very low density lipoproteins (VLDL).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="triglycerides">TRIGLYCERIDES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#triglycerides" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Triglycerides are long chain fatty acids esterified to glycerol. Usually there are three different fatty acids present in a molecule (Fig. 8.2).</p>
<p>Triglycerides are the primary constituents used for long-term storage of energy. One molecule of triglyceride produces twice the amount of energy as compared to polysaccharides such as glycogen. Therefore, triglyceride metabolism is a key component which derives energy for many body functions including that of the heart. The primary source of triglycerides is from diet.</p>
<p>Triglycerides are transported in plasma mostly in the form of chylomicrons and VLDL but are also present in LDL and HDL in small amounts.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="phospholipids">PHOSPHOLIPIDS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#phospholipids" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Phospholipids are esters of glycerol with two fatty acyl groups and phosphatidic acid. They are similar in structure to triglycerides (Fig. 8.2). The main groups of phospholipids in plasma include lecithin, cephalins and sphingomyelin.</p>
<p>Phospholipids are one of the major components of plasma membrane. They usually carry both hydrophobic and hydrophilic charge on their molecules and provide a good interface between highly charged water molecules and neutral lipids for the transport of molecules across the membrane. About 25% of phospholipids are transported by LDL, about 30% by HDL and about 20% by VLDL.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="non-esterified-fatty-acids-nefa">NON-ESTERIFIED FATTY ACIDS (NEFA)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#non-esterified-fatty-acids-nefa" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Quantitatively, NEFA form a very small fraction of the plasma lipids. Fatty acids are grouped ac</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>190 Clinical Chemistry</p>
<p>cording to the presence or absence of double bonds in their chain. Saturated fatty acids have no double bonds and are present in the tissues. Polyunsaturated fatty acids, on the other hand, contain two or more double bonds. The human body cannot synthesise the polyunsaturated fatty acids and therefore are essential dietary components.</p>
<p>The primary function of long chain fatty acids is to provide energy to cells and muscle tissues by an oxidative process. NEFA are complexed with albumin for their transport in the plasma.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="lipoproteins">LIPOPROTEINS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#lipoproteins" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>To be able to perform their physiological function, lipids must be capable of movement from one cell or tissue to another in an aqueous environment. Lipids are bound to specific proteins to form lipoproteins which provide solubility in the aqueous environment and can be metabolised. Lipoproteins have a spherical shape with neutral lipid such as cholesterol esters or triglycerides at the centre, surrounded by free cholesterol, phospholipids and proteins on the surface. Specific proteins called apolipoproteins which have both hydrophilic and hydrophobic charges on their surface, are associated with lipoproteins.</p>
<p>Depending on their density, plasma proteins can be separated into several fractions according to their rates of sedimentation (S) or by Svedberg floatation index (Sₜ). Usually the sedimentation rate increases with the molecular weight of protein but lipoproteins are exception to this rule. In lipoproteins, the lipid fractions attached to the apoproteins are lighter than water, and therefore, lipoproteins are high molecular weight, low density, large-sized molecules. Ultracentrifugation separates lipoproteins on the basis of their density into very low density lipoproteins (VLDL), intermediate-density lipoprotein (IDL), low density lipoproteins (LDL) and high density lipoproteins (HDL), with the exception of chylomicrons. Chylomicrons are responsible for the visual opalescence of the plasma. Fig. 8.3 shows relative sizes of lipoproteins and Table 8.1 shows their composition.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-8527d5e9.jpeg" alt="img-55.jpeg">
Fig. 8.3 Relative sizes of lipoproteins</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="apolipoprotein">APOLIPOPROTEIN<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#apolipoprotein" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The protein fraction of the lipoprotein is composed of several specific proteins called apolipoproteins. Apolipoproteins function as the interface between lipid and water and allow lipid to function in aqueous media. The apolipoproteins help in the lipid metabolism by activating or inhibiting the enzymes and by binding lipoproteins to cell surface receptors.</p>
<p>The most significant apolipoproteins are AL, AII, B, CI, CII, CIII and E. AI and AII are major</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Lipoprotein</th><th>Density g/ml</th><th>Cholesterol (%)</th><th>Triglycerides (%)</th><th>Phospholipids (%)</th><th>Protein (%)</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Chylomicron</td><td>0.95</td><td>4</td><td>85</td><td>9</td><td>20</td></tr><tr><td>VLDL</td><td>0.97–1.006</td><td>19</td><td>50</td><td>18</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>IDL</td><td>1.006–1.019</td><td>?</td><td>?</td><td>?</td><td>?</td></tr><tr><td>LDL</td><td>1.019–1.063</td><td>45</td><td>10</td><td>20</td><td>23</td></tr><tr><td>HDL</td><td>1.063–1.120</td><td>17</td><td>4</td><td>24</td><td>55</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Lipids and Lipoproteins 191</p>
<p>components of HDL. About 90% of protein in LDL are in Apo-B. Chylomicrons and VLDL have B,C and some AI. E is a major component of VLDL. Apo AI and apo-B are considered as risk factors in coronary thrombosis.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="liporotein-metabolism">LIPOROTEIN METABOLISM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#liporotein-metabolism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Metabolism of lipoproteins can be divided into two groups. The exogenous metabolism deals with lipids and lipoproteins derived from external sources (food and nutrients). The endogenous metabolism involves lipids and lipoproteins produced in the body to synthesize complex lipids in the liver and other tissues.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="exogenous-metabolism">Exogenous Metabolism<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#exogenous-metabolism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>As the food passes through the stomach, pancreatic enzymes (amylase, lipase and peptidase) are released and act on the complex molecules in the food to break them down to metabolites which are readily absorbed. Triglycerides are hydrolysed by lipases to mono-glycerides and free fatty acids.</li>
<li>The monoglycerides and fatty acids are absorbed through the intestinal mucosa and are converted again to triglycerides and phospholipids.</li>
<li>The newly formed lipids are packaged into chylomicrons (triglyceride-rich lipoproteins), which pass into the lymph.</li>
<li>Chylomicrons in the lymph enter the blood stream through the thoracic duct. This absorption of triglycerides in blood can occur within 30–90 minutes from the intake of food.</li>
<li>The walls of the blood vessels contain lipoprotein lipase which hydrolyse triglycerides in the chylomicrons to fatty acids and glycerides. These are absorbed by the cells of the capillary wall.</li>
<li>The hydrolysed products are resynthesised to triglycerides which are stored for energy.</li>
<li>When all the triglycerides from chylomicrons are removed, the latter are cleared from the blood stream by the liver.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="endogenous-metabolism">Endogenous Metabolism<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#endogenous-metabolism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>The liver is the principal organ of metabolism of lipids and synthesis of lipoproteins.</p>
<ol>
<li>Triglycerides and cholesterol in the liver cells are packaged as VLDL and secreted into circulation.</li>
<li>The enzyme lipoprotein lipase acts on the VLDL in the same manner as on the chylomicrons. The hydrolysis of triglyceride from VLDL results in the formation of IDL with high cholesterol content.</li>
<li>IDL is rapidly processed to LDL which transports cholesterol to peripheral tissues.</li>
<li>LDL binds to the cell receptors on the cell surface and enters the cell.</li>
<li>The cholesterol content of the LDL is added to the intercellular pool. By a feedback mechanism, as the pool increases, the rate of synthesis is reduced, and vice versa.</li>
<li>HDL from the liver and intestine is released in circulation in the form known as ‘nascent’ form which is not spherical. However, it can absorb lipid from other lipoproteins to attain a spherical shape. Thus it can absorb cholesterol as cholesterol ester and regulate its movement from the peripheral tissues back to the liver, acting as a reverse cholesterol transport system.</li>
<li>HDL can also exchange cholesterol esters with triglycerides from VLDL.</li>
<li>Thus VLDL, LDL and HDL interact to maintain the intracellular lipid levels. The lipoproteins transport lipids from the area of synthesis to areas of storage, metabolic needs or catabolism.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="estimation-of-total-serum-plasma-cholesterol">ESTIMATION OF TOTAL SERUM/ PLASMA CHOLESTEROL<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#estimation-of-total-serum-plasma-cholesterol" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="method-1">Method 1<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#method-1" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p><strong>Principle</strong> In the presence of excess acid such as phosphoric acid and ferric (Fe³⁺) ions, cholesterol</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>192 Clinical Chemistry</p>
<p>is oxidised to disulphonic acid which is reddish purple in colour (Salkowski reaction). It is read colorimetrically at 560 nm (green yellow filter).</p>
<p><strong>Specimen</strong> Serum or plasma after 12 hours fast.</p>
<p><strong>Reagents</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Ferric chloride reagent Dissolve 2.5 g of ferric chloride (FeCl₃·6H₂O) in 100 ml of 85% phosphoric acid.</li>
<li>Cholesterol standard (250 mg/dl) Dissolve 250 mg of pure cholesterol in 100 ml glacial acetic acid.</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>Method</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Dilute the serum 1:20 with distilled water (0.1 ml serum +1.9 ml distilled water).</li>
<li>Dilute the cholesterol standard 1:20 with glacial acetic acid.</li>
<li>Set up three glass stoppered test tubes as follows:</li>
</ol>
<table><thead><tr><th></th><th>Test</th><th>Standard</th><th>Blank</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Ferric chloride reagent</td><td>5.0 ml</td><td>5.0 ml</td><td>5.0 ml</td></tr><tr><td>Diluted serum</td><td>0.5 ml</td><td>-</td><td>-</td></tr><tr><td>Diluted standard</td><td>-</td><td>0.5 ml</td><td>-</td></tr><tr><td>Distilled water</td><td>-</td><td>-</td><td>0.5 ml</td></tr></tbody></table>
<ol start="4">
<li>Shake the test tube rack for 10 seconds to mix the contents of each tube.</li>
<li>Place the tubes immediately in a boiling water bath for exactly 90 seconds.</li>
<li>Cool in running tap water for 5 minutes</li>
<li>Read the absorbance at 560 nm (green-yellow filter) against the blank, using a dry cuvette. The colour is stable for 15 minutes.</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>Calculation</strong></p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mtext>Serum&nbsp;cholesterol&nbsp;(mg/dl)</mtext><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mtext>Ab&nbsp;test</mtext><mtext>Ab&nbsp;standard</mtext></mfrac><mo>×</mo><mn>250</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\text{Serum cholesterol (mg/dl)} = \frac{\text{Ab test}}{\text{Ab standard}} \times 250</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Serum&nbsp;cholesterol&nbsp;(mg/dl)</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.0574em; vertical-align: -0.686em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3714em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Ab&nbsp;standard</span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Ab&nbsp;test</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.686em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">250</span></span></span></span></span></div>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mtext>Serum&nbsp;cholesterol&nbsp;(mmol/l)</mtext><mo>=</mo><mtext>mg/dl</mtext><mo>×</mo><mn>0.0259</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\text{Serum cholesterol (mmol/l)} = \text{mg/dl} \times 0.0259</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Serum&nbsp;cholesterol&nbsp;(mmol/l)</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">mg/dl</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">0.0259</span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p><strong>Note</strong> Haemolysed or icteric serum should not be used for the test.</p>
<p><strong>Method 2</strong></p>
<p><strong>Principle</strong></p>
<p>When dehydrated with acetic anhydride and oxidized with sulphuric acid, cholesterol forms a green coloured complex which is read colorimetrically at 560 nm (green-yellow filter)</p>
<p><strong>Reagents</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Colour reagent Mix 5.6 g of 2,5-dimethylbenzene sulphonic acid with 200 ml glacial acetic acid and 300 ml of acetic anhydride.</li>
<li>Concentrated sulphuric acid</li>
<li>Cholesterol standard (250 mg/dl) Dissolve 250 mg of pure cholesterol in 100 ml of glacial acetic acid.</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>Method</strong> Set up three tubes as follows:</p>
<table><thead><tr><th></th><th>Test</th><th>Standard</th><th>Blank</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Colour reagent</td><td>2.5 ml</td><td>2.5 ml</td><td>2.5 ml</td></tr><tr><td>Serum</td><td>0.1 ml</td><td>-</td><td>-</td></tr><tr><td>Cholesterol standard</td><td>-</td><td>0.1 ml</td><td>-</td></tr><tr><td>Distilled water</td><td>-</td><td>-</td><td>0.1 ml</td></tr><tr><td>Mix well Cool in running tap water</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Conc. sulphuric acid</td><td>0.5 ml</td><td>0.5 ml</td><td>0.5 ml</td></tr></tbody></table>
<ol start="4">
<li>Mix well. Cool in running tap water.</li>
<li>Read the absorbances using a dry cuvette at 560 nm (green-yellow filter) against the blank.</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>Calculation</strong></p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mtext>Serum&nbsp;cholesterol&nbsp;(mg/dl)</mtext><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mtext>Ab&nbsp;test</mtext><mtext>Ab&nbsp;standard</mtext></mfrac><mo>×</mo><mn>250</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\text{Serum cholesterol (mg/dl)} = \frac{\text{Ab test}}{\text{Ab standard}} \times 250</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Serum&nbsp;cholesterol&nbsp;(mg/dl)</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.0574em; vertical-align: -0.686em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3714em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Ab&nbsp;standard</span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Ab&nbsp;test</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.686em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">250</span></span></span></span></span></div>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mtext>Serum&nbsp;cholesterol&nbsp;(mmol/l)</mtext><mo>=</mo><mtext>mg/dl</mtext><mo>×</mo><mn>0.0259</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\text{Serum cholesterol (mmol/l)} = \text{mg/dl} \times 0.0259</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Serum&nbsp;cholesterol&nbsp;(mmol/l)</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">mg/dl</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">0.0259</span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p><strong>Note</strong> Reagents 1 and 2 are corrosive. Avoid pipetting by mouth and contact with skin.</p>
<p><strong>Method 3</strong></p>
<p><strong>Principle</strong> This is an enzymatic method. The reactions take place as follows:</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Lipids and Lipoproteins 193</p>
<ol>
<li>Cholesterol esters</li>
</ol>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mtext>Cholesterol&nbsp;ester&nbsp;hydrolase</mtext><mo>→</mo><mtext>cholesterol</mtext><mo>+</mo><mtext>fatty&nbsp;acids</mtext></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\text{Cholesterol ester hydrolase} \rightarrow \text{cholesterol} + \text{fatty acids}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Cholesterol&nbsp;ester&nbsp;hydrolase</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7778em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">cholesterol</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">+</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">fatty&nbsp;acids</span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<ol start="2">
<li>
<p>Total cholesterol <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mover><mo stretchy="true" minsize="3.0em">→</mo><mpadded width="+0.6em" lspace="0.3em"><mtext>Cholesterol&nbsp;oxidase</mtext></mpadded></mover></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\xrightarrow{\text{Cholesterol oxidase}}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.1191em; vertical-align: -0.011em;"></span><span class="mrel x-arrow"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.1081em;"><span style="top: -3.322em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight x-arrow-pad"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord mtight">Cholesterol&nbsp;oxidase</span></span></span></span></span><span class="svg-align" style="top: -2.689em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="hide-tail" style="height: 0.522em; min-width: 1.469em;"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="400em" height="0.522em" viewBox="0 0 400000 522" preserveAspectRatio="xMaxYMin slice"><path d="M0 241v40h399891c-47.3 35.3-84 78-110 128
-16.7 32-27.7 63.7-33 95 0 1.3-.2 2.7-.5 4-.3 1.3-.5 2.3-.5 3 0 7.3 6.7 11 20
 11 8 0 13.2-.8 15.5-2.5 2.3-1.7 4.2-5.5 5.5-11.5 2-13.3 5.7-27 11-41 14.7-44.7

-40.5-119-75.5s-58.3-74.8-73-119.5c-4.7-14-8.3-27.3-11-40-1.3-6.7-3.2-10.8-5.5
-12.5-2.3-1.7-7.5-2.5-15.5-2.5-14 0-21 3.7-21 11 0 2 2 10.3 6 25 20.7 83.3 67

cholest-4-en-3-one + H₂O₂</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>H₂O₂ <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mover><mo stretchy="true" minsize="3.0em">→</mo><mpadded width="+0.6em" lspace="0.3em"><mtext>Peroxidase</mtext></mpadded></mover></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\xrightarrow{\text{Peroxidase}}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.1191em; vertical-align: -0.011em;"></span><span class="mrel x-arrow"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.1081em;"><span style="top: -3.322em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight x-arrow-pad"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord mtight">Peroxidase</span></span></span></span></span><span class="svg-align" style="top: -2.689em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="hide-tail" style="height: 0.522em; min-width: 1.469em;"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="400em" height="0.522em" viewBox="0 0 400000 522" preserveAspectRatio="xMaxYMin slice"><path d="M0 241v40h399891c-47.3 35.3-84 78-110 128
-16.7 32-27.7 63.7-33 95 0 1.3-.2 2.7-.5 4-.3 1.3-.5 2.3-.5 3 0 7.3 6.7 11 20
 11 8 0 13.2-.8 15.5-2.5 2.3-1.7 4.2-5.5 5.5-11.5 2-13.3 5.7-27 11-41 14.7-44.7
 39-84.5 73-119.5s73.7-60.2 119-75.5c6-2 9-5.7 9-11s-3-9-9-11c-45.3-15.3-85
-40.5-119-75.5s-58.3-74.8-73-119.5c-4.7-14-8.3-27.3-11-40-1.3-6.7-3.2-10.8-5.5
-12.5-2.3-1.7-7.5-2.5-15.5-2.5-14 0-21 3.7-21 11 0 2 2 10.3 6 25 20.7 83.3 67

</li>
<li>
<p>O₂ + 4-aminophenazone/phenol <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>⟶</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\longrightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.522em; vertical-align: -0.011em;"></span><span class="mrel">⟶</span></span></span></span></span> Red complex</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="reagents">Reagents<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#reagents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li><strong>Colour reagent</strong> One litre of the reagent contains</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Sodium citrate 3.0 mmol</li>
<li>4-aminophenazone 0.82 mmol</li>
<li>Phenol 14.0 mmol</li>
<li>Na₂HPO₄ 50.0 mmol</li>
<li>NaH₂PO₄ 50.0 mmol</li>
<li>Carbowax 6000 0.17 mmol</li>
<li>Cholesterol ester hydrolase 33.0 U</li>
<li>Cholesterol oxidase 117.0 U</li>
<li>Peroxidase 67000.0 U</li>
<li>pH 7.0</li>
</ul>
<ol start="2">
<li>
<p><strong>Reagent blank</strong> Prepare the colour reagent without cholesterol ester hydrolase and cholesterol oxidase.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Cholesterol standard</strong> Dissolve 200 mg of pure cholesterol in 100 ml isopropanol.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>Note</strong> Reagents 1 and 2 are commercially available.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="method">Method<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#method" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Set up four tubes as follows:</p>
<table><thead><tr><th></th><th>Test</th><th>Standard</th><th>Test Blank</th><th>Standard Blank</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Colour reagent</td><td>3.0 ml</td><td>3.0 ml</td><td>-</td><td>-</td></tr><tr><td>Reagent blank</td><td>-</td><td>-</td><td>3.0 ml</td><td>3.0 ml</td></tr><tr><td>Serum Cholesterol standard</td><td>0.05 ml</td><td>-</td><td>0.05 ml</td><td>-</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Read the absorbance of all the tubes at 500 nm (Blue-green filter)</p>
<p>Serum cholesterol (mg/dl) =</p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mtext>Ab&nbsp;Test</mtext><mo>−</mo><mtext>Ab&nbsp;Test&nbsp;Blank</mtext></mrow><mrow><mtext>Ab&nbsp;Std.</mtext><mo>−</mo><mtext>Ab&nbsp;Std.&nbsp;Blank</mtext></mrow></mfrac><mo>×</mo><mn>200</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\frac{\text{Ab Test} - \text{Ab Test Blank}}{\text{Ab Std.} - \text{Ab Std. Blank}} \times 200</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.1408em; vertical-align: -0.7693em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3714em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Ab&nbsp;Std.</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Ab&nbsp;Std.&nbsp;Blank</span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Ab&nbsp;Test</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Ab&nbsp;Test&nbsp;Blank</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7693em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">200</span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p>Serum cholesterol (mmol/L) = mg/dl × 0.0259</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="estimation-of-serum-plasma-hdl-cholesterol">ESTIMATION OF SERUM/PLASMA HDL CHOLESTEROL<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#estimation-of-serum-plasma-hdl-cholesterol" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Principle</strong> Chylomicrons, VLDL and LDL are precipitated by phosphotungstic acid in the presence of magnesium ions, leaving HDL in solution. The cholesterol content of the supernatant can be determined by a suitable method.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="reagents">Reagents<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#reagents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Phosphotungstic acid reagent (PTA) Dissolve 4.5 g phosphotungstic acid in about 50 ml water. Add 16 ml of 1 N NaOH and make up to 100 ml with distilled water.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Magnesium chloride (2 mol/L) Dissolve 40.6 g of magnesium chloride (MgCl₂·6 H₂O) in 100 ml distilled water.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Tris buffer 10 mmol/L, pH 7.6 Dissolve 1.21 g tris in 90 ml distilled water. Adjust the pH to 7.6 with 1N HCl and dilute to 100 ml with distilled water.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Colour reagent Prepare as for method 2 above.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Concentrated sulphuric acid</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Cholesterol standard (100 mg/dl) Dissolve 100 mg of pure cholesterol in 100 ml glacial acetic acid.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="method">Method<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#method" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Pipette 1 ml of serum into a centrifuge tube.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Add 0.1 ml of PTA reagent. Mix well</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Add 0.05 ml of the magnesium chloride. Mix well.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Centrifuge at 2500 rpm or 1500 g for 30 min.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Carefully remove the clear supernatant with a pasteur pipette.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>194 Clinical Chemistry</p>
<p><strong>Note</strong>
If the supernatant is not clear, centrifuge again at a higher speed. If still turbid, dilute the serum 1:2 with the tris buffer and centrifuge.</p>
<ol start="6">
<li>Estimate the cholesterol level in the supernatant as in method 2 using 100 mg/dl cholesterol standard.</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>Calculation</strong></p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mtext>Serum&nbsp;HDL&nbsp;Cholesterol&nbsp;(mg/dl)</mtext><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mtext>Ab&nbsp;Test</mtext><mtext>Ab&nbsp;Std</mtext></mfrac><mo>×</mo><mn>115</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\text{Serum HDL Cholesterol (mg/dl)} = \frac{\text{Ab Test}}{\text{Ab Std}} \times 115</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Serum&nbsp;HDL&nbsp;Cholesterol&nbsp;(mg/dl)</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.0574em; vertical-align: -0.686em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3714em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Ab&nbsp;Std</span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Ab&nbsp;Test</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.686em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">115</span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p><strong>Note</strong>
Multiplication factor 115 is obtained by adding the dilution factor of the serum because of steps 1 to 3 (1 ml of serum is diluted to 1.15 ml).</p>
<p>Serum HDL cholesterol (mmol/L) = mg/dl × 0.0259</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="estimation-of-serum-plasma-ldl-cholesterol">ESTIMATION OF SERUM/PLASMA LDL CHOLESTEROL<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#estimation-of-serum-plasma-ldl-cholesterol" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>LDL cholesterol (mmol/L) = Total cholesterol – (HDL cholesterol + 0.46 × triglycerides) (All in mmol/L).</p>
<p><strong>Note</strong>
This equation is true only if triglycerides do not exceed 4.5 mmol/L.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="normal-values">Normal values<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#normal-values" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Total cholesterol: 150–250 mg/dl (3.8–6.2 mmol/L)
HDL cholesterol: 40–50 mg/dl (1.1–1.2 mmol/L)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="clinical-significance">Clinical Significance<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#clinical-significance" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p><strong>Total cholesterol</strong> Serum cholesterol rises with age and the rise is more marked in men than in women. In the middle age it may rise up to 300 mg/dl (7.0 mmol/L). In pregnancy there may be about 20–25% rise in cholesterol levels.</p>
<p><strong>Increase in cholesterol occurs in</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Nephrotic syndrome</li>
<li>Diabetes mellitus</li>
<li>Obstructive jaundice</li>
<li>Myxodema</li>
<li>Xanthomatosis</li>
<li>Coronary thrombosis</li>
<li>Angina pectoris</li>
<li>Hypothyroidism</li>
</ol>
<p>Cholesterol levels as high as 600 mg/dl (14–16 mmol/L) may be observed in some cases of nephrotic syndrome. Cholesterol level may be normal in chronic glomerulonephritis. In acute glomerulonephritis increased levels are seen in later stages.</p>
<p><strong>Decrease in serum cholesterol may occur in</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Pernicious anaemia</li>
<li>Haemolytic anaemia</li>
<li>Malabsorption syndrome</li>
<li>Acute infections</li>
<li>Terminal illness</li>
<li>Hyperthyroidism</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>HDL cholesterol</strong> The serum concentration of HDL cholesterol is a negative risk factor for coronary heart disease (CHD). The risk of CHD increases as the value falls below 0.9 mmol/L and diminishes as levels become higher.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="estimation-of-serum-triglycerides">ESTIMATION OF SERUM TRIGLYCERIDES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#estimation-of-serum-triglycerides" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="method-1">Method 1<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#method-1" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="principle">Principle<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#principle" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<ol>
<li>Triglycerides from serum or plasma are extracted with isopropanol.</li>
<li>Extracted triglycerides are saponified with an alkali, sodium methylate, forming glycerol and fatty acids.</li>
</ol>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mtext>Triglyceride</mtext><mo>+</mo><mtext>Sodium&nbsp;methylate</mtext><mo>→</mo><mtext>Glycerol</mtext><mo>+</mo><mtext>Fatty&nbsp;acids</mtext></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\text{Triglyceride} + \text{Sodium methylate} \rightarrow \text{Glycerol} + \text{Fatty acids}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Triglyceride</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">+</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Sodium&nbsp;methylate</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Glycerol</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">+</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Fatty&nbsp;acids</span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<ol start="3">
<li>Glycerol is oxidised with sodium periodate to produce formaldehyde.</li>
</ol>
<p>Glycerol + Sod. periodate → Formaldehyde</p>
<ol start="4">
<li>Formaldehyde is reacted with acetylacetone in the presence of ammonium ions to produce a yellowish</li>
</ol>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Lipids and Lipoproteins 195</p>
<p>low compound (diacetyl dihydrolutidine) which is measured colorimetrically.</p>
<p>Formaldehyde + Acetylacetone + NH₄⁺ → Diacetyldihydrolutidine</p>
<p>Specimen Serum or plasma after 12 hours fast.</p>
<p>Reagents</p>
<ol>
<li>Heptane</li>
<li>Isopropanol</li>
<li>Sulphuric acid (0.08 N) Add 2.25 ml conc. H₂SO₄ (36.0 N) to about 500 ml distilled water. Dilute up to 1 litre.</li>
<li>Sodium methylate Dissolve 50 mg of sodium methylate in 100 ml of isopropanol. Prepare fresh and keep tightly stoppered.</li>
<li>Periodate reagent (sodium metaperiodate (NaIO₄, 0.06 mol/L) Dissolve 1.283 g of NaIO₄ in 100 ml of 0.88 M (5% v/v) acetic acid. Store in a brown bottle.</li>
<li>Acetylacetone reagent (chromogen) Mix 0.75 ml acetylacetone and 2.5 ml isopropanol. Add 2 M ammonium acetate (15.4%) to make the volume up to 100 ml. Keep in a brown bottle at 4°C (Stable for 1 month).</li>
<li>Triglyceride standard Dissolve 200 mg of pure triolein (mol. wt 885) in 100 ml isopropanol. Keep tightly stoppered.</li>
</ol>
<p>Method</p>
<p>Step I: Extraction</p>
<ol>
<li>Set up three glass stoppered tubes as follows:</li>
</ol>
<table><thead><tr><th></th><th>Test</th><th>Standard</th><th>Blank</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Serum</td><td>0.5 ml</td><td>-</td><td>-</td></tr><tr><td>Triglyceride standard</td><td>-</td><td>0.5 ml</td><td>-</td></tr><tr><td>Distilled water</td><td>-</td><td>0.5 ml</td><td>0.5 ml</td></tr><tr><td>Isopropanol</td><td>3.5 ml</td><td>3.0 ml</td><td>3.5 ml</td></tr><tr><td>H₂SO₄ (0.08 N)</td><td>1.0 ml</td><td>1.0 ml</td><td>1.0 ml</td></tr><tr><td>Heptane</td><td>2.0 ml</td><td>2.0 ml</td><td>2.0 ml</td></tr></tbody></table>
<ol start="2">
<li>
<p>Mix all the tubes for 30 seconds, preferably in a vortex mixer.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Let tubes stand at room temperature for 10 minutes for clear separation of two layers. Use the top solvent layer for further assay.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>Step II: Saponification</p>
<ol start="4">
<li>Prepare another set of three stoppered tubes</li>
</ol>
<table><thead><tr><th></th><th>Test</th><th>Standard</th><th>Blank</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Top solvent layer from the respective tube</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Step I</td><td>0.2 ml</td><td>0.2 ml</td><td>0.2 ml</td></tr><tr><td>Sodium methylate</td><td>3.0 ml</td><td>3.0 ml</td><td>3.0 ml</td></tr></tbody></table>
<ol start="5">
<li>Mix again with a vortex mixture.</li>
<li>Incubate at 60°C for 10 minutes. Cool to room temperature.</li>
</ol>
<p>Step III: Colour development</p>
<ol start="7">
<li>Add 0.1 ml periodate reagent to each tube. Mix well.</li>
<li>Add 1.0 ml of acetylacetone reagent to each tube. Mix well.</li>
<li>Incubate at 60°C for 10 minutes. Cool to room temperature.</li>
<li>Centrifuge the tubes, and transfer the upper phase liquid to fresh tubes.</li>
<li>Read the absorbance of test and standard at 420 nm (violet filter) against the blank.</li>
</ol>
<p>Calculation</p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mtext>Serum&nbsp;triglyceride&nbsp;mg/dl</mtext><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mtext>Ab&nbsp;Test</mtext><mtext>Ab&nbsp;Std</mtext></mfrac><mo>×</mo><mn>200</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\text{Serum triglyceride mg/dl} = \frac{\text{Ab Test}}{\text{Ab Std}} \times 200</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Serum&nbsp;triglyceride&nbsp;mg/dl</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.0574em; vertical-align: -0.686em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3714em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Ab&nbsp;Std</span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Ab&nbsp;Test</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.686em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">200</span></span></span></span></span></div>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mtext>Serum&nbsp;triglyceride&nbsp;mmol/L</mtext><mo>=</mo><mtext>mg/dl</mtext><mo>×</mo><mn>0.0113</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\text{Serum triglyceride mmol/L} = \text{mg/dl} \times 0.0113</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Serum&nbsp;triglyceride&nbsp;mmol/L</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">mg/dl</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">0.0113</span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p>Method 2</p>
<p>Principle The enzymatic method for serum triglycerides involves the following steps:</p>
<ol>
<li>Triglycerides are hydrolysed by the enzyme lipase to produce glycerol and fatty acids.</li>
</ol>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mtext>Triglycerides</mtext><mo>+</mo><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mover><mo stretchy="true" minsize="3.0em">→</mo><mpadded width="+0.6em" lspace="0.3em"><mtext>Lipase</mtext></mpadded></mover><mtext>Glycerol</mtext><mo>+</mo><mtext>Fatty&nbsp;acids</mtext></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\text{Triglycerides} + \mathrm{H_2O} \xrightarrow{\text{Lipase}} \text{Glycerol} + \text{Fatty acids}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Triglycerides</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">+</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.2503em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">H</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathrm mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">O</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel x-arrow"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.1003em;"><span style="top: -3.322em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight x-arrow-pad"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord mtight">Lipase</span></span></span></span></span><span class="svg-align" style="top: -2.689em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="hide-tail" style="height: 0.522em; min-width: 1.469em;"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="400em" height="0.522em" viewBox="0 0 400000 522" preserveAspectRatio="xMaxYMin slice"><path d="M0 241v40h399891c-47.3 35.3-84 78-110 128
-16.7 32-27.7 63.7-33 95 0 1.3-.2 2.7-.5 4-.3 1.3-.5 2.3-.5 3 0 7.3 6.7 11 20

-12.5-2.3-1.7-7.5-2.5-15.5-2.5-14 0-21 3.7-21 11 0 2 2 10.3 6 25 20.7 83.3 67
 151.7 139 205zm0 0v40h399900v-40z"></path></svg></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.011em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Glycerol</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">+</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Fatty&nbsp;acids</span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<ol start="2">
<li>The enzyme glycerol kinase acts on glycerol in the presence of ATP to form glycerol-3-phosphate and ADP.</li>
</ol>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>196 Clinical Chemistry</p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mtable rowspacing="0.16em" columnalign="left" columnspacing="1em"><mtr><mtd><mstyle scriptlevel="0" displaystyle="false"><mrow><mtext>Glycerol&nbsp;+&nbsp;ATP</mtext><munderover><mo stretchy="true" minsize="3.0em">→</mo><mpadded width="+0.6em" lspace="0.3em"><mtext>Kinase</mtext></mpadded><mpadded width="+0.6em" lspace="0.3em"><mtext>Glycerol-3</mtext></mpadded></munderover><mtext>Glycerol-3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mstyle scriptlevel="0" displaystyle="false"><mtext>-phosphate&nbsp;+&nbsp;ADP</mtext></mstyle></mtd></mtr></mtable><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\begin{array}{l}
\text{Glycerol + ATP} \xrightarrow[\text{Kinase}]{\text{Glycerol-3}} \text{Glycerol-3} \\
\text{-phosphate + ADP}
\end{array}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.9084em; vertical-align: -1.2042em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mtable"><span class="arraycolsep" style="width: 0.5em;"></span><span class="col-align-l"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.7042em;"><span style="top: -3.7042em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3.1081em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Glycerol&nbsp;+&nbsp;ATP</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel x-arrow"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.1081em;"><span style="top: -3.322em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight x-arrow-pad"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord mtight">Glycerol-3</span></span></span></span></span><span class="svg-align" style="top: -2.689em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="hide-tail" style="height: 0.522em; min-width: 1.469em;"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="400em" height="0.522em" viewBox="0 0 400000 522" preserveAspectRatio="xMaxYMin slice"><path d="M0 241v40h399891c-47.3 35.3-84 78-110 128
