<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="reports">Reports<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#reports" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<table><thead><tr><th>Trace</th><th>: Faint blue-green in 1 minute</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>1+</td><td>: Light blue-slowly</td></tr><tr><td>2+</td><td>: Clear blue-rapidly</td></tr><tr><td>3+</td><td>: Deep blue-almost immediately</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="benzidine-test-for-occult-blood">Benzidine Test for Occult Blood<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#benzidine-test-for-occult-blood" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Benzidine is a chromogen which catalyses the transfer of an oxygen atom from hydroperoxide producing a distinct colour. The following is the method for the test.</p>
<ol>
<li>Add 0.5 ml of glacial acetic acid to a small amount of benzidine in a test tube.</li>
<li>Add a few drops of hydrogen peroxide (10 vol).</li>
<li>Observe for green or blue colour.</li>
<li>In the absence of green or blue colour, add 3–5 ml of a faecal suspension in saline.</li>
<li>Production of blue or green colour is indicative of presence of blood in the faeces.</li>
</ol>
<p>&gt; <strong>Note</strong> Benzidine is a carcinogen and should be handled with care.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="faecal-fat">FAECAL FAT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#faecal-fat" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Most dietary fat is absorbed in the small intestine with very little being excreted in the faeces. Disorders of fat absorption cause excessive quantity of fat to be excreted in the faeces. This condition is referred to as steatorrhoea. Steatorrhoea is commonly associated with post-infective malabsorption (tropical sprue), giardiasis, strongyloidiasis and chronic pancreatitis.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="microscopic-examination-of-faeces-for-fat">Microscopic Examination of Faeces for Fat<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#microscopic-examination-of-faeces-for-fat" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Steatorrhoeal stools are usually bulky, pale in colour, float on water, are frothy and have an offensive odour. Excess fat in faeces may be in the form of neutral fat globules, fatty acid crystals or soapy flakes.</p>
<p><strong>Interpretation of results</strong> The presence of neutral fat globules (the unsplit fat in food before digestion) is indicative of lipase deficiency due to pancreatic disease. The presence of fatty acid crystals and soapy fats (slit fats not yet absorbed) is suggestive of malabsorption.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="chemical-estimation-of-excess-fat-in-faeces">Chemical Estimation of Excess Fat in Faeces<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chemical-estimation-of-excess-fat-in-faeces" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A long (3–5 days) collection of faeces is homogenised. Fats and fatty acids in the faeces are released by boiling an aliquot of the homogenate with 5% alcoholic potassium hydroxide. After cooling, the fatty acids which are in the form of potassium salts (the process is saponification) are converted to fatty acids by the addition of excess hydrochloric acid. These acids are then extracted into an immisible organic solvent (petroleum ether) and titrated against a standardised alkali such as tetramethyl ammonium hydroxide (TMAH) which is soluble in the organic solvent. The amount of fats present is calculated as fatty acids and it is equal to the titration volume.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>204 Clinical Chemistry</p>
<p>Note
Because of the messy and unsafe nature of the test, most laboratories no longer measure faecal fats.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pancreas">PANCREAS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pancreas" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Pancreas is a gland that lies across the back of the abdominal cavity with its head in contact with the duodenum and the tail near the spleen. It is about six to eight inches long. It produces both external (exocrine) and internal (endocrine) secretions. The external secretion is popularly known as the pancreatic fluid or juice, and it passes into the duodenum via the pancreatic duct. It contains among others, three important digestive enzymes.</p>
<ol>
<li>Trypsin to digest protein</li>
<li>Lipase to digest fat and</li>
<li>Diastase to digest carbohydrate.</li>
</ol>
<p>Endocrine secretions of pancreas are released by special groups of cells known as islets of Langerhans scattered in the pancreatic tissue. There are two types of cells. The β-cells produce the hormone insulin which stimulates conversion of glucose to glycogen and reduces blood sugar level. The other cells are the α cells that produce hormone glucagon which increases blood sugar level by enhancing gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis. Failure in the production of sufficient insulin results in diabetes mellitus.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pancreatic-juice">Pancreatic Juice<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pancreatic-juice" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The specimen of pancreatic juice is obtained by duodenal drainage mixed with bile. The secretion of pancreatic juice is stimulated by injection of the hormone, secretin, which is produced by upper intestinal mucosa as a result of the presence of acid. The flow of pancreatic juice starts shortly after a meal and lasts for about 6–8 hours.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="characteristics">Characteristics<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#characteristics" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Volume per 24 hours: 450–800 ml</li>
<li>Specific gravity: 1.007</li>
<li>Alkalinity: pH 7.0–8.3</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="digestive-enzymes">Digestive Enzymes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#digestive-enzymes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="proteolytic-enzymes">Proteolytic enzymes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#proteolytic-enzymes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Trypsin It is a protease and the concentration is 100–200 units/L. The precursor trypsinogen is activated to trypsin by the enzyme enterokinase. Trypsin hydrolyses proteins which are reduced to small polypeptides.</li>
<li>Chymotrypsin Two forms of chymotrypsinogen—A and B—are secreted and these are activated to chymotrypsin by trypsin. It is similar to trypsin in action. Chymotrypsin acts most effectively on proteases and peptones obtained by the action of gastric pepsin on proteins.</li>
<li>Collagenase It digests collagen and initiates destruction of the tissues in necrotising pancreatitis.</li>
<li>Elastase It digests elastin, the highly resistant protein to lytic agents.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="peptidases">Peptidases<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#peptidases" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Carboxypeptidase This enzyme is involved in removal of aminoacids from the carboxyl ends of the peptide chains.</li>
<li>Aminopeptidase This removes amino acids from the ends of the peptide chains carrying free amino groups.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="nucleases">Nucleases<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#nucleases" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Ribonuclease and deoxyribonuclease These are secreted in various forms, and they breakdown the respective nucleic acids.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="amylolytic-enzymes">Amylolytic enzymes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#amylolytic-enzymes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Amylase It hydrolyses starches, breaking them down to the disaccharide maltose.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="lipolytic-enzymes">Lipolytic enzymes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#lipolytic-enzymes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Lipase It partially hydrolyses neutral fat and in the process forms diglycerides and monoglycerides along with liberated fatty acids. It is most active at pH 7.0–9.0. It is activated by sodium cholate and deoxycholate of the bile. The acid pH of the intestine prevents the liberated fatty acids from producing soap.</p>
<p>Lecithinase (Phospholipase) Lecithinase breaks down lecithin to form lysolecithin.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Chemical Tests for Diseases of the Alimentary Tract 205</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="acute-pancreatitis">Acute Pancreatitis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#acute-pancreatitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Acute pancreatitis is the condition of acute inflammation of the pancreas. This causes the release of amylase into the circulation. Measurement of serum or plasma amylase is usually requested to differentiate acute pancreatitis from other forms of acute abdominal pain. Serum amylase activity is increased in acute pancreatitis within hours following an episode. Values over 5 times the upper limit of normal are suggestive of the diagnosis. The urine amylase activity in patients with acute pancreatitis rises quickly in the wake of rise of serum amylase activity. High values of urine amylase are diagnostic of acute pancreatitis. In non-pancreatic disorders such as intestinal obstruction or perforation, ruptured ectopic pregnancy, renal dysfunction, mumps, alcoholism, diabetic ketoacidosis and following upper abdominal surgery there may be a rise in blood amylase activity.</p>
<p>Serum lipase levels are not measured on routine basis but they are of some value in the diagnosis of acute pancreatitis when the values rise. The rise in lipase activity is slower but lasts longer than the amylase activity. It is a confirmatory evidence of acute pancreatitis.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="chronic-pancreatitis">Chronic Pancreatitis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chronic-pancreatitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>In chronic pancreatitis, measurement of amylase and lipase levels is not of much value. This is because parenchymal destruction leads to a high level of depression of the pancreal enzyme production and therefore, low levels of both lipase and amylase in blood are seen.</p>
<p>Serum amylase level may rise in carcinoma of pancreas but this is of little diagnostic importance.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="estimation-of-serum-plasma-amylase">Estimation of Serum/Plasma Amylase<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#estimation-of-serum-plasma-amylase" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The estimation of amylase in serum or urine is one of the important investigations for the diagnosis of diseases of the pancreas.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="principle">Principle<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#principle" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A small quantity of plasma or serum is incubated at <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>37</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∘</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">37^{\circ}\mathrm{C}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">3</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">7</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∘</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">C</span></span></span></span></span> for 7.5 minutes with a solution containing <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>0.4</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">0.4\mathrm{mg}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8389em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">0.4</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">mg</span></span></span></span></span></span> of starch. The disappearance of blue colour that starch gives with iodine solution is the measure of the extent to which the starch has been hydrolysed by the amylase.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="reagents">Reagents<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#reagents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Buffered starch substrate (pH 7.0) Dissolve <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>13.3</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">13.3\mathrm{g}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8389em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">13.3</span><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">g</span></span></span></span></span> of dry anhydrous disodium hydrogen phosphate and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>6.25</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">6.25\mathrm{g}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8389em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">6.25</span><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">g</span></span></span></span></span> potassium dihydrogen phosphate in <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>250</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">250\mathrm{ml}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord">250</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">ml</span></span></span></span></span></span> of cold water. Bring to boil. Mix <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>0.2</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">0.2\mathrm{g}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8389em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">0.2</span><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">g</span></span></span></span></span> of soluble starch in <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>5</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>10</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">5-10\mathrm{ml}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">5</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord">10</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">ml</span></span></span></span></span></span> of cold water in a beaker and add it to the boiling mixture. Boil for further 1 minute; cool to room temperature and make up volume to <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>500</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">500\mathrm{ml}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord">500</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">ml</span></span></span></span></span></span>. Store the solution at <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>4</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∘</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">4^{\circ}\mathrm{C}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">4</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∘</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">C</span></span></span></span></span> and prepare fresh each month.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Stock iodine solution (0.1 N) Dissolve <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>3.567</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">3.567\mathrm{g}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8389em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">3.567</span><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">g</span></span></span></span></span> potassium iodate and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>45.0</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">45.0\mathrm{g}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8389em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">45.0</span><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">g</span></span></span></span></span> potassium iodide in 800 ml distilled water. Add slowly <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>9</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">9\mathrm{ml}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord">9</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">ml</span></span></span></span></span></span> of concentrated hydrochloric acid. Make up the volume to 1 litre with distilled water. Store in brown bottle.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Working iodine solution (0.01 N) Dilute <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>50</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">50\mathrm{ml}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord">50</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">ml</span></span></span></span></span></span> of the stock iodine solution to <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>500</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">500\mathrm{ml}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord">500</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">ml</span></span></span></span></span></span> with distilled water. Keeps at <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>−</mo><msup><mn>8</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∘</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">2-8^{\circ}\mathrm{C}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">2</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">8</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∘</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">C</span></span></span></span></span> for 1 month.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>Method Set up two tubes as follows</p>
<table><thead><tr><th></th><th>Test</th><th>Blank</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Buffered substrate</td><td>2.5 ml</td><td>2.5 ml</td></tr><tr><td>Incubate at 37°C for 5 minutes</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Serum</td><td>0.1 ml</td><td>—</td></tr><tr><td>Mix and incubate at 37°C for exactly 7.5 minutes</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Working iodine solution</td><td>2.5 ml</td><td>2.5 ml</td></tr><tr><td>Serum</td><td>—</td><td>0.1 ml</td></tr><tr><td>Distilled water</td><td>20 ml</td><td>20 ml</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>206 Clinical Chemistry</p>
<p>Mix well and read absorbance at 660 nm (red filter)</p>
<p><strong>Calculation</strong></p>
<p>Serum amylase (Caraway units) =</p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mtext>Ab&nbsp;Blank</mtext><mo>−</mo><mtext>Ab&nbsp;Test</mtext></mrow><mtext>Ab&nbsp;Blank</mtext></mfrac><mo>×</mo><mn>400</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\frac{\text{Ab Blank} - \text{Ab Test}}{\text{Ab Blank}} \times 400</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.0574em; vertical-align: -0.686em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3714em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Ab&nbsp;Blank</span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Ab&nbsp;Blank</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Ab&nbsp;Test</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.686em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">400</span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p><strong>Note</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>One Caraway unit is the amount of amylase per 100 ml of serum/plasma which will hydrolyse 5 mg starch in 15 minutes at 37°C. In the test, 2.5 ml of buffered substrate is used which contains 1 mg starch (400 mg/L). Incubation period is for 7.5 minutes. The amount of serum used is 0.1 ml. Therefore, the factor 400 is derived as follows:</li>
</ol>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mfrac><mn>100</mn><mn>0.1</mn></mfrac><mo>×</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>5</mn></mfrac><mo>×</mo><mfrac><mn>15</mn><mn>7.5</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>400</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\frac{100}{0.1} \times \frac{1}{5} \times \frac{15}{7.5} = 400</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.0074em; vertical-align: -0.686em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3214em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0.1</span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">100</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.686em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.0074em; vertical-align: -0.686em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3214em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">5</span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">1</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.686em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.0074em; vertical-align: -0.686em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3214em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">7.5</span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">15</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.686em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">400</span></span></span></span></span></div>
<ol start="2">
<li>
<p>Amylase International Units/Litre (IU/L) = Caraway units × 1.85</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Avoid contamination of the test with saliva or sweat as they contain amylase.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>If serum amylase is more than 400 Caraway units, dilute the serum 1:5 and multiply the result by the dilution factor.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>Normal values</strong></p>
<p>60–160 Caraway units</p>
<p>100–340 International units</p>
<p><strong>Amylase In Urine</strong></p>
<p>Urinary amylase (aka diastase) is raised in acute pancreatitis and may remain so even after the serum level has returned to normal. The method of measurement given here was originally described by Wohlgemuth in 1908, and modified by Harrison. It is a good example of urinary enzyme determination that provides a useful practical exercise for students.</p>
<p><strong>Principle</strong> The amylase in urine breaks down starch into smaller compounds and finally to maltose. Starch gives blue colour with iodine but when it has been broken down to around 10 glucose units, it gives red colour; and at less than 5 glucose units, no colour is produced.</p>
<p><strong>Specimen</strong> Collect a 24 hour urine specimen with thymol as preservative.</p>
<p><strong>Reagents</strong></p>
<p><strong>(a) Starch solution</strong></p>
<p>(i) Stock solution Make a paste with 2 g of soluble starch and small volume of distilled water; then wash into 60 ml of boiling water. Add 10 g of sodium chloride, dissolve, cool and transfer to a 100 ml volumetric flask and make up to mark with distilled water.</p>
<p>(ii) Working starch solution Dilute stock solution 1:20 with distilled water.</p>
<p><strong>(b) Iodine solution</strong></p>
<p>(i) Stock solution (approx. 0.05 M) Weigh 6.4 g of iodine into a 500 ml flask and add 10–12 g KI (Analar, free from KIO₃) and 20 ml of distilled water. Stopper the flask, mix thoroughly to dissolve. Make to the mark with distilled water.</p>
<p>(ii) Working solution of iodine (approx. 0.01 M) Dilute stock solution 1:5 with distilled water.</p>
<p><strong>Method</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Adjust pH of urine to less than 7.0 using concentrated acid.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Arrange a series of tubes as follows:</p>
</li>
</ol>
<table><thead><tr><th>Tube No.</th><th>1</th><th>2</th><th>3</th><th>4</th><th>5</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Urine (ml)</td><td>1.00</td><td>0.50</td><td>0.30</td><td>0.20</td><td>0.14</td></tr><tr><td>Water (ml)</td><td>0.00</td><td>0.50</td><td>0.70</td><td>0.80</td><td>0.86</td></tr><tr><td>Working solution of starch (ml)</td><td>2.00</td><td>2.00</td><td>2.00</td><td>2.00</td><td>2.00</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>(Contd.)</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Chemical Tests for Diseases of the Alimentary Tract 207</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Tube No.</th><th>6</th><th>7</th><th>8</th><th>9</th><th>10</th><th>11</th><th>12</th><th>13</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Urine diluted in 1:10 (ml)</td><td>1.00</td><td>0.70</td><td>0.50</td><td>0.40</td><td>0.30</td><td>0.20</td><td>0.15</td><td>0.12</td></tr><tr><td>Water (ml)</td><td>0.00</td><td>0.30</td><td>0.50</td><td>0.60</td><td>0.70</td><td>0.80</td><td>0.85</td><td>0.88</td></tr><tr><td>Working starch solution (ml)</td><td>2.00</td><td>2.00</td><td>2.00</td><td>2.00</td><td>2.00</td><td>2.00</td><td>2.00</td><td>2.00</td></tr></tbody></table>
<ol start="3">
<li>Incubate at 37°C for 30 minutes.</li>
<li>Cool immediately in cold water.</li>
<li>Add working iodine solution drop by drop from a pipette to each tube, watching carefully for the appearance of a blue colour.</li>
<li>Note the smallest amount of urine which does not give a blue colour.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="calculation">Calculation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#calculation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Diastase index = ml of 0.1% starch digested by 1ml of urine at 37°C in 30 minutes</p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>2</mn><mtext>Smallest&nbsp;volume&nbsp;of&nbsp;urine&nbsp;not&nbsp;giving&nbsp;a&nbsp;blue&nbsp;colour</mtext></mfrac></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">= \frac{2}{\text{Smallest volume of urine not giving a blue colour}}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.2019em; vertical-align: -0.8804em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3214em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Smallest&nbsp;volume&nbsp;of&nbsp;urine&nbsp;not&nbsp;giving&nbsp;a&nbsp;blue&nbsp;colour</span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8804em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p>Example If on completion of test, a blue colour was first noticed in tube 7, so the smallest volume of urine not showing a blue colour is 1.0 ml of 1:10 dilution in tube 6 (i.e., 0.1 ml)</p>
<p>Therefore</p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mtext>Diastase&nbsp;index</mtext><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>2</mn><mn>0.1</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>20</mn><mtext>&nbsp;units</mtext></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\text{Diastase index} = \frac{2}{0.1} = 20 \text{ units}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Diastase&nbsp;index</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.0074em; vertical-align: -0.686em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3214em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0.1</span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.686em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6679em;"></span><span class="mord">20</span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">&nbsp;units</span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p>The diastase index should be multiplied by the total volume of a 24 hour sample of mine.</p>
<p>Normal range Up to 3000 Caraway units for 24 hours</p>
<p>&gt; <strong>Note</strong>: Urinary amylase can also be estimated in the same way as serum amylase on a 24 hour specimen.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="clinical-significance">Clinical Significance<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#clinical-significance" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Increased serum amylase (&gt;1800 U/L) is diagnostic of acute pancreatitis. The rise in serum amylase level is often brief and the level may return to normal within 48–72 hours. Urinary amylase, on the other hand may persist for a longer period.</p>
<p>Serum amylase is moderately increased (740–1500 U/L) in conditions such as renal failure, diabetic ketoacidosis, hypothermia, perforated peptic ulcer or appendicitis. Normal values may be obtained in chronic pancreatitis.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="fibrocystic-disease-of-the-pancreas-cystic-fibrosis">Fibrocystic Disease of the Pancreas (Cystic fibrosis)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fibrocystic-disease-of-the-pancreas-cystic-fibrosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is a familial Mendelian recessive disease characterised by abnormally high secretion of sodium and chloride by the various exocrine glands of the body such as pancreas, salivary, peritracheal, sweat and lacrimal glands as well as the glands of the small intestine and bile ducts.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="laboratory-diagnosis">Laboratory diagnosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#laboratory-diagnosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>The principle is to demonstrate increased sodium and chloride in the sweat of patients. Screening test for sweat chloride depends upon hand imprints on agar or paper containing silver nitrate. Chloride precipitates with silver and intensity of the print is roughly proportional to the chloride precipitation. Chemical estimation is more reliable. Analysis of electrolytes in sweat is a most valuable investigation. Collection of sweat is carried out using:</p>
<p>(1) Methacholine chloride Injecting 2 mg of methacholine chloride into the forearm and covering the area with filter paper. This produces local stimulation of sweat. About 100–300 mg of sweat can be collected. This method is now obsolete.</p>
<p>(2) Pilocarpine iontophoresis A current of 1.5 mA is passed between the two electrodes for about 30 minutes. The positive electrode contains 0.5% aqueous pilocarpine nitrate solution while the negative electrode contains 1% aqueous sodium nitrate solution. Ashless filter paper saturated with pilocarpine nitrate solution is placed under the surface of the positive electrode and under the surface of the negative electrode is a gauze saturated</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>208 Clinical Chemistry</p>
<p>with sodium nitrate solution. The positive electrode is then strapped to the flexor surface and the negative electrode on the exterior surface of the forearm. The area of the positive is washed with distilled water. Whatman No. 40 filter paper of a known weight is carefully placed over the area and covered with parafilm. The sweat is collected for about 30 minutes. The paper is then removed, weighed, placed in a flask. The electrolytes are eluted with 10 ml distilled water. The concentration of sodium and chloride ions is measured in the usual way (Chapter 7).</p>
<p>A machine called the cystic fibrosis analyser, has been developed to stimulate sweat by a pilocarpine iontophoresis and to measure the sodium and chloride concentrations by conductivity meter.</p>
<p>(3) Wescar sweat collection system This system is also based on pilocarpine iontophoresis but uses a unique collection device—a heated cup which reduces evaporation and condensation errors. The sweat electrolytes are measured by the usual methods while sweat osmolality is by using a Wescar vapour pressure osmometer.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="normal-range">Normal range<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#normal-range" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="children">Children<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#children" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Sweat sodium: 70 mmol/L (upper limit)</p>
<p>Sweat chloride: 65 mmol/L (upper limit)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="adults">Adults<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#adults" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Sweat sodium: up to 90 mmol/L</p>
<p>Sweat chloride: upto 60 mmol/L</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Chapter 10</p>
<p>CSF and Other Body Fluids</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="cerebrospinal-fluid-csf">CEREBROSPINAL FLUID (CSF)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cerebrospinal-fluid-csf" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The investigation of clinical disorder of the central nervous system (CNS) is partly based on the examination of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). The central nervous system consists of the brain, spinal cord and peripheral nerves.</p>
<p>The brain is encased within the cranial cavity and weighs about one-fifth of the body weight. Structurally it is partitioned into the cerebrum (greater brain), the brain stem (midbrain, pons varolii and medulla oblongata) and the cerebellum (lesser brain) (Fig. 10.1 a). The brain is protected by the cranium, and the spinal cord by the vertebral column. The brain and the spinal cord are covered by three membranes collectively called the meninges. The meninges consist of</p>
<ol>
<li>An outer protective membrane called the dura mater;</li>
<li>A middle membrane called the arachnoid mater; and</li>
<li>An inner membrane called the pia mater (Fig. 10.1b).</li>
</ol>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-bd46e458.jpeg" alt="img-56.jpeg">
Fig. 10.1 (a) Human brain</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-39231ea8.jpeg" alt="img-57.jpeg">
Fig. 10.1 (b) The brain, spinal cord and the site of lumber puncture</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>210 Clinical Chemistry</p>
<p>The arachnoid mater and the pia mater are separated from each other by the subarachnoid space which is filled with the cerebrospinal fluid. Between the dura mater and the arachnoid mater is the subdural space.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="formation-of-cerebrospinal-fluid-csf">Formation of Cerebrospinal Fluid (CSF)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#formation-of-cerebrospinal-fluid-csf" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The lateral ventricle is a large irregularly shaped chamber that lies deep within each cerebral hemisphere. Within these lateral ventricles are vascular structures called choroid plexuses where the CSF is formed. The cells of choroid plexus actively secrete CSF. The fluid passes into the third ventricle via the interventricular foramen of Monro before flowing down to the cerebral aquaduct into a fourth ventricle. The fourth ventricle lies between the pons and cerebellum of the brain. The CSF then flows from the fourth ventricle down the small central canal of the spinal cord and through openings (foramina) into the subarachnoid space to completely surround the brain and the spinal cord. Small blood vessels in the arachnoid mater constantly reabsorb CSF in circulation so that the production is balanced by an equal reabsorption of fluid.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="functions-of-csf">Functions of CSF<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions-of-csf" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>CSF provides a “fluid cushion” to support and protect the brain and the spinal cord.</li>
<li>It acts as a shock absorber for the brain and the spinal cord.</li>
<li>It carries nutrients to the brain and spinal cord and removes waste products.</li>
<li>It helps to maintain a constant pressure inside the head and around the spinal cord.</li>
<li>It keeps the brain and spinal cord moist.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="collecting-csf">Collecting CSF<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#collecting-csf" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A specimen of CSF is collected by a lumbar puncture, using a long needle with a stylette inside. The needle is introduced between the third and fourth lumbar vertebrae into the spinal sub-arachnoid space with the patients back well flexed for good separation of the vertebrae. It is a very delicate operation and damage to the spinal cord can easily occur. The cord stops at the level of the first lumbar vertebra and cannot be damaged by the needle entering the subarachnoid space a few centimeters lower.</p>
<p>The CSF is usually collected into 2 or 3 sterile containers, numbered according to the order of collection, each containing about 1–3ml of CSF.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="possible-complications-of-lumbar-puncture">Possible complications of lumbar puncture<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#possible-complications-of-lumbar-puncture" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Production of cerebellar pressure cone in patients with increased intracranial pressure.</li>
<li>In the case of spinal cord tumour, paresis may progress to paralysis as a result of lumbar puncture.</li>
<li>During the whole process of lumbar puncture, infection can inadvertently be introduced by
(a) the use of unsterile equipment;
(b) by passing the needle through a septic spot in the lumbar region, and
(c) by not observing aseptic precautions.</li>
<li>After-puncture headache as a result of leakage of CSF. This condition can be minimised by using a small bore needle.</li>
<li>Infantile death due to asphyxiation caused by restraint or tracheal obstruction from pushing the head forward.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="indications-for-csf-examination">Indications for CSF examination<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#indications-for-csf-examination" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Diagnosis and detection of suspected meningitis, subarachnoid haemorrhage, encephalitis, central nervous system syphilis, spinal cord tumour or multiple sclerosis.</li>
<li>Differential diagnosis of cerebral infarction from intracerebral haemorrhage (about 80% of the latter show xanthochromia or bloody appearance of CSF).</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="composition-of-csf">Composition of CSF<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#composition-of-csf" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The CSF is mainly composed of water, dissolved oxygen and solids. The average volume is between</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>CSF and Other Body Fluids 211</p>
<p>100 ml and 150 ml which is produced at the rate of 430 ml/day. It is similar to plasma in composition, but the concentrations of sodium, chloride, magnesium and glutamine are greater in CSF than in plasma; while concentrations of glucose, potassium, calcium, cholesterol, uric acid and iron are higher in plasma.</p>
<p>Table 10.1 shows the composition of normal CSF.</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Volume</th><th>100–150 ml</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Total Protein</td><td>0.15–0.45 g/L</td></tr><tr><td>Glucose</td><td>3–4.5 mmol/L</td></tr><tr><td>(50–80 mg%)</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Chloride</td><td>118–132 mmol/l</td></tr><tr><td>Sodium</td><td>144–154 mmol/l</td></tr><tr><td>Potassium</td><td>2.0–3.5 mmol/l</td></tr><tr><td>Iron</td><td>0.2–0.4 mmol/l</td></tr><tr><td>pH</td><td>7.3–7.4</td></tr><tr><td>Cells</td><td>0–5 lymphocytes/cu.mm</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>♦ ROUTINE LABORATORY EXAMINATION OF CSF</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="macroscopic-gross-examination">Macroscopic (gross) Examination<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#macroscopic-gross-examination" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Appearance</strong> Normal CSF is clear and colourless. Colour can be evaluated by holding CSF tube beside a distilled water tube against a clean white paper.</p>
<p><strong>Turbidity</strong> A purulent or turbid or markedly cloudy CSF is associated with meningitis caused by pyogenic bacteria such as <em>Neisseria meningitidis</em>, <em>Streptococcus pneumoniae</em>, and <em>Haemophilus influenzae</em>. The turbidity may be due to large numbers of pus cells (leucocytes above 200 × 10⁶/l) or bacteria. It may be slightly cloudy in tuberculous or viral meningitis and trypanosomiasis.</p>
<p><strong>Blood</strong> The presence of blood in CSF is often a result of traumatic lumbar puncture. Pathological causes of blood in CSF include a recent subarachnoid bleeding and meningoencephalitis caused by pathogenic amoebae such as <em>Naegleria</em> species. Blood stained CSF is not suitable for biochemical analysis. If blood in CSF is due to a traumatic tap, the first tube collected will contain more blood than the succeeding tubes. If all the tubes are bloody to the same degree a haemorrhage in the brain or spinal cord is more likely.</p>
<p><strong>Xanthochromia</strong> Pale yellow or yellow coloured CSF is described as xanthochromic. It is associated with the breakdown of haemoglobin as a result of earlier subarachnoid haemorrhage, cerebral tumour or jaundice. Yellow colour may also be due to high level of protein (over 100 mg %) or contamination of CSF by iodine or methiolate used to disinfect the skin.</p>
<p><strong>Note:</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Xanthochromia due to subarachnoid bleeding appears in CSF within 2–12 hours in most cases.</li>
<li>Xanthochromia due to jaundice appears within 2–4 days and may persist for up to 40 days.</li>
<li>Blood in CSF due to subarachnoid bleeding may disappear within 24 hours but generally persists for up to 14 days.</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>Clot</strong> Clotting or coagulation occurs on standing in specimen containing enough fibrinogen. It is usually indicative of markedly elevated protein concentration. It can also occur in moderately elevated protein concentration as in TB meningitis where a web-like clot usually forms; this usually contains the tubercle bacilli. Clotting is also a common feature of traumatic tap.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="cell-count">Cell Count<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cell-count" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Normally there are no red cells in CSF. The normal white cell count in CSF is 0–5/cu.mm. (μl). A predominance of polymorphonuclear cells indicates a pyogenic bacterial infection while the presence of many mononuclear cells indicates a viral, tubercular or fungal infection.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>212 Clinical Chemistry</p>
<p>Many workers place emphasis on white blood cell count only. The argument is that the number of red blood cells counted is not an important diagnostic tool. What is important is to describe CSF as slightly, moderately or grossly blood stained.</p>
<p>The rules of counting cells in blood are loosely applied to CSF. The Fuch-Rosenthal counting chamber was originally designed for counting cells in CSF. It has a depth of 0.2 mm and the ruled area has 16 squares, 1 mm² each, divided by triple lines. Each of these 16 squares is subdivided into 16 smaller squares, each with an area of 1/16 of 1 mm. The new type of Fuch-Rosenthal counting chamber has the same depth but is ruled over 9 mm² only. Many workers prefer to use the popular improved Neubauer counting chamber which has a depth 0.1 mm and is ruled over 9 mm².</p>
<p><strong>Diluting the CSF</strong> CSF is diluted 1:20 with the WBC diluting fluid which lyses all the red blood cells present and makes the WBC easily visible. A suitable diluting fluid is 2% acetic acid (20 ml per litre) tinged with a few drops of crystal or gentian violet. This fluid also stains the white cells. A simple, though not very accurate, method for dilution is 1 drop of CSF + 19 drops of diluting fluid. The drops must be of the same size. Leave for about 2–3 minutes and then charge the chamber to count the white cells.</p>
<p>For a clear and colourless CSF the count can be done using the neat specimen.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="calculations">Calculations<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#calculations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Count cells in 4 large squares (4 mm²) of improved Neubauer counting chamber.</li>
</ol>
<p>Number of cells counted = N</p>
<p>Dilution factor = 20</p>
<p>Depth of chamber = 0.1</p>
<p>Therefore white cell count = <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>N</mi><mo>×</mo><mn>20</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>0.1</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\frac{N \times 20}{4 \times 0.1}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.2757em; vertical-align: -0.4033em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8723em;"><span style="top: -2.655em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">4</span><span class="mbin mtight">×</span><span class="mord mtight">0.1</span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.394em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight" style="margin-right: 0.10903em;">N</span><span class="mbin mtight">×</span><span class="mord mtight">20</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.4033em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span></span></span></span></span></p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>N</mi><mo>×</mo><mn>20</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>10</mn></mrow><mn>4</mn></mfrac></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">= \frac{N \times 20 \times 10}{4}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.0463em; vertical-align: -0.686em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3603em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">4</span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.10903em;">N</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mord">20</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mord">10</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.686em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mo>=</mo><mi>N</mi><mo>×</mo><mn>50</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mtext>cu&nbsp;mm</mtext></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">= N \times 50 / \text{cu mm}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7667em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.10903em;">N</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">50/</span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">cu&nbsp;mm</span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<ol start="2">
<li>Using improved Neubauer counting chamber and neat sample.</li>
</ol>
<p>White cell count = <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>N</mi><mo>×</mo><mn>10</mn></mrow><mn>4</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mi>N</mi><mo>×</mo><mn>2.5</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mtext>cu.mm</mtext></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\frac{N \times 10}{4} = N \times 2.5 / \text{cu.mm}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.2173em; vertical-align: -0.345em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8723em;"><span style="top: -2.655em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">4</span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.394em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight" style="margin-right: 0.10903em;">N</span><span class="mbin mtight">×</span><span class="mord mtight">10</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.345em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7667em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.10903em;">N</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">2.5/</span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">cu.mm</span></span></span></span></span></span></p>
<ol start="3">
<li>Using Fuch-Rosenthal counting chamber and neat sample</li>
</ol>
<p>Count cells in 5 large square = N</p>
<p>Cell count is N cells/cu.mm</p>
<p><strong>Differential count</strong> Spin the CSF and make smears from the deposit. Stain with Leishman or Giemsa stain as for blood smear. Count the cells, expressing the number and type of white blood cells as percentages, with more emphasis on polymorphs and mononuclear cells. For example, polymorphs 70%, mononuclear cells 30%. If any abnormal cells, such as tumour cells are detected, the specimen should be referred for cytological examination.</p>
<p><strong>Types of cells in CSF</strong> in various disease conditions:</p>
<ol>
<li>Large numbers of polymorphs are seen in pyogenic meningitis caused by:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li><em>Neissria meningitidis</em></li>
<li><em>Haemophilus influenzae</em></li>
<li><em>Streptococcus pneumoniae</em></li>
<li><em>Streptococcus Group B</em></li>
<li><em>Staphylococcus aureus</em></li>
<li><em>Escherichia coli</em></li>
</ul>
<ol start="2">
<li>Mixed cellular representation (polymorphs, lymphocytes and monocytes) is seen in cases of</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Subacute bacterial meningitis</li>
<li>Tuberculous meningitis</li>
<li>Fungal meningitis</li>
<li>Viral meningoencephalitis</li>
</ul>
<ol start="3">
<li>Large numbers of lymphocytes and monocytes are seen in cases of</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Viral meningoencephalitis</li>
<li>Multiple sclerosis</li>
<li>Tuberculous meningitis</li>
<li>Fungal meningitis</li>
<li>Syphilitic meningitis</li>
</ul>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>CSF and Other Body Fluids 213</p>
