<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="chemical-examination-of-csf">Chemical Examination of CSF<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chemical-examination-of-csf" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="proteins">Proteins<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#proteins" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Turbidimetric methods are commonly employed for the estimation of total proteins in CSF.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="turbidimetric-methods">Turbidimetric methods<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#turbidimetric-methods" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Principle</strong> Proteins in CSF are precipitated by either dilute trichloroacetic acid or sulphosalicylic acid in sodium sulphate solution. The turbidity of the resultant uniform suspension is measured in a colorimeter against a known standard.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="trichloroacetic-acid-method">Trichloroacetic Acid method<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#trichloroacetic-acid-method" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="reagents">Reagents<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#reagents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Trichloroacetic acid 3% aqueous solution.</li>
<li>Stock standard protein solution 5.0 g/L in 0.90% NaCl: Distribute in small volumes and store at -18°C. The standard can be prepared from diluted pooled serum, or making suitable dilutions of commercial control serum or from bovine albumin.</li>
<li>Working standard protein solution 0.5 g/L (50 mg %): Dilute the stock standard 1 in 10 with 0.9% NaCl. Fresh stock is to be prepared each week and stored in 1.5ml volumes at about -18°C. Thaw a sample for use each day.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="method">Method<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#method" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>To 4.0 ml of trichloracetic acid, add 1.0 ml of CSF drop by drop with constant mixing.</li>
<li>In the same manner, add 1.0 ml of standard to 4.0 ml of trichloroacetic acid.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="preparation-of-calibration-curve">Preparation of calibration curve<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#preparation-of-calibration-curve" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Dilute the stock standard protein (5.0 g/L) 1 in 5 with 0.9% NaCl (saline) and prepare a series of tubes as follows:</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>g protein per litre CSF</th><th>0</th><th>0.1</th><th>0.2</th><th>0.3</th><th>0.4</th><th>0.5</th><th>0.6</th><th>0.7</th><th>0.8</th><th>0.9</th><th>1.0</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>ml of standard protein solution (1g/L)</td><td>0</td><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>ml of saline</td><td>10</td><td>9</td><td>8</td><td>7</td><td>6</td><td>5</td><td>4</td><td>3</td><td>2</td><td>1</td><td>0</td></tr></tbody></table>
<ol start="3">
<li>Add 1.0 ml distilled water to 4.0ml trichloroacetic acid. This is the blank.</li>
<li>Stand at room temperature for 10 minutes and remix the turbid solutions.</li>
<li>Read the absorbances of the standard and test against the blank at 450 nm or by using a blue filter.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="calculations">Calculations<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#calculations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>T = Absorbance of Test; S = Absorbance of standard</p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mfrac><mi>T</mi><mi>S</mi></mfrac><mo>×</mo><mn>0.5</mn><mo>=</mo><mi>g</mi><mtext>&nbsp;CSF&nbsp;protein&nbsp;per&nbsp;litre</mtext></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\frac{T}{S} \times 0.5 = g \text{ CSF protein per litre}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.0463em; vertical-align: -0.686em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3603em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05764em;">S</span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.13889em;">T</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.686em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">0.5</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.03588em;">g</span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">&nbsp;CSF&nbsp;protein&nbsp;per&nbsp;litre</span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p>To convert to mg/100 ml (mg %), multiply by 100.</p>
<p><strong>Note</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Use appropriate dilutions if the value of the test exceeds the upper limit of the method as established by a calibration curve.</li>
<li>A calibration curve will show if a linear relationship holds for increasing protein concentration and should be prepared for each photometric instrument.</li>
<li>The method is temperature dependent.</li>
<li>The size and shape of the particles affect the absorbance. The tubes must be shaken to mix constantly for up to 4 times.</li>
</ol>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>214 Clinical Chemistry</p>
<p>Mix well; add 1.0 ml of each standard protein solution to 4.0 ml trichloroacetic acid. Read the absorbance at 450 nm (blue filter). A straight line calibration curve is obtained if the absorbance is linear.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="method-using-permanent-standard">Method using permanent standard<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#method-using-permanent-standard" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This method is not very accurate but it is such a rapid and simple method that most bacteriology laboratories which are not usually equipped for chemical procedures, find it of adequate accuracy.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="reagents">Reagents<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#reagents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>3% Sulphosalicylic acid.</li>
<li>Permanent protein standard marked in mg/100 ml (10–100 mg/100 ml) supplied commercially.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="method">Method<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#method" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Add 1.0 ml of clear CSF to 3.0 ml of sulphosalicylic acid in a standard test tube.</li>
<li>Mix contents and leave for 5 minutes.</li>
<li>Compare the tube with the turbidity standards.</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>Results</strong> Normal CSF contains protein between 0.15–0.45 g/L (15 to 45 mg/100 ml). If the value of the CSF protein is higher than 100 mg/100 ml, dilute with saline and adjust the result accordingly.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="micromethod">Micromethod<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#micromethod" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This method is very useful when the volume of the CSF is small.</p>
<p><strong>Reagent</strong> 3% aqueous trichloroacetic acid.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="method">Method<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#method" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Set up 3 test tubes as follows:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Blank: 0.2 ml of saline</li>
<li>Standard: 0.2 ml of standard protein</li>
<li>Test: 0.2 ml of CSF</li>
</ul>
<ol start="2">
<li>Add to all tubes 0.8 ml of 3.0% trichloroacetic acid. Mix by inverting about 5 times. Allow to stand for 10 minutes. Read absorbance of the standard and test against the blank at 450 nm with glass microcuvettes of 1 cm light path.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="calculation">Calculation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#calculation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mfrac><mtext>Ab&nbsp;Test</mtext><mtext>Ab&nbsp;Standard</mtext></mfrac><mo>×</mo><mn>0.5</mn><mo>=</mo><mtext>g&nbsp;CSF&nbsp;proteins/L</mtext></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\frac{\text{Ab Test}}{\text{Ab Standard}} \times 0.5 = \text{g CSF proteins/L}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.0574em; vertical-align: -0.686em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3714em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Ab&nbsp;Standard</span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Ab&nbsp;Test</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.686em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">0.5</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">g&nbsp;CSF&nbsp;proteins/L</span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="globulin">Globulin<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#globulin" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Tests for globulin are performed only on blood-free CSF specimens.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="c8b9c1d0">1. Pandy’s test<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c8b9c1d0" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p><strong>Principle</strong> In a saturated aqueous solution of phenol, globulin molecule absorbs water and the phenol is displaced from the solution, causing a fine persistent turbidity.</p>
<p><strong>Method</strong> Add 1 drop of CSF to 0.5 ml of saturated aqueous solution of phenol (must be very clear) in a small test tube. Cloudiness/turbidity against a dark background indicates increase in globulin content. Normal CSF remains clear.</p>
<p>Report as Nil, +, ++, +++ or ++++.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="3fa40146">2. Nonne-Apelt’s method<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3fa40146" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p><strong>Principle</strong> Globulin is precipitated by solution of saturated ammonium sulphate.</p>
<p><strong>Method</strong> Carefully layer 1.0 ml of clear CSF on to 1.0 ml of saturated ammonium sulphate. A thin white ring of precipitation appears at the interface of the two liquids. On mixing, the ring may disappear indicating a 1+ reaction. Heavy cloudiness indicates a 4+ reaction.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="3-radial-immunodiffusion-test">3. Radial Immunodiffusion test<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-radial-immunodiffusion-test" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>This is a useful test for the measurement of concentrations of albumin and globulin in CSF. This involves the diffusion of an antigen (IgG or albumin) in the CSF through a semi-solid medium containing an antibody (anti-IgG or anti albumin), thereby forming visible zones of precipitation. The measurement of the zones of precipitation corresponds to the concentration of the antigen. This method also determines IgG/albumin ratio which is of diagnostic importance in multiple sclerosis and other neurological disorders.</p>
<p>&gt; <strong>Note</strong>
&gt; Electrophoresis of CSF protein can also be carried out to evaluate albumin and globulin content in CSF. The Lange’s colloidal gold test, though now possible, is a good substitute for electrophoresis.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>CSF and Other Body Fluids 215</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="normal-range">Normal range<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#normal-range" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Normal CSF contains approximately 60% albumin, 8% immunoglobulins and 32% other proteins.
IgG/albumin ratio: 17.5
IgG index: &lt; 0.7</p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mo fence="true">(</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">I</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">G</mi><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">i</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">n</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">d</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">e</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">x</mi></mrow><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">F</mi><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">I</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">G</mi></mrow><mo>×</mo><mtext>serum&nbsp;albumin</mtext></mrow><mrow><mtext>serum&nbsp;IgG</mtext><mo>×</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">F</mi><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">b</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">u</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">i</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">n</mi></mrow></mrow></mfrac><mo fence="true">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\left(\mathrm{IgG\ index} = \frac{\mathrm{CSF\ IgG} \times \text{serum albumin}}{\text{serum IgG} \times \mathrm{CSF\ albumin}}\right)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.4em; vertical-align: -0.95em;"></span><span class="minner"><span class="mopen delimcenter" style="top: 0em;"><span class="delimsizing size3">(</span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">IgG</span><span class="mspace">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">index</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3714em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">serum&nbsp;IgG</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">CSF</span><span class="mspace">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">albumin</span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">CSF</span><span class="mspace">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">IgG</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">serum&nbsp;albumin</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8804em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mclose delimcenter" style="top: 0em;"><span class="delimsizing size3">)</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="clinical-significance">Clinical Significance<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#clinical-significance" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="increase-in-csf-proteins">Increase in CSF proteins<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#increase-in-csf-proteins" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>(a) Mild increase can be seen in viral meningitis, neurosyphilis, subdural haematoma, cerebral thrombosis, brain tumour, multiple sclerosis.
(b) CSF globulins, especially the immunoglobulin IgG, are raised in cases of multiple sclerosis, neurosyphilis.
(c) Pronounced increase in CSF proteins is seen in acute bacterial meningitis, tuberculous meningitis, spinal cord tumour, cerebral haemorrhage and intracranial tumour.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="glucose">Glucose<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#glucose" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>CSF glucose is estimated in the same way as for blood glucose. Usually CSF glucose less than 40 mg/100 ml is considered as a reduced level.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="disease-conditions-that-effect-the-csf-glucose-level">Disease conditions that effect the CSF glucose level<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#disease-conditions-that-effect-the-csf-glucose-level" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>|  Viral meningitis
Neurosyphilis
Brain or cord tumour
Cerebral thrombosis</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Multiple sclerosis</th><th>No significant change</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>CNS leukaemia</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Subarachnoid haemorrhage</td><td>Moderate reduction</td></tr><tr><td>Bacterial meningitis</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Tuberculous meningitis</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Fungal meningitis</td><td>Marked reduction</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>It is essential that the glucose assay is carried out as soon as possible after collection in order to prevent the action of glycolytic enzymes in the CSF. This may result in the reduction of glucose level.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="bacteriological-examination-of-csf">Bacteriological Examination of CSF<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bacteriological-examination-of-csf" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>CSF for bacterial examination must reach the laboratory as soon as possible after collection in a sterile container. The examination involves mainly (1) Grams stain and any other stain requested for, (2) Isolation of pathogens, (3) Serology.</p>
<p>Bacteriological examination of CSF is discussed in the Microbiology Section of this book.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="synovial-fluid">SYNOVIAL FLUID<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#synovial-fluid" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The synovial fluid (SF) is found in each large joint such as the knee, ankle, wrist, hip, elbow and shoulder. About 1ml of the fluid is normally present.</p>
<p>To aspirate the fluid, aseptic precautions must be observed. The fluid is commonly sterile. It is collected into sterile containers and then sent to the laboratory without delay for the microbiological examination. For serological tests, a chemically clean tube should be used. In most cases EDTA or heparinised tubes are used to prevent clotting.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="bacteriological-examination-of-synovial-fluid">Bacteriological Examination of Synovial Fluid<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bacteriological-examination-of-synovial-fluid" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The procedure is similar to that used for CSF. Refer to the Microbiology Section of this book.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="viscosity-of-synovial-fluid">Viscosity of Synovial Fluid<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#viscosity-of-synovial-fluid" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Normal synovial fluid will form a tenacious strand about 4–6cm long if allowed to drop from the end of the needle. A strand of less than 3 cm indicates reduced viscosity. Viscosity is evaluated in the laboratory by the mucin clot test.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>216 Clinical Chemistry</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="mucin-clot-test">Mucin Clot Test<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mucin-clot-test" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><strong>Principle</strong> This test is based on the polymerisation of hyaluronidase.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="method">Method<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#method" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Add synovial fluid drop by drop to about 20 ml of 5% acetic acid in a beaker.</p>
<p>A normal synovial fluid will form a firm clot with clear surrounding fluid.</p>
<p>A poor clot is surrounded by a cloudy fluid and may fragment easily. This indicates an inflammatory condition.</p>
<p>The clots can be graded as good, fair, poor or very poor depending on the firmness of the clot and the clarity of the surrounding fluid. If no clot forms, only flakes in a cloudy fluid are seen, it is regarded as a very poor clot.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="microscopic-examination-of-synovial-fluid">Microscopic Examination of Synovial Fluid<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#microscopic-examination-of-synovial-fluid" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Total and differential white cell count is performed as for CSF.</p>
<p>Crystals such as monosodium urates (MSU) which are needle or rod shaped, and calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate (CPPD) crystals which are rhomboid or rod shaped may be present. They are better seen in wet preparation viewed with polarised or light microscope. The MSU crystals are seen in cases of gout joints while CPPD crystals are seen in pseudogout.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="262056e2">♦ PLEURAL FLUID<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#262056e2" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The pleurae are two thin sheets of tissues that cover the lungs. The inner (or visceral) pleura is a serous membrane which closely surrounds the lung while the outer (or parietal) pleura lines the thoracic cavity. The two layers are joined at the root of the lung.</p>
<p>Normally, the two pleurae are separated by 1 to 10 ml of fluid so that during normal breathing they slide smoothly over each other. The volume of this fluid is increased in some diseased conditions such as pneumonia, tuberculosis, lung cancer etc. This increase in volume of the liquid is called pleural effusion. If the amount is large it can result in difficulty in breathing.</p>
<p>The pleural fluid is collected in three sterile anticoagulated EDTA tubes labelled sequentially. The first tube is used for bacteriological examination. The remaining two are used for cell counts, differential counts, total protein, glucose and cytology.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="macroscopic-gross-examination">Macroscopic (Gross) Examination<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#macroscopic-gross-examination" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Normally the pleural fluid is straw coloured, but very often it is blood stained. This appearance may be due to existing haemorrhage or trauma. Usually in traumatic tap, the fluid becomes clearer in the successive containers.</p>
<p>Haemorrhagic pleural fluid is prevalent in intrapleural malignancy. It is found also in pancreatitis, pulmonary infarction, tuberculosis and very occasionally in congestive heart failure and liver cirrhosis.</p>
<p>Cloudy or turbid fluid is usually due to the large number of pus cells associated with inflammation. Milky fluid can occur in cases of tuberculosis and rheumatoid arthritis.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="microscopic-examination">Microscopic Examination<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#microscopic-examination" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Follow the same procedure as for CSF. A white cell count of over 1000/cu.mm or over 50% polymorphs in the differential count is indicative of septic inflammation.</p>
<p>A predominance of lymphocytes (&gt;75%) is highly suggestive of tuberculosis, lymphoma or carcinoma. Lymphocytosis (lymphatic pleural effusion) may also be seen in cardiopulmonary disease, cirrhosis, systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), infectious mononucleosis and subacute bacterial pulmonary infection.</p>
<p>Occasionally, rheumatoid arthritis (RA) cells are seen in rheumatoid pleural effusion while lupus erythematosus (LE) cells are seen in SLE. High percentage of eosinophils (Eosinophilic pleural</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>CSF and Other Body Fluids 217</p>
<p>effusion) is present in late pneumonia, pulmonary infarction, asthma and parasitic diseases. The presence of immature blood cells in pleural fluid indicates chronic myeloid leukaemia or myeloid metaplasia.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="bacteriological-examination">Bacteriological Examination<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bacteriological-examination" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Pleural fluid, like the CSF, is examined for bacteria by Gram's stain and culture. Tuberculosis should also be excluded. Refer to the Microbiology Section for details.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="biochemical-examination">Biochemical Examination<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#biochemical-examination" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Glucose and protein estimations are the major biochemical tests done on pleural fluid. Normally, pleural fluid glucose level is about the same as blood glucose. In case of bacterial infection, non-septic inflammations or malignancy, the glucose level is less than that of blood. Protein level is normally slightly raised in pleural fluid.</p>
<p><strong>Estimation of glucose</strong> same as for blood glucose.</p>
<p><strong>Estimation of proteins</strong> Same as for CSF proteins.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="peritoneal-fluid">PERITONEAL FLUID<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#peritoneal-fluid" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Normally the peritoneal cavity contains just about 100 ml of clear straw-coloured fluid. Like most other body fluids, the peritoneal fluid is collected into clean sterile containers containing 3.8% sodium citrate or heparin to prevent clotting; and sent to the laboratory without delay.</p>
<p>Peritoneal fluid, is examined under the following conditions:</p>
<ol>
<li>Ascitis of known and unknown aetiology.</li>
<li>Acute abdominal pain of unknown aetiology.</li>
<li>Possible ruptured abdominal organ.</li>
<li>Post-operative complications.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="macroscopic-examination">Macroscopic Examination<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#macroscopic-examination" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Normal peritoneal fluid is pale and straw coloured. An abnormal fluid may appear cloudy, turbid or bloody. Turbidity indicates an inflammatory reaction whereas blood may be due to various disease conditions or due to a traumatic tap.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="microscopic-examination">Microscopic Examination<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#microscopic-examination" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Microscopy and cell count are performed in the same way as for CSF. Both the white and red cell counts are good diagnostic tools. Increased white cell count with predominantly neutrophils is highly indicative of acute peritonitis. A high count of lymphocytes is suggestive of possible tuberculous peritonitis.</p>
<p>Papanicoleau stained smears should be examined. A study of exfoliated cells may rule out neoplasm.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="bacteriological-examination">Bacteriological Examination<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bacteriological-examination" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Smears are made from the deposit of centrifugal sample; and stained by Gram's stain and Ziehl Neilsen stain. Cultures are done in same manner as for CSF to isolate any causative pathogen.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="biochemical-examination">Biochemical Examination<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#biochemical-examination" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A routine biochemical examination is performed in the same manner as for CSF. A low (acid) pH of peritoneal fluid is highly suggestive of perforated peptic ulcer. Amylase level is raised in case of acute pancreatitis. In malignancy of peritoneum and haemorrhage, the fluid LDH level is raised.</p>
<p>&gt; <strong>Note</strong>
&gt; In trying to aspirate peritoneal transudate, urine may be accidentally aspirated. Simultaneous measurements of creatinine and urea nitrogen on blood and fluid provide differential diagnosis. High levels of fluid urea and creatinine with normal serum levels suggest that there was an inadvertent aspiration of urine from the urinary bladder.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Chapter 11
Endocrine Function Tests</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="hormones-and-endocrine-glands">HORMONES AND ENDOCRINE GLANDS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hormones-and-endocrine-glands" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A hormone is a substance produced by specific tissue or gland within the body which conveys a message to regulate the function of another tissue or gland, the target tissue. These specific tissues may be grouped together into an organ or may be discretely distributed. The organs which produce hormones are called endocrine or ductless glands because the hormones produced by them are directly released into the circulating blood as it passes through them. The major endocrine glands in the body are the hypothalamus, pituitary, adrenal, thyroid, testes in men and ovaries in female.</p>
<p>These glands, along with some tissue cells scattered in other non-endocrine organs such as the stomach and pancreas, form the endocrine system. The function of the endocrine system is to co-ordinate and correlate the various metabolic activities of the body with the help of hormones. They maintain chemical composition of extracellular and intracellular fluids for proper function of the body. The hormones regulate the metabolism of salt, water, carbohydrate, protein and fat. Whenever this balance is disturbed, appropriate hormones come into play to correct it. If, for example, there is an increase in blood glucose level due to high carbohydrate intake, insulin is promptly secreted by the pancreas to monitor breakdown of glucose until the glucose level has returned to normal.</p>
<p>However, even though a particular hormone mainly influences a single metabolic event, other hormones produced by different endocrine glands may also be important in regulating a single function. For example, insulin alone is not adequate to maintain the balance of carbohydrate metabolism. Other hormones such as glucagon from the pancreas, growth hormone from the pituitary, glucocortocosteroids and adrenaline from the adrenal glands, thyroxine from thyroid glands and oestrogens from gonads work together to maintain the carbohydrate metabolism. Autonomic nervous system is also involved to adjust the rate of blood flow and blood pressure. Derangement of this coordination and interrelation may give rise to disease states.</p>
<p>The hormones produced by various endocrine glands and their interrelationships are shown in Fig. 11.1.</p>
<p>Chemically, hormones may be steroids such as cortisol, polypeptides such as adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) and growth hormone; and substances derived from amino acids such as thyroxine and catecholamines. They are required in very small amount to perform their functions. The hormones can increase, decrease or coordinate the activities of other glands or organs in the body to maintain a stable state of equilibrium in all its functions. A balanced hormonal function is necessary to maintain controlled cell propagation and normal metabolic activity. Some</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Endocrine Function Tests 219</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-e62853e4.jpeg" alt="img-58.jpeg">
Fig. 11.1 Major endocrine glands and their hormones</p>
<p>hormones, such as the growth hormone secreted by anterior pituitary gland, directly influence tissue metabolism. Others, such as trophic hormones from the pituitary, stimulate other endocrine glands such as adrenal to synthesize further hormones, which partly control the trophic hormone released by a phenomenon called negative inhibition.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="hypothalamus">HYPOTHALAMUS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hypothalamus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The hypothalamus is a specialised area of the brain. It does not have a definite anatomical boundary. It lies below the third ventricle of the brain and directly above the pituitary gland. The nerve cells (neurones) of the hypothalamus are members of both the nervous and the endocrine system. When activated by a stimulus from the central nervous system, the cell bodies of the neurones release their hormones which are carried by blood vessels to the anterior lobe of pituitary gland. These hormones (factors) stimulate the production of respective hormones in the anterior pituitary. Such hormones are known as trophic hormones. They are:</p>
<ol>
<li>Growth hormone releasing factor (GHRF)</li>
<li>(a) Prolactin releasing factor (PRF)
(b) Prolactin inhibiting factor (PIF)</li>
<li>Corticotropic releasing factor (CRF)</li>
<li>Gonadotropin releasing factor (GnRH)</li>
<li>Thyrotropin</li>
</ol>
<p>Two more hormones, vasopressin (antidiuretic hormone, ADH) and oxytocin are also synthesised by the hypothalamus. They are transported by the nerve fibres to the posterior pituitary, without involving the blood vessels. These hormones are stored in the posterior pituitary until required.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>220 Clinical Chemistry</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="92d869ce">♦ PITUITARY GLAND<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#92d869ce" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The pituitary gland is a small gland situated at the base of the brain in close association with the hypothalamus. The gland consists of two parts, the anterior pituitary made up of glandular tissue, and the posterior pituitary, which is an extension of hypothalamus, consists of nervous tissue (Fig. 11.2).</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-47a93c00.jpeg" alt="img-59.jpeg">
Fig. 11.2 Relationship between the hypothalamus and the pituitary</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="hormones-produced-by-anterior-pituitary">Hormones Produced by Anterior Pituitary<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hormones-produced-by-anterior-pituitary" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The anterior pituitary produces several hormones (Fig. 11.1). Out of these, the growth hormone and prolactin have direct target tissues. The others are trophic hormones, that is, they stimulate the activity of other endocrine glands. The ACTH stimulates the adrenal cortex, the TSH stimulates the thyroid gland whereas LH and FSH control the activity of the gonads.</p>
<ol>
<li>Growth hormone (GH) This hormone is essential for normal growth. With the help of liver, GH brings about skeletal growth. Carbohydrate metabolism is affected by GH by antagonising insulin leading to hyperglycaemia. GH also stimulates fat metabolism, increasing free fatty acids in the serum.</li>
</ol>
<p>Increased level of growth hormone may cause: Gigantism Excess of GH secretion in childhood causes gigantism, reaching heights of up to 7 feet. The patients may have a short life as a result of infection, cardiac failure or due to pituitary tumours. Acromegaly This results from GH excess in adults. It causes increase in skeletal bones and soft tissues, excessive hair growth, impaired tolerance and menstrual disturbances.</p>
<p>Deficiency of growth hormone in adults does not show clinical symptoms.</p>
<p>Dwarfism: This is retardation of growth in children.</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>Prolactin Prolactin stimulates and sustains lactation after childbirth.</li>
</ol>
<p>Hyperprolactenaemia is an important cause of amenorrhoea and infertility. Deficiency of prolactin causes failure of lactation.</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) ACTH is a trophic hormone. It stimulates the synthesis and secretion of steroid hormones, (except aldosterone) from the adrenal cortex and maintains the growth of adrenal cortex. A part of the hormone molecule has melanin stimulating activity.</li>
</ol>
<p>Excess of ACTH may cause Cushing's syndrome whereas deficiency may lead to secondary adrenal hypofunction.</p>
<ol start="4">
<li>Thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH) TSH acts on the thyroid gland to produce thyroid hormones—thyroxine and triiodothyronine.</li>
</ol>
<p>Secretion of TSH from the anterior pituitary is controlled by circulating concentrations of thyroid hormones and thyrotropin releasing hormone from the hypothalamus.</p>
<p>Excess of TSH may rarely cause hyperthyroidism and deficiency can cause secondary hypothyroidism.</p>
<ol start="5">
<li>Gonadotrophins Gonadotrophin releasing hormone (GnRH) from the hypothalamus regulates the secretion of gonadotrophic hormones, namely luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle stimulating hormone (FSH). LH and FSH control the function</li>
</ol>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Endocrine Function Tests 221</p>
<p>and secretion of hormones by the testes and ovaries. LH primarily stimulates the production of hormones by the male/female gonads, where as FSH stimulates the development of the respective germ cells (ovulation in women and spermatogenesis in men).</p>
<p>Hypersecretion of LH or FSH may be responsible for early puberty where as deficiency may cause infertility and secondary hypogonadism (underdevelopment of gonads).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="hormones-released-by-posterior-pituitary">Hormones Released by Posterior Pituitary<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hormones-released-by-posterior-pituitary" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Two hormones, antidiuretic hormone (ADH) and oxytocin are synthesised in the hypothalamus and transported down the nerve fibres to posterior pituitary. Each is released into the bloodstream under hypothalamic control.</p>
<ol>
<li>Antidiuretic hormone (ADH) ADH enhances water reabsorption from the collecting ducts in the kidneys, irrespective of the solute concentration.</li>
</ol>
<p>Deficiency of ADH leads to a condition called diabetes insipidus in which excess of water is excreted by the kidneys, resulting in concentration of body fluids with a tendency to dehydrate. Excessive secretion of ADH results in low sodium concentration with water retention.</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>Oxytocin Oxytocin controls the ejection of milk from the lactating breasts and may have a role in initiating uterine concentrations at childbirth.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="hypopituitarism-reduced-activity">Hypopituitarism (Reduced activity)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hypopituitarism-reduced-activity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Reduced activity of pituitary gland may occur due to tumour, surgery, head injury or infections. It may lead to conditions such as secondary hypogonadism (LH, FSH), growth retardation in children (GH), secondary hypothyroidism (TSH), secondary adrenocortical deficiency (ACTH) or prolactin deficiency.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="hyperpituitarism-excess-secretion">Hyperpituitarism (Excess secretion)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hyperpituitarism-excess-secretion" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Tumours of secretory cells may result in excess secretions of hormones leading to amenorrhoea and infertility (prolactin), acromegaly or gigantism (GH) or Cushing’s syndrome (ACTH).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="adrenal-glands">ADRENAL GLANDS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#adrenal-glands" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The adrenal glands are paired, pyramid-like structures situated above each kidney. Each weighs about 5-10g. Figure 11.3 shows a cross section through the adrenal glands.</p>
<p>The adrenal glands are embryologically and functionally divided into two distinct parts:</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="adrenal-cortex">Adrenal Cortex<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#adrenal-cortex" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This forms a part of the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal endocrine system. It makes up about 80% of the gland, is firm and golden yellow in colour. Morphologically, adrenal cortex consists of three layers.</p>
<p>Zona glomerulosa is the outer thin layer which secretes aldosterone hormone.</p>
<p>Zona fasciculata is the middle layer which is the widest and is made up of lipid rich cells. These cells synthesise most of the cortisol, a glucocorticoid.</p>
<p>Zona reticularis is the innermost layer and has cells similar to those in zona fasciculata, but have less lipid. These cells synthesise most of the androgen.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="adrenal-medulla">Adrenal Medulla<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#adrenal-medulla" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The innermost portion of the gland is soft and reddish brown in clour. The adrenal medulla is a part of the sympathetic nervous system. It produces epinephrine (adrenalin) and norepinephrine (noradrenalin).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="hormones-produced-by-adrenal-cortex">Hormones Produced by Adrenal Cortex<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hormones-produced-by-adrenal-cortex" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The hypothalamus, anterior pituitary and adrenal cortex form a functional unit—hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis. The adrenocortical hormones are steroid hormones and can be classified into three groups:</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>222 Clinical Chemistry</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-e093144e.jpeg" alt="img-60.jpeg">
Fig. 11.3 Structure of adrenal gland</p>
<ol>
<li>Mineralocorticoids Aldosterone is the most significant mineralocorticoid. It promotes reabsorption of sodium ions in the kidney tubules resulting in a decrease in the reabsorption of potassium and hydrogen ions as well as an increase in the reabsorption of chlorides and water.</li>
</ol>
<p>Abnormal increase in aldosterone results in sodium retention, potassium depletion with increased extracellular fluid. This may lead to oedema and hypertension.</p>
<p>Deficiency of aldosterone occurs in Addison's disease which, on the other hand, causes sodium depletion with loss of extracellular fluid, and hypotension.</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>Glucocorticoids Cortisol is the major glucocorticoid produced by adrenal cortex. It stimulates breakdown of proteins and fat, and stimulates gluconeogenesis. It also helps maintain the extracellular fluid volume and normal blood pressure.</li>
</ol>
<p>Metabolism During blood circulation most of the cortisol is bound to cortisol binding globulin (CBG) and to albumin. Therefore, only 5% of the total concentration which is unbound, is physiologically active. Cholesterol is the main precursor in steroid synthesis.</p>
<p>Glucocorticoids are conjugated with glucuronate and sulphate in the liver to form inactive metabolites. They are more water soluble than the CBG bound fractions and are excreted in urine. Hypersecretion of cortisol causes Cushing's syndrome whereas deficiency leads to Addison's disease.</p>
<p>Regulation of cortisol secretion Cortisol is synthesised and secreted in response to ACTH from the anterior pituitary gland. ACTH secretion is dependant on the CRF (corticotropin releasing factor) released from the hypothalamus. CRF secretion in turn is influenced by</p>
<p>(i) Negative feedback from adequate plasma concentration of cortisol on both CRF and ACTH.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Endocrine Function Tests 223</p>
<p>(ii) Inherent rhythms of CRF and ACTH secretion which are followed by cortisol release.
(iii) Stress, physical or mental, overrides the first two mechanisms.</p>
<p>Most of the steroid hormones are converted by the liver into a water soluble form by conjugating with substances such as glucuronides and excreted in urine as 17-ketosteroids.</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>Androgens The adrenal androgens dehydroepiandrosterone (DHA), its sulphate (DHAS) and androstenedione are only mildly androgenic.</li>
</ol>
<p>The most powerful androgen, testosterone, is not synthesised in the adrenal cortex, but in the testes and ovaries.</p>
<p>Most circulating androgens, like cortisol, are bound to proteins (sex-hormone binding protein, SHBG) and to albumin. Adrenal and gonadal androgens are continuously converted into each other. The end products are conjugated with glucuronides and sulphates in the liver and excreted in urine.</p>
<p>Hypersecretion of androgens occurs in adrenocortical carcinoma and congenital adrenal hyperplasia.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="adrenocortical-hyperfunction">Adrenocortical Hyperfunction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#adrenocortical-hyperfunction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Hyperactivity of adrenal cortex causes Cushing's syndrome which is characterised by obesity with typical 'moon' face, hyperglycaemia and glycosuria due to impaired glucose tolerance, increased protein catabolism with urinary protein loss. Androgen excess shows hirsutism (unusual and excessive growth of hair) and menstrual disturbances in women, and hypertension.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="adrenal-hypofunction">Adrenal Hypofunction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#adrenal-hypofunction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Adrenal hypoactivity may be primary or secondary. Addison's disease is caused by the destruction of all zones of the adrenal cortex (primary hypofunction). This may be due to an autoimmune disease or infection such as tuberculosis.</p>
<p>Secondary adrenal hypofunction is due to ACTH deficiency, most commonly due to tumour or infection.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="hormones-produced-by-adrenal-medulla">Hormones Produced by Adrenal Medulla<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hormones-produced-by-adrenal-medulla" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The adrenal medulla is a part of the sympathetic nervous system. It produces two catecholamine hormones, epinephrine (adrenalin) and norepinephrine (noradrelin). The amino acid tyrosine is the precursor in their synthesis. They are metabolised into an inactive form, which is excreted in urine.</p>
<p>Epinephrine and norepinephrine Both the hormones act on the cardiovascular system, and are responsible for ready responses in any emergencies. Epinephrine dilates blood vessels in skeletal muscles and increases the heart rate. Norepinephrine causes generalised vasoconstriction with hypertension. Both increase breakdown of glycogen causing a rise in the blood glucose level. The adrenalin is partly responsible for the visible signs of anxiety, increased rate of breathing, shaking (tremor) of the fingers and increased alertness.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="hypersecretion-of-catecholamines">Hypersecretion of Catecholamines<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hypersecretion-of-catecholamines" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Tumours of the sympathetic nervous system, whether adrenal or extra-adrenal, produce excess of catecholamines.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="thyroid-gland">THYROID GLAND<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#thyroid-gland" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The thyroid gland is made up of two lobes situated one on each side of the trachea with a connecting bridge, the isthmus. Thus the gland has 'H' shaped appearance.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="hormones-of-the-thyroid-gland">Hormones of the Thyroid Gland<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hormones-of-the-thyroid-gland" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The thyroid gland produces three hormones. They are</p>
<ol>
<li>Thyroxine (T₄)</li>
</ol>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>224 Clinical Chemistry</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>Triiodothyronine (T₃)</li>
<li>Calcitonin</li>
</ol>
<p>T₄ and T₃ are produced by the follicular cells whereas calcitonin is produced by the specialised C-cells.</p>
<p>T₄ and T₃ affect many metabolic processes, e.g., increasing the oxygen consumption. They are essential for normal growth, mental development and sexual maturation. They can influence the cardiac output and heart rate by increasing the sensitivity of cardiovascular and nervous systems to catecholamines.</p>
<p>Calcitonin regulates the level of plasma calcium by reducing the release of calcium from bones. It has the opposite effect on plasma calcium concentrations to parathyroid hormone, which is mainly responsible for the regulation of calcium level.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="65ddada1">Synthesis of T₃ and T₄<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#65ddada1" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Thyroid hormones T₃ and T₄ are synthesised in the thyroid gland by iodination and coupling of two molecules of tyrosine and is dependent on an adequate supply of iodide:</p>
<p>(i) Iodide from the diet (sea foods and iodised salt) is actively taken up by the thyroid gland under the influence of thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH). Low iodine diet may cause enlargement of the thyroid gland (goitre).
(ii) Iodide is converted to iodine in the thyroid gland.
(iii) Iodine, tryosine and a large glycoprotein thyroglobulin are joined together to form mono- and diiodotyrosine (MIT and DIT).
(iv) Two molecules of DIT form T₄, and one molecule of MIT and DIT each form T₃. The T₄ is produced in much larger amounts than T₃ when sufficient iodine is present. While in the thyroid gland, the T₃ and T₄ are incorporated in thyroglobulin and are stored in the colloid in thyroid follicles.
(v) Before the release of thyroid hormone into the blood stream, thyroglobulin is taken up by the follicular cells and T₄ and T₃ are released by proteolytic enzymes.</p>
<p>Various enzymes are involved in each step of the synthesis.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="regulation-of-thyroid-hormones">Regulation of Thyroid Hormones<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#regulation-of-thyroid-hormones" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
