<p>TSH from the pituitary gland stimulates the synthesis and release of thyroid hormones. TSH secretion is in turn regulated by the circulating concentrations of thyroid hormones from thyroid gland and thyrotropin releasing hormone from hypothalamus.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="disorders-of-the-thyroid-gland">Disorders of the Thyroid Gland<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#disorders-of-the-thyroid-gland" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Hyperthyroidism Hypersecretion of thyroid hormones causes a weight loss, a fine tremor, tiredness, and sometimes cardiac arrhythmias due to increased metabolic rate.</li>
</ol>
<p>Grave’s disease is an autoimmune thyroid disease and is more common in women. Among other symptoms it also shows bulging eyes.</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>Hypothyroidism Deficiency of thyroid hormones shows generalised slowing down of metabolism with mental dullness, lethargy, weight gain, menstrual disturbances and a puffy face.</li>
</ol>
<p>Hashimoto’s disease is caused by low hormone levels due to the destruction of thyroid tissue by autoantibodies.</p>
<p>Secondary hypothyroidism is less common and is due to hypothalamic (TRH) or pituitary (TSH) deficiency.</p>
<p>Goitre If plasma T₄ concentrations fall, enlargement of the thyroid gland (goitre) may occur due to TSH stimulation resulting in cellular hyperplasia. T₄ synthesis falls due to iodine deficiency or by drugs.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="parathyroid-glands">PARATHYROID GLANDS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#parathyroid-glands" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>There are two pairs of parathyroid gland, situated posterior to the lobes of the thyroid gland. The parathyroid glands produce parathyroid hormone also known as parathormone (PTH). The biological actions of PTH include.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Endocrine Function Tests 225</p>
<ol>
<li>Release of both free ionised calcium and phosphates from bones into the extracellular fluid.</li>
<li>Decrease in reabsorption of phosphate causing phosphaturia and increased reabsorption of calcium. This reduces plasma phosphate but increases plasma calcium.</li>
</ol>
<p>The secretion of PTH is regulated by the concentration of free ionised calcium in the plasma. Deficiency of PTH causes reduction in calcium and increase in phosphate levels in plasma.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="hormones-of-the-reproductive-system-gonadal-hormones">HORMONES OF THE REPRODUCTIVE SYSTEM (GONADAL HORMONES)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hormones-of-the-reproductive-system-gonadal-hormones" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The gonads are the sex organs which produce the gametes. Egg is the female gamete produced by the ovaries and spermatozoan is the male gamete produced by the testes.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-testes-and-male-hormones">The Testes and Male Hormones<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-testes-and-male-hormones" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>In the male, there are two testes contained in a sac called scrotum situated outside the body. The main functional components of each testis are the seminiferous tubules (Fig. 11.4). The tubules are separated by interstitial tissue containing islands of cells called Leydig cells. These are the cells which produce the male androgen testosterone. The male gametes, the sperm cells, are produced by the cells in the epithelium of the seminiferous tubules, namely the premature germ cells and the Sertoli cells. The Sertoli cells, on stimulation by the FSH (follicle stimulating hormone) from the pituitary and the testosterone from the Leydig cells help in the maturation of sperm cells in the testes. The Sertoli cells also produce a protein hormone called inhibitin. Inhibitin controls FSH secretion by negative feed-back.</p>
<p>The mature spermatozoa are transported to the ejaculatory duct via the epididymis and the vas deferens. The seminal vesicles and prostate gland add their secretions to the sperm cells, and contribute to the seminal fluid (semen).</p>
<p>Testosterone Testosterone is a steroid hormone produced by interstitial Leydig cells. It is involved</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-6609183f.jpeg" alt="img-61.jpeg">
Fig. 11.4 Cross-section of a testis</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>226 Clinical Chemistry</p>
<p>in sexual differentiation, development of secondary sexual characteristics and spermatogenesis.</p>
<p>The effects of testosterone depend on its conversion to dihydrotestosterone by the enzyme 5a-reductase which is present in target cells. During circulation, testosterone is bound to a carrier protein, sex-hormone binding globulin (SHBG) and albumin. Only the free portion is metabolically active. After conjugation with glucuronic or sulphuric acid, the testosterone metabolites are excreted in urine as 17-ketosteroids.</p>
<p>Inhibitin Inhibitin produced by Sertoli cells regulates FSH secretion from the pituitary by negative feedback.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-ovaries-and-the-female-hormones">The Ovaries and the Female Hormones<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-ovaries-and-the-female-hormones" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The ovaries, which produce the eggs, are paired structures in the abdomen, weighing about 4–8 g at sexual maturity. Ovaries change continuously as they perform their physiological functions. They release a mature ovum (ovulation) every 28–30 days. The ovaries secrete steroid sex hormones oestrogen and progesterone which are necessary for the maturation of the ovum and the development of fertilised ovum.</p>
<p>Each ovary contains about 2 million primordial follicles at birth, each containing an underdeveloped oocyte. After the age of puberty, each month one of these follicles begin to develop under the influence of FSH and LH from the pituitary (Fig. 11.5). Three hormones: oestrogen, progesterone and androgens are secreted by the developing follicles.</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Oestrogens Oestrogens are produced by the theca and granulosa cells around the oocyte in a developing follicle. Oestrogens are essential for the development of female secondary sex characteristics and for normal menstruation. Oestradiol is the most important ovarian oestrogen.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Progesterone Progesterone is secreted by the corpus luteum after the mature ovum has been released from the ovarian follicle. It prepares the endometrium (lining of the uterus) to receive a fertilised ovum. It is also necessary for the maintenance of the early pregnancy.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-7fdb3891.jpeg" alt="img-62.jpeg">
Fig. 11.5 Ovary showing the development of follicles</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Endocrine Function Tests 227</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>Androgens Androstenedione is the main androgen produced by the ovaries. It is produced in very small amounts.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="regulation-and-metabolism-of-gonadal-hormones">Regulation and Metabolism of Gonadal Hormones<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#regulation-and-metabolism-of-gonadal-hormones" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The hypothalamus produces gonadotropin releasing hormone or gonadotropin producing factor (GnRH, GnRF) which regulates the secretion of the pituitary gonadotrophins, luteinising hormone (LH) and follicle stimulating hormone (FSH). LH and FSH, in turn, control the function and secretion of hormones of the testes and ovaries. LH mainly stimulates the production of hormones androgens and oestrogens by the gonads whereas FSH stimulates the development of germ cells.</p>
<p>Like adrenal hormones, the gonadal hormones are cleared from the body by conjugation with glucuronides and excreted in the kidney as 17-ketosteroids.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="fertilisation">Fertilisation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fertilisation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Within 12 hours of ovulation the ovum is fertilised in the fallopian tubes by the spermatazoan before reaching the uterus. It is then implanted in the uterus where it begins to grow.</p>
<p>Chromosomal sex is determined by the chromosomes present in the ovum and the sperm during fertilisation. The ovum and the sperm each contribute 22 autosomes and one sex chromosome, X or Y. A normal male has 46, XY karyotype, whereas a normal female has 46, XX. The sex chromosome determines whether the primitive gonads become testes or ovaries.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="development-of-male-characteristics">Development of Male Characteristics<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#development-of-male-characteristics" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>In the presence of the Y chromosome, the foetal gonads develop into testes at 7 weeks gestation. During childhood, FSH and LH are secreted in very small amounts. As puberty approaches LH secretion increases, Leydig cells synthesise testosterone, and the development of secondary male characteristics occurs. At maturity the seminiferous tubules start producing sperm cells continuously.</p>
<p>Gonadal function disorders in males Gonadal dysfunction in men may be indicated by the symptoms of androgen deficiency, infertility or both.</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Androgen (testosterone) deficiency It is due to impaired secretion by Leydig cells. The testosterone level is low and LH level may be raised (primary dysfunction) or LH level may be low resulting in low testosterone (secondary dysfunction).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Infertility Most common causes of male infertility are</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>(i) Sertoli cell dysfunction leading to failure of spermatogenesis.
(ii) Testosterone deficiency, either due to Leydig cell dysfunction (primary) or due to anterior pituitary failure showing low FSH (secondary).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="development-of-female-characteristics">Development of Female Characteristics<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#development-of-female-characteristics" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>If a Y chromosome is absent in the foetus, female characteristics start developing at about 12 weeks of gestation. Foetal germ cells proliferate to produce several million oocytes. All the germ cells degenerate by late foetal life, and no more new oocytes can be produced till the end of life.</p>
<p>Puberty At the onset of puberty, as in male, the LH secretion increases, which raises the ovarian oestrogen secretion. This stimulates the development of female secondary sex characteristics and the onset of menstruation. Abnormal hormone secretion may cause delayed puberty.</p>
<p>Menstrual cycle and ovulation At the beginning of each menstrual cycle, a small number of follicles in the ovary (Graafian follicles) begin to develop but only one reaches maturation; and releases an ovum from the ovary (ovulation) for the fertilisation to occur. The menstrual cycle can be divided into two phases.</p>
<p>(i) Follicular (preovulatory or proliferative) phase: In this phase, increasing</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>228 Clinical Chemistry</p>
<p>concentration of oestrogen is produced by the developing Graafian follicles.</p>
<p>(ii) Luteal (postovulatory or secretory) phase: In this phase, progesterone concentration increases to prepare the endometrium of the uterus for future implantation of the fertilised ovum (Fig. 11.6).</p>
<p>Follicular phase At the beginning of a new menstrual cycle, ovarian follicles are undeveloped and plasma concentration of oestrogen is low. Negative feedback by oestrogens causes increase in the secretion of LH and FSH. The LH and FSH together cause the growth of a group of follicles. LH also causes a rise in oestrogen concentration. One of the follicles starts growing towards maturation. In addition to the follicular development, oestrogen also causes a coordinated proliferation of the endometrial lining of the uterus.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-86127f80.jpeg" alt="img-63.jpeg">
Fig. 11.6 Menstrual cycle</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Endocrine Function Tests 229</p>
<p>Ovulation Late in the follicular phase, rising oestrogen levels stimulate the hypothalamus by a positive feedback to release gonadotrophin releasing hormone (GnRH). This results in an abrupt peak of LH and FSH (Fig. 11.6). Shortly after this LH surge, the egg in the maturing follicle loses its nutritional support from the follicle and is discharged from the ruptured follicle on the surface of the ovary. This is called ovulation. It is the central point in the menstrual cycle and occurs 14 days before the next menstrual period.</p>
<p>Luteal phase The high concentration of LH after the ovulation stimulates the granulosa cells of the ruptured follicle to luteinize and to form corpus luteum which synthesises and releases progesterone and oestrogens. Progesterone prepares the endometrial lining of the uterus for the implantation of a fertilised ovum.</p>
<p>If the ovum is not fertilised, the corpus luteum regresses. Concentrations of ovarian hormones fall, resulting in the sloughing of the uterine endometrium and menstrual bleeding. A fall in the concentrations of ovarian hormones also releases LH and FSH from the pituitary by negative feedback. The new cycle begins with the follicular phase.</p>
<p>Progesterone secretion is associated with a rise in body temperature. If monitored every month, it is possible to determine the time of ovulation.</p>
<p>Pregnancy If the ovum is fertilised, it is carried from the oviduct to the endometrium which is prepared by progesterone for implantation. Implantation of fertilised ovum in the uterus results in pregnancy. An implantation that occurs outside the uterus is called ectopic pregnancy. In the uterus, the function of LH is taken over by human chorionic gonadotrophin (HCG) which is produced by the chorion and the developing placenta. HCG acts in the same way as LH, and prevents the involution of corpus luteum so that progesterone and oestrogen levels continue to rise. Endometrial sloughing is prevented by these high levels. During pregnancy, the predominant oestrogen is oestriol. After the first trimester, these hormones are produced by the placenta. Prolactin secretion increases progressively after eight weeks of pregnancy.</p>
<p>Human chorionic gonadotrophin (HCG) Secretion of HCG by the placenta reaches a peak level at about 13 weeks of pregnancy. Detection of HCG in urine or serum is used to diagnose pregnancy. These tests are not very sensitive, and can give positive results only one or two weeks after the first missed menstrual period. A more sensitive immunoassay, however, can detect plasma HCG soon after implantation of the ovum even before the missed period.</p>
<p>Menopause The menopause marks the end of the fertile period, and occurs when all the ovarian follicles have undergone atrophy. Oestrogen concentrations fall and there is increase in LH and FSH concentration.</p>
<p>Gonadal disorders in females Gonadal dysfunction in female is indicated as</p>
<p>(i) Delayed puberty and primary amenorrhoea This can occur due to</p>
<p>(a) High plasma concentrations of LH and FSH.
(b) Low plasma concentrations of GnRH.
(c) High plasma concentrations of prolactin.</p>
<p>(ii) Infertility Infertility is defined as one year of unprotected sexual intercourse with a fertile male without conception. It may be caused by:</p>
<p>(a) Ovulatory disorders, which is inability to release a mature ovum in each menstrual cycle, can be due to inadequate hormones from the hypothalamus (GnRH) and the pituitary (LH and FSH).
(b) Failure of the ovary to respond to gonadotrophic stimulation.
(c) Non-coordinated production of LH, FSH and oestrogen.</p>
<p>Infertility in the presence of ovulation can be due to infections or defects in fertilisation and transport of ovum to the uterus.</p>
<p>(iii) Hirsutism and virilism Increased concentrations of free plasma androgens in females can</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>230 Clinical Chemistry</p>
<p>produce effects ranging from increased hair growth (hirsutism) to marked masculinisation (virilism). Adrenal androgens and sex-hormone binding globulin (SHBG) may play an important role in these abnormalities.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pancreas-and-its-hormones">PANCREAS AND ITS HORMONES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pancreas-and-its-hormones" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The pancreas performs a dual role of an exocrine gland and an endocrine gland. The exocrine gland with a duct releases its secretions in the gastrointestinal tract for digestion. Scattered in the exocrine glandular tissue are groups of endocrine cells called islets of Langerhans. These islets are highly vasculised and release their secretions directly into the blood stream. The islets have two types of cells; the α-cells which secrete the hormone glucagon and the β-cells which secrete the hormone insulin.</p>
<p>Insulin stores carbohydrates as energy in the form of glycogen from endogenous sources (liver, fat, muscle). In general, it tends to reduce the blood glucose level. Glucagon, on the other hand, enhances catabolic functions such as hepatic glycogenolysis and stimulated formation of glucose. In this way homeostasis of blood glucose level is maintained.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="general-principles-of-evaluating-endocrine-function">GENERAL PRINCIPLES OF EVALUATING ENDOCRINE FUNCTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#general-principles-of-evaluating-endocrine-function" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Abnormalities of endocrine function may be due to the secretion of either excessive or deficient amounts of hormone. Abnormalities of target glands may be primary in which case the target gland is defective; or secondary, due to dysfunction of the controlling mechanism usually in the hypothalamus or anterior pituitary. The target gland, in the latter case, is normal.</p>
<p>Production of hormones is not constant over a 24-hour or even longer periods. They may respond predictably to physiological stimuli such as stress. For correct interpretation of laboratory tests, the physiological patterns of hormone secretion must be properly understood. A blood sample should be collected when hormone concentration should be easily distinguished from normal levels. Therefore, if hypofunction is suspected, the blood sample should be taken when the hormone level is high. For hyperfunction, the sample should be taken when the levels should be low.</p>
<p>Simultaneous measurement of both the trophic hormones and their controlling factor is more informative than measurement of either of them alone.</p>
<p>In case of indecisive results, dynamic tests should be performed. In these tests, the response of the gland is measured after stimulation and suppression by an exogenous hormone.</p>
<p>Suppression tests are performed for the diagnosis of excessive hormone secretion. For example, dexamethasone suppression test for suspected Cushing’s syndrome.</p>
<p>Stimulation tests are performed to diagnose deficient hormone secretion. e.g., hypothalamic pituitary stimulation test for suspected hypopituitarism.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="methods-used-for-the-assay-of-hormones">Methods Used for the Assay of Hormones<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#methods-used-for-the-assay-of-hormones" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The concentrations of hormones in body fluids, especially in plasma are very low, expressed only in micrograms or nanograms per litre. Therefore, the methods used for their assay should be extremely sensitive and specific. Immunoassays such as radioimmunoassay (RIA), fluorimetric assay or enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) and such other sensitive techniques as high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) are used for the estimation of hormones.</p>
<p>For immunoassays, it is necessary to obtain specific antisera. Most of the hormones are not antigenic by themselves and they must be coupled to a larger antigenic carrier molecule, such as bovine serum albumin. Antibodies to hormones bound to a carrier protein can be raised in rabbit or sheep.</p>
<p>Commercial kits are available for many commonly requested hormone assays. Special attention should be given to the specificity of the antiserum used.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Endocrine Function Tests 231</p>
<p>Radiolimmunoassay and ELISA The principles involved in the competitive binding RIA and ELISA techniques are described in the Clinical Immunology and Serodiagnosis section of this book.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="fluorimetric-assay-for-cortisol-principle">Fluorimetric assay for cortisol Principle<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fluorimetric-assay-for-cortisol-principle" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The method is used for assay of steroids. Steroids, which possess 11-hydroxyl group, will fluoresce in the presence of concentrated sulphuric acid. The two main steroids assayed by fluorimetry are cortisol and corticosterone.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="reagents">Reagents<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#reagents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Methylene dichloride Extract the solvent successively with 1/10th volume of concentrated sulphuric acid till the extract is colourless. Wash with distilled water (200 ml/L) till neutral. Distil after drying over sodium sulphate (B.P 40°C). Store in the dark.</li>
</ol>
<p>Caution Do not inhale vapour during preparation.</p>
<p><strong>Note</strong> The reagent is commercially available.</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>Concentrated sulphuric acid.</li>
<li>Ethanol, absolute.</li>
<li>Fluorescence reagent To 30 ml of ethanol kept over ice, slowly add 70 ml of conc. H₂SO₄. If yellow or brown colour develops, discard the ethanol.</li>
<li>Cortisol standard 30.0 mmol/L (stock) Dissolve 10.86 mg cortisol in 10ml ethanol. Dilute 1:100 with ethanol. Store at 4°C.</li>
<li>Cortisol standard, 3.0 mmol/L (working) Dilute the stock standard 1:10 with distilled water.</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>Note</strong> All glassware must be thoroughly cleaned to leave no trace of any fluorescence reagent. Washing with chromic acid followed by sodium metabisulphite is recommended.</p>
<p>Specimen Heparinised blood. Separate plasma as soon as possible and store at 4°C.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="method">Method<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#method" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Set up three large stoppered tubes (20 ml) and add reagents as follows:</li>
</ol>
<table><thead><tr><th></th><th>Test</th><th>Standard</th><th>Blank</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Plasma</td><td>2.0 ml</td><td>-</td><td>-</td></tr><tr><td>Working standard (3.0 μmol/L)</td><td>-</td><td>1.0 ml</td><td>-</td></tr><tr><td>Distilled water</td><td>-</td><td>1.0 ml</td><td>2.0 ml</td></tr><tr><td>Methylene dichloride</td><td>15.0 ml</td><td>15.0 ml</td><td>15.0 ml</td></tr></tbody></table>
<ol start="2">
<li>Stopper the tubes and shake for 2 minutes.</li>
<li>Centrifuge to separate phases. Remove the plasma layer.</li>
<li>Start a stop watch (zero time). Transfer 10 ml of extract from 'Test' to 5.0 ml fluorescent reagent in a glass stoppered tube. Shake vigorously for 20 seconds and remove the supernatant carefully.</li>
<li>Exactly after 1 minute from the zero time, repeat the same procedure with 'Standard'.</li>
<li>Exactly after 2 minutes from zero time, repeat for 'Blank'.</li>
<li>Exactly at 12 minutes from the zero time read the fluorescence of Test in a fluorimeter at 530 nm, with the excitation wavelength 470 nm.</li>
<li>Repeat with Standard and Blank at 1 minute intervals.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="calculation">Calculation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#calculation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Plasma cortisol nmol/L</p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mtext>Reading&nbsp;of&nbsp;Test</mtext><mo>−</mo><mtext>Reading&nbsp;of&nbsp;Blank</mtext></mrow><mrow><mtext>Reading&nbsp;of&nbsp;Std.</mtext><mo>−</mo><mtext>Reading&nbsp;of&nbsp;Blank</mtext></mrow></mfrac><mo>×</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>3.0</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>1000</mn></mrow><mn>2</mn></mfrac></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">= \frac{\text{Reading of Test} - \text{Reading of Blank}}{\text{Reading of Std.} - \text{Reading of Blank}} \times \frac{3.0 \times 1000}{2}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.2519em; vertical-align: -0.8804em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3714em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Reading&nbsp;of&nbsp;Std.</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Reading&nbsp;of&nbsp;Blank</span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Reading&nbsp;of&nbsp;Test</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Reading&nbsp;of&nbsp;Blank</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8804em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.0074em; vertical-align: -0.686em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3214em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">2</span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">3.0</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mord">1000</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.686em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p>Normal value Plasma 11-hydroxycorticosteroids at 9.00 hours: 220 - 750 nmol/L</p>
<p><strong>Note</strong> This method is not specific for cortisol. About 60% of the total fluorescence is due to cortisol. Therefore, the reference range for this method is higher.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="salivary-steroids">Salivary steroids<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#salivary-steroids" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Estimation of steroids in saliva instead of plasma is preferred mainly because only the free steroid hormone in plasma can enter the saliva. Therefore</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>232 Clinical Chemistry</p>
<p>it gives direct estimation of free steroid which is responsible for the biological activity of the hormone. It is a non-invasive technique and the required number of samples can be easily collected.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="investigation-of-pituitary-adrenal-thyroid-and-gonadal-disorders">INVESTIGATION OF PITUITARY, ADRENAL, THYROID AND GONADAL DISORDERS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#investigation-of-pituitary-adrenal-thyroid-and-gonadal-disorders" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>In this section, the pituitary and adrenal glands and the gonads are considered together because pituitary disorders may be present with adrenal or gonadal deficiency.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="1-suspected-hypopituitarism">1. Suspected Hypopituitarism<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-suspected-hypopituitarism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>(i) Measure the plasma concentrations of</p>
<ul>
<li>LH, FSH, testosterone (in male) or oestradiol (in female)</li>
<li>TSH and total or free T₄</li>
<li>Prolactin (to test for hypothalamic involvement)</li>
<li>Cortisol</li>
</ul>
<p>(ii) If the plasma concentrations of the target gland hormones (testosterone/oestradiol, T₄ or cortisol) are low and the trophic hormone (FSH, LH, TSH) are raised, investigate the affected target gland.</p>
<p>(iii) If concentrations of all the hormones tested are low, perform hypothalamic-pituitary stimulation test.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="combined-hypothalamic-pituitary-stimulation-test">Combined hypothalamic-pituitary stimulation test<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#combined-hypothalamic-pituitary-stimulation-test" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>(a) Take a basal sample of blood from the patient.
(b) Inject 0.15 U/kg body weight of soluble insulin intravenously to induce hypoglycaemia.
(c) Immediately inject 200μg TRH and 100μg GnRH.
(d) Take blood samples at 30, 60, 90 and 120 minutes after the injection.
(e) Perform assays as shown in Table 11.1.</p>
<p><strong>Note</strong>: The dose of insulin should be reduced for hypoglycaemic patients. Glucose for intravenous injections must be kept ready for an emergency. The test is dangerous and must be performed under medical supervision.</p>
<p>A normal individual should show the following results:</p>
<p>Table. 11.1 Tests schedule for combined pituitary stimulation test</p>
<table><thead><tr><th></th><th>Time (minutes) after the injection</th><th></th><th></th><th></th><th></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td></td><td>0</td><td>30</td><td>60</td><td>90</td><td>120</td></tr><tr><td>Insulin</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Glucose</td><td>*</td><td>*</td><td>*</td><td>*</td><td>*</td></tr><tr><td>Cortisol</td><td>*</td><td>*</td><td>*</td><td>*</td><td>*</td></tr><tr><td>Growth hormone</td><td>*</td><td>*</td><td>*</td><td>*</td><td>*</td></tr><tr><td>TRH</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>T4</td><td>*</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>TSH</td><td>*</td><td>*</td><td>*</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Prolactin</td><td>*</td><td>*</td><td>*</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>GnRH</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>LH</td><td>*</td><td>*</td><td>*</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>FSH</td><td>*</td><td>*</td><td>*</td><td></td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<ul>
<li>Indicates when blood should be analysed for specific hormones.</li>
</ul>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Endocrine Function Tests 233</p>
<p>Cortisol level should be &gt;200 nmol/L (7μg/dl). GH concentration should be &gt;20 mU/L. TSH concentration should increase by 2 mU/L. Prolactin and gonadotrophin concentrations should rise significantly.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-suspected-growth-hormone-deficiency">2. Suspected Growth Hormone Deficiency<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-suspected-growth-hormone-deficiency" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>(i) Collect blood immediately after exercise or during sleep. Determine plasma GH concentration. A level of 20 mU/L is normal.</p>
<p>(ii) If plasma level indicates deficiency, perform the insulin stimulation test. The insulin stimulation test is performed in the same way as the combined stimulation test except that TRH and GnRH are not injected.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="3-suspected-gigantism-or-acromegaly">3. Suspected Gigantism or Acromegaly<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-suspected-gigantism-or-acromegaly" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="glucose-suppression-test">Glucose suppression test<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#glucose-suppression-test" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>(a) Collect a basal blood sample.
(b) The patient should drink 75 g of glucose in 300 ml of water.
(c) Collect blood samples for glucose and GH assay at 30, 60, 90 and 120 minutes after consumption of glucose. Perform the assays.</p>
<p>In a normal individual, GH concentration should be suppressed in response to a rising level of blood glucose, in comparison to that in the basal sample. Plasma GH concentrations which fall to 4 mU/L at the highest blood glucose level shows normal activity. Failure to suppress indicates gigantism or acromegaly.</p>
<p><strong>Note</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>GH levels are high even in severe renal or liver diseases, and in drug addicts.</li>
<li>The test also detects impaired glucose tolerance.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="4-suspected-cushing-s-syndrome">4. Suspected Cushing's Syndrome<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#4-suspected-cushing-s-syndrome" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>(i) Perform dexamethasone suppression test</p>
<p>(a) Give a single oral dose of dexamethasone at 23.00 hours.</p>
<p>(b) Collect blood specimen at 09.00 hours next morning.
(c) Measure the cortisol level in plasma. Suppression of plasma cortisol (&lt;190 nmol/L) indicates normal activity.</p>
<p>(ii) Estimate the free-cortisol in urine in a 24-hour specimen. Extremely high plasma cortisol or urinary free-cortisol concentrations are suggestive of adreno-cortical carcinoma or ectopic ACTH secreting tumours.</p>
<p>Investigate further as follows:</p>
<p>(iii) Estimate plasma ACTH concentrations, preferably in specimens collected between 0800–100 hours. Normal individuals have ACTH level of &lt;50 pg/ml (11 pmol/L).
(a) In ectopic ACTH secreting tumours, ACTH levels are &gt;200 pg/ml (44 pmol/L).
(b) In adrenal carcinoma, ACTH levels are low or undetectable due to high levels of plasma cortisol.
(c) Moderately raised ACTH levels are suggestive of Cushing’s disease.</p>
<p>(iv) Perform high dose dexamethasone suppression test:</p>
<p>(a) Give 2 mg dexamethasone orally every 6 hours for 48 hours, starting at 0900 hours.
(b) Determine cortisol levels in specimens collected at 0900 hours on the first and third days. Suppression is the level less than half of the original estimation.</p>
<p>Suppression suggests Cushing’s disease which is pituitary dependent.</p>
<p>Failure to suppress suggests either adrenocorticotropic tumour (low ACTH) or ectopic ACTH secreting tumour (very high ACTH).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-suspected-adrenal-hypofunction">5. Suspected Adrenal Hypofunction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-suspected-adrenal-hypofunction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="a-chronic-hypofunction">A. Chronic hypofunction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-chronic-hypofunction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>(i) If plasma cortisol concentration is high, it excludes Addison’s disease (primary adrenal hypofunction).
(ii) If plasma cortisol is low, perform a short tetracosactrin stimulation test.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>234 Clinical Chemistry</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="short-tetracosactrin-stimulation-test">Short tetracosactrin stimulation test<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#short-tetracosactrin-stimulation-test" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>(a) Collect a basal sample for plasma cortisol assay.
(b) Inject 250 µg of tetracosactrin dissolved in 1 ml of water or saline, intramuscularly.
(c) Collect blood samples for cortisol assay 30 and 45 minutes after injection. Perform test.</p>
<p>Increase in cortisol concentration by at least 200 nmol/L (7 µg/dl), to a concentration of 550 nmol/L (20 µg/dl) indicates a normal response. A normal response excludes Addison’s disease.</p>
<p>In case of low or normal cortisol concentration, perform ACTH assay (cortisol normal range at 0900 hours is 138–635 nmol/L (5–23 µg/dl)).
(iii) Perform ACTH assay if cortisol is low. A high concentration of ACTH confirms primary adrenal hypofunction. A low concentration of ACTH suggests secondary adrenal hypofunction. Perform combined pituitary stimulation test.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="b-suspected-addisonian-crisis">B. Suspected Addisonian crisis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-suspected-addisonian-crisis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Perform plasma urea, electrolytes and cortisol estimations.</p>
<p>A very low or undetectable cortisol with low sodium, high potassium and high urea levels indicates Addisonian crisis.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="6-investigation-of-thyroid-function">6. Investigation of Thyroid Function<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#6-investigation-of-thyroid-function" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="a-investigation-of-suspected-hyperthyroidism">A. Investigation of suspected hyperthyroidism<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-investigation-of-suspected-hyperthyroidism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Measure TSH and total T₄ concentrations in plasma.</p>
<p>(a) A suppressed TSH concentration and significantly raised T₄ concentration clearly indicates hyperthyroidism.
(b) If the TSH level is suppressed and T₄ level is normal measure free T₃ level in plasma. A significantly raised free T₃ confirms the hyperthyroidism.
(c) A normal TSH level with raised T₄ is suggestive of thyroxine binding globulin (TBG) abnormality. Measure plasma TBG level for confirmation.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="b-investigation-of-suspected-hypothyroidism">B. Investigation of suspected hypothyroidism<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-investigation-of-suspected-hypothyroidism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Measure TSH and total T₄ concentrations in plasma.</p>
<p>(a) Slightly raised TSH level with low T₄ concentration may indicate early hypothyroidism. Circulating thyroid antibodies may be present.
(b) Normal TSH level with low T₄ concentration is suggestive of TBG deficiency. Measure TBG level to confirm.
(c) A significantly high TSH with very low T₄ is due to either primary hypothyroidism or TBG deficiency.
(d) If both TSH and T₄ levels are low, perform a TRH test to exclude pituitary or hypothalamic hypothyroidism.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="trh-test">TRH test<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#trh-test" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Collect a basal blood sample. Inject intravenously, 200 µg of TRH in 2 ml saline slowly (over about 1 minute). Collect blood samples at 20 and 60 minutes after the injection. Measure TSH in all the 3 samples. Perform perform the assay. An increase in TSH level at 20 minutes by at least 2 mU/L is considered a normal response.</p>
<p>If basal TSH level is high normal with more than 2 mU/L rise at 20 minutes and a slight fall at 60 minutes suggests early primary hypothyroidism.</p>
<p>A rise of &lt; 2 mU/L at 20 minutes is confirmative of secondary hypothyroidism of pituitary origin.</p>
<p>A normal or increased but delayed response that is, TSH level higher at 60 minutes than at 20 minutes is suggestive of secondary hypothyroidism due to hypothalamic dysfunction.</p>
<p>A flat response (no rise in TSH) may be due to hyperthyroidism.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="7-investigation-of-amenorrhoea-due-to-pregnancy">7. Investigation of Amenorrhoea (due to pregnancy)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#7-investigation-of-amenorrhoea-due-to-pregnancy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="1-perform-the-test-for-pregnancy">(1) Perform the test for pregnancy<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-perform-the-test-for-pregnancy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="diagnosis-of-pregnancy">Diagnosis of pregnancy<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#diagnosis-of-pregnancy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<p>Human chorionic gonadotrophin (HCG) is a hormone secreted by the chorionic cells after fertilization of the ovum. Serum and urine HCG levels rise rapidly in the early gestation, reach a peak towards the end of the first trimester and at about 16 weeks.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Endocrine Function Tests 235</p>
<p>reach a plateau which is maintained for the remainder of the pregnancy (Fig. 11.7). The HCG activity can be measured by five general methods—Bioassays, agglutination immunoassay, radioimmunoassay, radioreceptor assay and immunometric assay. The HCG concentration may be expressed as IU/ml or ng/ml of urine or serum (1 ng/ml = 10 mIU/ml).</p>
<p>Bioassay tests These involve the use of experimental animals. When urine of a pregnant woman is injected into a rabbit or mouse, enlargement and luteinisation of the corpus luteum indicates a positive test. It is difficult to standardise a bioassay and is no longer used.</p>
<p>Immunoassay Immunoassays are simple, expensive and relatively rapid tests for pregnancy. They are not very sensitive and therefore, are more often used for qualitative or semiquantitative detection of HCG. The commonly used immunoassays are:</p>
<p>(a) Latex particle agglutination inhibition (LAI) assay In this assay, latex particles coated with HCG are incubated with anti-HCG serum and patient's urine. In pregnancy, the HCG in urine will neutralise the anti-HCG antibody, so there will be no agglutination (clumping) with HCG coated latex particles. Thus no agglutination indicates the presence of HCG in patient's urine (positive test) and agglutination indicates a negative test.</p>
<p>The test is performed on a slide and requires only a few minutes. The test can detect 500–3500 mIU/ml.</p>
<p>(b) Haemagglutination inhibition (HAI) assay This is very similar to LAI, except that erythrocytes are coated with HCG instead of latex particles. HAI tests are more sensitive than LAI test and can detect 150–4000 mIU/ml.</p>
<p>(c) Direct agglutination test In this test antibody to HCG is coated either on latex particles or on erythrocytes. Therefore, agglutination occurs in the presence of HCG in the patient's urine. Agglutination indicates a positive test.</p>
<p>Radioimmunoassay (RIA) The RIAs for HCG detection are based on the principle of competitive binding (see Clinical Immunology and Serodiagnosis). HCG in test serum and a radiolabelled HCG compete for binding sites on anti-HCG antibody. The bound radiolabelled HCG is related to the concentration of HCG in the specimen. This is a very sensitive quantitative technique and it can detect HCG of less than 5 mIU/ml.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-81976056.jpeg" alt="img-64.jpeg">
Fig. 11.7 Normal serum HCG levels during pregnancy</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>236 Clinical Chemistry</p>
<p>Radioreceptor assay In this assay, a radiolabelled target tissue such as testes or ovary of rats, pigs or cows is used for binding with HCG from the specimen. The resultant radioactivity is proportional to the amount of HCG in the specimen (Sensitivity: 20–50 mIU/ml).</p>
<p>Immunometric assay This type of assay uses HCG antibody labelled with enzyme or radioisotope for the detection of HCG in the specimen. The principle is similar to the sandwich technique for the detection of antigen by ELISA (Clinical Immunology and Serodiagnosis section). This is also a sensitive, quantitative assay technique (Sensitivity: 25–50 mIU/ml).</p>
<p>Interpretation of pregnancy test In a normal pregnancy, a detectable amount of HCG is present in serum and urine almost immediately after the implantation of fertilised ovum in the uterus (Fig. 11.7). However, the results depend on the sensitivity of the test used. The serum HCG values can range from 100–100,000 mIU/ml from four to eight weeks of gestation.</p>
<p>Ectopic pregnancy Serum HCG values in ectopic pregnancy are often significantly lower than those observed in normal uterine pregnancy. After four to eight weeks of ectopic gestation, the serum HCG values may range from 20–20,000 mIU/ml.</p>
<p>By using specific monoclonal antibody, it is possible to measure the β-chain subunit of HCG (β-HCG). If serum specimens are collected at intervals over a 48 hour period, a normal pregnancy will show a 66% rise in β-HCG where as in ectopic pregnancy, the rise will be less than 30%.</p>
<p>Trophoblastic disease Trophoblastic cells are the cells which surround the early embryo and which secrete the HCG. In trophoblastic disease very high values of β-HCG are seen and may be 3–100 times higher than in normal pregnancy.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="8-investigation-of-amenorrhoea-not-due-to-pregnancy">8. Investigation of Amenorrhoea (not due to pregnancy)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#8-investigation-of-amenorrhoea-not-due-to-pregnancy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>If the pregnancy test is negative</p>
<p>(i) Measure LH, FSH and oestradiol concentrations in serum
(a) Raised LH or FSH with low oestradiol concentrations indicates ovarian failure.
(b) Normal LH and FSH levels with low oestradiol concentration suggest the possibility of testicular termination syndrome. It is a form of pseudohermaphroditism. Testosterone fails to act on its target cells owing to its end organ resistance or insensitivity. An individual may be born with female external genitalia but with no uterus or Fallopian tubes. This is confirmed by measuring plasma testosterone. A concentration within the male reference range (10.4–41.6 nmol/L or 300–1200 ng/ml) supports the diagnosis.
(c) Low LH or FSH with low oestradiol concentrations suggests the involvement of the hypothalamus or pituitary.
(ii) Measure prolactin concentration of plasma which is collected more than 3 hours after waking.</p>
<p>A high plasma concentration of prolactin supports the involvement of hypothalamus or pituitary. (normal range 1–25 ng/ml or 1–25 μg/L)
(iii) Perform the gonadotrophin releasing hormone (GnRH) test.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="gnrh-test">GnRH test<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#gnrh-test" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>(a) Collect a basal sample.
(b) Inject 100 μg of synthetic GnRH intravenously.
(c) Collect blood sample 30 and 60 minutes after the injection.
(d) Measure plasma LH and FSH concentrations in the sample.
A normal LH and FSH response suggests a hypothalamic cause.
A subnormal response may suggest a pituitary lesion.
(iv) Perform the combined pituitary stimulation test.</p>
<p>A rise in concentration by at least 5 U/L is considered normal. Failure to raise these levels indicates pituitary hypofunction.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Endocrine Function Tests 237</p>
<p><strong>Note</strong>
Cushing's syndrome and hyperthyroidism also can cause amenorrhoea and should be investigated as described earlier for their respective investigations.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="9-investigations-of-hirsutism-and-virillism">9. Investigations of Hirsutism and Virillism<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#9-investigations-of-hirsutism-and-virillism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Perform assays of total and free testosterone, and dehydroepiandrosterone (DHA) or DHA-sulphate (DHAS), LH and FSH.</p>
<p><strong>Interpretation</strong> Interpret as shown in Table 11.2.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="10-investigation-of-infertility-due-to-ovulatory-disorders">10. Investigation of Infertility Due to Ovulatory Disorders<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#10-investigation-of-infertility-due-to-ovulatory-disorders" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>(i) Measure the plasma levels of LH, FSH and progesterone at various stages of ovulation.</p>
<p>(a) FSH values &gt; 40 mIU/ml indicate ovarian failure because of the loss of oestrogen feed back control. FSH values &lt; 5 mIU/ml indicate hypogonadotropism due to hypothalamic-pituitary dysfunction.</p>
<p>(b) LH values elevated to &gt; 30 mIU/ml for a short time at mid-cycle indicates normal LH surge at ovulation. LH levels elevated throughout the cycle indicates ovarian failure or polycystic disease. LH concentration &lt; 5 mIU/ml can be due to hypothalamic-pituitary dysfunction.</p>
<p>(c) In a normal ovulatory cycle, progesterone should be &gt; 2.5 ng/ml after ovulation, and should reach 10–30 ng/ml at the midluteal phase. It drops to &lt; 2.5 ng/ml just before menses. A low concentration of progesterone suggest either ovulatory failure or impaired function.</p>
<p><strong>Note</strong>
Histological examination of an endometrial biopsy should indicate if the luteal function is normal.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="11-investigation-of-male-infertility">11. Investigation of Male Infertility<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#11-investigation-of-male-infertility" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>(i) Perform a semen analysis.</p>
<p>(ii) Measure plasma testosterone, LH and FSH concentrations.</p>
<p><strong>Interpretation</strong></p>
<p>(a) A low testosterone and raised LH concentrations indicate Leydig cell failure.</p>
<p>(b) A low testosterone with low LH concentrations suggest hypothalamic or pituitary disease</p>
<p>(c) A raised concentration of FSH, usually with oligospermia, indicates failure of seminiferous tubules. Testosterone concentration may be normal.</p>
<p>(d) A low FSH level with oligospermia is suggestive of pituitary or hypothalamic disease.</p>
<p>(iii) Measure plasma prolactin level.</p>
<p>(a) A significantly raised plasma prolactin is indicative of a pituitary disorder.</p>
<p><strong>Table 11.2 Diagnosis of hirsutism and other disorders</strong></p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Testosterone</th><th>DHAS</th><th>LH</th><th>FSH</th><th>Diagnosis</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>N or slightly ↑</td><td>N or slightly ↑</td><td>N</td><td>N</td><td>Simple hirsutism</td></tr><tr><td>↑</td><td>N</td><td>↑</td><td>N or ↓</td><td>Polycystic ovaries</td></tr><tr><td>↑↑</td><td>N</td><td>N or ↑</td><td>N or ↓</td><td>Ovarian tumour</td></tr><tr><td>N or slight ↑</td><td>↑ ↑</td><td>N or ↓</td><td>N or ↓</td><td>Adrenocortial tumour</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>238 Clinical Chemistry</p>
<p>(iv) Perform combined pituitary stimulation test, if necessary.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="semen-analysis">SEMEN ANALYSIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#semen-analysis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Semen analysis is an important part of the overall evaluation of male infertility. It helps to determine the fertilizing capacity of human spermatozoa. Many factors (e.g., sperm count, motility, morphology) are considered before conclusions can be drawn regarding the potential fertility status of a man.</p>
<p>Semen is made up of spermatozoa (sperms) suspended in seminal fluid. Roughly the total semen volume is composed of:</p>
<p>(1) Spermatozoa 5%
(Sperm is derived from the testes).</p>
<p>(2) Seminal plasma 60%
(Seminal plasma or fluid which is derived from seminal vesicles is viscid and yellowish in colour due to its high flavin content).</p>
<p><strong>Note</strong>: Semen is also referred to as seminal fluid.</p>
<p>(3) Prostatic fluid 20%
(Prostatic fluid from the prostates is milky and slightly acidic (pH 6.5) due to its high citric acid content; is also rich in proteolytic enzymes and acid phosphatase).</p>
<p>(4) Other fluids 10–15%
(These fluids are derived from epididymis, vasa deferentia and urethral glands).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="sample-collection-and-delivery">Sample Collection and Delivery<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sample-collection-and-delivery" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The individual should be provided with clearly written instructions of when and how to collect and transport the seminal fluid. These instructions should include the following.</p>
<ol>
<li>The sample should be collected after 2–5 days abstinence from sexual intercourse or masturbation.</li>
<li>The sample should be collected preferably at the laboratory by masturbation.</li>
<li>The sample should be delivered within 2 hours of collection if collected outside the laboratory.</li>
<li>Coitus interruptus, though not satisfactory, may be acceptable where the subject cannot masturbate. With coitus interruptus, the first portion of the ejaculate which contains the highest concentration of spermatozoa, may be lost.</li>
<li>The use of condom is not acceptable unless the condom is clean and plain with no spermicides or lubricants.</li>
<li>If any portion of the ejaculate is lost or if the container leaks during transportation, the sample should not be used for analysis.</li>
<li>The container, which should be clean and dry, must be labelled with the subject’s name, registration number, and collection date and time.</li>
<li>During transportation of the sample, it should not be exposed to extremes of temperatures (not less than 20°C or more than 40°C).</li>
<li>Two to three specimens should be collected on weekly or bi-weekly intervals. The examination of a single specimen is not adequate because of the variation of sperm production within one man.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="semen-characteristics">Semen Characteristics<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#semen-characteristics" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Freshly ejaculated normal seminal fluid is highly viscid, opaque and creamy-white in colour and has a distinct musty or sickly sweet smell. The specimen should liquefy within 20 minutes of collection. On liquefaction, the sample may become slightly viscous, turbid and slightly alkaline (pH 7.7). The total sample volume is measured. On average, a man may produce 2–5 ml of semen after 2–5 days abstinence. The following parameters are checked during initial examination.</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p><strong>Time of arrival</strong>: The time of arrival of the specimen in the laboratory must be noted to know the length of time interval between collection and commencement of test.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Appearance</strong>: Check the semen for abnormal colouration—yellow, brown or blood stained.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Endocrine Function Tests 239</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>
<p>Viscosity/Liquefaction The specimen is checked for viscosity, or if already liquefied, use a sterile pipette to suck up some fluid and try to release. If it falls drop by drop, its viscosity is normal. It is important to distinguish persistent viscosity from delayed liquefaction, and true liquefaction from watery semen. Increased persistent viscosity may inhibit the motility of the spermatozoa.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Volume Liquefied semen can be measured with 10 ml or 5 ml pipette. For viscous specimen, a wide mouth pipette should be used. Less volume may be due to non-abstinence, and may result in reduced total sperm count.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="microscopic-examination">Microscopic Examination<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#microscopic-examination" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Motility Normal spermatozoa should be actively and progressively motile since they have to move from the cervix to the fallopian tube where fertilisation of the ovum occurs. A normal sample will show 60% or more motile spermatozoa with the majority exhibiting good to excellent forward progressive movement up to 3 hours after ejaculation. Unusual motility pattern (e.g., circular movements) should be noted.</p>
<p>One drop of liquefied and mixed specimen is placed on a clean slide and covered with a clean cover slip and then examined microscopically.</p>
<p>The World Health Organisation (WHO) recommends both Quantitative and Qualitative estimation of motility.</p>
<p>Quantitative motility is determined by counting both motile and non-motile spermatozoa in at least 10 randomly selected fields (at least 100 must be counted). The percentage of motile sperm is calculated from the mean percentage motility for all the fields counted. This is then adjusted to the nearest 5% (e.g., 73% = 75%). This is difficult as motile sperms are difficult to count.</p>
<p>Qualitative motility is determined by subjectively grading the forward progression made by the largest members of the spermatozoa. The graduations are:</p>
<p>None, Poor, Good, and Excellent and are defined and coded as follows:</p>
<p>None indicates absence of forward progression: 0
Poor indicates weak forward progression: 1
Good indicates moderate forward progression: 2
Excellent indicates very active forward progression: 3</p>
<p>Most laboratories perform a motility test that is between the two.</p>
<p>The number of forwardly motile spermatozoa is subjectively estimated against the number of non motile ones in about 4 separate fields.</p>
<p>The average is expressed as percentages of all the sperm in a field.</p>
<p><strong>Note:</strong> A semen sample with 40% motile sperm or with less than good forward movement after 2–3 hours should be re-evaluated. The man should be requested to produce fresh specimen 2–3 days later. This additional specimen should be analysed within 30 minutes to determine whether the motility is good but quickly declines, or whether it is inherently poor from the start. The fellow should, as before, abstain from sexual intercourse or masturbation.</p>
<p>Sperm count The concentration of sperm is performed with a counting chamber (haemocytometer). An electronic Coulter Counter can also be used if available. The specimen is diluted 1:20, using the white blood cell (WBC) pipette: draw semen to the "0.5" mark, dilute with diluting fluid to the 11 mark.</p>
<p>Alternatively, micro pipettes of 10 μl, 50 μl or 100 μl volumes can also be used to make 1:20 dilution in a test tube.</p>
<p>The diluting fluid should immobilise and preserve the sperms. A common diluting fluid consists of:</p>
