<table><thead><tr><th>Sodium bicarbonate (NaHCO₃)</th><th>5 g.</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Formalin (Neutral)</td><td>1 ml</td></tr><tr><td>Distilled water</td><td>100 ml</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>240 Clinical Chemistry</p>
<p><strong>Note</strong>
This diluting fluid is satisfactory for both bright light and phase contrast microscopy; but 0.5 ml of saturated aqueous solution of gentian violet can be added for light microscopy. Also, tap water that is not acidic, can be used.</p>
<p>The Neubauer counting chamber (Fig. 11.8) is prepared and charged with the diluted seminal fluid and allowed to stand in a moist chamber for 15–20 minutes. Only complete, morphologically mature sperm cells are counted.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-ffa77cd0.jpeg" alt="img-65.jpeg">
Fig. 11.8 Sperm count using an improved Neubauer chamber</p>
<p><strong>Counting procedure</strong> The Neubauer Chamber has a grid containing 1–5 large squares (1 mm² each) as is shown in Fig. 11.8. The central square is subdivided into 25 smaller squares of which the 4 corner squares are designated 5a, 5b, 5c, 5d and the central small square as 5e. The depth of the chamber is 0.1 mm, so the volume of fluid held between cover slip and chamber in the large square 5 is 0.1 cu.mm, and the volume in 5a, 5b, 5c, 5d and 5e is 0.02 cu.mm.</p>
<p>To calculate the number of spermatozoa per ml counted in the chamber, a multiplication factor is used. The multiplication factor for square 5 is 10,000, for all large squares 1–5, the factor is 2000; for the smaller squares 5a, b, c, d and e, the multiplication factor is 50,000.</p>
<p><strong>Calculations</strong></p>
<p>No. of sperm cells counted in 5a,b,c,d, and e = n</p>
<p>Multiplication factor = 50,000</p>
<p>Dilution factor = 20</p>
<p>Sperm count per ml = n × 50,000 × 20
= n × 10⁶
(Sperm concentration)</p>
<p>Total sperm count = n × 10⁶ × Volume of semen</p>
<p>i.e = n × 10⁶ × volume per ejaculate.</p>
<p>Generally, normal sperm count range is 50–150 million/ml. But the WHO recommends that men with sperm counts ranging from 20–200 million/ml are in the fertile range. Pregnancies have been known to occur in counts of 20 million/ml; and infertility may be encountered in men with more than 100 million/ml. Absence of spermatozoa is called azoospermia.</p>
<p>The potential fertility of a man should not be evaluated solely on the basis of one sperm count. Other factors such as motility, morphology and other functional properties of the spermatozoa must be considered.</p>
<p><strong>Note:</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>For very viscous samples, a mucolytic agent can be added in equal volumes (1:1) before making dilution and the final count adjusted by multiplying by 2.</li>
<li>In low sperm concentration, the count is done in all the large squares (1–5) and then multiplied by 2000.</li>
<li>In high sperm concentration, use a higher dilution.</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>Particulate debris</strong> Microscopic examination of semen includes the detection of the presence of particulate debris. Any excessive contamination of the seminal fluid sample by bacteria, epithelial cells, red blood cells, white blood cells or immature germ cells should be noted and quantified.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Endocrine Function Tests 241</p>
<p>Also the sample should be examined for the presence of yeast cells and <em>Trichomonas vaginalis</em>. In addition, any non-liquefied streaks of mucus should be reported.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="sperm-morphology">Sperm morphology<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sperm-morphology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The morphological characteristics of the sperm cells are important for the complete assessment of the seminal fluid. Morphological examination is done by performing differential count of morphologically normal and abnormal sperm types on stained preparations.</p>
<p>A normal sperm measures 50–70 μm in length. It has a large oval head which measures about 3–6 × 2–3 μm, a short middle piece and a long tail (Fig. 11.9).</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-d7a645ad.jpeg" alt="img-66.jpeg">
Fig. 11.9 Morphology of a normal mature sperm</p>
<p>Smears are made as for blood film (i.e. by placing a small drop of well mixed seminal fluid on a clean slide and smearing it to a feather edge) and quickly fixed (while still wet) in a cytological fixative such as 95% alcohol or ether-alcohol mixture. The smear is stained with either Papanicolaou or Giemsa or 5% aqueous eosin or dilute (1:20) carbol fuchsin.</p>
<p>The Papanicolaou stain is considered the most satisfactory, though it may be difficult to differentiate specific immature germ cells from one another as well as from some white blood cells. The Papanicolaou stained smear should be mounted with DPX mountant. The Papanicolaou staining method is described in the Histopathology Section.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="carbol-fuchsin-staining-technique">Carbol fuchsin staining technique<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#carbol-fuchsin-staining-technique" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Fix in the fixative (95% alcohol) for 5–10 minutes.</li>
<li>Wash with sodium bicarbonate-formalin solution to remove any mucus.</li>
<li>Cover smear with dilute carbol fuchsin for 3 minutes.</li>
<li>Wash with water.</li>
<li>Counter stain with polychrome methylene blue for 2–3 minutes.</li>
<li>Wash with water and air dry.</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>Note</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>If the sperm count is less than 10 million/ml, the seminal fluid should be centrifuged at 2000 rpm for 15–20 minutes. The deposit is then used to make smear.</li>
<li>Smears made from frozen and thawed sample give poor staining reaction.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="staining-result">Staining result<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#staining-result" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Nucleus of head —dark blue
Cytoplasm of head —pale blue
Middle piece and tail —pink-red</p>
<p>The stained smear should be examined under the oil immersion objective. About 100–200 spermatozoa with tails are counted, and the percentage of abnormal forms are noted. Figure 11.10 shows the morphological abnormal forms of spermatozoa; Fig. 11.11 (Plate 1) shows immature germinal cells.</p>
<p>Abnormal spermatozoa usually exhibit the following features:</p>
<ol>
<li>Greatly increased or decreased head size.</li>
<li>Abnormal shape</li>
<li>Double head</li>
<li>Double tail</li>
<li>Nuclear chromatin (in the head) unevenly distributed (amorphous head).</li>
</ol>
<p>A normal semen may contain up to 20% abnormal forms. The small pin head sperm is the most encountered abnormal form.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>242 Clinical Chemistry</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-3abd4eae.jpeg" alt="img-67.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 11.10 Normal and abnormal forms of spermatozoa</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="semen-culture">Semen Culture<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#semen-culture" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>It may be necessary to culture semen in order to exclude microbiological causes of infertility. Cultures should be airmed at the isolation of <em>Neisseria gonorrhoeae</em>, <em>Chlamydia trachomatis</em> and <em>Ureaplasma species</em>. Culture is done if there are pus cells in the semen.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="post-coital-analysis">Post Coital Analysis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#post-coital-analysis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>As part of the overall screening of fertility, some other tests may be requested to complement the semen analysis.</p>
<ol>
<li>Effects of cervical pH The motility and migration through the cervical mucus of sperms is</li>
</ol>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Endocrine Function Tests 243</p>
<p>greatly affected by the pH of the cervix. Acid pH (less than 6.0) immobilises sperm, while alkaline pH (between 7 and 8) enhances its motility.</p>
<p>The pH of the endocervical mucus should be taken with pH paper either in situ or immediately after collection. The in situ measurement of the pH should be done with care in order to avoid contamination with exocervical and vaginal secretions which have lower pH than the endocervical mucus.</p>
<p>The optimum pH for sperm penetration is between 7 and 8.5 which is the range of a normal mid cycle endocervical mucus.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-post-coital-evaluation">2. Post coital evaluation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-post-coital-evaluation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Post coital evaluation is used to determine:</p>
<p>(i) the number of active spermatozoa in the cervix.</p>
<p>(ii) the survival rate and behaviour of sperms many hours after coitus.</p>
<p>The cervical mucus is a hydrogel consisting of a macro molecular network of mucin (high viscosity component); and a combination of electrolytes, organic compounds and soluble proteins (low viscosity component). The power of sperm to penetrate and survive in mucus is greatly influenced by cyclical changes in the constituents of cervical mucus.</p>
<p>Part of the post coital test involves evaluating some rheological properties of the mucus which include:</p>
<p>(i) Viscosity—the ratio of pressure to flow rate. It depends on the molecular arrangement and phospholipid content of the cervical mucus.</p>
<p>(ii) Spinnbarkeit—the tenacity or fibrosity of the cervical mucus. Measure the spinnbarkeit as follows: with forceps, grasp a portion of mucus and note how far the mucus can be drawn before breaking. At mid cycle, a good spinnbarkeit should be greater than 10 cm.</p>
<p>Sperm migration in cervical mucus is only for a limited time. The post coital test is performed at the optimum time in the ovulatory phase of mid cycle. The test should preferably be performed within 8 hours after coitus, though it may also be carried out at a longer time interval up to 12–24 hours. It is necessary for the couple to abstain from sexual intercourse for 2 days prior to the day of the test.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="sample-collection">Sample collection<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sample-collection" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Insert a non-lubricated speculum into the vagina. With different tuberculin syringes (without needles) or pasteur pipettes, aspirate samples from the posterior vaginal fornix, exocervical and endocervical canal. Place the samples on separate slides and cover with coverslips. Examine microscopically.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vaginal-sample">Vaginal sample<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vaginal-sample" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Spermatozoa, when deposited in the vagina, are destroyed within four hours. Examination of the vagina sample will reveal if semen has actually been deposited in the vagina.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="exocervical-sample">Exocervical sample<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#exocervical-sample" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>In about two to three hours after coitus, spermatozoa accumulate in the lower part of the cervical canal. A good quality semen sample will contain more than 25 actively motile spermatozoa per high power field (HPF) in 2–3 hours after coitus. The presence of ten or more motile sperms is considered satisfactory. Fewer than 5 sluggish sperms/HPF indicates decrease in number and motility of sperms or abnormality of cervical mucus. The sperm motility is scored as follows:</p>
<p>0 = non motile
1 = in situ motility
2 = sluggish motility
3 = vigorous forward motility.</p>
<p>Usually, the number of sperms in the exocervical pool begins to decrease from 4 hours after coitus.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="endocervical-sample">Endocervical sample<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#endocervical-sample" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The highest number of sperms reach the internal os of the cervix in 2–3 hours after coitus. The number remains relatively constant for up to about 24 hours. Therefore, at 8 hours post coitus, more than 10 adequately motile sperms (score of 2–3) per HPF should normally be found. A similar result is usually obtained in 10–24 hours delayed post coital test.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>244 Clinical Chemistry</p>
<p>Interpretation The interpretation of post coital test results should be done with proper rational approach. A positive test (i.e. adequate number of motile sperms in the endocervix) excludes cervical factors as possible causes of infertility.</p>
<p>Negative tests (i.e. no spermatozoa are found) may be due to:</p>
<ol>
<li>No ejaculation or no deposition of spermatozoa in the vagina.</li>
<li>Incorrect timing of test—too early or too late in the menstrual cycle. Where ovulation period cannot be accurately timed, the test may be performed several times during a cycle.</li>
</ol>
<p>For negative or abnormal post-coital tests, in vitro cervical mucus penetration tests should be done. These tests are usually carried out by specialist laboratories because they are not routine tests. Details about such tests are beyond the scope of this book.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="effect-of-sperm-antibody">Effect of Sperm Antibody<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#effect-of-sperm-antibody" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>It has been established that antibodies to spermatozoa have adverse effect on sperm penetration and survival in cervical mucus. These antibodies are found in circulation in the semen or in the cervical mucus. The antibodies may be detected by agglutination or ELISA (enzyme linked immunosorbent assay) tests. The greatest effect is characterised by low number or absence of motility of sperms in the cervical mucus.</p>
<p>With the evidence, wide range of studies are needed to monitor therapy, investigations, and manual operations. Results on a large number of studies should be provided with the results. The results are running the same way with every batch.</p>
<p>An autoanalysis can perform all the tests, or it may be possible to determine if the procedure is completely automated.</p>
<p>(i) a device of standard use.
(ii) a mechanism that the reagent is used.
(iii) incubation temperature.
(iv) a monitor test.
(v) a record result.</p>
<p>The new gel microprocessors are used to test the reagent.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Chapter 12</p>
<p>Automation in Clinical Chemistry</p>
<p>With the evolution of Clinical Chemistry, a wide range of tests has been developed to assist in the diagnosis of diseases and disorders and to monitor therapy. With the growing demand for investigations, it is becoming inevitable to replace manual operations by mechanical devices for fast results on a large number of specimens. Automation provides a means by which an increased work load can be processed rapidly and with reproducible results. The quality of results is controlled by running the samples of known values (standards) with every batch of tests.</p>
<p>An autoanalyser may be fully automated and can perform all the steps involved in a manual assay, or it may be semiautomated which needs a part of the procedure to be performed manually. A completely automated system should have:</p>
<p>(i) a device for sampling patient's specimen, standards, controls or blanks.
(ii) a mechanism to add a required amount of the reagents in proper sequence.
(iii) incubation modules for the required temperature and time.
(iv) a monitoring or measuring device to quantitate the extent of reaction.
(v) a recording mechanism to provide the final result with a permanent record.</p>
<p>The new generation of autoanalysers include a microprocessor or a small computer which monitors the operations of the analyser.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="advantages-of-an-autoanalyser">Advantages of an Autoanalyser<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#advantages-of-an-autoanalyser" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>A large number of samples may be processed with minimal staff time.</li>
<li>Two or more assays may be performed simultaneously.</li>
<li>Precision is superior to that of the manual method.</li>
<li>Calculations may not be required.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="disadvantages-of-an-autoanalyser">Disadvantages of an Autoanalyser<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#disadvantages-of-an-autoanalyser" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Many systems are impractical for small number of specimens. Therefore, manual methods are still necessary when there is a smaller work load.</li>
<li>Instrument failures do occur; back-up procedures must be available.</li>
<li>It needs additional training of the staff about the working, maintenance and potential problems of the machine.</li>
<li>There may be limitations to the methodology that can be used for automated systems.</li>
<li>They are expensive to purchase and maintain.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="types-of-automated-analyser">TYPES OF AUTOMATED ANALYSER<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types-of-automated-analyser" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>There are four main types of autoanalysers which are used in a Clinical Chemistry laboratory for</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>246 Clinical Chemistry</p>
<p>routine tests. Depending on their working principles, they can be grouped as shown in Fig. 12.1. The working principles of various types are discussed briefly.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="continuous-flow-systems">CONTINUOUS FLOW SYSTEMS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#continuous-flow-systems" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="single-channel-continuous-flow-analyser">Single Channel Continuous Flow Analyser<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#single-channel-continuous-flow-analyser" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>The single channel continuous flow analyser can perform a single estimation on a large number of specimens simultaneously.</p>
<p>In this system, the specimens to be analysed pass sequentially through a single hydraulic line in which all the reactions and incubations take place in a continuous stream of fluid. All the samples and reagents pass along tubular pathways. The reagents flow continuously and the specimens are introduced at intervals. Each specimen segment is separated by air bubbles which are large enough to scrub the sides of the tube to prevent mixing from specimen to specimen. The relative proportions of samples and reagents are determined by manipulating their flow rates by varying the diameters of the tubes. Mixing takes place when the specimen and reagents join to form a common pathway. The reactions take place as the fluid mixture passes through the tube. Various separation steps such as dialysis, use of density gradient, removal of inter-fering substances such as proteins or extraction by solvents, occur during the passage. The extent of reaction is finally read using a colorimeter spectrophotometer, fluorimeter, flame photometer or nephelometer. The results may be displayed on a screen or are printed out.</p>
<p>The autoanalyser is divided into modules, one for each specific function. The modules required for one analytical method, such as glucose estimation, are linked together to form an analytical channel. The linked channels, arranged together to facilitate analysis of a series of specimens for one or more constituents, form the analytical system. The modular design permits intercharging of major parts.</p>
<p>A continuous flow analyser has five main parts: the sampler, proportionating pump, manifold, colorimeter and recorder.</p>
<ol>
<li><strong>Sampler</strong> This consists of a circular tray with separate cups for samples along its periphery. The tray is placed on a turntable which moves at preselected intervals. A probe is connected by plastic tubing to the mainfold and aspirates the samples or controls serially by suction. An appropriate wash solution is aspirated between two samples. The amount of sample or wash solution aspirated is regulated by an electrical timing de</li>
</ol>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-7f010644.jpeg" alt="img-68.jpeg">
Fig. 12.1 Different types of autoanalysers</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Automation in Clinical Chemistry 247</p>
<p>vice which controls the pumping rate and dwell time of the probe in each cup. A bar coding system is used for specimen identification.</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>
<p>Proportionating pump This module represents the use of different sizes of pipettes to add varying volumes of reagents to the reaction mixture in manual methods. A peristaltic pump drives the fluid along the pump tubes. The peristaltic action is produced by a series of rollers passing along a set of plastic tubes parallel to each other. Each roller compresses all the tubes so that the rate of flow in each tube depends on its diameter. As each roller moves along the manifold, it forces the liquid forward. The air bubbles are also introduced by this pump. The correct size and timing of air bubbles is controlled by the air bar.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Manifold The manifold may have 3 or more submodules which can remove proteins, mix reagents and incubate at the desired temperature. The common submodules are the dialyser, mixing coils and incubator bath.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>Dialyser The dialyser removes the protein molecules from the specimen by moving the specimen across a semi-permeable membrane in a perspex chamber. This membrane allows the passage of smaller molecules but prevents large protein molecules from passing over.</p>
<p>Mixing coils The mixing coils bring about mixing of two streams of fluids. These are multi-turn horizontal glass coils. The passage of fluids moving in the coils resembles gentle repeated inversion of a stoppered tube.</p>
<p>Apart from mixing the contents, the mixing coils also perform other functions such as</p>
<p>Extraction of a constituent using two immiscible liquids.</p>
<p>Cooling of the reaction mixture by jacketing the coils with cold water.</p>
<p>Time delay in the reaction by passing the reaction mixture through one or more delay coils. (In other words, it provides incubation at room temperature).</p>
<p>Heating bath This consists of a delay coil vertically mounted in a sealed oil bath. The oil bath is thermostatically controlled to provide a desired temperature for a particular length of time. Usually, the temperature from <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>37</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∘</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">37^{\circ}\mathrm{C}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">3</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">7</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∘</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">C</span></span></span></span></span> to <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>95</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∘</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">95^{\circ}\mathrm{C}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">9</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">5</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∘</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">C</span></span></span></span></span> can be achieved. The incubation time is regulated by the flow rate and the coil volume.</p>
<ol start="4">
<li>
<p>Colorimeter The colorimeter continuously measures the absorbance of the solution which is passing through the flow cell, at a given wavelength. The absorbance is compared against the blank, standard or control absorbances.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Recorder The light transmitted by the coloured solution causes a voltage change in the photodetector. This voltage is constantly measured and recorded by the recorder.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>The results may be recorded by a pen travelling to record the voltage changes in the form of a graph on a paper drive or the voltage can be analysed by a microprocessor to give the value of all the specimens sequentially on a print-out. Example: Autoanalyser II System</p>
<p>Multi-channel Continuous Flow Analyser</p>
<p>As opposed to single-channel analysers, the multi-channel continuous flow analysers are large scale machines which analyse twenty or more parameters at the same time. The principles used for the analysers are generally the same as those for the single channel machines. A computer is used for the continuous monitoring of the chemical reactions. It also calibrates the machine with reference sera at fixed intervals. The report is produced by the printer. Example: Sequential Multiple Analyser with Computer, SMAC</p>
<p>◆ DISCRETE ANALYSERS</p>
<p>A discrete analyser may be regarded as manual pipetting, mixing, movement of tubes, incubation and colorimetric reading being replaced by a machine. Each specimen is labelled as a separate process in its own designated reaction vessel.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>248 Clinical Chemistry</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="single-and-multi-channel-discrete-analysers">Single and Multi-channel Discrete Analysers<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#single-and-multi-channel-discrete-analysers" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The discrete analysers may be single-channel or multi-channel. In single-channel instruments, each specimen is analysed for one selected constituent only. On the other hand, the multi-channel analysers can select more than one analyses to be performed. Example: ASTRA analyser.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="end-point-and-reaction-rate-discrete-analysers">End-point and Reaction-rate Discrete Analysers<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#end-point-and-reaction-rate-discrete-analysers" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The discrete analysers, both single or multi-channel, may also differ in the method of analysis selected. Some instruments use the traditional end-point method where the absorbance is measured at the end of the reaction. The reaction rate analysers measure the rate of change of absorbance during the reaction. These instruments were originally developed for the estimation of enzyme levels. Later, the technique was adapted for the estimation of other non-enzyme constituents using the initial reaction rate methods. By this method, the results are available much faster because the reaction need not reach the end-point stage of completion.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="working-principles-of-discrete-analysers">Working Principles of Discrete Analysers<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#working-principles-of-discrete-analysers" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>It is difficult to generalise the working principle of a discrete analyser because of the wide range of instruments available. Generally, they are similar to the modular arrangement of the continuous flow system.</p>
<p><strong>Sampler</strong> This module aspirates the sample and transfers it with diluents to a tube held in a reaction unit. The measuring and diluting functions are performed by using mechanised dispensers and diluters. The mixing of the sample and the diluent is achieved either by using a forceful jet of the reagent or by convection currents generated by warming up the mixture.</p>
<p><strong>Reaction unit</strong> The reaction unit may have an incubator as an integral part for temperature regulation. The other reagents are added as the reaction proceeds.</p>
<p><strong>Measuring unit</strong> This measures the chemical change either by the end-point method or by the reaction rate method. Colorimetry is the most common choice, but other methods such as flame photometry, nephelometry or fluorimetry may also be used.</p>
<p><strong>Display unit</strong> The result is usually displayed in a digital form, stored in the computer memory until deleted, or recorded in a print-out.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="discrete-analyser-with-complete-discretionary-ability">Discrete Analyser with Complete Discretionary Ability<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#discrete-analyser-with-complete-discretionary-ability" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>In this type of analysers, the operator loads the specimen tray and programs the required tests for each sample into the computer. The computer determines the sequence in which the various tests will be done to attain the maximum speed. At the end of the analyses, the computer collates the sample results, giving the desired test results for each sample on a print-out. Examples: Abott 200, Hitachi 705.</p>
<p>Some discrete analysers use special plastic packs or units for each test which incorporate the reagents and a reaction chamber, which can also be used as a cuvette for photometry. The sample is automatically discharged into the pack, the reactions occur and the results are indicated. Although expensive, this type of analysers are useful in small sized laboratories. Any combination of tests can be run on any sample at any time. Example: DuPont automatic clinical analyzer.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="centrifugal-analysers">CENTRIFUGAL ANALYSERS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#centrifugal-analysers" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>In this type of analysers, the reaction takes place in the rotor of a centrifuge. The system consists of:</p>
<ol>
<li><strong>Rotor disc</strong> This is a disc which can be spun at a high speed by a vertically mounted electric motor. The upper surface of the disc has concentric rings of specially designed cavities, forming 3-4</li>
</ol>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Automation in Clinical Chemistry 249</p>
<p>discrete wells along the radius (Fig. 12.2). The wells in one radial row are connected with each other by capillary passages. There are about 30 such radial rows, separated from each other. Each row, which contains 3–4 wells, can process one specimen. Out of the four wells, the two innermost ones contain diluent or reagents, the third contains serum specimens while the outermost wells act as cuvettes. The details of the design may vary from one model to another.</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>Photometer A photometer is mounted near the periphery of the rotor disc in such a way that its light path is parallel to the axis of rotation (vertical). As the rotor spins, the cuvettes located at the periphery of the disc pass through the photometer beam sequentially.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="working-of-centrifugal-analysers">Working of Centrifugal Analysers<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#working-of-centrifugal-analysers" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The rotor disc is loaded with reagents, diluents and samples in appropriate wells, including the blank and control sera. When the rotor starts spinning, the reagents are transferred outward through the capillary passages due to the centrifugal force (Fig. 12.3). Proper mixing of reagents and sera is</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-32997d5a.jpeg" alt="img-69.jpeg">
Fig. 12.2 The rotor disc of a centrifugal analyser</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-a9749ed5.jpeg" alt="img-70.jpeg">
Fig. 12.3 Working of the centrifugal analyser</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>250 Clinical Chemistry</p>
<p>achieved by various means such as by passing air through the wells or by increasing and lowering the speed of the rotor.</p>
<p>The reaction proceeds in the peripheral cuvettes and is detected by the photometer, reading each cuvette several times as the disc rotates. Thus the photometer generates a series of signals corresponding to the light transmitted by each cuvette sequentially. Each cuvette generates several hundred signals per minute. By averaging the values, an accurate result can be obtained within two minutes. The signals are processed by a computer and results are displayed. Since the signals can be read repetitively at fixed intervals, reaction rate analyses can be easily performed. Example: ENI Ge MSAEC automatic fast analyser.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="thin-film-or-dry-chemistry-autoanalysers">THIN-FILM OR DRY CHEMISTRY AUTOANALYSERS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#thin-film-or-dry-chemistry-autoanalysers" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The thin-film analysers are discrete analysers. They use dry reagents spread in extremely thin layers on a plastic slide to which serum specimen is added. The reaction is read with the help of a reflectometer instead of a photometer. The system consists of.</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Plastic chip This is a small (16×16 mm) plastic chip which contains several very thin layers of dry reagents. The serum specimen provides the solvent necessary for the reaction. The coloured end products are confined to a fixed area on the slide.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Reflectance spectrophotometer As the coloured end product reaches the defined area, it is read by a reflectance spectrophotometer. The intensity of colour is measured by determining the proportion of a beam of a light which is reflected off the coloured area.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="working">Working<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#working" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The thin film analysers are completely discretionary. Any sample can be tested for the desired number of tests. The samples are placed on a rotating turntable; and each is programmed for the test required. As each cup in the turntable reaches the loading station, the appropriate chips are delivered from the cartridges. The chips move to the incubation and read out stations and the results are displayed when ready. The analyser uses a very small (about 20 μl) volume of serum. Example: Kodak Ektachem.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="modifications-of-dry-chemistry-analysers">Modifications of Dry Chemistry Analysers<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#modifications-of-dry-chemistry-analysers" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The dry chemistry technology in its modified form is also used for 'stick test' for urinary constituents, or for simple analysis such as blood glucose outside the main laboratory, e.g., by the patient's bedside. All the reagents are held in a dry form on a solid matrix in the form of a film or strip. All the stages of the reaction occur in this matrix when the sample is added. The colour change is measured by reflectance spectroscopy. If whole blood is used, only plasma reaches the reagent layer. The blood cells are separated from the plasma with the help of a glass fibre pad in the matrix.</p>
<p>In the systems, a small microprocessor is attached to the reflectometer which simplifies calculation, calibration and overall operation.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="use-of-automatic-measuring-devices">USE OF AUTOMATIC MEASURING DEVICES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#use-of-automatic-measuring-devices" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="automatic-pipettes">Automatic Pipettes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#automatic-pipettes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Automatic and semiautomatic pipettes are useful in many areas of laboratory work. They permit rapid, repetitive, accurate measurement and delivery of predefined volumes of any fluid. Some dispensers have tip-ejector devices, variable digital settings or repetitive dispensing capabilities.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="hand-operated-mechanical-pipette">Hand-operated mechanical pipette<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hand-operated-mechanical-pipette" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>This is a mechanical pipette with disposable plastic tip at one end and a thumb operated push button at the other end of a syringe (Fig. 12.4). The air from an enclosed syringe is displaced by pressing the push button. On releasing the pressure, the liquid enters the tip. This trapped liquid can then be delivered in</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Automation in Clinical Chemistry 251</p>
<p>the desired container by repressing the push button. The liquid does not enter the syringe at any stage. The tip is discarded between two samples or separate liquids to avoid carry over or contamination. A digital setting on the pipette allows variation in the volume of the fluid and can cover from 1 μl to 1000 μl (1 ml) in various ranges (1–10 μl, 2–20 μl, 10–100 μl, 20–200 μl, 50–500 μl or 100 to 1000 μl).</p>
<p>Automatic dispensers These are useful for repetitive adding of multiple volumes of the same reagent or diluent. The principle is similar to that of the automatic pipettes. These dispensers are available as syringes or as bottle top devices.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="automatic-diluters">Automatic Diluters<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#automatic-diluters" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Automatic diluters are used to prepare a number of different samples for analyses. These devices are mostly of the dual piston type, one is used for the sample and the other for the diluent.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-9407f8b5.jpeg" alt="img-71.jpeg"></p>
<p>Commercial examples:</p>
<ol>
<li>Volac volumetric pipettes</li>
<li>Gilson Pipetman automatic pipettes</li>
<li>Eppendorf automatic pipettes</li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 12.4 Using automatic pipettes</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
